PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES  
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Rockledge Code of Ordinances" and may be so cited. 
(Code 1964, § 1-1)  
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction. 
In the construction of this Code the following rules shall be observed unless otherwise provided, or unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the provisions: 
General rule. All words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning. 
City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Rockledge, and shall extend to and include its several officers, agents and employees. 
City council. The words "city council" shall be construed to mean the city council of the City of Rockledge. 
Computation of time. In computing any period of time prescribed or allowed by this Code, the day of the act, event or default from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be included. The last day of the period so computed shall be included unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday in which event the period shall run until the end of the next day which is neither a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than seven (7) days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
When a party has a right to or is required to do some act or take some proceeding within a prescribed period after the service of a notice or other paper upon him and the notice or paper is served upon him by mail, three (3) days shall be added to the prescribed period. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Fla. R. Civ. P. 1.090. 
County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean Brevard County, Florida. 
Gender. The masculine includes the feminine and vice versa. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 1.01(2). 
Joint authority. All words purporting to give a joint authority to three (3) or more city officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons unless it shall be otherwise expressly declared in the provision giving the authority. 
May. "May" is always directory and not mandatory. 
Number. The singular includes the plural and vice versa. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 1.01(1). 
Oath. The word "oath" includes affirmations. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 1.01(6). 
Officers, departments, agencies. Whenever reference is made to officers, boards, commissions, departments, or other agencies of the city by title only, they shall be deemed to refer to the officers, boards, commissions, departments and agencies of the City of Rockledge, and shall include their duly authorized subordinates and personnel. 
Owner. The word "owner" applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of part of such building or land. 
Person. The word "person" includes individuals, children, firms, associations, joint adventures, partnerships, estates, trusts, business trusts, syndicates, fiduciaries, corporations, and all other groups or combinations. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 1.01(3). 
Personal property. Personal property shall extend and be applied to every species of property except real property. 
Provisions declared minimum; greater restriction applied. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code or any ordinance of the city, it shall be held to be the minimum requirement adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general provisions imposed by this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be controlling. 
Shall. "Shall" is always mandatory and not directory. 
State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Florida. 
Tense. The present tense includes the future when applicable. 
Week. The word "week" shall be construed to mean seven (7) days; but publication in a newspaper of any notice or other matter indicated to be for a stated number of weeks shall be construed to mean one insertion in each week, unless specifically stated to be for each day of the week or for more than one day in each week. 
(Code 1964, §§ 1-2, 1-3)  
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines; references to chapters or sections. 
In addition to the rules of construction set out in section 1-2, the following rules shall be observed in the construction of this Code: 
(a)	Catchlines. The catchlines of the several sections of this Code are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines are amended or reenacted. 
(b)	References to chapters or sections. All references to chapters or sections are to the chapters and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified. 
(Code 1964, § 1-4)  
Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision of this Code, shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision of this Code, unless it shall be expressly so provided. 
The repeal of an ordinance, clause or section of this Code, shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed under the ordinance, clause or section of this Code repealed. 
(Code 1964, § 1-5) 
State Law reference— Repealed statute not revived by implication, F.S. § 2.04.  
Sec. 1-5. - Severability. 
If any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph, section or subsection of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs, sections or subsections of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 1-6)  
Sec. 1-6. - Amendments to Code. 
All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect any section or subsection, clause or paragraph of this Code shall be numbered consecutively, but may refer specifically to the section or subsection affected, and be printed for inclusion herein. When subsequent ordinances repeal any chapter, section, subsection, clause or paragraph, or any portion thereof, such repealed portions shall be excluded from said Code by omission from reprinted pages. The subsequent ordinances, as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the city council. 
Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the provision of this Code in the following language: "That Section (subsection, clause or paragraph) of the Rockledge Code of Ordinances is hereby amended to read as follows: …." The new provisions shall then be set out in full. 
In the event a new provision not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Rockledge Code of Ordinances is hereby amended by adding a new section (subsection, clause or paragraph) to be numbered ____________ , which reads as follows: …." The new provisions shall then be set out in full. 
All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed may be specifically repealed in the following language: "That ;daterule; of the Rockledge Code of Ordinances is hereby repealed."  
Sec. 1-7. - Altering Code. 
No person in the city shall change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of Rockledge to be misrepresented thereby. 
(Code 1964, § 1-8)  
Sec. 1-8. - General penalty; violations. 
(a)	Whenever in this Code any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code shall be punished as follows: 
(1)	Where the particular act or default constituting a violation of this Code also constitutes a violation of any law of the State of Florida, such violation shall be punished in the same manner and within the same limits as are provided for such state violation. 
(2)	Where the act or default does not also constitute a violation of a state law, it shall be punished by a fine of not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)	Each day a violation of any provision of this Code shall continue shall constitute a separate offense, and each act in violation of the provisions of this Code shall be considered a separate and distinct offense. 
(c)	In addition to the penalties herein provided, any condition caused or permitted to exist in violation of any of the provisions of this Code shall be deemed a public nuisance and may be, by the city, abated as provided by law, and each day that such condition continues shall be regarded as a new and separate offense. 
(Code 1964, § 1-9)  
Sec. 1-9. - Court costs for law enforcement education. 
(a)	For the purpose of creating and maintaining a fund for law enforcement education expenditures of city law enforcement officers, and pursuant to the authority granted by F.S. § 943.258(a), the city by and through its governing body, does hereby assess every person convicted of violating a Rockledge municipal ordinance or State of Florida penal, criminal or civil traffic infraction statute within the city, the sum of two dollars ($2.00) for criminal justice education and training, including basic training expenditures, for city law enforcement officers, parttime law enforcement officers, auxiliary law enforcement officers, correctional officers and support personnel; provided, that such education and training activities conform to the requirements of F.S. § 943.14. In addition, two dollars ($2.00) is hereby assessed with respect to every bond estreature or forfeited bail bond related to a Rockledge municipal ordinance or State of Florida penal, criminal or civil traffic infraction statute, violated within the municipal limits of the city. Provided, however, no such assessment shall be made against any person convicted for violation of any state statute or Rockledge municipal ordinance relating to the parking of vehicles. All courts exercising lawful jurisdiction with respect to violations within the city of city ordinances or state penal, criminal or civil traffic infraction statutes are hereby authorized to collect the assessments hereby made. All assessments received by the city under authority of this section shall be deposited in the general administrative fund of the city to the credit of the law enforcement education account. 
(b)	The city council shall from time to time authorize payment from such account of law enforcement education expenditures for the city law enforcement officers, as permitted by law. 
(Code 1964, § 2-45; Ord. No. 645-83, § 1, 3-16-83) 
State Law reference— Court costs for law enforcement education authorized, F.S. 943.25(5).  
Sec. 1-10. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed to repeal or otherwise affect the validity of any of the following when not inconsistent with this Code: 
(a)	Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness; 
(b)	Any appropriation ordinance or ordinance providing for the levy of taxes or providing for or amending the annual budget; 
(c)	Any ordinance annexing territory to the city or excluding territory as a part of the city; 
(d)	Any ordinance granting any franchise, permit or other right; 
(e)	Any ordinance approving, authorizing or otherwise relating to any contract, agreement, lease, deed or other instrument; 
(f)	Any administrative ordinance not inconsistent with this Code; 
(g)	Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating or repairing any street or public way; 
(h)	Any ordinance prescribing traffic regulations for specific locations, within the city, not inconsistent herewith; 
(i)	Any ordinance prescribing the street grades of any street in the city; 
(j)	Any ordinance providing for local improvements or making assessments therefor; 
(k)	Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city, or any improvements therein; 
(l)	Any ordinance zoning or rezoning of specific property; 
(m)	Any ordinance providing for the compensation of officers and employees; 
(n)	Any temporary or special ordinance; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein.  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Municipal organization and officers, Subpt. A, Art. III; administration, Subpt. B, Art. I. 
Cross reference— Nuisance abatement board, § 10-19; civil emergencies, § 13-3; impersonating officer, § 13-8; interfering with officers, § 13-9; reward for information regarding theft or destruction of city-owned property, § 13-12; disposition of lost or abandoned property, unclaimed evidence, § 13-16; citizen's advisory committee on planning, § 16-11 et seq. 
State Law reference— State Election Code, F.S. Chs. 97—106. 
 
ARTICLE I. - RESERVED 
 
Secs. 2-1—2-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ELECTIONS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference— Elections, Subpt. A, Art. I, §§ 6, 7. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-11. - Definitions. 
As used in this article: 
Absent elector means any registered and qualified elector who is unable without another's assistance to attend the polls or who is an inspector, a poll worker, a deputy voting machine custodian, city policeman, supervisor of elections, or a deputy supervisor who is assigned to a different precinct than that in which he is registered to vote, or who on account of the tenets of his religion cannot attend the polls on the day of an election, or any qualified and registered elector wherever he may be, except persons confined in prison or jail, so long as he will not be in the city during the hours the polls are open for voting on the day of an election. 
Armed forces means and includes the Army of the United States, Navy, Air Force of the United States, Marine Corps, Coast Guard, Coast and Geodetic Survey, and Public Health Service, when on active duty. 
Ballot, when used in reference to: 
(a)	Voting machines (except when reference is made to irregular ballots) means that portion of the printed strips of cardboard, paper or other material within the ballot frames containing the names of candidates, or a statement of a question or proposition submitted to the electorate at any election. 
(b)	Paper ballot means that printed sheet of paper containing the names of candidates, or a statement of questions or propositions submitted to the electorate at any election, on which sheet of paper an elector casts his vote. 
(c)	Electronic or electromechanical device means a ballot which is voted by the process of punching or marking with a marking device for tabulation by automatic tabulating equipment or data processing equipment. 
Candidate means any person who has filed his qualification papers, and paid his qualifying fees as required by law. 
Dependent means any person who is in fact a dependent. 
Election board means the clerk and inspectors appointed to conduct an election. 
Elector is synonymous with the word "voter" or "qualified elector or voter." 
Freeholder means any person who has an immediately beneficial ownership interest, legal or equitable, in the title to a fee simple estate in land. For the purposes of this article, an owner of condominium property, as well as a tenant-stockholder of a cooperative apartment corporation is deemed to have an immediately beneficial ownership interest, legal or equitable, in the title to a fee simple estate in land. As used herein, a "cooperative apartment corporation" means a corporation organized for the purpose of owning, maintaining and operating an apartment building or apartment buildings to be occupied by its stockholders, which building or buildings are located on realty owned in fee simple by the corporation, and "tenant-stockholder" means any individual who is entitled, solely by reason of his ownership of stock in a cooperative apartment corporation, to occupy for dwelling purposes an apartment in a building owned by such corporation. As used herein, "condominium property" is that real property, whereby units of an improvement or improvements on such real property are subject to ownership as a fee simple or life estate by different owners, and there is appurtenant to each unit as part thereof an undivided share in the common elements. 
Irregular ballot means a vote cast for a person whose name does not appear on the ballot, commonly referred to as a "write-in" vote. 
Registration officer means the county supervisor of elections or such deputies as may be appointed by the supervisor. 
Voting booth or booth means that booth or enclosure wherein an elector casts his ballot, be it a paper ballot, a voting machine ballot, or a ballot cast for tabulation by an electronic or electromechanical device. 
(Code 1964, § 7-1) 
State Law reference— Similar definitions for purpose of state election law, F.S. § 97.021.  
Sec. 2-12. - Precincts and polling places. 
The boundaries of precincts in the city, and the location of polling places, shall be arranged and established as provided by state law. 
(Code 1964, § 7-2) 
State Law reference— Determination of precincts and polling places generally, F.S. § 98.031; arrangement of precincts to conform to municipal boundaries, F.S. § 98.091(1).  
Sec. 2-13. - Registration required. 
No person shall vote in any city election unless such person is an elector duly registered as a resident of the city on the county voter registration books under the permanent single voter registration system established by state law. 
(Code 1964, § 7-8) 
State Law reference— City residents registered by county entitled to vote, F.S. § 98.091(3).  
Sec. 2-14. - Registration procedure. 
The procedure for registration, time and place of registration, the time when registration will be permitted, the qualifications of registrants, the registration of members of the armed forces and their dependents, the eligibility and procedure for absentee registrations, the procedure for the change of name and change of residence of electors, the purging and removal of names from voter registration books, restoration of names of aggrieved persons and other rules and regulations pertaining to the registration of electors of the city shall all be as prescribed and provided for by the permanent single voter registration system established by state law. 
(Code 1964, § 7-9) 
State Law reference— Registration of voters generally, F.S. Chs. 97, 98.  
Sec. 2-15. - Call and notice of election. 
The city clerk shall publish a notice of election in a newspaper of general circulation in the city between the sixty-third day and sixty-sixth day prior to each election, stating the offices to be filled at said election and the date of said election and same shall be held to be the official call for such election. 
(Code 1964, § 7-27; Ord. No. 803-86, § 1, 9-3-86)  
Sec. 2-16. - Procedure for candidates to qualify. 
(a)	The city clerk or deputy city clerk shall receive a written statement from every person desiring to enter an election, announcing his or her candidacy, during the qualifying period which shall commence at noon on the seventy-seventh (77th) day immediately preceding the election and close at noon on the sixty-seventh (67th) day immediately preceding the election. Such written statement shall state that the candidate is a qualified elector of the city, that such candidate is qualified under the charter and ordinances of the city and of this Code for the office to which he desires to be elected, that such candidate has paid the assessment, if any, levied against him or her as a candidate for such office, and such candidate shall swear or affirm to the truth thereof. A copy of such sworn statement shall be filed with the city clerk. A copy of this election ordinance shall be furnished to each prospective candidate upon qualification by the city clerk or deputy city clerk. 
(b)	The form of the written statement provided in the above subsection shall be substantially as follows: 
I, ____________ , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I am a candidate for the office of ____________ in the City of Rockledge, Florida. 
I do further swear (or affirm) that I am a qualified voter of the City of Rockledge, Florida, and that I am qualified under the Charter and Ordinances of said city to hold the office of ____________ in the City of Rockledge, Florida, and that I have paid the assessment of $ ____________ levied against me in accordance with the Ordinances of said City for said office. 
I acknowledge having received a copy of the Election Ordinance of the City of Rockledge, Florida. 
_____
Signature of Candidate 
Sworn to and subscribed before me this ____________ day of ____________ / ____________ / ____________ , 19 ____________ . 
_____
Notary Public 
(Notarial Seal) 
_____
City Clerk 
(Deputy City Clerk) 
(c)	Should the procedures established in section 2-16(a) above become unreasonable to comply with, and ensure a ten-day qualifying period for candidates ie: changes in state or federal voting statutes; acts of God; county supervisor of elections submittal dates, etc.), then the city clerk in her capacity as the city supervisor of elections shall establish a ten-day qualifying period as close as practicable to that period which would be set by section 2-16(a). The city clerk shall bring any need for changes to the qualifying period to the city council at the first opportunity for its approval. The city clerk shall then publicize, in the established fashion, any qualifying period established by this section. If the necessity for changing the qualifying period is recurring due to any single change in circumstances, then this section may be utilized until such time as section 2-16(a) is amended as necessary to address the circumstances. 
(Code 1964, § 7-28; Ord. No. 703-84, § 3, 9-5-84; Ord. No. 798-86, § 1, 7-16-86; Ord. No. 1273-02, §§ 1, 2, 6-5-02; Ord. No. 1381-05, § 1, 6-15-05; Ord. No. 1411-06, §§ 1, 2, 5-17-06)  
Sec. 2-17. - Payment of fee prerequisite to qualifying. 
(a)	There shall be levied against every candidate qualifying in accordance with section 2-20 a qualifying fee in an amount equal to one-half of one month's pay for the office which the candidate seeks. 
(b)	The city clerk shall receive such fee and shall issue a receipt therefor to the candidate. 
(Code 1964, §§ 7-30, 7-31; Ord. No. 703-84, § 4, 9-5-84)  
Sec. 2-18. - Preparation, approval of ballots; candidates to be listed. 
The ballot for each election shall be prepared by the city clerk. Every person who shall have filed his or her sworn statement and paid his or her qualifying fee, if any, shall be entitled to have his name printed on the official ballot for the office for which such person has qualified. 
(Code 1964, § 7-35; Ord. No. 703-84, § 5, 9-5-84)  
Sec. 2-19. - Preparation of absentee ballots. 
Ballots for absent electors shall be prepared immediately after the last day for qualification of candidates on a form to be adopted by the city council to insure the secrecy of the ballot. 
(Code 1964, § 7-36)  
Sec. 2-20. - List of absentee voters required. 
It shall be the duty of the city clerk to deliver to the clerk at each polling place prior to the opening of the polls on election day a complete list of the names of the electors who have cast absentee ballots. 
(Code 1964, § 7-37)  
Sec. 2-21. - Casting of absentee ballots. 
An absentee elector's ballot shall be received in the office of the city clerk or in the office of the county supervisor of elections, in the event the election is being conducted by the county supervisor of elections, prior to 7:00 p.m. on the day of election. The city clerk or the county supervisor of elections, as the case may be, shall cause the time of receipt of each ballot received thereafter to be indelibly marked on the outside of the sealed envelope containing the ballot, and such ballots shall be delivered to the city council at the time of the canvass. Such ballots shall be null and void and shall be delivered separately to the city council from other absentee ballots. 
(Code 1964, § 7-38)  
Sec. 2-22. - Early voting. 
The City of Rockledge hereby exercises its right to exempt itself from the provisions of F.S. (2003) § 101.657, and may contract with the Brevard County Supervisor of Elections to conduct early voting for the City of Rockledge at the office of the supervisor of elections and any other early voting sites the supervisor may establish. 
(Ord. No. 1359-04, § 1, 10-20-04) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 1359-2004, § 1, adopted October 20, 2004, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance was treated as adding a new § 2-22 at the editor's discretion.  
Secs. 2-23—2-35. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONDUCT OF ELECTIONS 
 
Sec. 2-36. - Hours. 
Polling places shall be open for the casting of ballots by electors between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. on the date of any general or special election in the city. Any elector who appears at the polling place before 7:00 p.m. shall be entitled to cast his vote. It shall be the duty of the clerk at each polling place to mark the time at 7:00 p.m. and announce or cause to be announced to the electors arriving thereafter that the polling place is closed. 
(Code 1964, § 7-44) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 100.011.  
Sec. 2-37. - Voting to be secret; facilities for write-ins required. 
All elections shall be conducted in a manner so that the voting is secret. Instructions and equipment shall be provided at the polling place for electors to cast write-in votes in such a manner as to maintain the secret ballot and further in such a manner so that it is not necessary for the elector to specifically request same from an election official. 
(Code 1964, § 7-45) 
State Law reference— Voting to be secret, F.S. § 101.041.  
Sec. 2-38. - Paper ballots. 
In the event the voting at the polling places in an election shall be by paper ballot the procedures set forth in F.S. Ch. 101 are hereby adopted and made applicable. 
(Code 1964, § 7-46)  
Sec. 2-39. - Maintenance of good order at polls; authorities; persons allowed in polling rooms; unlawful solicitation of voters. 
(a)	Each election board appointed by the county supervisor of elections shall possess full authority to maintain order at the polls and enforce obedience to its lawful commands during an election and the canvass of the votes. 
(b)	The sheriff of the county is hereby authorized to deputize a deputy sheriff for each precinct who shall be present during the time the polls are open and until the election is completed, who shall be subject to all lawful commands of the elections clerk or inspectors appointed by the county supervisor of elections, and who shall maintain good order. The deputy may summon assistance from among bystanders to aid him when necessary to maintain peace and order at the polls. 
(c)	(1) 
No person may enter any polling room or polling place where the polling place is also a polling room during voting hours except the following: 
a.	Official poll watchers; 
b.	Inspectors; 
c.	Elections clerks; 
d.	The county supervisor of elections or his deputy; 
e.	Persons there to vote, persons in the care of a voter; or 
f.	Law enforcement officers or emergency service personnel there with permission of the clerk or a majority of the inspectors. 
(2)	The restriction in this subsection does not apply where the polling room is in an area commonly traversed by the public in order to gain access to businesses or homes or in an area traditionally utilized as a public area for discussion. 
(3)	No person, political committee, committee of continuous existence, or other group or organization may solicit voters within fifty (50) feet of the entrance to any polling place, or polling room where the polling place is also a polling room on the date of any election. 
a.	Solicitation shall not be restricted if: 
1.	Conducted from a separately marked area within the fifty-foot zone so as not to disturb, hinder, impede, obstruct or interfere with voter access to the polling place or polling room entrance; and 
2.	The solicitation activities and subject matter are clearly and easily identifiable by the voters as an activity in which they may voluntarily participate; or 
3.	Conducted on property within the fifty-foot zone which is a residence, established business, private property, sidewalk, park or property traditionally utilized as a public area for discussion. 
b.	Solicitation shall not be permitted within the fifty-foot zone on a public sidewalk or other similar means of access to the polling room if it is clearly identifiable to the pollworkers that the solicitation is impeding, obstructing or interfering with voter access to the polling room or polling place. 
(4)	For the purpose of this subsection, the term "solicit" shall include, but not be limited to, seeking or attempting to seek any vote, fact, opinion or contribution; distributing or attempting to distribute any political or campaign material, leaflet or handout; conducting a poll; seeking or attempting to seek a signature on any petition; and selling or attempting to sell any item. 
(5)	Pursuant to Florida Statutes, the county supervisor of elections shall inform the elections clerk of each precinct of the area within which soliciting is unlawful, based on the particular characteristics of that polling place. The supervisor or the clerk may take any reasonable action necessary to ensure order at the polling places which shall include: 
a.	Designating a specific area for soliciting pursuant to subparagraph (3) of this subsection; or 
b.	Having disruptive and unruly persons removed by law enforcement officers from the polling room or place or from the fifty-foot zone surrounding the polling place. 
(d)	Any person willfully violating any provisions of this section shall upon conviction thereof be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Code 1964, § 7-48; Ord. No. 952-90, § 1, 3-21-90)  
Sec. 2-40. - Poll watchers. 
Each duly qualified candidate shall be entitled to designate five (5) poll watchers for each polling place. Only one of such watchers may be within such polling place at any one time. Lists of poll watchers shall be submitted to the city clerk or to the county supervisor of elections, if the election is being conducted by the county supervisor of elections, not less than seven (7) days before the election, in a form to be signed by the candidate. It shall be the duty of the election clerk and inspectors to announce the name of an elector so that the poll watcher may hear same, or provide a list of those electors who have voted. Poll watchers shall conduct themselves at the polling place so as not to interfere with the orderly conduct of the election. 
(Code 1964, § 7-49; Ord. No. 703-84, § 6, 9-5-84) 
State Law reference— Poll watchers generally, F.S. § 101.131.  
Sec. 2-41. - Counting ballots and tabulating results. 
At the close of any election, the inspectors and clerks thereof shall count the votes cast for each candidate or issue, shall record same on the forms provided by the city clerk and shall certify the results and swear to same, shall announce said results to the public outside the polling place immediately thereafter, and shall deliver to the city clerk their certification of said count and their oaths thereto, together with the voting list and the ballots cast and/or machine records, sealed in an envelope, which shall be provided by the city clerk. The city clerk shall deliver the certificates of count and oaths and machine records in their sealed envelopes to the chairman of the city council as soon as possible. 
(Code 1964, § 7-50)  
Sec. 2-42. - Canvassing and certification of results. 
The city council shall meet at 8:00 p.m. on the day following the election day and shall canvass the returns of such election and shall count absentee ballots and shall promptly certify the results of such election. 
(Code 1964, § 7-51)  
Secs. 2-43—2-52. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CITY COUNCIL[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Charter reference— Rules of procedure for council, Subpt. A, Art. I, § 9; removal of councilmembers, Subpt. A, Art. I, § 13; officers of council, Subpt. A, Art. II, § 2; ordinances, Subpt. A, Art. V; voting by mayor, Subpt. B, § 103. 
 
Sec. 2-53. - Regular meetings. 
(a)	Date and time. Prior to December 31 of each calendar year the Rockledge City Council shall establish its meeting schedule for regular meetings for the next calendar year by resolution, passed by a majority of the members present and voting. The resolution shall establish the date and time for the meetings and shall comply with city Charter provisions regarding city council regular meetings. Amendments of any resolution setting the regular meeting schedule, in full or in part, may be accomplished by subsequent resolution passed with like dignity. 
(b)	Place. Regular meetings of the city council shall be held in such place as shall be designated by them, pursuant to city Charter provisions. 
(c)	Length. Unless extended by vote of a majority of members present, regular council meetings shall adjourn no later than 11:00 p.m. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.1; Ord. No. 1267-02, § 1, 2-6-02; Ord. No. 1608-2012, §§ 1, 2, 11-21-12 )  
Sec. 2-54. - Special meetings. 
The mayor, chairman or acting chairman of the city council, city manager or the city clerk may call a special meeting of the council whenever in the opinion of such official the public business may require it, or at the express written request of any four (4) members of the council. Whenever a special meeting shall be called, a summons or a notice of such meeting shall be given each member of the council, stating the date and hour of the meeting and the purpose for which such meeting is called, and any business which may properly come before any regular meeting of the city council, or any business whatever which the council could properly act upon, shall be proper business at any special meeting. Such notice shall be given not less than twenty-four (24) hours prior to the meeting unless due to the emergency nature of the situation such notice cannot be given. Should any member of the city council absent himself from the limits of the city, such action shall render it unnecessary that he be served with notice of a special meeting. In such case any action taken by a majority of the members shall not be subject to question by the absent member. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.2)  
Sec. 2-55. - Quorum; compelling attendance. 
A majority of all the members elected to the council shall constitute a quorum at any regular or special meeting of the council. In the absence of a quorum, the presiding officer may, at the instance of any three (3) members present, compel the attendance of absent members. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.7) 
State Law reference— Majority to constitute quorum, F.S. § 166.041(4).  
Sec. 2-56. - Meetings to be public. 
All meetings of the council shall be open to the public. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.8) 
State Law reference— State sunshine law, F.S. § 286.011.  
Sec. 2-57. - Agenda. 
All reports, communications, ordinances, resolutions, contract documents or other matters to be submitted to the council shall be delivered to the city clerk no later than the Thursday immediately preceding the regular council meeting, whereupon the city manager shall immediately arrange a list of such matters according to the order of business and furnish each member of the council, the mayor and the city attorney with a copy of same prior to the council meeting and as far in advance of the meeting as time for preparation will permit. None of the foregoing matters shall be presented to the council by administrative officials except those of an urgent nature, and the same, when so presented, shall have the written approval of the chairman of the council before presentation. Notwithstanding the provisions of this section the council may allot time at council meetings for the presentation to the council of business or matters not scheduled on the agenda. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.3)  
Sec. 2-58. - Election, duties of presiding officer. 
The presiding officer of the council shall be the chairman of the council, or in his absence the vice-chairman of the council, or in the absence of both chairman and vice-chairman, the senior member of the council as provided in the city charter. The chairman and vice-chairman shall be elected annually at the first regular meeting of the city council after the first Tuesday after the first Monday in November of each year by the members from their membership. The chairman shall assume the chair of presiding officer immediately after his election. The presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at all regular and special meetings of the council. He shall state every question coming before the council, announce the decision of the council on all subjects and decide all questions of order, subject, however, to an appeal to the council, in which event a majority vote of the council shall govern and conclusively determine such question of order. The chairman may follow Robert's Rules of Order on questions of parliamentary procedure. He shall vote on all questions, his name being called last. He shall sign all ordinances and resolutions adopted by the council during his presence. In the event of the absence of the chairman of the council, the presiding officer shall sign ordinances or resolutions as then adopted. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.4)  
Sec. 2-59. - Call to order; relinquishment of chair by temporary chairman. 
The presiding officer shall take the chair precisely at the hour appointed for the meeting and shall immediately call the council to order. If the meeting is being chaired by an officer other than the highest ranking presiding officer of the council, then upon the arrival of a higher ranking presiding officer, the temporary chairman shall immediately relinquish the chair upon the conclusion of the business immediately before the council. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.5)  
Sec. 2-60. - Commencement of meeting; order of business. 
Promptly at the hour set by law on the day of each regular meeting, the members of the council, the mayor, city manager, city clerk and city attorney shall take their regular stations in the council chambers, and the business of the council shall be taken up for consideration and disposition in the following order: 
(1)	Roll call. 
(2)	Invocation. 
(3)	Salute to flag. 
(4)	Approval of minutes of previous meeting. 
(5)	Approval of collector's report (on second meeting of month) or approval of the bills (on first meeting of month). 
(6)	Introduction and adoption of resolutions and ordinances. 
(7)	Report of officers, boards and committees. 
(8)	Unfinished business. 
(9)	New business. 
(10)	Petitions, remonstrances and communications. 
(11)	Miscellaneous. 
(12)	Appropriations. 
(13)	Adjournment. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.8)  
Sec. 2-61. - Roll call and record of attendance. 
Before proceeding with the business of the council, the city clerk shall record and enter in the minutes the names of the members present and the names of the members absent. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.6)  
Sec. 2-62. - Reading of minutes. 
Unless a reading of the minutes of a council meeting is requested by a member of the council, such minutes may be approved without reading if the city clerk has previously furnished each member with a synopsis thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.9)  
Sec. 2-63. - Rules of debate. 
(a)	Participation by presiding officer. The chairman of the council, or such other member of the council as may be presiding, may move, second and debate from the chair, subject only to such limitations of debate as are by this article imposed on all members, and shall not be deprived of any of the rights and privileges of a councilman by reason of his acting as the presiding officer. 
(b)	Getting the floor; improper references to be avoided. Every member desiring to speak shall address the chair and, upon recognition by the presiding officer, shall confine himself to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. Upon completion of his address a councilman shall announce to the chairman that he has yielded the floor. 
(c)	Interruptions. A member, once recognized, shall not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call him to order, or as herein otherwise provided. If a member, while speaking, is called to order, he shall cease speaking until the question of order has been determined and, if in order, he shall be permitted to proceed. 
(d)	Privilege of closing debate. The councilman moving the adoption of an ordinance or resolution shall have the privilege of speaking last to the motion under debate. 
(e)	Motion to reconsider. A motion to reconsider any action taken by the council may be made only during the meeting at which such action was taken or during the next succeeding meeting of the council. Such motion must be made by one of the prevailing side, but may be seconded by any member, and may be made at any time and have precedence over all other motions or while a member has the floor, it shall be debatable. Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent any member of the council from making or remaking the same or any other motion at a subsequent meeting of the council. 
(f)	Entry of remarks in minutes. A councilman may request, through the presiding officer, the privilege of having an abstract of his statement on any subject under consideration by the council entered in the minutes. If the council consents thereto, such statement shall be entered in the minutes. 
(g)	When synopsis of debate entered in minutes. The city clerk may be directed by the presiding officer, with consent of the council, to enter in the minutes a synopsis of the discussion on any question coming regularly before the council. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.10)  
Sec. 2-64. - Addressing council authorized. 
Any person desiring to address the council shall first secure the permission of the presiding officer to do so; provided, that during the agenda time allotted to petitions, remonstrances and communications, any qualified person may address the council without securing such prior permission, unless the presiding officer rules otherwise, as follows: 
(a)	Written communications. Interested parties or their authorized representatives may address the council by written communications in regard to matters then under discussion. 
(b)	Oral communications. Taxpayers or residents of the city, or their authorized legal representatives, may address the council by oral communications on any matter concerning the city's business, or any matter over which the council has control; provided, that preference shall be given to those persons who may have notified the city manager in advance of their desire to speak in order that the same may appear on the agenda of the council. 
(c)	Reading of protests, etc. Interested persons or their authorized representatives may address the council by reading of protests, petitions or communications relating to zoning, sewer and street proceedings, hearings on protests, appeals and petitions or similar matters, in regard to matters then under consideration. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.11)  
Sec. 2-65. - Addressing council after motion made. 
After a motion is made by the council, no person shall address the council without first securing the permission of the presiding officer to do so. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.12)  
Sec. 2-66. - Manner of addressing council; time limit. 
Each person addressing the council shall step up to the podium to the microphone, shall give his name, address, the subject matter of his interest and the party or interests he represents, in an audible tone of voice for the records, and unless further time is granted by the council, shall limit his address to five (5) minutes. All remarks shall be addressed to the council as a body and not to any member thereof. No person other than the council and the person having the floor shall be permitted to enter into any discussion, either directly or through a member of the council, without the permission of the presiding officer. No question shall be asked a councilman except through the presiding officer. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.13)  
Sec. 2-67. - Decorum required. 
(a)	By councilmembers. While the council is in session, the members must preserve order and decorum, and a member shall neither, by conversation or otherwise, delay or interrupt the proceedings or the peace of the council nor disturb any member while speaking or refuse to obey the orders of the council or its presiding officer, except as otherwise herein provided. 
(b)	By public. Any person making personal, impertinent or slanderous remarks or who shall become boisterous while addressing the council shall be forthwith, by the presiding officer, ordered to cease and desist from addressing the council further, unless permission to continue is granted by a majority vote of the council. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.15)  
Sec. 2-68. - Enforcement of decorum. 
The chief of police or such member or members of the police department as he may designate shall be sergeant-at-arms at council meetings. He, or they, shall carry out all orders and instructions given by the presiding officer for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum at the council meeting. Upon instructions of the presiding officer, it shall be the duty of the sergeant-at-arms or any of them present to place any person who violates the order and decorum of the meeting under arrest and cause him to be prosecuted under the provisions of this Code or applicable statute, the complaint to be signed by the presiding officer. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.16)  
Sec. 2-69. - Persons authorized beyond podium. 
No person, except city officials, their representatives and newspaper reporters, shall be permitted beyond the podium in front of the council platform without the express consent of the council while the council is in session. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.17)  
Sec. 2-70. - Appointment of special committees. 
All special committees shall be appointed by the presiding officer, unless otherwise directed by the council. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.18)  
Sec. 2-71. - Members may file protests against council action. 
Any member shall have the right to have the reasons for his dissent from, or protest against, any action of the council entered on the minutes. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.19)  
Sec. 2-72. - Silence constitutes affirmative vote. 
Unless a member of the council states that he is not voting, his silence shall be recorded as an affirmative vote. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.14)  
Sec. 2-73. - Preparation of ordinances. 
All ordinances shall be prepared by the city attorney or under his direction and control. No ordinance shall be prepared for presentation to the council unless ordered by a majority vote of the council or requested by the city manager or prepared by the city attorney on his own initiative. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.20)  
Sec. 2-74. - Approval of documents before presentation to council. 
All ordinances, resolutions and contract documents shall, before presentation to the council, have been approved as to form and legality by the city attorney or his authorized representative and shall have been examined and approved for administration by the city manager or his authorized representative. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.20)  
Sec. 2-75. - Introduction of matters for council approval. 
Ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects requiring action by the council must be introduced and sponsored by a member of the council; except, that the mayor, city manager or city attorney may present ordinances, resolutions and other matters or subjects to the council and any councilman may assume sponsorship thereof by moving that such ordinances, resolutions, matters or subjects be adopted; otherwise, they shall not be considered. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.20)  
Sec. 2-76. - Procedure for resolutions making appropriations. 
Any resolution providing for the appropriation of money shall designate the particular fund from which the appropriation is to be made and shall not be granted immediate consideration unless the votes of the number of members required for the affirmance of such resolution shall be cast in favor of immediate consideration. An objection voiced by one member shall require a roll call upon the motion for immediate consideration. If no objection is voiced, the clerk shall record a unanimous consent to the motion for immediate consideration and the presiding officer shall proceed to state the principal question. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.20)  
Sec. 2-77. - Reports, resolutions to be filed and recorded. 
All reports and resolutions shall be filed with the clerk and entered on the minutes. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.21)  
Sec. 2-78. - Public hearing on annual budget. 
There shall be a public hearing on the proposed administrative budget for each year, which public hearing shall be held during the first regular city council meeting of September of each year. The city clerk shall cause one advertisement of such public hearing to be placed in a newspaper of general circulation in the city between the seventh and fourteenth day preceding such public hearing. 
(Code 1964, § 2-16)  
Sec. 2-79. - Authorization and procedure for ordinance adoption. 
(a)	Authorization. The city council shall have the right to adopt such ordinances authorized by the powers granted under the charter, the constitution and statutes of the state as are deemed necessary or advisable for the government of the city. 
(b)	To be written; title; amendments. Each ordinance shall be introduced in writing and shall embrace but one subject and matters properly connected therewith. The subject shall be clearly stated in the title. No ordinance shall be revised or amended by reference to its title only. Ordinances to revise or amend shall set out in full the revised or amended act, section, subsection or paragraph of a section or subsection. 
(c)	Reading; notice; procedure. 
(1)	Except as provided in subsection (3) of this paragraph, a proposed ordinance may be read by title, or in full, on at least two (2) separate days and shall, at least ten (10) days prior to adoption, be noticed once in a newspaper of general circulation in the city. The notice of proposed enactment shall state the date, time and place of the meeting, the title or titles of proposed ordinances and the place or places within the municipality where such proposed ordinances may be inspected by the public. Such notice shall also advise that interested parties may appear at the meeting and be heard with respect to the proposed ordinance. See F.S. § 166.041(3)(a). 
(2)	The city council may, by a two-thirds vote, enact an emergency ordinance without complying with the requirements of paragraph (1) of this subsection, and such emergency ordinance shall not be subject to mayoral veto. However, no emergency ordinance shall be enacted which enacts or amends a land use plan or which rezones private real property. See F.S. § 166.041(3)(b). 
(3)	Ordinances initiated by the governing body of the city or its designee which rezone specific parcels of private real property or which substantially change permitted use categories in zoning districts shall be enacted in accordance with the procedure prescribed by F.S. § 166.041(3)(c), as same may be amended from time to time. The process for adoption of a comprehensive plan or amendment thereto, shall be as prescribed by F.S. §§ 163.3184 and 163.3187 as the same may be amended from time to time. 
(d)	Passage at special meetings. Ordinances and resolutions may be adopted at special meetings of the city council, provided such adoption is in compliance with the procedural requirements established by state law and this Code. 
(e)	Quorum; vote. The majority of the members of the city council shall constitute a quorum, and except as is otherwise provided by state law or this Code, the affirmative vote of the majority of a quorum present shall be necessary to adopt any ordinance or resolution; provided, that two-thirds of the membership of the council is required to enact an emergency ordinance. On final passage, the vote of each member of the city council voting shall be entered on the official records of the meeting. 
(f)	Signing or veto; overriding veto. All ordinances passed by the city council, other than emergency ordinances, shall be promptly submitted to the mayor for his approval; if approved he shall sign the same and return them to the city clerk. If the mayor disapproves such ordinances he shall return the same to the city council with his objections thereto in writing; and the city council shall cause the same to be entered in full upon the minutes and shall proceed to consider the mayor's objections, and to act upon the same, and if the city council shall pass it by a two-thirds vote, which vote shall be entered upon the minutes, the ordinance shall then become a law the mayor's veto to the contrary notwithstanding, and if the mayor fails or refuses to return any ordinance to the city clerk within ten (10) days after he receives the same, such ordinance shall become a law without his approval. 
(g)	When ordinances effective. Emergency ordinances shall become effective ten (10) days after passage, or as otherwise provided therein. All other ordinances, if approved by the mayor, shall become effective ten (10) days after passage by the city council, or as otherwise provided therein. If the mayor fails or refuses to signify to the city clerk in writing his approval or disapproval of any ordinance within ten (10) days after its passage by the city council, such ordinance shall become effective ten (10) days after passage by the city council, or as otherwise provided therein. If the mayor shall veto an ordinance, other than an emergency ordinance, and the city council shall after consideration of the mayor's objections to the ordinance override the veto of the mayor by a two-thirds vote, the ordinance shall become a law, the mayor's veto to the contrary notwithstanding, and shall become effective ten (10) days after its final passage overriding the mayor's veto, or as otherwise provided therein. 
(h)	Recordation. Every ordinance shall, upon its final passage, be recorded in a book kept for that purpose, and shall be signed by the presiding officer and the clerk of the governing body. 
(Code 1964, § 2-17; Ord. No. 471-78, § 2, 3-15-78; Ord. No. 1034-92, § 1, 3-18-92) 
Editor's note— F.S. § 166.041 provides the procedures for adoption of ordinances and resolutions, but subsection (6) thereof authorizes additional requirements by future ordinance or charter amendment. The above section was derived from ordinances enacted in 1974, 1976, 1977 and 1978, all of which were subsequent to the enactment of said § 166.041. 
Charter reference— Ordinances, Subpt. A, Art. V.  
Sec. 2-80. - Motions to adjourn. 
A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and decided without debate. 
(Code 1964, § 2-11.22)  
Secs. 2-81—2-90. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CITY MANAGER 
 
Sec. 2-91. - Position established. 
There is hereby established the position of city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 2-21)  
Sec. 2-92. - Appointment; qualifications; compensation. 
(a)	The city council shall appoint a city manager, who is a United States citizen, solely on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications, and his compensation shall be fixed by mutual agreement of the city council and the city manager, and shall be paid pursuant to the terms of such agreement. The city manager may be removed by a majority vote of the city council if the entire city council is present, or, if the entire city council is not present, then by the affirmative vote of at least four (4) members of the city council. Upon removal of the city manager, the city council shall appoint an acting city manager. 
(b)	Within ninety (90) days of a vacancy, the city council shall appoint a city manager. The term of appointment shall be for one year, and the city manager reappointed on an annual basis at the pleasure of the city council. Provided, however, if the city manager has a valid employment contract with the city council, then the employment contract will take precedence over the requirement in the code for appointments and reappointments. 
(Code 1964, § 2-22; Ord. No. 791-86, § 2, 6-18-86; Ord. No. 1111-95, § 1, 9-20-95)  
Sec. 2-93. - Residency. 
The city manager need not be a resident of the city, but shall become a resident within thirty (30) days after taking the oath of office. 
(Code 1964, § 2-22; Ord. No. 791-86, § 2, 6-18-86)  
Sec. 2-94. - Acting city manager. 
By letter to the city council, the city manager shall appoint a qualified administrative officer to exercise the powers and perform the duties of the city manager during the city manager's temporary absence or disability. If desired, the city council may revoke such appointment at any time and appoint another officer of the city to serve until the city manager shall return or the disability shall cease. 
(Code 1964, § 2-23; Ord. No. 688-84, § 1, 5-16-84; Ord. No. 791-86, § 2, 6-18-86)  
Sec. 2-95. - Powers; duties; responsibilities. 
The city manager shall be designated as the chief administrative officer of the city, and head of the administrative branch of the city government. The city manager shall report directly to the city council concerning proper administration of the city, and subject to provisions of the charter, have the following powers: 
(a)	Appoint and remove department heads and employees: 
(1)	Except as provided in the city charter, appoint and remove department heads as necessary. The city manager shall exercise authority over all department heads and employees of the city. Supervision and direction of all departments shall be the responsibility of the city manager; however, the city manager may appoint persons to be department heads. 
(2)	Supervise and manage city personnel and exercise the prerogative of final approval as to the employment, suspension and termination of city employees all pursuant to the city personnel manual, and applicable collective bargaining agreements. 
(3)	Neither the city council nor any of its members shall direct or request any personnel action by the city manager or any of his subordinates, nor interfere in any manner with the internal administrative service, except solely through the city manager, and neither the city council nor its members shall give directions to any subordinates of the city manager, either publicly or privately. This section shall not preclude the city council from making known to the city manager its views concerning personnel actions and the internal administration of city government. 
(4)	Fix the compensation of city officers and employees within pay schedules established by the city council, except those persons appointed by the city council. 
(b)	Administrative code. The city manager shall develop and keep current the Rockledge Code of Ordinances and other legislative actions of the city council for the purpose of implementing the laws of the city. 
(c)	Meetings. The city manager shall attend all regular and special called city council meetings, unless excused by the city council; in the case of his absence, the city manager shall be responsible to have a designated replacement. The city manager shall also be responsible for attending any other meetings necessary to conduct city business. 
(d)	Municipal budget. The city manager shall prepare the budget of expenditures and revenues annually and submit the program to the city council for adoption; upon adoption of the budget, it shall be the responsibility of the city manager to implement and monitor the budget. 
(e)	Control of expenditures from city treasury. The city manager shall not draw money, nor permit money to be drawn from the city treasury except in pursuance of appropriation made by law. The city manager is hereby granted the power to authorize and make expenditures of public funds of the city, not exceeding the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in any single incident or occasion, without prior specific approval of such expenditures by the city council; provided, however, that any such expenditure by the city manager shall be only for a valid municipal purpose for which funds have been appropriated by law in the then current fiscal budget of the city, and the amount of any such expenditure does not overspend the amount budgeted for such purpose. The twenty-five thousand dollar ($25,000.00) maximum limitation per expenditure imposed in the preceding sentence is subject to the exception for emergency situations as hereinafter provided, and the specific exceptions described in section 2-172 of this code. In an emergency situation the city manager or his designee may make or authorize without prior city council approval the expenditure of public funds of the city in an amount not exceeding fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) in any single instance provided that any such expenditure shall be only for a valid municipal purpose as an emergency measure, and shall be made only from funds previously appropriated by law to a contingency, emergency, or discretionary fund budget classification, or from funds appropriated generally or specifically for the purpose for which the funds are expended. Any such expenditure authorized by the city manager or his designee in excess of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in an emergency situation shall be reported to the city council at the next regular meeting of the council with the city manager's request for ratification and approval of such expenditure by the city council. 
(f)	Annual financial and administrative activity report. The city manager shall be responsible for directing an audit of the financial condition of the city and submit a report to the city council. 
(g)	Implementation of policy. The city manager shall ensure that city council policy is implemented, and that all laws, council acts and directives, and charter provisions are implemented in a timely fashion. 
(h)	Capital program. The city manager shall prepare a capital improvement program for the city council, and, upon adoption, shall implement said program. 
(i)	Provision of information. The city manager shall keep the city council informed through weekly and/or monthly reports, as necessary, and is to provide all necessary information regarding the finances and operations of the city. 
(j)	Contracts. The city manager shall execute contracts on behalf of the city pursuant to ordinances or resolutions and oversee their implementation. 
(k)	Travel expenses. Within budgetary limitations, and subject to applicable statutory provisions, the city manager shall have authority to approve or disapprove travel and travel expenses, including mileage, food and lodging away from home, for travel by all city personnel, including department heads, if such travel is in connection with city work. Approval of travel and payment or reimbursement of travel expenses of city personnel must be obtained in advance in all cases. Non-overnight travel by the city manager within the state shall not require council approval. Overnight travel expenses of the city manager will require prior authorization by the city council except in emergency or extraordinary situations in which case the city manager may expend public funds for his own reasonable and necessary overnight travel expenses without council approval provided the city manager shall first notify and obtain the concurrence of the mayor or chairman of the city council as to the necessity for such travel and payment of travel expenses. 
(l)	Other. Perform such other duties as are specified by the charter, ordinances, and resolutions of the city, or as requested by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 791-86, § 2, 6-18-86; Ord. No. 974-90, § 2, 8-15-90; Ord. No. 1007-91, § 3, 8-20-91; Ord. No. 1057-93, § 1, 7-7-93; Ord. No. 1668-2015 , § 1, 3-18-15)  
Secs. 2-96—2-105. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CITY ATTORNEY 
 
Sec. 2-106. - Position established. 
There is hereby established the position of city attorney. 
(Ord. No. 791-86, § 2, 6-18-86)  
Sec. 2-107. - Appointment; qualifications. 
(a)	The city council shall appoint a city attorney who is a member of the Florida Bar and a citizen of the United States. The city attorney shall be appointed, and may be removed, by a majority vote of the city council if the entire city council is present, or if the entire city council is not present, then by the affirmative vote of at least four (4) members of the city council. Upon removal of the city attorney, the city council shall appoint an acting city attorney. 
(b)	Within ninety (90) days of a vacancy in the office of city attorney, the city council shall appoint a city attorney. As provided by Subpart A, Article I, section 5 of the codified city charter, the term of appointment of the city attorney shall be for one year, and the city attorney reappointed on an annual basis at the pleasure of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 792-86, § 2, 6-18-86) 
Charter reference— Appointment of officers, Subpt. A, Art. I, § 5.  
Sec. 2-108. - Compensation. 
The compensation of the city attorney shall be fixed by mutual agreement of the city council and the city attorney, and shall be paid pursuant to the terms of such agreement. 
(Ord. No. 792-86, § 2, 6-18-86)  
Sec. 2-109. - Acting city attorney. 
By letter to the city council the city attorney may appoint a qualified assistant city attorney to exercise the powers and perform the duties of the city attorney during the city attorney's temporary absence or disability. If desired, the city council may revoke such appointment at any time and appoint another attorney to serve until the city attorney shall return or the disability shall cease. 
(Ord. No. 792-86, § 2, 6-18-86)  
Sec. 2-110. - Powers; duties; responsibilities. 
(a)	The city attorney shall be the corporation counsel and legal advisor of the governing body of the city. He shall prepare all ordinances of the city, represent the city in litigation involving the city, prepare such contracts, documents and legal instruments as the city council may direct and in general be the legal officer and head of the legal department of the city. In matters wherein the city attorney has a conflict of interest, or in litigations wherein the city attorney feels that specialized representation will be in the best interests of the city, the city attorney may recommend employment of an assistant city attorney, or the association of one or more attorneys specializing in a particular area of practice to handle that particular matter of business or litigation, or to assist the city attorney therein. 
(b)	Meetings. The city attorney shall attend all regular and special meetings of the city council unless excused by the chairman of the council, and shall attend such meetings of committees of the city council and city staff as he is specifically instructed to do by the city council. 
(c)	Budget. No later than June 1 of each year the city attorney shall submit to the city manager his recommendations for cost and expense items of the city attorney's office for inclusion in the general administrative budget of the city for the next ensuing fiscal year, and such recommendation shall be considered by the finance committee and city council prior to adoption of the budget for the next succeeding fiscal year. 
(d)	Other duties. The city attorney shall perform such other legal duties as are specified by the charter, the Code or as requested by the city council. 
(e)	Annual engagement letter. On or before September 30th of each year, if the then serving Rockledge City Attorney desires to continue to serve in that capacity during the city's next ensuing fiscal year said attorney shall prepare and furnish the Rockledge City Council duplicate originals of a professional engagement letter describing the scope of legal services proposed to be performed by said city attorney during the city's next ensuing fiscal year, the manner in which said attorney will perform those services, the amount said attorney will charge the city for such services, and other relevant information pertaining to the proposed attorney-client relationship between the City of Rockledge and said attorney, including but not in way of limitation, assurances that said attorney will comply with the provisions of section 2-111 of this Code pertaining to said attorney's representation of other clients and the avoidance of representation in matters constituting, or appearing to constitute, a conflict of interest. Said engagement letter shall be signed by the attorney submitting same and be in form and content satisfactory and acceptable to the Rockledge City Council which shall signify its acceptance of same by authorizing the mayor or chairman of said council to sign and return a duplicate original of said council to sign and return a duplicate original of said engagement letter to the attorney submitting the same. If the terms of the submitted engagement letter are unacceptable to the city council, the attorney and council may negotiate such terms toward a mutually acceptable engagement, provided however, that the term of office of the Rockledge City Attorney shall always be terminable at will by the city council or the attorney unless otherwise expressly provided in a written instrument signed by the attorney and approved by action of the city council. An engagement letter as described above shall be submitted and approved as aforesaid before any city attorney is appointed by the Rockledge City Council to render legal services for the city after September 30th, 1993. 
(Ord. No. 792-86, § 2, 6-18-86; Ord. No. 1056-93, § 1, 7-7-93)  
Sec. 2-111. - Other clients. 
The city attorney shall be at liberty to render legal services to, and accept employment by, clients other than the city; provided, that the city attorney shall not accept employment by any person or party in any matter conflicting with the interests of the city, nor shall the city attorney represent clients other than the city in matters appearing before the city council or any board, committee, or agency of the city. 
(Ord. No. 792-86, § 2, 6-18-86)  
Secs. 2-112—2-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PENSIONS AND RETIREMENT[4] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Insurance premium taxes for police and fire department retirement, § 19-11 et seq.; retirement trust and retirement plan for city employees, App. A. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 2-121—2-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - SOCIAL SECURITY FOR CITY EMPLOYEES 
 
Sec. 2-131. - Declaration of policy. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend, effective April 1, 1953, to the employees and officials of the city not excluded by law, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function, the benefits of the system of old age and survivor's insurance as authorized by the federal Social Security Act and amendments thereto, including Public Law 734, of the 81st Congress, and by F.S. Ch. 650; and to cover by such plan all services which constitute employment as defined by F.S. § 650.02(2), performed in the employ of the city by employees thereof. 
(Code 1964, § 19-1)  
Sec. 2-132. - Federal act adopted. 
The city does hereby adopt the terms, conditions, requirements, reservations, benefits, privileges and other conditions thereunto appertaining, of Title II of the Social Security Act as amended by Public Law No. 734, 81st Congress, for and on behalf of all the officers and employees of the city, and of its departments and agencies, save and except any of such officers and employees now covered or authorized to be covered by any retirement system provided by law, and further excepting any official or employee who occupies any position, office or employment not authorized to be covered by applicable state or federal laws or regulations. 
(Code 1964, § 19-7)  
Sec. 2-133. - Agreement with state agency authorized. 
The mayor, or other chief executive officer of the city, is hereby authorized and directed to execute all necessary agreements and amendments thereto with the Florida Industrial Commission, or its successors, for the purpose of extending the benefits provided by the system of old age and survivor's insurance to the employees and officials of the city, as provided by section 2-131. The agreement shall provide for such methods of administration of the plan by the city as are found by the state agency to be necessary for the proper and efficient administration thereof, and shall be effective with respect to services in employment covered by such agreement performed after April 1, 1953. 
(Code 1964, § 19-3) 
Editor's note— The agreement to extend social security coverage to the employees of the city, entered into between the city and the Florida Industrial Commission, received federal approval on June 22, 1953. 
The successor to the Florida Industrial Commission as the state agency is now the division of retirement of the department of administration under F.S. § 650.02(4).  
Sec. 2-134. - Withholdings authorized. 
Withholdings from salaries, wages or other compensation of employees and officials for the purpose of the employees' contributions to the social security plan provided by this article, are hereby authorized to be made, and shall be made, in the amounts and at such times as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall be paid over to the state agency designated by such laws or regulations to receive such amounts. 
(Code 1964, § 19-4)  
Sec. 2-135. - Appropriations required. 
There shall be appropriated from available funds, derived from the administration fund, such amounts and at such times as may be required to pay promptly the contributions required of the city, as employer, by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, which funds shall be paid over to the lawfully designated state agency at the times and in the manner provided by law and regulation. 
(Code 1964, § 19-5)  
Sec. 2-136. - Records; reports; adherence to regulations. 
The city shall keep such records and make such reports as may be required by applicable state or federal laws or regulations, and shall adhere to the rules and regulations of the state agency for the enforcement of such laws and regulations. 
(Code 1964, § 19-6)  
Sec. 2-137. - Custodian; withholding and reporting agent. 
The city clerk is hereby designated the custodian of all sums withheld from the compensation of officers and employees, and of the appropriate funds of the contributions of the city, and the clerk is hereby made the withholding and reporting agent and charged with the duty of maintaining personnel records for the purposes of this article. 
(Code 1964, § 19-8)  
Secs. 2-138—2-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - RESERVED[5]

ARTICLE VIII. - FINANCES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Charter reference— Revenue and taxation, Subpt. A, Art. VII. 
Cross reference— Taxation, Ch. 19. 
 
Sec. 2-171. - Trust account. 
The treasurer of the city shall establish and maintain an account to be designated as the "City of Rockledge Trust Account," which account shall be accounted for separately from all other bank accounts of the city. All cash bonds and cash security deposits to be held by the city, and all trust funds and funds to be held by the city as escrowee, or as agent of or for one or more other parties, all of which bonds, deposits and funds are herein referred to as "trust funds," shall be promptly deposited into and kept on deposit in said trust account pending fulfillment and satisfaction of the condition or conditions under which the same come into the possession of the city. Proper accountings shall be maintained of all funds deposited in said trust account, and any income therefrom, in accordance with recognized and acceptable accounting methods. Funds in said trust account may be invested in certificates of deposit, or other forms of investment permitted by law unless the investment of such funds is expressly prohibited by the provisions of the bond or other trust agreement; provided, however, that no investment shall be made which will render the city unable to timely meet its obligation to return or disburse all trust funds in accordance with the terms of the applicable bond or other trust agreement. Unless otherwise expressly provided in the bond, deposit, trust, escrow, agency, or other agreement, any income derived from the investment of any trust funds shall belong to the city, and may be withdrawn from the trust account from time to time upon authorization by the city council. Trust funds from different bonds, deposits, trust, escrow or agency agreements may be commingled in said trust account, and such trust funds held by the city may be commingled with any other funds of the city. Trust funds shall be disbursed from said trust account to the proper party or parties entitled thereto upon fulfillment and satisfaction of the condition or conditions pertaining to the particular bond or other trust agreement involved upon authorization by the city manager; and, in the event of forfeiture or default on the part of the obligor under any bond, deposit, trust, escrow or agency agreement, the city council may authorize the withdrawal of funds from said trust account for disbursement to the city for the appropriate purpose.
