(b)	In the event a franchisee has not completed construction and is not offering cable service to at least seventy-five (75) percent of the homes within the service area described in its franchise at the expiration of three (3) years from the date of the issuance of said franchise, the council shall have the right to withdraw the franchise in the interest of the public convenience and necessity. Said action shall be taken only after a public hearing established by the council for the purpose of allowing the franchisee to show cause why such action should not be taken. 
(c)	Said franchisee shall have one (1) year to sell its system but must continue to operate the system for those subscribers who are already connected. 
(d)	It shall be the responsibility of the city to inspect and verify performance. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 4, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-5. - Bonding requirements. 
(a)	Initial performance bond. Each new franchisee shall, within thirty (30) days after the effective date of an original franchise granted under this chapter, post with the city a performance bond with good and sufficient surety in the amount of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00), conditioned upon the faithful performance and discharge of the obligations imposed by the franchise awarded hereunder from the date thereof including, but not limited to, faithful compliance with the construction timetable proposed by the franchisee in its bid as incorporated into the franchise, unless appropriate extension is approved by the city upon authorization of the city council. If the franchisee shall fail to perform the obligations heretofore or hereinafter set out in this franchise, the franchisee shall forfeit in total to the city the hereinabove initial performance bond. The city's right to recover under the bond shall be in addition to any other rights retained by the city under this chapter and other applicable law, any proceeds recovered under the bond may be used to reimburse the city for loss of expected payments of the franchise fee and other valuable consideration given for the grant of the franchise, and such additional expenses as may be incurred by the city as a result of franchisee's failure to comply with the obligations imposed by the franchise including, but not limited to, attorney's fees and costs of any action or proceeding, the cost of refranchising with another entity, and the cost of removal or abandonment of any property, or other costs which may be in default. In the event franchisee satisfactorily performs any and all obligations hereunder for a period of eight (8) years from the award of its franchise, applicant shall be entitled to file a request for a return of the bond hereunder. The city council hereby waives said bond for this renewal franchise to be awarded to Bright House Networks on the basis that this franchisee has established in the City of Rockledge a record of satisfactory performance and has in place a significant investment. 
(b)	Guarantee bond. Each franchisee shall within sixty (60) days of the effective date an initial franchise is granted under this chapter, furnish to the city a bond in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00). This bond shall remain in full force and effect for a period of five (5) years from the date the franchise is granted under this chapter to guarantee the compliance with performance requirements and payment of all sums which may become due to the city under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 5, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-6. - Service requirements. 
(a)	System capability. 
(1)	The franchisee's cable distribution system shall provide at least seventy (70) television channels. 
(2)	Each franchisee shall at all times provide programming on its basic service pursuant to FCC requirements and provided that such programming is available. 
(3)	The franchisee shall extend cable television service to any residence within the city which is located on property within one hundred twenty five (125) feet of any portion of the subscriber distribution facilities of the franchisee's existing plant at the time of application for service. The one hundred twenty five (125) feet is measured following appropriate easements and rights of way and running contiguous with power and telephone. Such extension shall be made within sixty (60) calendar days after receipt of a legitimate written request for such service. There shall, however, be no obligation on the part of the franchisee to extend cable service in an area that does not have a density of at least (20) homes per trunk cable mile continuous to existing plant. Provided, however, the franchisee at its option may serve any building in excess of one hundred twenty five (125) feet if the owner of said building is willing to pay the actual cost of the service extension to such building; franchisee will pay for one hundred twenty five (125) feet as measured from the structure desiring service. 
(b)	Lock-out devices. The franchisee shall make available, to any residential subscriber so requesting, a "parental guidance" or "lock-out" device which shall permit the subscriber, at his or her option, to eliminate any channel from reception. The franchisee shall advise all residential subscribers regarding the availability of this device, and an additional reasonable charge for any such device may be imposed. 
(c)	Denial of service. 
(1)	The franchisee shall not, without good cause, fail to provide available service to individuals or prospective subscribers nor shall the franchisee terminate service without good cause. Service shall be provided to all interested customers where economically feasible. 
(2)	Franchisee may deny service to any subscriber where such subscriber has previously been a subscriber of the franchisee and franchisee previously terminated subscriber's service due to non-payment. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 6, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-7. - General penalties. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to make any unauthorized connection, whether physically, electrically, acoustically, inductively or otherwise, with any part of a franchised cable system within the incorporated City of Rockledge for the purpose of enabling himself or others to receive any signal, pictures, programs or sound. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 7, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-8. - Compliance with applicable laws and ordinances. 
The franchisee shall, at all times during the life of this franchise, be subject to all lawful exercise of the police power by the city and to such reasonable regulation as the city shall hereafter provide, provided that such regulation is not destructive of the rights granted herein. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 8, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-9. - Territorial area involved. 
This chapter relates to the present territorial limits of the city and to any area henceforth added thereto during the term of this franchise. 
In the event the city annexes property into the municipal limits of the city, and said area is presently being served by a county franchised company, said franchised company shall not be obligated to obtain a franchise pursuant to this chapter in order to continue serving the annexed area unless required by the city to do so. Said company shall be obligated to pay the city a franchise fee for said area in accordance with the rates set by the city pursuant to this chapter and applicable law. Said company shall submit a letter indicating their agreement to comply with all rules and regulations set forth in this cable ordinance. In the event the company serving the annexed area desires to extend its service beyond the annexed area, said company shall be required to apply for and obtain a franchise pursuant to the terms and conditions of the ordinance prior to construction/installation of any additional cable outside the annexed area. Any existing city franchised cable operator shall not be obligated to provide service to an area that when annexed by the city is being served by an existing county franchised cable operator. The city shall notify the current franchisee of any annexations including the legal description of the annexed area. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 9, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-10. - Liability and indemnification. 
(a)	Liability in case of emergency. If, at any time in case of fire, disaster, or other emergency, it shall appear necessary in the judgment of the city to cut, move or otherwise interfere with any of the wires, cables, amplifiers, appliances or appurtenances thereto of the franchisee, the city shall not be liable for any injury or damage to such property and equipment of the franchisee as a result of such emergency cutting, moving or interference. The city shall hold the franchisee harmless for damage or injury to property or person other than the franchisee if such damage or injury to property is the result of city's cutting, moving, or interfering with franchisee's system plant and facilities. City shall immediately notify franchisee of such emergency and franchisee shall make necessary repairs. 
(b)	Indemnification. 
(1)	The franchisee shall hold the city harmless and shall pay any and all damages which the city may be required to pay as a result of the negligence of franchisee, its agents, employees or contractors resulting from the performance of their work-related duties. 
(2)	The franchisee agrees that it will maintain throughout the term of this franchise liability insurance insuring the city and the franchisee with regard to all damages mentioned in subparagraph (a) above in the minimum amounts of: 
a.	One million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death to any one person, within the limit, however, or one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for bodily injury or death resulting from any one accident. 
b.	One hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage resulting from any one accident. 
(3)	The insurance policy obtained by the franchisee in compliance with this paragraph must be approved by the city and such insurance policy, along with written evidence of payment of required premiums, shall be filed and maintained with the city clerk during the term of this franchise. 
(4)	Whenever in the judgment of the council said insurance shall be deemed insufficient or inadequate, then franchisee, upon demand by said council, shall furnish such new or additional insurance in such reasonable amount or amounts as may be specified by it and cost to be borne by the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 10, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-11. - Signal quality requirements. 
The franchisee shall operate and maintain its cable system in full compliance with the standards set forth by the Federal Communications Commission. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 11, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-12. - Operation and maintenance of system. 
(a)	The franchisee shall render efficient service, make repairs promptly, and interrupt service only for good cause and for the shortest time possible. Such interruption, insofar as possible, shall be preceded by notice and shall occur during periods of minimum use of the system. 
(b)	The franchisee shall maintain a local business office (within Brevard County), or agent, which shall be open, or available, during all usual business hours and have a listed telephone in the local telephone directory, and be so operated that complaints and requests for repairs or adjustments may be received at any time. 
(c)	All subscriber complaints and requests pertaining to repairs, quality of service, equipment malfunctions, or adjustments shall be handled in an expeditious manner by the franchisee. Complaints shall be directed to the franchisee's local office and shall be resolved or a reasonable explanation for the absence of resolution shall be given no later than three (3) working days except for adjustments which shall be five (5) working days after receipt of notice thereof excluding periods of natural disasters. A complete record of all written complaints received and the measures taken to resolve them shall be kept by the franchisee for three (3) years and made available to the city manager upon request. The city manager shall be designated as the official of the city who has primary responsibility for the continuing administration of the Franchise and implementation of complaint procedures. Notice of the procedures for reporting and resolving complaints shall be given to each subscriber at the time of initial subscription to the cable system. 
(d)	The franchisee agrees to comply with the following measures to insure prompt and efficient service to customers in the City of Rockledge: 
(1)	Keep at least one (1) repair crew with a vehicle, tools, and equipment adequate for making repairs on call, twenty-four (24) hours a day, seven (7) days a week, for the specific purpose of responding promptly to customer calls for restoration of interrupted service, pursuant to FCC regulations; and taking into account the safety of company employees. 
(2)	Simultaneous with the execution of this chapter, the franchisee shall implement a policy and program whereby customers within the City of Rockledge will be given fair and equitable credit or reduction in their cost of service for interruptions of service lasting more than one twenty-four-hour day per billing period. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 12, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-13. - Carriage of signals. 
All Federal Communications Commission regulations shall be complied with regarding the carriage of the programming of any existing or future television broadcasting station which covers the City of Rockledge in its principal broadcasting area. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 13, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-14. - Program alteration. 
All programs of broadcasting stations carried by the franchisee shall be carried in their entirety as received, with announcements and advertisements and without additions except as the Federal Communications Commission may otherwise specify. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 14, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-15. - Other business activities. 
This chapter does not take the place of any other franchise, license, or permit which might be required by law of the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 15, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-16. - Safety requirements. 
(a)	The franchisee shall at all times employ ordinary care and shall install and maintain in use commonly accepted methods and devices for preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injuries, or nuisances to the public. 
(b)	The franchisee shall install and maintain its wires, cables, fixtures, and other equipment in accordance with the requirements of the city's codes and ordinances, state and federal law, and in such manner that they will not interfere with any installations of the city or of a public utility serving the city. 
(c)	All structures and all lines, equipment, and connections in, over, under, and upon the streets, sidewalks, alleys and public ways or places of the city, wherever situated or located, shall at all times be kept and maintained in safe, suitable, substantial condition, and in good order and repair. 
(d)	The franchisee shall have sufficient employees to provide safe, adequate, and prompt service for its facilities. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 16, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-17. - Conditions on street occupancy. 
(a)	All transmissions and distribution structures, lines, and equipment erected by the franchisee within the city shall be so located as to cause minimum interference with the proper use of streets, alleys, and other public ways and places, and to cause minimum interference with the rights and reasonable convenience of property owners who join any of the said streets, alleys or other public ways and places. 
(b)	In case of disturbance by franchisee of any street, sidewalk, alley, public way, or paved area, the franchisee shall, at its own cost and expense and in a manner approved by the city, replace and restore such street, sidewalk, alley, public way, or paved area in as good a condition as before the work involving such disturbance was done. 
(c)	If at any time during the period of this franchise the city shall lawfully elect to alter or change the grade of any street, sidewalk, alley, or other public way, the franchisee, upon reasonable notice by the city, shall remove, relay, and relocate its poles, wires, cables, underground conduits, manholes, and other fixtures at its own expense except shall be compensated as other users of the public rights-of-way are compensated for moving their facilities. This would not apply to the relocation of city water lines under the city agreement with the City of Cocoa. 
(d)	Any poles or other fixtures placed in any public way by the franchisee shall be placed in such manner as not to interfere with the usual travel on such public way. 
(e)	The franchisee shall, on the request of any person holding a building moving permit issued by city, temporarily raise or lower its wires to permit the moving of buildings or structures. The expense of such temporary removal or raising or lowering of wires shall be paid to franchisee by the person requesting same, and payment shall be paid in advance of franchisee raising or lowering their wires. The franchisee shall be given not less than five (5) business days advance notice to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
(f)	The franchisee shall have the authority to trim trees upon and overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks and public ways and places of the city so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires and cables of the franchisee, except that, in an emergency situation and at the option of the city, such trimming may be done by it or under its supervision and direction at the expense of the franchisee. 
(g)	In all sections of the city where the cables, wires, or other like facilities of public utilities are placed underground, the franchisee shall place its cables, wires or other like facilities underground, to the maximum extent that existing technology reasonably permits the franchisee to do so. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 17, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-18. - Removal of facilities upon request. 
Upon termination of service to any subscriber, the franchisee shall promptly remove all its facilities and equipment from the premises of such subscriber upon his request. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 18, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-19. - Transfer of franchise. 
The franchisee shall not transfer this franchise to another person without prior approval of the city, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld. The request for transfer shall come from the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 19, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-20. - Change of control of franchisee. 
Approval of the city council shall be required where ownership or control of more than fifty (50) percent of the right of control of the current franchise holder is acquired by a person or group of persons, none of whom already own or control fifty (50) percent or more of such right of control, singularly or collectively. By its acceptance of this chapter the franchisee specifically grants and agrees that any such acquisition occurring without approval of the city council shall constitute a violation of this chapter by the franchisee. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 20, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-21. - City rights in franchise. 
(a)	The right is hereby reserved to the city or the city council to adopt, in addition to the provisions contained herein and in existing applicable ordinances, such additional regulations as it shall find necessary in the exercise of the police power; provided that such regulations, by ordinance or otherwise, shall be reasonable and not in conflict with the rights herein granted. 
(b)	The city shall have the right to inspect the books, records, maps, plans and other financial records of the franchisee applicable to the Rockledge Franchise at any time during the normal business hours. 
(c)	The city shall have the right, during the life of this franchise, to install and maintain free of charge upon the poles of the franchisee any wire and pole fixtures necessary for a police alarm system, on the condition that such wire and pole fixtures do not interfere with the cable operations of the franchisee or violate any applicable Federal, State or Local construction code applicable thereto. 
(d)	The city shall have the right to inspect all construction or installation work performed subject to the provisions of this chapter and make such inspections as it shall find necessary to insure compliance with the terms of this chapter and other pertinent city ordinances and provisions of law. 
(e)	At the expiration of the term for which this franchise is granted, absent right of renewal pursuant to 47 U.S.C. 546, or upon its termination and cancellation, as provided for herein, the city shall have the right to require the franchisee to remove at its own expense all portions of the cable system from all public ways within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 21, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-22. - Maps, plats, and reports. 
(a)	The franchisee shall make available in its office, true and accurate maps or plats of all existing and proposed system facilities within the franchise area. 
(b)	If requested by the city council, the franchisee shall file with the city clerk not later than one hundred twenty (120) days after the end of the franchisee's fiscal year, a copy of its report to its stockholders (if it prepares such a report), an income statement applicable to its operations during the preceding twelve-month period, and a balance sheet. If requested by the city council, these reports shall be prepared or approved by a certified public accountant and there shall be submitted along with them such other reasonable information as the city council shall request. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 22, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-23. - Franchise fee/payment to the city. 
(a)	Franchisee shall pay to the City of Rockledge a franchise fee of five (5) percent of gross receipts, as defined in section 7-2 of this chapter, derived from the operation of the cable system in the franchise area. Payments shall be made to the city on a monthly, quarterly, semi-annual, or annual basis as determined by the city. Sufficient notice shall be given by the city to the franchisee on any payment schedule change. Payments shall be made thirty (30) days after the close of the designated period. 
(b)	The city shall have the right to an annual audit of franchisee's revenue records for the operation of the cable system in the franchise area. Within a three-year period, if a discrepancy is determined as a result of the audit process, an adjustment will be made. If a deviation of greater than ten (10) percent of gross receipts for the City of Rockledge is found, the cost of the audit shall be borne by the franchisee. 
(c)	The provisions of section 7-23 and other provisions referring to franchise fees within this agreement shall not be in effect so long as the franchisee pays the Florida Communications Services Tax or a similar tax or fee throughout the term of this franchise agreement. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 23, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-24. - Forfeiture of franchise. 
(a)	In addition to all other rights and powers pertaining to the city by virtue of this chapter or otherwise, the city reserves the right to terminate and cancel this franchise and all rights and privileges of the franchisee hereunder, pursuant to federal law, in the event that the franchisee: 
(1)	Violates any material provisions of this chapter or any rule, order, or determination of the city or city council made pursuant to this chapter, however no material provision of this franchise ordinance shall be unilaterally modified by the city; 
(2)	Becomes insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts, or is adjudged as bankrupt; or 
(3)	Attempts to evade any of the provisions of this chapter or practices any fraud or deceit upon the city. 
(b)	Such termination and cancellation shall be by resolution duly adopted after thirty days written notice to the franchisee and shall in no way affect any of the city's rights under this chapter or any provision of law. In the event that such termination and cancellation depends upon a finding of fact, such finding of fact as made by the city council shall be conclusive, provided however, that before this franchise may be terminated and cancelled under this paragraph, the franchisee must be provided with an opportunity to be heard before the city council in a full public proceeding affording due process. At least thirty (30) days before any action or proceeding to terminate is commenced by the city, franchisee shall be furnished written notice of the alleged violation and a reasonable opportunity to cure and correct the same. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 24, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-25. - Term of franchise. 
This franchise ordinance shall remain in full force and effect for a period of ten (10) years from January 1st, 2005 to January 1st, 2015 and shall be subject to renewal by the city through negotiations of a new franchise document mutually agreed upon by both parties, pursuant to federal law. Renewal applications shall be accompanied by a fee of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 2, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-26. - Erection, removal, and common user of poles. 
(a)	No poles or other wire-holding structures shall be erected by the franchisee without prior approval of the city with regard to location, height, type and any other pertinent aspects. However, no location of any pole or wire-holding structure of the franchisee shall be a vested interest and such poles or structures shall be removed or modified by the franchisee at its own expense whenever the city manager determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. 
(b)	Where poles or other wire-holding structures already exist for use in serving the city and are available for use by the franchisee, franchisee will make every effort to utilize such existing poles. 
(c)	Where the city or public utility serving the city desires to make use of the poles or other wire-holding structures of the franchisee but agreement therefore with the franchisee cannot be reached, the city council may require the franchisee to permit such use for such consideration and upon such terms as the council shall determine to be just and reasonable, if the council determines that the use would enhance the public convenience and would not unduly interfere with the franchisee's operations. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 26, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-27. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)	When not otherwise prescribed herein, all matters herein required to be filed with the city shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(b)	Franchisee shall make every reasonable effort to provide its service to all inhabitants of the city requesting same, provided it is economically feasible for the franchisee to do so, and will not withhold service from any prospective subscriber whose premises is passed by franchisee's cable without justifiable cause. 
(c)	The franchisee shall provide one (1) basic and one (1) standard cable service outlet to City Hall, police stations, fire stations, public libraries, emergency services buildings, and public school buildings within the city's franchise area at no cost to the facility, provided, however, each facility must be within one hundred twenty-five (125) feet of the franchisee's distribution system. The franchisee shall continue to provide the above service to all standard drops to city or public school buildings in existence at the location as of the date of this chapter. The distribution of the cable facility inside such buildings and the extent thereof shall be the option, duty and expense of the building owner. 
(d)	In the case of any emergency or disaster, the franchisee shall provide the system capability to transmit an emergency alert signal as required by FCC EAS regulations and shall be coordinated by the county. 
(e)	In the event the federal legislation is revised and/or amended, then the terms and conditions of this franchise agreement may be revised or amended if legally mandated by the federal legislation, or if the parties decide by mutual written agreement to revise or amend this document. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 27, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-28. - Force majeure. 
Prevention or delay of performance by the franchisee of any obligation under this chapter because of circumstances beyond the control of the franchisee, unforeseen circumstances or Acts of God shall not be deemed noncompliance with, or in violation of, this chapter. To the extent the Franchisee's performance of any obligation in this chapter is delayed by circumstances described in the preceding sentence, the franchisee's compliance with such obligation shall be excused until such circumstances are removed or resolved which shall be accomplished within a reasonable amount of time. The franchisee shall have a reasonable time following the removal or resolution of such circumstances to complete its performance under this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 28, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-29. - No third party beneficiary. 
This chapter is solely for the benefit of, and shall be binding upon, the parties hereto and their respective successors in interest. No right or cause of action shall accrue upon, or by reason hereof, to or for the benefit of any person not a party to this chapter or a successor in interest. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 29, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-29.1. - Entire agreement. 
This agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the parties and supersedes all previous discussions, understandings and agreements. Modifications to and waivers of the provisions herein may only be made by agreement of both parties and only in writing. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 30, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-29.2. - Acceptance. 
Franchisee shall forfeit and shall be deemed to have forfeited and abandoned all rights and privileges conferred by this chapter, and this chapter shall be null and void and of no force and effect unless franchisee shall, within thirty (30) days after adoption hereof, file with the city clerk its written acceptance of the rights and privileges hereby conferred and of the terms, conditions, and restrictions hereby imposed. 
(Ord. No. 1365-05, § 31, 1-19-05)  
Sec. 7-30. - Rates and charges. 
(a)	Any rate or charge established for cable television service, equipment, repair and installation shall be reasonable, just and fair to the public. In determining whether a rate or charge is reasonable, just and fair, the city shall apply the cable television rate regulation criteria established by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) by rule as amended from time to time. 
(b)	Should a franchisee desire to change any rate or charge, it shall submit a written proposal for the amounts and effective date of such change to the city manager who shall evaluate the proposal in a manner consistent with FCC cable television rate regulation standards and report this evaluation to the city council. The city manager's report shall be placed before the council at a duly noticed public hearing. At such hearing, evidence shall be taken and received on whether the proposed rate or charge is consistent with FCC standards. Upon conclusion of the public hearing, the city council shall decide the matter by majority vote and adopt a resolution approving, disapproving or modifying the proposed rate changes and providing such relief as is appropriate and authorized by FCC rate regulation standards. The resolution shall set forth findings of fact and conclusions regarding the city council's determination. 
(Ord. No. 1068-94, §§ 1, 2, 2-16-94)  
Chapter 8 - FIRE PROTECTION AND PREVENTION[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Nuisance vegetation, § 10-17; fireworks, § 13-6; interference with fire department signal system, § 13-11. 
 
Sec. 8-1. - General duties of chief. 
The chief of the fire department shall have charge and control of the fire department, firefighting personnel, fire equipment and apparatus of the city, and of any volunteer fire company whose services may be offered. He shall order and superintend the work of such company, and shall make recommendations to the city council from time to time as he deems appropriate for the better and more adequate protection of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 9-4)  
Sec. 8-2. - Powers of assistant chief in absence of chief. 
In the absence or disability of the chief of the fire department the assistant chief shall have charge and control of the fire department to the same extent as the chief. 
(Code 1964, § 9-6)  
Sec. 8-3. - Authority of officer in charge at fire. 
The chief of the fire department, or the fire department officer in charge, during any fire, shall have full and plenary police authority with power to order and make arrests of all persons in any way interfering with, hindering or impeding the work of the firefighting force, and shall have full power to regulate traffic on any and all streets in the area of the fire. 
(Code 1964, § 9-5)  
Sec. 8-4. - Adoption, enforcement of state regulations. 
(a)	All rules and regulations issued by the state fire marshal, under authority of F.S. § 633.05, shall be enforced by the chief of the fire department. 
(b)	The chief of the fire department is hereby authorized to perform within the city any duties imposed upon him by such law or in accordance therewith, and to have such assistance as he shall require from other officials of the city in the discharge of such duties. 
(Code 1964, § 9-7)  
Sec. 8-5. - Unauthorized use of equipment. 
No engine or other apparatus used for extinguishing fires shall be assigned to any private use or enterprise, or used therein, or carried or placed beyond the place assigned to it, except in case of fire, or for repairs, without written consent of the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1964, § 9-14)  
Sec. 8-6. - Obstructing firemen. 
No person shall resist, impede, obstruct or interfere with the movements of the chief of the fire department or his assistants or any regular or volunteer fireman in the execution of his duty. 
(Code 1964, § 9-16) 
Cross reference— Interfering with officers, § 13-9. 
State Law reference— Assault or battery of firefighter, F.S. § 784.07; preventing or obstructing extinguishment of fire, F.S. § 806.10.  
Sec. 8-7. - Refusal to obey firemen; interference with equipment. 
No person shall refuse to obey any lawful order of any officer of the regular or volunteer fire department at any fire, or meddle or interfere with any engine, carriage, hook and ladder, truck, hose, or fire apparatus when engaged at or going to any fire. 
(Code 1964, § 9-17) 
State Law reference— Obstructing or preventing extinguishment of fire, F.S. § 806.10.  
Sec. 8-8. - False fire alarms. 
No person shall knowingly turn or send in a false alarm of fire. 
(Code 1964, § 9-20) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 806.101.  
Sec. 8-9. - Unauthorized persons prohibited in vicinity of fires. 
No person, except firemen, policemen, owners of property immediately contiguous thereto or in danger therefrom and their agents and servants, newspaper and radio reporters, and representatives and agents of fire insurance companies, shall be allowed in the immediate vicinity of any fire without the express consent of the officer of the fire department in command at such fire, or in command of some section or subdivision of the department. 
(Code 1964, § 9-15)  
Sec. 8-10. - Crossing fire lines. 
No person shall go beyond a certain line to be designated by the chief or other officer in command at a fire. 
(Code 1964, § 9-18)  
Sec. 8-11. - Parking near fires. 
No person, except a member of the fire department or public official, shall park within three hundred (300) feet of any fire, or in any manner which will interfere with the proper operation of the apparatus or hose lines, or within any prescribed fire lines which have been established. 
(Code 1964, § 9-19) 
Cross reference— Parking, stopping and standing, § 21-31 et seq.  
Chapter 9 - GARBAGE AND TRASH[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Prohibited discharges from boats and vessels, § 6-6; health and sanitation, Ch. 10; nuisance accumulations of refuse, § 10-18; wrecked, abandoned and derelict property, § 13-14; sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 17; vehicles spilling load, § 18-8. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 9-1—9-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY COLLECTION SYSTEM 
 
Sec. 9-11. - Ownership of recyclable materials. 
(a)	Recyclable materials placed at the curb or at the designated collection point shall remain in the ownership of the individual placing said recyclable materials at said curb or designated collection point until said recyclable materials are collected by the city or an authorized collector of recyclable materials. 
(b)	Once recyclable materials are collected by the city or an authorized collector of recyclable materials said recyclable materials become the property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 960-90, § 2, 5-2-90)  
Sec. 9-12. - Prohibiting unauthorized taking of recyclable materials. 
No individual other than an officer, employee or agent of the city authorized for such purposes shall tamper or meddle with any container of recyclable materials, or the contents of such container, nor remove the container of recyclable materials, nor engage in scavenging of its contents, from the location where said container of recyclable materials has been placed by the depositor of the recyclable materials. 
(Ord. No. 960-90, § 2, 5-2-90)  
Sec. 9-13. - Billing, collection of charges. 
(a)	All garbage and trash collection charges due the city shall be included on a monthly water, sewer and garbage collection bill submitted to the owner or occupant of the premises from which the garbage and trash is collected. In any instance where premises do not receive the usual water and sewer bill, the garbage and trash collection charge shall be separately billed to the occupant of the premises for which the service is rendered. 
(b)	All accounts shall be considered delinquent if not paid by the fifteenth of the month following the billing period for which service is rendered. If a delinquent account is not paid within thirty (30) days, the superintendent shall cease all refuse collection for that account unless otherwise directed by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 844-87, § 1, 9-2-87; Ord. No. 960-90, § 1, 5-2-90)  
Sec. 9-14. - Collection fees for pickup of bulky items, furniture, appliances, etc. 
(a)	An owner or occupant of property who places for pickup and collection bulky items such as discarded household furniture and appliances will be charged an appropriate collection fee according to a schedule of collection fees compiled by the superintendent of public works, representative examples of such fees being as follows: 
Chair ..... $2.00 
Couch ..... 3.00 
Freezer ..... 3.00 
Refrigerator ..... 3.00 
Stove ..... 3.00 
Washing machine ..... 3.00 
(b)	The fees authorized by this section shall be paid to the city employee in charge of making the collection at the time the collection is made. 
(Code 1964, § 11-10A; Ord. No. 497-78, § 2, 9-20-78; Ord. No. 844-87, § 1, 9-2-87; Ord. No. 960-90, § 1, 5-2-90)  
Sec. 9-15. - Prearrangement for pickup of bulky items. 
An owner or occupant of property desiring the pickup and collection of bulky items such as discarded household furniture and appliances shall prearrange such pickup and collection by request in person or by telephoning the street department of the city department of public works. 
(Code 1964, § 11-10A; Ord. No. 497-78, § 2, 9-20-78; Ord. No. 844-87, § 1, 9-2-87; Ord. No. 960-90, § 1, 5-2-90)  
Sec. 9-16. - Wastes prohibited in containers. 
No person shall deposit or place in or cause to be deposited or placed in any garbage container or recycling container required by this chapter the following: 
(a)	Offal. The term "offal" shall mean all matter of a waste nature of butchered animals. 
(b)	Dead animals. The term "dead animals" shall mean all animals which may die or may be killed for other than food purposes. 
(c)	Excreta. The term "excreta" shall mean all human body wastes and animal dung and excrement. 
(d)	Fish heads, fish or fowl viscera or entrails, unless the same are contained in a plastic bag securely enclosed and tied. 
(e)	Ashes, sawdust, grass trimmings and other items of a fine nature unless the same are contained in a plastic bag securely enclosed and tied. 
(f)	Sharp items, razors, needles, broken glass and other similar material, unless same are placed in sealed boxes and labeled: "DANGER: CONTENTS CONTAINED ARE SHARP ITEMS." 
(g)	Hazardous waste of any variety. 
(h)	Flammable or explosive items; these items shall be disposed of as directed by the fire chief or designee, and the cost of disposal borne by the owner or possessor. 
(Code 1964, § 11-13; Ord. No. 838-87, § 6, 6-17-87; Ord. No. 844-87, § 1, 9-2-87; Ord. No. 960-90, § 1, 5-2-90; Ord. No. 989-91, § 6, 1-9-91)  
Sec. 9-17. - Fee for container. 
No building permit for the construction of any new single-family dwelling, duplex or triplex shall be issued unless the applicant therefor shall first pay to the city at the time of the filing of the application for such permit, in addition to any other fee or charge properly payable under the ordinance of the city, a fee computed at the rate of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) per dwelling unit described in the application. Such fee shall entitle the applicant to delivery and right to use for garbage collection and recycling purposes only one (1) wheeled garbage container and one (1) recycling container at each dwelling unit described in the application. When the certificate of occupancy is issued for such new residential construction the city shall deliver one (1) wheeled garbage container and one (1) recycling container to the premises of each dwelling unit for which the said sum of one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) has been paid, said containers to be used only for the collection of garbage and recyclable materials at said premises. 
(Ord. No. 996-91, § 1, 5-1-91; Ord. No. 1181-99, § 1, 3-24-99) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 996-91, § 1, adopted May 1, 1991, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 8-24. Said provisions have been included herein as § 9-17 at the discretion of the editor.  
Sec. 9-18. - Garbage collection fees. 
In order to cover the costs of inspecting, collecting, hauling and disposing of garbage, trash and recyclable materials, service charges in the amounts set forth below shall be paid to the city by the owner or occupant of each residence, building, structure, establishment, enterprise, land or premises from which garbage, trash or recyclable material are collected: 
(a)	Residential. The rate for residential recycling, garbage and trash collection shall be thirteen dollars and ninety cents ($13.90) per month per residence. A "residence" within the meaning of this section shall include a single residential unit, duplex residential unit, triplex residential unit, and each residential unit of a townhouse, mobile home or manufactured home subdivision. 
(b)	Commercial, multiple residence complexes and all entities other than "residential". The rate for garbage and trash collection from commercial establishments, multiple residence complexes, and all entities other than "residential" as defined in subsection (a) above shall be four dollars and seventy-five cents ($4.75) per cubic yard of garbage and trash collected on each occasion of collection by the city. There shall be a minimum charge of thirty dollars ($30.00) per month regardless of the amount of garbage and trash collected or the size of the garbage and trash container. The rate for collection of recyclable materials from multiple residence complexes shall be two dollars and thirty-five cents ($2.35) per month per residence. 
The rates in subsection (a) above shall be effective on all bills for services rendered after October 1, 2016. 
The rates in subsection (b) above shall be effective on all bills for services rendered after October 1, 2016. 
(Ord. No. 1323-03, § 2, 9-17-03; Ord. No. 1389-05, §§ 1—3, 9-7-05; Ord. No. 1424-06, §§ 1, 2, 9-20-06; Ord. No. 1467-07, §§ 1, 2, 9-19-07; Ord. No. 1523-09, §§ 1, 2, 9-9-09; Ord. No. 1692-2016 , §§ 1, 2, 9-7-16)  
Chapter 10 - HEALTH AND SANITATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Adult businesses, Ch. 3; animals, Ch. 5; prohibited discharges from boats and vessels, § 6-6; garbage and trash, Ch. 9; sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 17. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 10-1—10-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - NUISANCES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Nuisance animals, § 5-16; wrecked, abandoned and derelict property, § 13-14; storage of wrecked or dismantled motor vehicles, § 13-15. 
 
Sec. 10-16. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following words, terms or phrases shall have the meanings set forth below: 
Board means the nuisance abatement board of the city. 
City means the City of Rockledge. 
City Council means the city council of the City of Rockledge. 
Code enforcement officer means any authorized agent or employee of the city whose duty it is to assure compliance with provisions of this Code. 
Improved lot means any lot on which improvements have been made, including, but not limited to, construction of a building or structure, change of grade through filling or excavation, platted residential subdivision, with installed water or sewer lines, clearing of property to begin construction, or any other physical alteration which has significantly disturbed the natural vegetation on the site. 
Invoice for cost of abatement of nuisance means a written notice served by the city manager upon a property owner informing the property owner of the cost incurred by the city in causing the abatement of a nuisance as described in this article upon such property owner's failure to abate such nuisance within the time prescribed for abatement by the owner in a notice of violation or in an order of the nuisance abatement board. 
Notice of violation means a written notice from a code enforcement officer to a property owner informing such property owner of the existence or presence of a nuisance described in this article. 
Nuisance means any condition, occurrence, event, happening or thing declared to be a nuisance by any provision of this article. 
Nuisance abatement board means the administrative board created by the city council by the provisions of section 10-19 of this Code. 
Parkage is that space between the private property survey line of the property owner and the paved or graded portion of the public street adjacent thereto and includes that area between the sidewalk and street. 
Property owner means the owner or owners of the fee simple title to real property in the city upon which property a public nuisance is alleged to exist. 
Request for hearing means a written request from a property owner to the nuisance abatement board requesting said board to conduct a hearing on the issue of the existence or nonexistence of an alleged nuisance described in a notice of violation, or a written request from a property owner to the city council requesting a hearing on the amount of an invoice from the city for nuisance abatement costs. 
Undergrowth means herbaceous plants, plants and grasses with stems that wither away annually as distinguished from trees or shrubs with woody stems that live from year to year. 
Unimproved lot means any lot which remains undisturbed and in a natural vegetative state. 
Untended vegetation shall mean grass, weeds or undergrowth in excess of twelve (12) inches in height from the ground, dead trees, hedges, or dense growth of trees, vines, or other vegetation which tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare by creating a fire hazard; by providing a nesting, breeding or feeding area for insects, rodents, snakes, or other species of pest or vermin, or disease-bearing organisms; by impairing the vision of motorists or bicyclists or impeding pedestrians to the extent that traffic and pedestrian safety is impaired; or by adversely affecting the aesthetic appearance of the property upon which the vegetation is found, and adjacent properties. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87; Ord. No. 1152-97, § 1, 12-3-97)  
Sec. 10-17. - Maintenance of undergrowth and untended vegetation. 
(a)	Maintenance of improved residential lots/parcels, with a building or structure. The owner of an improved lot or parcel in a residential zone with a lot size of one (1) acre or less shall keep such lots free and clear of all fallen trees and limbs. All untended vegetation, grass and undergrowth shall be cut to a height not exceeding twelve (12) inches. However, nothing in this subsection shall be construed to require natural areas located within larger improved lots, one acre or more, to be cut to a height less than twelve (12) inches within such areas. 
(b)	Maintenance of improved residential lots/parcels, without a building or structure. The owner of an improved lot or parcel in a residential zone shall keep such lot/parcel of land and that portion of his property abutting and within ten feet of any improved lot/parcel, sidewalk, street or bicycle path and free and clear of all fallen trees and maintain all untended vegetation, grass and undergrowth therein shall be cut to a height not exceeding of twelve (12) inches. 
(c)	Maintenance of unimproved residential lots/parcels. The owner of an unimproved lot in a residential zone with lot sizes of one (1) acre or less shall keep that portion of his property abutting and within ten feet of any improved lot, sidewalk, street or bicycle path free and clear of all fallen trees and limbs and all untended vegetation, grass and undergrowth therein shall be cut to a height not exceeding of twelve (12) inches. 
(d)	Maintenance of non-residential zoned lots/parcels. The owner of every lot, piece and parcel of land located within a non-residential zone within the city shall keep such lot, piece, or parcel of land and that portion of his property abutting and within ten feet of any improved lot/parcel, sidewalk, street or bicycle path and free and clear of all fallen trees and maintain all untended vegetation, grass and undergrowth therein shall be cut to a height not exceeding of twelve (12) inches. 
(e)	No property maintenance permit required; other restrictions and requirements applicable. No permit shall be required for limited property maintenance required by this section; however the requirements, restrictions, and limitations imposed by other sections of this Code and applicable provisions of the land development regulations pertaining to environmental preservation, tree removal, change of grade, etc. shall be effective. In the event of any conflict between this section and other provision of this Code or applicable provision of the land development regulations, the other sections of this Code or applicable provisions of the land development regulations shall prevail and govern. 
(f)	Abutting property owner maintenance of parkages. It shall be the responsibility of every owner of real property within the city to at all times cause to be cut and mowed the undergrowth, grass and untended vegetation, and to cause to be cut and trimmed the flowers, vines, grasses, shrubbery and trees, in a manner that protects and promotes the public health, safety and welfare and presents an aesthetically pleasing appearance in those areas of the parkage most nearly abutting their properties. Parkages abutting improved residential or commercial lots/parcels shall be maintained as provided in this subsection (a) of this section for improved residential lots/parcels. Parkages abutting unimproved residential lots/parcels shall be maintained as provided in subsection (b) of this section for maintained portion of the unimproved residential lot/parcel. At all times this area shall be maintained in order to provide clear and safe visibility for pedestrian and vehicle movement. Every property owner shall have the duty of removing any refuse or other debris existing within the adjacent parkage, but the placement of refuse for collection in a manner and in containers specified by other provisions of this code is not prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87; Ord. No. 1152-97, § 2, 12-3-97)  
Sec. 10-18. - Garbage, refuse, dead animals, debris, other accumulations constituting a nuisance. 
Uncontained and exposed garbage, refuse, surface closets, dead animals, trash, waste and unused lumber or metals, or other waste materials, sawdust, or debris of any kind, are things that attract flies and insects, harbor rodents, vermin and dangerous reptiles, increase the danger of fires and the spread thereof, produce unpleasant odors, stenches and smells, and are otherwise dangerous to the health, comfort, convenience and general welfare of residents of the city, and any of such things, separately or severally, is hereby declared to be a public nuisance. No owner of any lot, place or area in the city shall cause, permit or allow to be placed, deposited, stored, kept or allowed to exist upon such lot, place or area any uncontained and exposed garbage, refuse, surface closet, dead animal, trash, waste lumber or metal, or other waste materials, sawdust, or debris of any kind. Any public nuisance as described in this section may be abated by the city in the manner hereinafter provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87) 
Cross reference— Garbage and trash, Ch. 9.  
Sec. 10-19. - Nuisance abatement board created. 
There is hereby created the nuisance abatement board of the city, hereinafter referred to as the "board," composed of the city manager, fire chief and director of public works, all of the city, the purpose, duty and function of which board is to serve as a quasijudicial administrative board of the city to hear and determine the issue of the existence or nonexistence of any alleged violation of the provisions of this article as charged in a notice of violation presented by a code enforcement officer of the city when a hearing on such issue is timely requested in writing by a property owner, and to perform such other duties and functions as the city council may from time to time prescribe by ordinance to further the objectives of this article. The city manager shall be the chairman of the board. Two (2) members of the board will constitute a quorum, and the concurring vote of two (2) members will be necessary to carry any motion, action or ruling of the board. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public and reasonable advance public notice shall be given of all meetings of the board. The board shall cause a written record to be prepared and maintained of its proceedings and actions. The board shall adopt rules of procedure for the conduct of its affairs and shall meet as often as required to effectively discharge its duties. In all hearings conducted by the board strict rules of evidence shall not be imposed, however, substantive rights of due process shall be observed and protected. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87)  
Sec. 10-20. - Notice of violation. 
When any code enforcement officer of the city finds and determines that any public nuisance as described in this article exists, he shall serve the owner of record of the property upon which the nuisance exists with a written notice of violation, which notice shall contain the following information: 
(a)	Identify the property upon which the nuisance exists. 
(b)	Describe the alleged nuisance. 
(c)	Describe the action required to abate the nuisance. 
(d)	Contain the city's estimate of the cost of abating the alleged nuisance in the manner described in said notice. Such estimate shall in no way be binding upon the city in its abatement of the nuisance if the nuisance is abated by the city. 
(e)	Instruct the owner to abate the alleged nuisance within ten (10) days after date of service of violation upon the owner, and that if the owner fails to so abate the alleged nuisance within said ten-day period the city will cause the nuisance to be abated and the property owner will be liable to the city for the cost of such abatement work, and unless such cost is paid in full within thirty (30) days after invoicing, the city will assess a lien against the property for such abatement costs with interest thereon at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum from the date of assessment, and the property owner will be liable for the city's costs in enforcing the lien, including the city's reasonable attorney's fees. 
(f)	Advise the property owner that if the property owner denies the existence of the nuisance as alleged in this notice of violation and desires a hearing before the nuisance abatement board for determination of the issue of the existence or nonexistence of the alleged nuisance, the property owner may obtain such hearing if, within ten (10) days after the date of service of the notice of violation upon the property owner, the property owner serves upon the nuisance abatement board a written request for hearing; and that the owner's failure to serve upon the nuisance abatement board such a request for hearing within said ten-day period shall constitute the property owner's waiver of the right to a hearing on the issue of the existence or nonexistence of the alleged nuisance, and shall also be deemed as the property owner's acknowledgment and agreement that the nuisance exists as alleged in the notice of violation. 
(g)	State both the street address and mailing address of the nuisance abatement board. 
A copy of this article (sections 10-16 through 10-27, inclusive) shall be served upon the property owner with the notice of violation. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87; Ord. No. 1094-95, § 1, 2-15-95)  
Sec. 10-21. - Request for hearing on existence of nuisance. 
Any property owner upon whom a notice of violation has been served as provided in section 10-20 of this article shall be entitled to a hearing by the nuisance abatement board of the city on the issue of the existence or nonexistence of the alleged nuisance described in the notice of violation; provided, that the property owner serves upon the nuisance abatement board a written request for hearing within ten (10) days after date of service of the notice of violation upon the property owner. Failure of a property owner to serve upon the nuisance abatement board a written request for hearing within the ten-day period above-stated shall constitute the property owner's waiver of the right to a hearing on the issue of the existence or nonexistence of the alleged nuisance, and shall also be deemed as the property owner's acknowledgment and agreement that the nuisance exists as alleged in the notice of violation. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87)  
Sec. 10-22. - Hearing on existence of nuisance. 
Within twenty (20) days after timely service upon the city of a written request for hearing by a property owner pursuant to section 10-21 of this article, the nuisance abatement board (board) shall conduct a hearing on the issue of the existence or nonexistence of the public nuisance alleged in the notice of violation served on the property owner by the code enforcement officer. The board shall serve the property owner with written notice of the time and place of the hearing not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing. The property owner shall have the right to be present and to be heard at the hearing and the right to be represented at the hearing by an attorney. At the hearing the nuisance abatement board shall receive sworn testimony and other evidence on the issue of the existence or nonexistence of the alleged nuisance and at the conclusion of the hearing the board shall issue its final order. The board's final order will be in writing and will contain findings of fact and a final determination as to the existence or nonexistence of the alleged nuisance. A copy of the board's order shall be served upon the property owner within five (5) days after the hearing and, if the order contains a finding that a nuisance does in fact exist, such order shall require the property owner to cause such nuisance to be abated within ten (10) days from the date of service of the order upon the property owner. The order shall also inform the property owner that in the event the property owner fails to abate the nuisance within said ten-day period, the city will thereafter at its earliest practicable opportunity cause the nuisance to be abated and charge the cost of abatement to the property owner. Further, the order shall in substance state that if the property owner fails to abate the nuisance and in consequence thereof the city abates the same, the city will thereafter serve upon the property owner a written notice of cost of abatement of nuisance, and an invoice for such cost, and unless the property owner pays the amount of such invoice to the city within thirty (30) days after service of the invoice upon the property owner the amount of such nuisance abatement cost will automatically be assessed against the real property upon which the nuisance was located, which assessment will constitute a lien against said real property which will bear interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum from the date of the lien until fully paid, and said lien may be enforced at the expense of the property owner as provided in section 10-26 below. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87)  
Sec. 10-23. - Abatement of nuisance by city. 
If a property owner fails to abate an alleged nuisance within the time stated in the notice of violation, or if a property owner timely files a request for hearing and fails to abate the nuisance within ten (10) days after the nuisance abatement board has conducted a hearing, found a nuisance to exist and ordered the property owner to abate such nuisance, the city shall take the action described in the notice of violation to abate the nuisance and remedy the condition or situation described in the notice of violation. Authorized representatives of the city shall have the right to go upon the land described in the notice of violation at reasonable times to abate the nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87)  
Sec. 10-24. - Invoicing property owner for abatement costs. 
In any instance wherein the city causes labor to be performed or materials to be supplied to abate a public nuisance pursuant to the provisions of this article, upon completion of the abatement work the city manager shall ascertain the necessary and reasonable costs and expenses incurred by the city in abating the nuisance, including reasonable costs of administration incurred in such abatement, and the city manager shall prepare a written invoice for cost of abatement of nuisance which shall contain a reasonably detailed itemization of the city's cost in abating the nuisance. A copy of such invoice shall be served upon the property owner together with a demand for payment to the city within thirty (30) days from the date of service of the invoice of all such costs and expenses. Said invoice shall advise the property owner that if the property owner contests the reasonableness of the amount of the invoice and desires a hearing before the city council for determination of the issue of the reasonableness of the amount of the invoice, the property owner may obtain such hearing if, within ten (10) days after date of service of the invoice upon the property owner said property owner serves upon the city council a written request for hearing. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87)  
Sec. 10-25. - Hearing on amount of abatement costs. 
If within ten (10) days after date of service of an invoice for the cost of abatement of nuisance upon a property owner such property owner serves upon the city council a written request for hearing on the issue of the reasonableness of the amount of the nuisance abatement costs reflected on an invoice, such property owner shall have a right to a hearing before the city council on such issue; provided, that nothing contained in this section is to be construed to permit a review of the determination by the nuisance abatement board of the existence of the public nuisance. The city council shall conduct said hearing within thirty (30) days from the date of service upon the city of the property owner's written request for hearing and shall cause written notice of the time and place of the hearing to be served upon the property owner not less than ten (10) days prior to the hearing. At said hearing the council shall receive testimony and other evidence on the issue of the reasonableness of the amount of the abatement costs invoiced by the city manager and at the conclusion of the hearing the city council shall determine and announce its decision as to the amount of the reasonable cost of abating the nuisance and the amount so determined by the city council shall be due and payable by the property owner to the city within five (5) days after the hearing by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87)  
Sec. 10-26. - Lien for costs of abatement by city. 
If a property owner fails to pay the city the nuisance abatement costs as invoiced by the city manager or as determined by the city council, as the case may be, on or before the date such payment is due under the provisions of this article, the amount of such abatement costs shall automatically be an assessment against the real property upon which the nuisance existed, and such assessment shall create and constitute a lien against such property, subject only to the lien for taxes due the city, the county, and the state. Said assessment shall bear interest at the rate of twelve (12) percent per annum from the date of assessment until fully paid and shall be collectible in the same manner as liens for taxes and with the same interest, penalties and advertising costs as are applicable to defaults in payment of other city taxes, and under the same procedure as to sale and forfeiture as applies to other city taxes. As an alternative to enforcement of the city's lien by sale of the property as for delinquent taxes the city may enforce its said lien by a proceeding in the circuit court of the county to foreclose the lien of the assessment in the manner in which a lien for mortgages is foreclosed under the Laws of Florida, and it shall be lawful to join in any complaint for foreclosure any one or more lots or parcels of land, by whomever owned, if assessed under the provisions of this article. In any such foreclosure action in which judgment is rendered in favor of the city, the city shall be entitled to recover of and from the defendants, as part of the judgment, the city's court costs and reasonable attorney's fees. The property subject to lien may be redeemed at any time prior to or within ten (10) days after the foreclosure sale by the owner paying the total amount due under the judgment of foreclosure including interest, court costs, advertising costs and reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87) 
State Law reference— Foreclosure of mortgages, F.S. Ch. 702.  
Sec. 10-27. - Service of notices and proof of service. 
(a)	All notices to property owners served pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be deemed properly served when: 
(1)	Mailed to such owner by United States certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to such owner at the last known mailing address of such owner as shown on the records in the office of the county property appraiser, with proper postage affixed; or 
(2)	Hand delivered to such owner by any code enforcement officer or police officer of the city, if such service is effected in the county; or 
(3)	Personal service upon such owner by a sheriff, deputy sheriff or other law enforcement officer authorized to serve judicial process under the law of the jurisdiction wherein service is made, if service is effected outside the county. 
(b)	All notices to the city served pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be deemed properly served when: 
(1)	Mailed to the city by United States certified mail, return receipt requested, addressed to City of Rockledge, P.0. Box 488, Rockledge, Florida, 32955, with proper postage affixed. 
(2)	Hand delivered to the city manager, city clerk or any code enforcement officer of the city. 
(3)	Personally served upon the city manager, city clerk or any code enforcement officer of the city by the sheriff or any deputy sheriff of the county, in the manner prescribed by state law for service of summons ad respondendum. 
(c)	Proof of service shall be as follows: 
(1)	For service effected pursuant to subsection (a)(1) above, by affidavit of the person mailing the notice accompanied by the return receipt for certified mail furnished by the postal department. 
(2)	For service effected pursuant to subsection (a)(2) above, by affidavit of the police officer or code enforcement officer making the service. 
(3)	For service effected pursuant to subsection (a)(3) above, by sheriff's return of service or other form of certificate permitted and recognized as an acceptable and lawful form of proof of service under the law of the jurisdiction wherein the service is made. 
(Ord. No. 832-87, § 2, 5-20-87)  
Chapter 10.5 - MOTION AND STILL PHOTOGRAPHY PRODUCTION PERMITS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1093-94, § 1, adopted Nov. 16, 1994, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as Ch. 22. In order to maintain the alphabetical sequence of chapters, said provisions have been included herein as Ch. 10.5 at the discretion of the editor. 
 
Sec. 10.5-1. - Title. 
This chapter shall be known and cited as the "Rockledge Motion and Still Photography Production Permit Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 1093-94, § 1, 11-16-94)  
Sec. 10.5-2. - Purposes. 
The purposes of this chapter are to establish a one-stop permitting process for motion picture and still photography on public property owned or controlled by or under the jurisdiction of the city, to provide a means whereby acts otherwise prohibited by this Code may be allowed during such productions, and to provide for an exemption from other City Code permit requirements in recognition of the positive economic impact of the motion picture and television industry. 
(Ord. No. 1093-94, § 1, 11-16-94)  
Sec. 10.5-3. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly requires otherwise: 
City equipment is any tangible property, other than real property, purchased by public funds and utilized in the normal course and scope of providing governmental service by the city. 
City facility is any public street, sidewalk, place or building owned or controlled by or under the jurisdiction of the city to include, but not be limited to, city park and recreation facilities and other city buildings. 
City manager is the contact for the motion picture and television division of the city and acts as liaison with the Brevard County Film Commissioner. 
Photography is the commercial taking or making of a motion picture, television, videotape, or still production utilizing city facilities. This term shall include, and a production permit shall be required for, such productions on private property not at a studio involving the erection of tents or other temporary structures or involving the use of pyrotechnics, explosives, or other incendiary devices. 
Product permit (also referred to herein as permit) is the permit required by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1093-94, § 1, 11-16-94)  
Sec. 10.5-4. - Film commissioner. 
The film commissioner, under the direction of the executive director of the Brevard County Tourist Development Council, has been authorized by county ordinance to act as the agent for the County of Brevard in the receipt and procession of applications for production permits and to coordinate same with the city for activity within the city. After review and approval by the city and final approval by the city manager, the permit will be issued by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1093-94, § 1, 11-16-94)  
Sec. 10.5-5. - Permit required; suspension and/or revocation; violation. 
(a)	No person shall advertise, engage in, participate in, and/or start any motion and still photography production on private property or on or upon any city facility or utilizing city equipment unless a production permit shall first have been obtained from the city manager. The city may adopt a reasonable fee schedule for the production permits. Violation of this section shall be punishable as provided for by law. 
(b)	Failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the production permit once issued shall be grounds for immediate suspension of the production until such time as the non-compliance is remedied. The suspension shall be initially communicated orally, followed by a written suspension order. Continued failure to comply with the terms and conditions of the production permit may result in revocation of the permit. Continuation of the production in violation of the suspension and/or revocation shall be punishable as provided for by law. 
(Ord. No. 1093-94, § 1, 11-16-94)  
Sec. 10.5-6. - Application for permit. 
(a)	Any person seeking the issuance of a production permit shall file an application with, and on forms provided by, the city manager prior to commencement of production. The application shall be signed by an authorized representative of the applicant. 
(b)	The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)	Location(s) of the production. 
(2)	Duration and type of the production. 
(3)	Proof of liability insurance coverage with the city named as an additional insured. The amount of said coverage shall be as determined by the city manager on a case by case basis. 
(4)	Special effects to be utilized, especially incendiary or explosive devices. In addition, the application shall list the person in charge (pyrotechnician) of such special effects together with his/her qualifications and licensure by the applicable federal and/or state agencies. 
(5)	Proposed utilization of city equipment. 
(6)	Necessity for closures of public streets or sidewalks and for what duration. 
(7)	A written summary or explanation of the portion of the production to be shot within unincorporated areas of the city. 
(8)	Number and type of vehicles and/or equipment and number of personnel to be on location with the production. 
(9)	An agreement to pay for extraordinary services provided by the city. 
(10)	Execute a hold harmless/indemnification agreement for the benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1093-94, § 1, 11-16-94)  
Sec. 10.5-7. - Exemption from other City Code requirements. 
(a)	Once a production permit has been issued, and notwithstanding any other provisions of the City Code to the contrary, other city permits may be required for any of the activities forming a part of the production. 
(b)	The provisions of this Code, insofar as certain acts are required or prohibited, may be suspended in connection with the conduct of a production pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1093-94, § 1, 11-16-94)  
Sec. 10.5-8. - Cost for extraordinary services. 
The city shall recover direct costs for extraordinary services rendered in connection with a production. Such costs shall include, but not be limited to, charges for personnel and/or equipment committed in support of the production which are outside the normal scope of government services. Based on the information contained in the permit application, an estimate of these costs shall be provided to the applicant prior to the issuance of the permit. The applicant agrees to pay the city in advance for any services provided by it at its usual rates. The city manager will provide coordination and advise the applicant of estimated costs. 
(Ord. No. 1093-94, § 1, 11-16-94)  
Chapter 11 - BUSINESS, OCCUPATIONS, SOLICITATION, CANVASSING AND FOR PROFIT ACTIVITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1449-07, § 2(Exh. A), adopted July 18, 2007, repealed the former Ch. 11, §§ 11-1—11-13, and enacted a new Ch. 11 as set out herein. The former Ch. 11 pertained to licenses and derived from Ord. No. 1102-95, § 1, 6-21-95; Ord. No. 1212-00, § 1, 5-17-00; Ord. No. 1309-03, § 1, 7-16-03. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 11-1. - Short title. 
Business ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1449-07, § 2(Exh. A), 7-18-07)  
Sec. 11-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to insure the public welfare by overseeing all business transactions and operations. This shall include uninvited solicitors and canvassers within the city by permitting same. Further, to levy a tax and issue receipts therefore on all businesses as allowed by state statute. 
(Ord. No. 1449-07, § 2(Exh. A), 7-18-07)  
Sec. 11-3. - Exclusions. 
This chapter does not include the taxing of: 
(1)	Religious institutions which shall mean churches, ecclesiastical or denominational organizations, or established physical places for worship in this state at which nonprofit religious services and activities are regularly conducted and carried on, and shall also mean church cemeteries. 
(2)	Educational institutions which shall mean state tax-supported or parochial, church and nonprofit private schools, colleges or universities conducting regular classes and courses of study required for accreditation by or membership in the Southern Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools, department of education or Florida Council of Independent Schools. Nonprofit libraries, art galleries and museums open to the public are defined as educational institutions and eligible for exemption. These institutions shall be permitted at no fee. 
(3)	Charitable institutions which shall mean only nonprofit corporations operating physical facilities in the city at which are provided charitable services, a reasonable percentage of which shall be without cost to those unable to pay. These institutions shall be permitted at no fee. 
(Ord. No. 1449-07, § 2(Exh. A), 7-18-07)  
Sec. 11-4. - Definitions to be used in this chapter. 
Business shall mean any activity as defined and listed by the North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) published by the U.S. Bureau Census (www.census.gov/naics). 
Business tax receipt shall mean those taxes authorized by the Local Business Tax Act, set out in F.S. ch. 205. 
Business permit shall mean the method by which the city grants the privilege of engaging in or managing any business as defined in the NAICS within its jurisdiction.
