Cross reference— Consumption of alcoholic beverages on city property, § 4-3; consumption of alcoholic beverages on streets, § 4-4. 
 
Sec. 13-1. - Adoption of state misdemeanors. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any act, within the corporate limits of the city, which is or shall be recognized by the laws of the state as a misdemeanor, and the commission of such acts is hereby forbidden. 
(Code 1964, § 16-29)  
Sec. 13-2. - Attempt to commit offense. 
Whoever attempts to commit any offense prohibited by this Code, and in such attempt does any act toward the commission of such offense, but fails in the perpetration thereof, or is intercepted or prevented in the execution of the same, shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 16-6) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 777.04.  
Sec. 13-3. - Civil emergencies. 
Pursuant to F.S. § 870.042(2), the city council hereby designates the mayor as the officer empowered to declare a state of emergency and to exercise the emergency powers conferred in F.S. §§ 870.041—870.047, inclusive. The violation of any of the provisions of said statutes or of any emergency measure established pursuant thereto shall be punished as is provided by F.S. § 870.048.  
Sec. 13-4. - Curfew for minors. 
The purpose of this section is to: (i) promote the general welfare and protect the general public through the reduction of juvenile violence and crime within the city; (ii) promote the safety and well-being of the city's youngest citizens, persons under the age of eighteen (18), whose inexperience renders them particularly vulnerable to becoming participants in unlawful activities, particularly unlawful drug activities, and to being victimized by older perpetrators of crime; and (iii) foster and strengthen parental responsibility for children. 
(a)	Definitions. As used within this section, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them below: 
1.	Curfew hours refers to the hours of 12:00 a.m. through 6:00 a.m., Monday through Friday, except in the case of a legal holiday; and the hours of 1:00 a.m. through 6:00 a.m. on Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays. Juveniles under seventeen (17) years of age who are enrolled in school shall also be subject to a curfew during school hours when their school attendance is compulsory. 
2.	Emergency refers to unforeseen circumstances, or the status or condition resulting therefrom, requiring immediate action to safeguard life, limb or property. The term includes, but is not limited to, fires, natural disasters, automobile accidents, or other similar circumstances. 
3.	Establishment refers to any privately-owned place of business within the city operated for a profit, to which the public is invited, including, but not limited to any place of amusement or entertainment. With respect to such establishment, the term "operator" shall mean any person, and any firm, association, partnership (and the members or partners thereof) and/or any corporation (and the officers thereof) conducting or managing that establishment. 
4.	Minor refers to any person under eighteen (18) years of age who has not been emancipated by court order entered pursuant to Florida Statutes. 
5.	Officer refers to a police or other law enforcement officer charged with the duty of enforcing the laws of the State of Florida and/or the ordinances of the City of Rockledge. 
6.	Parent refers to: 
a.	A person who is a minor's biological or adoptive parent and who has legal custody of a minor (including either parent, if custody is shared under a court order or agreement); 
b.	A person who is the biological or adoptive parent with whom a minor regularly resides; 
c.	A person judicially appointed as a legal guardian of the minor; and/or 
d.	A person eighteen (18) years of age or older standing in loco parentis (as indicated by the authorization of an individual listed in part(s) 1., 2., or 3. of this definition, above, for the person to assume the care or physical custody of the child, or as indicated by any other circumstances). 
7.	Person refers to an individual, not to any association, corporation, or any other legal entity. 
8.	Public place refers to any place to which the public or a substantial group of the public has access, including, but not limited to: streets, highways, roads, sidewalks, alleys, avenues, parks, and/or the common areas of schools, hospitals, apartment houses, office buildings, transportation facilities and shops. 
9.	Remain refers to the following actions: 
a.	To linger or stay at or upon a place; and/or 
b.	To fail to leave a place when requested to do so by an officer or by the owner, operator or other person in control of that place. 
10.	Temporary care facility refers to a location at which minors may be taken to be retrieved by a parent or referred to another appropriate agency. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for a minor, during curfew hours, to remain in or upon any public place within the city, to remain in any motor vehicle operating or parked therein or thereon, or to remain in or upon the premises of any establishment within the city, unless: 
1.	The minor is accompanied by a parent; 
2.	The minor is involved in an emergency; 
3.	The minor is engaged in an employment activity, or is going to or returning home from such activity, without detour or stop; 
4.	The minor is on the sidewalk directly abutting a place where he or she resides with a parent; 
5.	The minor is attending an activity sponsored by a school, religious, or civic organization, by a public organization or agency, or by another similar organization or entity, which activity is supervised by adults, and/or the minor is going to or returning from such an activity without detour or stop; 
6.	The minor is on an errand at the direction of a parent, and the minor has in his or her possession a writing signed by the parent containing the following information: the name, signature, address and telephone number of the parent authorizing the errand, the telephone number where the parent may be reached during the errand, the name of the minor, and a brief description of the errand, the minor's destination(s) and the hours the minor is authorized to be engaged in the errand; 
7.	The minor is involved in interstate travel through, or beginning or terminating in, the City of Rockledge; or 
8.	The minor is exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly. 
(c)	It shall be unlawful for a minor's parent to knowingly permit, allow or encourage such minor to violate subsection 13-4(b). 
(d)	It shall be unlawful for a person who is the owner or operator of any motor vehicle to knowingly permit, allow or encourage a violation of subsection 13-4(b). 
(e)	It shall be unlawful for the operator of any establishment, or for any person who is an employee thereof, to knowingly permit, allow or encourage a minor to remain upon the premises of the establishment during curfew hours. It shall be a defense to prosecution under this subsection that the operator or employee of an establishment promptly notified the police department that a minor was present at the establishment after curfew hours and refused to leave. 
(f)	It shall be unlawful for any person (including any minor) to give a false name, address, or telephone number to any officer investigating a possible violation of this section 13-4. 
(g)	Enforcement. 
1.	Minors. Before taking any enforcement action hereunder, an officer shall make an immediate investigation for the purpose of ascertaining whether or not the presence of a minor in a public place, motor vehicle and/or establishment within the city during curfew hours is in violation of subsection 13-4(b). 
a.	If such investigation reveals that the presence of such minor is in violation of subsection 13-4(b), then: if the minor has not previously been issued a warning for any such violation, the officer may issue a verbal warning to the minor, or, if the minor has previously been issued a warning for any such violation, the officer may charge the minor with a violation of this section. 
b.	As soon as practicable, the officer shall: 
1.	Release the minor to his or her parent(s); or 
2.	Place the minor in a temporary care facility or place the minor in his or her school of enrollment. 
2.	Others. If an investigation by an officer reveals that a person has violated subsections 13-4(c), (d) and/or (e), and if the person has not previously been issued a warning with respect to any such violation, an officer may issue a verbal warning to the person, however, if any such warning has previously been issued to that person then the officer may charge the person with a violation of this section. 
(h)	Each violation of this section 13-4 shall constitute a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1964, §§ 16-7—16-9; Ord. No. 486-78, §§ 1—3, 7-5-78; Ord. No. 1183-99, § 1, 6-16-99)  
Sec. 13-5. - Disorderly conduct. 
The following persons are hereby declared to be guilty of disorderly conduct, which shall be a violation of this Code: 
(1)	Any person who is engaged in any illegal occupation or business; proof of recent reputation for engaging in an illegal occupation or business shall be prima facie evidence of being engaged in an illegal occupation or business; 
(2)	Any prostitute; 
(3)	Any person who shall engage in any indecent or obscene conduct in any public place; 
(4)	Any vagrant; 
(5)	Any person who is found begging in a public place; 
(6)	Any person found loitering in a house of ill fame or prostitution, or place where prostitution or lewdness is practiced, encouraged or allowed; 
(7)	Any person who shall loiter in and about any police station, police headquarters building, jail, hospital, court building or any other place or public building, scene of an accident, crime or disaster, for the purpose of soliciting employment of legal services or the services of sureties upon criminal recognizances; 
(8)	Any person who shall be found jostling or roughly crowding people unnecessarily in a public place; 
(9)	Any person who shall make, aid, countenance or assist in making undue noise, riot, disturbance, breach of the peace or diversion tending to a breach of the peace, within the limits of the city; 
(10)	All persons who shall collect in bodies or crowds for unlawful purposes, or for any purpose to the annoyance or disturbance of other persons; 
(11)	Any person who is idle or dissolute and goes about begging; 
(12)	Any person who uses or exercises any juggling or other unlawful games or plays; 
(13)	Any person who is found in a house of ill fame or gaming house; 
(14)	Any person lodging in or found at any time in any outhouse, shed, barn, garage or unoccupied building or underneath a sidewalk or lodging in the open air and not giving a good account of himself; 
(15)	Any person who shall be engaged in or aid or abet in any fight, quarrel or any other disturbance in the city; 
(16)	Any person who stands, loiters or strolls about in any place in the city waiting or seeking to obtain money or other valuable things from others by trick or fraud, or to aid or assist therein; 
(17)	Any person who shall engage in any fraudulent scheme, device or trick to obtain money or other valuable thing in any place in the city or who shall aid or abet or in any manner be concerned therein; 
(18)	Any tout, roper, steerer or capper, so called, for any gambling room or house who shall ply or attempt to ply his calling in the city; 
(19)	Any person found loitering about any hotel, block, barroom, juke joint, gambling house or disorderly house, or wandering about the streets either by night or by day, without known lawful means of support or without being able to give a satisfactory account of themselves; 
(20)	Any person who is known to be a thief, burglar, pickpocket, robber or confidence man, either by his own confession or otherwise, or by having been convicted of larceny, burglary or another crime against the laws of the state or any state in the United States, who is found lounging in or prowling or loitering around any boat landing, railroad depot, banking institution, place of amusement, auction room, hotel, store, shop, thoroughfare, car, public conveyance, public gathering, public assembly, public buildings, private dwelling house, house of ill fame, gambling house, barroom or any public place who is unable to give a reasonable excuse for being so found; 
(21)	Any person who fails to heed the lawful order of a police officer or interferes with any police officer while in the execution of his lawful duties; 
(22)	Any person who insults any police officer on the streets, public roads or other places while in the performance of his lawful duties or who makes derogatory or insulting remarks either to or about any police officer, or makes any sign, motion or gesture calculated to insult or humiliate such police officer or officers; 
(23)	Any person who willfully disturbs the peace of others within the city by violent or offensive conduct or by making undue noise or by using loud, profane or obscene language; 
(24)	Any person who shall accost, approach, proposition, pick up or attempt to pick up, insult or embarrass any female, or who shall aid, countenance, abet or assist or in any manner be concerned therein; 
(25)	Any person who shall enter upon any private, public or parochial school property, school cafeteria or any public place of business or upon the premises of such public place of business, or any other public place whatsoever in the city and while therein, thereon or in the immediate vicinity thereof, shall create a disturbance or breach of the peace in any way whatsoever, including but not restricted to loud and offensive talk, the making of threats or attempting to intimidate, or any conduct which causes a disturbance or breach of the peace or threatened breach of the peace. 
(Code 1964, § 16-62) 
State Law reference— Breach of the peace and disorderly conduct, F.S. § 877.03.  
Sec. 13-6. - Public displays of fireworks. 
The chief of police and the chief of the fire department may grant permits for supervised public displays of fireworks by organizations or groups of individuals, provided that every such display shall be handled by a competent operator approved by the chief of police and the chief of the fire department, and further provided that the display shall be of such a character, and so located, discharged or fired, as in the opinion of the chief of police and the chief of the fire department shall not be hazardous to property or endanger any person. 
(Code 1964, §§ 16-17—16-19) 
State Law reference— Fireworks defined and prohibited, F.S. §§ 791.01, 791.02; exceptions for public displays under municipal regulation, F.S. § 791.02.  
Sec. 13-7. - Loitering. 
(a)	In parks. No person shall loiter in any park within the city between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(b)	In public places. No person shall loiter upon the streets, sidewalks or other public places within the city. 
(c)	In or near city hall. No person shall loiter in or near the city hall. 
(d)	Around use or possession of drugs or harmful chemical substances. No person or persons shall loiter in any place with one or more persons knowing that a narcotic or dangerous drug, or harmful chemical substance, as defined in F.S. §§ 893.02, 893.03 and 877.11, is being unlawfully used or possessed thereat. 
(Code 1964, § 16-26; Ord. No. 487-78, § 1, 7-5-78) 
State Law reference— Loitering or prowling generally, F.S. § 856.021.  
Sec. 13-8. - Impersonating officer. 
No person shall impersonate any officer of the city or in any way assert or act as an officer or official of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 16-35) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 843.08.  
Sec. 13-9. - Interfering with officers. 
No person shall interfere or conduct himself in any manner which shall interfere with or prohibit any official or employee of the city from performing his official duties. 
(Code 1964, § 16-36) 
Cross reference— Obstructing firemen, § 8-6.  
Sec. 13-10. - Peeping toms. 
Any person who trespasses on or about the property of another and spies or looks through windows, transoms or doors is hereby defined as a peeping tom. No person shall be a peeping tom. 
(Code 1964, §§ 16-38, 16-39)  
Sec. 13-11. - Police and fire department signal systems; interference with, misuse. 
No person shall deface, injure, destroy or otherwise incapacitate any telephone or other fire or police signalling apparatus, device or mechanism, or use such apparatus, device or mechanism for any purpose other than that for which it is intended. 
(Code 1964, § 16-41)  
Sec. 13-12. - Reward for information leading to arrest and conviction for certain offenses. 
(a)	The city hereby offers a reward in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person or persons of one or more of the following designated offenses: 
(1)	Theft of property owned by the city. 
(2)	Destruction of property owned by the city. 
(3)	Defacing of property owned by the city. 
(b)	Only one reward of one hundred dollars ($100.00) will be payable in connection with any one incident or occasion of theft, destruction or defacing of city property, and, if more than one person furnishes information leading to the arrest and conviction of one or more persons of the herein designated offenses occurring on the same occasion, the reward will be equally divided among the persons furnishing such information. 
(c)	Rewards authorized by this section are to be paid out of the general administrative contingency fund of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 16-65; Ord. No. 543-80, § 1, 1-2-80)  
Sec. 13-13. - Weapons safety. 
(1)	Purpose. The use and transport of weapons of all types in the proximity of persons and property manifest a present danger to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city. The increased urbanization within the city makes it necessary to regulate the use and transportation of weapons within the city. 
(2)	Exclusion. The following activities are excluded from this section: 
(a)	The regulation of firearms and ammunition has been preempted by the State of Florida pursuant to F.S. § 790.33(1). This prohibits the city from enacting any regulation affecting firearms and ammunition. If for any reason the regulation of firearms and ammunition enacted within F.S. ch. 790, ceases to be law, then the version of said chapter, in effect at that time, is hereby adopted for a period of one (1) year. 
(b)	The use of animals, such as falconry. 
(c)	Any activities authorized by the city manager, by its employees or agents, within the scope of their duties. 
(3)	Definitions. 
(a)	Prohibited activity. The launching, propelling, or otherwise causing of any projectile from the user property by the user, outside or over the property line of the user property, in or onto other property, or properties. 
(b)	Projectile. Any object which may cause physical harm or property damage when launched or propelled by any means. 
(c)	User property. The property owned by the user, and/or property which user has the owner's permission to utilize said property for the activity. 
(d)	User. The person or persons who, by any means, cause a projectile to be launched, propelled or otherwise set in motion. 
(e)	Methods causing prohibited activity. Any force set in motion which puts a projectile in motion, such as, but not limited to: 
1.	Compressed gases, such as air, carbon dioxide, etc.; 
2.	Fluids under pressure; 
3.	Chemical reactions, such as rockets; 
4.	Mechanical force, such as bows and cross bows; 
5.	Human force, such as throwing knives, rocks and javelins. 
(4)	Transportation. All projectiles must be incapable of being launched when transported onto or off of the user property. 
(5)	Violation. It is a violation of this section for a user to knowingly, willfully or negligently: 
a.	Cause a projectile to cross the user's property line onto another property, or properties. 
b.	Transport a projectile in a condition which might allow it to be set in motion either intentionally or negligently. 
c.	Cause a projectile to be activated while not on the user's property. 
(6)	Hunting. Hunting is allowed only in those areas designated by any state agency authorized to designate areas for hunting. The city manager may authorize, at his discretion, hunting needed to insure public health or safety. 
(7)	Penalty. Any person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred ($500.00) dollars. 
(8)	No defense. This section may not be used by any person as a defense or in any other fashion to defeat the applicability regarding a violation of any Federal or Florida Statutes, Brevard County or City of Rockledge Ordinances, case law or common law causes of action, for said person's intentional or negligent acts. 
(Code 1964, §§ 16-54—16-56; Ord. No. 1564-10, § 1, 11-17-10) 
State Law reference— Use of weapons by children, F.S. § 790.22.  
Sec. 13-14. - Wrecked, abandoned and derelict property. 
(a)	Definitions. As used in this section: 
(1)	Abandoned property means all tangible personal property which does not have an identifiable owner and which has been disposed of in a wrecked, inoperative, or partially dismantled condition or which has no apparent intrinsic value to the rightful owner. 
(2)	Private property means all land and improvements other than public property as herein defined. 
(3)	Public property means lands and improvements owned by the federal government, the state, the county or the city, lying within the city, and includes buildings, grounds, parks, playgrounds, streets, sidewalks, parkways, rights-of-way and other similar property. 
(4)	Enforcement officer means the police chief or any police officer of the city, or any other officer or employee of the city designated by resolution of the city council to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(5)	Inoperative motor vehicle means a motor vehicle that is not capable of operating under its own power, or a motor vehicle with one or more flat tires, or a motor vehicle off the ground resting on blocks or other supports, or a motor vehicle not having properly displayed thereon a valid and current motor vehicle license plate. 
(b)	Nuisances declared. Abandoned property in all yards, open areas and vacant lots in violation of this section is hereby declared to be a nuisance detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare, and such nuisances shall be abated as herein provided. 
(c)	Prohibited on public property; procedure. No person or party shall discard, abandon, store, place, keep or maintain any abandoned property on public property within the city. 
(d)	Prohibited on private property; procedure. No person or party shall discard, abandon, store, place, keep or maintain any abandoned property in or upon any yard, vacant lot or open area of private property or in any open garage or carport on private property within the city. 
(1)	Whenever the enforcement officer shall ascertain that an article or articles of abandoned property are present in or upon any yard, vacant lot or open area of private property or in any open garage or carport on private property within the limits of the city in violation of this section or any zoning ordinance or regulation, antilitter ordinance or regulation, or other ordinance or regulation of the city, the enforcement officer shall cause a notice to be placed upon such article in substantially the following form: 
NOTICE TO THE OWNER AND ALL PERSONS INTERESTED IN THE ATTACHED PROPERTY. This property, to wit: (setting forth brief description) located at (setting forth brief description of location) is improperly stored and is in violation of (setting forth ordinance or regulation violated) and must be removed within ten (10) days from date of this notice, otherwise it shall be presumed to be abandoned property and will be removed and destroyed by order of the City Council of Rockledge, Florida. Dated this: (setting forth date of posting of notice). Signed: (setting forth name, title address and telephone number of enforcement officer). 
Such notice shall not be less than eight (8) inches by ten (10) inches and shall be sufficiently weatherproof to withstand normal exposure to the elements for a period of ten (10) days. In addition to posting, the enforcement officer shall mail a copy of the notice to the owner of the real property upon which the abandoned articles are located as shown by the real estate tax records used by the city on or before the date of posting of such notice. 
(2)	If at the end of ten (10) days after posting such notice the owner or any person interested in the abandoned article or articles described in such notice has not removed the article or articles and complied with the ordinance or regulation cited in the notice, the enforcement officer may cause the article or articles of abandoned property to be removed and destroyed, and the salvage value, if any, of such article or articles shall be retained by the city to be applied against the cost of removal and destruction thereof. 
(e)	Obstructing enforcement. It shall be unlawful to oppose, obstruct or resist any enforcement officer or any person authorized by the enforcement officer in the discharge of his duties as provided by this section. 
(f)	Immunity from prosecution for trespass. Any enforcement officer or any person authorized by the enforcement officer shall be immune from prosecution, civil or criminal, for reasonable good faith trespass upon real property while in the discharge of duties imposed by this section. 
(Code 1964, § 16-61; Ord. No. 729-85 § 1, 2-20-85; Ord. No. 953-90, § 2, 3-21-90) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 10-16 et seq.; parking inoperable motor vehicle on public street, § 21-32. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 765.16.  
Sec. 13-15. - Keeping or storing wrecked or dismantled motor vehicles. 
(a)	No person shall for any purpose keep, retain, store or place at any one time more than one motor vehicle which has been wrecked or dismantled or is in an inoperable condition upon any lot, parcel or tract of land in the city, except within an enclosed covered building; nor shall any person repair, rebuild, dismantle or tear down more than one motor vehicle at any one time upon any lot, parcel or tract of land in the city, except within an enclosed covered building; provided, however, that the one wrecked, dismantled or inoperable motor vehicle that is not required to be kept in an enclosed covered building under the foregoing provisions shall not be allowed to remain on the property outside of an enclosed covered building for a period exceeding seven (7) days. 
(b)	In areas zoned to permit storage, repair or maintenance of wrecked, dismantled or inoperable motor vehicles, such motor vehicles may be stored, placed, repaired and kept within an enclosure having opaque walls, or within a nontranslucent and nontransparent fence enclosure, the walls or sides of such enclosure to be of sufficient height to completely prevent all motor vehicles therein from being seen or viewed from abutting private properties or from any public property. The gate or entranceway into the enclosure must also be opaque, nontranslucent or nontransparent. 
(Code 1964, § 16-24; Ord. No. 730-85, § 1, 2-20-85) 
Cross reference— Nuisances, § 10-16 et seq.; use of streets for storage or sale of vehicles, § 18-4; parking inoperable motor vehicle on public street, § 21-32.  
Sec. 13-16. - Disposition of lost or abandoned property, unclaimed evidence. 
It appears that the state legislature through enactment of state statutes has intended to pre-empt unto itself power to legislate on the subject of disposition of lost or abandoned property found on public property, as well as the procedure for disposition of unclaimed evidence in criminal proceedings; therefore, all such state statutes applicable and pertaining to lost or abandoned property found on public property, and pertaining to disposition of unclaimed evidence in criminal proceedings, as amended from time to time, are hereby incorporated by reference as part of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 953-90, § 3, 3-21-90)  
Chapter 14 - PARKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Animals prohibited in parks, § 5-18; mooring boats at city property, § 6-5; loitering, § 13-7. 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Purpose. 
The city council finds that in order to preserve the public peace and good order, and to safeguard the health, safety and welfare of the community and the citizens thereof, it is necessary to regulate and restrict the conduct of individuals utilizing parks, playgrounds and places of public recreation within the city, and to confer upon law enforcement officers of the city lawful authority to enforce the rules and regulations applicable to the use of parks, playgrounds and places of public recreation within the city. 
(Ord. No. 768-85, § 1, 10-2-85)  
Sec. 14-2. - Authority of city police in county parks. 
The board of county commissioners operates within the city several parks, playgrounds, athletic facilities, swimming pools, and other places of public recreation, including McLarty Park, Rockledge Park and Taylor Park, and by resolution dated April 23, 1981, the board of county commissioners authorized the municipal police department of the city to make arrests for certain park violations denominated as misdemeanors by county ordinance, and to expel and eject from county parks violators of rules adopted by resolution of said board of county commissioners. 
(Ord. No. 768-85, § 1, 10-2-85)  
Sec. 14-3. - Facilities regulated. 
The regulations set forth in section 14-4 of this Code shall apply to all parks, recreational facilities and stormwater facilities within the city. 
(Ord. No. 768-85, § 1, 10-2-85; Ord. No. 1544-2010, § 1, 3-17-10 )  
Sec. 14-4. - Rules and regulations. 
No person utilizing any park or recreational facility specified in section 14-3 of this Code shall violate any of the following rules, regulations or prohibitions: 
(1)	It shall be unlawful for any person of any age to loiter, walk, stand, sit or lie in any of the above-described parks in the city after park hours, unless authorized by permit issued by the county district 4 recreation and parks department. Park hours for all above-described parks shall be from 7:00 a.m. until sunset. 
(2)	It shall be unlawful for any person to sell any alcoholic beverages in any of the above-described parks in the city. 
(3)	It shall be unlawful for any person to possess or consume any alcoholic beverages in any park grounds, parking lots, playgrounds, athletic facilities, or swimming pools located at any of the above-described parks in the city; provided, however, that beer only may be possessed and consumed in certain picnic areas, pavilions and campsites designated for said consumption, where a permit for said consumption has been issued by the county district 4 recreation and parks department. 
(4)	It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in any of the above-described parks in the city, except in designated roadways and parking areas. No person shall enter or exit any park by motor vehicle, except by such entrances and exits specifically designated and established for such purposes. 
(5)	It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle within the confines of the above-described parks in the city in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(6)	It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, keep or offer for sale any tangible or intangible object, thing or merchandise, or solicit for any trade, occupation, business or profession for any consideration within the confines of the above-described parks in the city without first obtaining a permit for such activity from the county district 4 recreation and parks department. 
(7)	It shall be unlawful for any person to cause any open fires, or other fires not in designated cooking grills and stoves, in any of the above-described parks in the city. 
(8)	It shall be unlawful for any person to use any loudspeaker, or other sound-amplifying equipment, within the confines of any of the above-described parks in the city without first obtaining a permit for such activity from the county district 4 recreation and parks department. 
(9)	It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, or participate in, any public meetings, assemblies, entertainments, tournaments, religious gatherings, demonstrations, parades or processions on any subject within the confines of any of the above-described parks in the city without first obtaining a permit for such activity from the county district 4 recreation and parks department. 
(10)	It shall be unlawful for any person to post any sign within the confines of any of the above-described parks in the city without first obtaining a permit for such activity from the county district 4 recreation and parks department. 
(11)	It shall be unlawful for any person to fail or refuse to leave the confines of any of the above-described parks in the city after being directed to so leave by supervisory personnel of the county district 4 recreation and parks department for violations of this section or other applicable posted park rules and regulations. 
(12)	The use of gill, cast or entangling nets of any size for the purpose of taking or harvesting fish is prohibited at all city parks, recreational facilities and stormwater facilities, including drainage canals. Such activities shall be unlawful. 
(13)	No person may launch or operate any motorboat, airboat, or personal watercraft, powered by internal combustion engine. Model boats, no larger than 48", are excluded from the internal combustion motor regulation found in this section. However electric trolling motors under five (5) horsepower in size shall be allowed. All launching area sites shall be as approved by city council. 
(Ord. No. 768-85, § 1, 10-2-85; Ord. No. 1544-2010, § 2, 3-17-10 )  
Sec. 14-5. - Penalties. 
Any person violating any rule, regulation, prohibition or provision of section 14-4 of this Code shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be prosecuted and upon conviction be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment in the county jail for a term not exceeding sixty (60) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 768-85, § 1, 10-2-85)  
Chapter 16 - PLANNING[1] 
Footnotes:

Charter reference— Roads and pavements, special assessments, Subpt. A, Art. VIII; local improvements and special assessments, Subpt. B, Art. 2; zoning, Subpt. B, Art. 3.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 16-1—16-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITIZENS ADVISORY COMMITTEE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Administration, Ch. 2. 
 
Sec. 16-11. - Creation; membership. 
There is hereby created and established a citizens advisory committee, hereby designated as the Rockledge Citizens Advisory Committee, consisting of seven (7) members who shall be appointed by the city council, each for a term of one year. 
At its first regular meeting in October of each year the city council shall appoint seven (7) members to constitute the citizens advisory committee. Members may be appointed to succeed themselves. The city council may, in its discretion, appoint one or more nonvoting ex officio members of the committee. Each member of the committee at the time of his appointment must have been a resident of the city for at least one year. Vacancies in membership shall be filled by appointment by the city council as soon as practicable after the vacancy occurs. Any member of the committee who shall fail to attend three (3) regular meetings of the committee shall be deemed to have vacated his office unless excused by the committee. 
No member of the committee shall be a relative (blood, marriage or adoption) or persons residing in the same household may simultaneously serve on the committee at any time. This shall not preclude those individuals from serving on other boards or committee. 
(Code 1964, § 2-46; Ord. No. 1242-2001, § 1, 2-7-01)  
Sec. 16-12. - Organization and officers. 
As soon as practicable after their appointment each year, the members of the citizens advisory committee shall elect a chairman, vice-chairman and secretary from its members. The term of such officers shall be for a period of one year to run concurrently with the term of such member's appointment to the committee; provided, that nothing shall prevent the committee from naming a chairman, vice-chairman or secretary to succeed himself. 
(Code 1964, § 2-47)  
Sec. 16-13. - Bylaws. 
The committee shall adopt bylaws setting forth its organization and government. Only those bylaws or amendments thereto approved by the city council by appropriate resolution shall become effective. 
(Code 1964, § 2-48)  
Sec. 16-14. - Meetings; quorum, vote required; records. 
The citizens advisory committee shall hold meetings at such times and places as may be prescribed in the bylaws of the committee or as may be called by the chairman or vice-chairman of the committee. All regular and special meetings of the committee shall be open to the public. The time and place of meetings and the order of business and procedure to be followed at meetings shall be prescribed by the committee. Four (4) members of the committee shall constitute a quorum and a majority vote of the members present at a meeting with a quorum shall be required to decide any issue. A written record of the proceedings of the committee shall be kept, showing its action on each question considered. Copies of such record shall be promptly filed with the chairman of the planning commission and with the city clerk and shall be open to public inspection. 
(Code 1964, § 2-49)  
Sec. 16-15. - Goals and objectives. 
The goals and objectives of the citizens advisory committee are to encourage, promote, solicit and obtain active citizen participation in the preparation of comprehensive plan elements and other studies and projects being carried on by the planning commission from time to time. 
(Code 1964, § 2-50)  
Sec. 16-16. - Functions and duties. 
The functions and duties of the citizens advisory committee shall be, in general, to: 
(a)	Hold meetings for public participation in planning programs. 
(b)	Employ various methods of soliciting public interest in planning programs. 
(c)	Monitor the progress of planning programs. 
(d)	Conduct specified operations of planning programs. 
(e)	Report all activities to the planning commission. 
(f)	Conduct business meetings for the purpose of making decisions and developing recommendations. 
(g)	Submit written recommendations to the planning commission as it deems necessary or as requested. 
(h)	Prepare written reports or documents as requested by the planning commission. 
(i)	Perform other functions and duties at the direction of the planning commission. 
(Code 1964, § 2-51)  
Sec. 16-17. - Removal of members. 
Any members of the committee may be removed for cause by the city council. Further, any member who has three (3) consecutive unexcused absences, which are those not approved by the committee chairman prior to the meeting involved, or a total of four (4) absences during any twelve-month period, excused or unexcused, shall automatically be terminated and removed as a member of the committee. The city council shall appoint a replacement for any removed member at its next regularly scheduled meeting in the same manner as other appointment of members for the remainder of such term. 
(Ord. No. 1343-04, § 1, 3-24-04)  
ARTICLE III. - ROCKLEDGE COMMUNITY REDEVELOPMENT AGENCY 
 
Sec. 16-18. - Rockledge Community Redevelopment Agency. 
(1)	Governing body: 
(a)	Name: The governing body for the Rockledge Community Redevelopment Agency shall be known as the Rockledge Community Redevelopment Agency Board of Commissioners. 
(b)	Number of commissioners: The board of commissioners shall consist of seven (7) commissioners, none of whom shall be members of the Rockledge City Council. 
(c)	Initial terms: The initial commissioners shall be appointed to terms as follows: 
1.	One (1) member shall be appointed for a term of (1) year. 
2.	One (1) member shall be appointed for a term of two (2) years. 
3.	One (1) member shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years. 
4.	Four (4) members shall be appointed for a term of four (4) years. 
These initial appointees shall serve from the date of appointment until the second city council meeting in April after the passage of the appropriate number of years. 
(d)	Term: Other than the initial appointments per subsection 16-18(1)(c), all subsequent terms of office of the commissioners shall be for four (4) years after the initial appointments. All necessary appointments shall be made at the second city council meeting in April. 
(e)	The city council, by majority vote, shall appoint the individual commissioners. 
(f)	A commissioner shall receive no compensation for services, but is entitled to necessary expenses, including travel expenses incurred in discharge of duties. 
(g)	Each commissioner shall hold office until his or her successor has been appointed and has been qualified. 
(h)	The city council shall designate an initial chair and vice chair from among the commission members. 
(i)	The commission shall nominate a chair and vice chair from its membership at the first meeting in each new year. Said nominations shall be referred to and subject to approval by the city council. 
(j)	A person may be appointed as a commissioner if he or she resides in or is engaged in a business within the city. 
(k)	The city council may remove a commissioner for inefficiency, neglect of duty, or misconduct in office after a hearing and after the commissioner has been given a copy of the charges at least ten (10) days prior to such hearing and has had an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel. 
(l)	Absences: Following appointment, any member who has three (3) consecutive unexcused absences (those not approved by the chair prior to the meeting involved) or a total of four (4) absences during any 12-month period (excused or unexcused) shall automatically be terminated and removed as a member of the commission. 
(Ord. No. 1355-04, § 1, 9-22-04; Ord. No. 1542-10, § 1, 2-17-10; Ord. No. 1542-2010, § 1, 2-17-10 )  
Sec. 16-19. - Powers. 
The Rockledge Community Redevelopment Agency is vested with the following powers pursuant to F.S. § 163.370. 
(1)	To make and execute contracts and other instruments necessary or convenient to the exercise of its powers under this division. 
(2)	To disseminate redevelopment information. 
(3)	To undertake and carry out community redevelopment projects and related activities within its area of operation, such projects to include: 
a.	Acquisition of a slum area or a blighted area of any portions thereof. 
b.	Demolition and removal of building and improvements. 
c.	Installation, construction or reconstruction of streets, utilities, parks, playgrounds, and other improvements necessary for carrying out the community redevelopment plan. 
d.	Disposition of any property acquired in the community redevelopment area at its fair value for uses in accordance with the community redevelopment plan. 
e.	Carrying out plans for a program of voluntary or compulsory repair and rehabilitation of buildings or other improvements in accordance with the community redevelopment plan. 
f.	Acquisition of real property in the community redevelopment project area which, under the community redevelopment plan, is to be repaired or rehabilitated for dwelling use or related facilities, repair or rehabilitation of the structures for guidance purposes, and resale of the property. 
g.	Acquisition of any other real property in the community redevelopment area when necessary to eliminate unhealthful, unsanitary or unsafe conditions, lessen density, eliminate obsolete or other uses detrimental to the public welfare, or otherwise, to remove or prevent the spread of blight or deterioration or to provide land for needed public facilities. 
h.	Acquisitions, without regard to any requirement that the area be a slum or blighted area, of air rights in an area consisting principally of land in highways, railway tracks, bridge entrances or other similar facilities which have a blighting influence on the surrounding area and over which air rights sites are to be developed for elimination of such blighting influences and for the provision of housing (and related facilities and uses) designed specifically for, and limited to, families and individuals of low or moderate income. 
i.	Construction of foundations and platforms necessary for the provision of air rights, sites of housing (and related facilities and uses) designed specifically for, and limited to, families and individuals of low or moderate income. 
(4)	To provide, or to arrange or contract for, the furnishings or repair by any person or agency, public or private, of services, privileges, works, streets, roads, public utilities or other facilities or in connection with a community redevelopment project; and to agree to any conditions that it may deem reasonable and appropriate attached to federal financial assistance and imposed pursuant to federal law relating to the determination of prevailing salaries or wages or compliance with labor standards, in the undertaking or carrying out of a community redevelopment project and related activities, and to include in any contract let in connection with such a project and related activities, provisions to fulfill such of said conditions as it may deem reasonable and appropriate. 
(5)	Within the community redevelopment area: 
a.	To acquire by purchase, lease, option, gift, grant, bequest, devise, eminent domain, or otherwise, any real property (or other personal property) for its administrative purposes together with any improvements thereon. 
b.	To hold, improve, clear, or prepare for redevelopment any such property; 
c.	To mortgage, pledge, hypothecate, or otherwise encumber, or to dispose of any real property; 
d.	To insure or provide for the insurance of any real or personal property or operations of the county or municipality against any risks or hazards, including the power to pay premiums on any such insurance; 
e.	To enter into any contracts necessary to effectuate the purpose of this division. 
(6)	To invest any community redevelopment funds held in reserves or sinking funds or any such funds not required for immediate disbursement in property or securities in which savings banks may legally invest funds subject to their control; to redeem revenue bonds issued pursuant to this part at the redemption price established therein or purchase such bonds at less than redemption price, all such bonds so redeemed or purchased to be canceled. 
(7)	To borrow money and to apply for and accept advances, loans, grants, contributions, and any other form of financial assistance from the federal government, the state, county, or other public body, or from any sources, public or private, for the purposes of this division and to give such security as may be required and to enter into and carry out contracts or agreements in connection therewith; and to include in any contract for financial assistance with the federal government for or with respect to a community redevelopment project and related activities such conditions imposed pursuant to federal laws as the county or municipality may deem reasonable and appropriate and which are not inconsistent with the purposes of this division. 
(8)	Within its area of operation, to make or have made all surveys and plans necessary to the carrying out of the purposes of this part and with the consent of the City Council to contract with any persons, public or private, in making and carrying out such plans, which plans may include, but not be limited to: 
a.	Plans for carrying out a program of voluntary or compulsory repair and rehabilitation of buildings and improvements; 
b.	Appraisals, title searches, surveys, studies, and other plans and work necessary to prepare for the undertaking of community redevelopment projects and related activities; 
c.	Plans for the enforcement of state and local laws, codes and regulations relating to the use of land and the use and occupancy of buildings and improvements and to the compulsory repair, rehabilitation, demolition, or removal of buildings, and improvements. 
(9)	To develop, test, and report methods and techniques, and carry out demonstrations and other activities, for the prevention and the elimination of slums and urban blight and developing and demonstrating new or improved means providing housing for families and persons of low income. 
(10)	To apply for, accept, and utilize grants of funds from federal government for such purposes. 
(11)	To prepare plans for and assist in the relocation of persons (including individuals, families, business concerns, nonprofit organizations and others) displaced from a community redevelopment area, and to make relocation payments to or with respect to such persons for moving expenses and losses of property for which reimbursement or compensation is not otherwise made, including the making of such payments financed by the federal government. 
(12)	To appropriate such funds and make such expenditures as may be necessary to carry out the purposes of this division. 
(13)	To close, vacate, plat or replat streets, roads, sidewalks, or other places. 
(14)	Within its area of operation to organize, coordinate, and direct the administration of the provisions of this division, as they may apply to the city in order that the objective of remedying slum and blighted areas and preventing the causes thereof within the city, and to establish such offices in order to carry out such purposes most effectively. 
(Ord. No. 1355-04, § 1, 9-22-04)  
Chapter 17 - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 17-1—17-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SERVICE CHARGES 
 
Sec. 17-11. - Free service prohibited. 
No sewage disposal service shall be furnished or rendered free of charge to any person whatsoever, and the city and each agency, department or instrumentality thereof which uses the sewage disposal service shall pay for such service at the rates fixed by this chapter. 
(Code 1964, § 21-25)  
Sec. 17-12. - Charges established. 
The owner or occupant of each residence or other building or structure which is now or hereafter connected to any sanitary sewage main in the city, hereinafter referred to as "customer" or "user," shall pay the city a monthly sewage disposal service charge for the use and availability of the city sewer and wastewater treatment system as set out in this chapter; and, in addition thereto, shall pay the city a monthly gallonage charge based upon the amount of Cocoa city water consumed at such residence, building or structure, as determined by the meter readings of the water meter installed at the premises, except as herein specified. The rate for each customer or user shall be computed in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(a)	Basic monthly sewer service charge. Each customer connected to the Rockledge sewer system and to whom a monthly water bill shall be rendered for water furnished by the City of Cocoa shall pay the City of Rockledge a basic monthly sewer service charge in an amount determined by the size of the water service meter at the premises, as follows: 
Meter Size (inches) 	Basic Monthly Sewer Service Charge 
¾ 	$14.00 
1 	25.00 
1½ 	47.00 
2 	73.40 
3 	179.00 
4 	278.00 
6 	443.00 
8 or larger 	$707.00 minimum, plus any additional charge determined by the city council to be just and equitable depending on the customer's demand upon the sewer system. 
 
Every condominium association or corporation, cooperative apartment corporation, owner, landlord, tenant or other party responsible to pay for sewer service to a condominium, cooperative apartment, rental apartment, trailer park other than travel trailer park, duplex, triplex, or other residential premises, except a motel, connected to the City of Cocoa water system and not having individual water meters for each living unit shall pay a monthly base sewer service charge of fourteen dollars ($14.00) for each living unit on the premises. The accumulated total of service charges per unit at the three-fourths-inch service meter rate shall, however, be not less than the listed service charge for the service meter actually installed in the single water service line, in which case the larger of the two (2) charges will be applied to the customer's water bill. 
Of the base sewer service charge four dollars ($4.00) per month per customer shall be applied as the renewal and replacement fee herein established for the purpose of providing funding for the upgrading and maintenance of the sewer system. These monies will be deposited into a separate account for the purpose hereinabove stated, and shall not be expended for any purpose other than the renewal or replacement of the sewer system or its related equipment. 
The rates in subsection (a) above shall be effective on all bills for services rendered after October 1, 2014. 
(b)	Gallonage charge. In addition to the monthly base sewer service charge stated above, each customer connected to the city's sewer system and to whom a monthly bill shall be rendered for water furnished by the City of Cocoa Water System serving inhabitants of the City of Rockledge shall pay the City of Rockledge for sewer service a quantity consumption charge based upon the number of gallons of water passing through such customer's water meter during the monthly billing period, at the rates set out below: 
For the period October 1, 2016 to September 30, 2017: 
0—5,000 gallons 	$3.60 per thousand gallons or any part thereof; 
5,000—15,000 gallons: 	$3.75 per thousand gallons or any part thereof; 
15,000—76,000 gallons 	$4.25 per thousand gallons or any part thereof; 
More than 76,000 gallons 	$5.00 per thousand gallons or any part thereof. 
For the period on or after October 1, 2017: 
0—5,000 gallons 	$3.75 per thousand gallons or any part thereof; 
5,000—15,000 gallons 	$3.90 per thousand gallons or any part thereof; 
15,000—76,000 gallons 	$4.40 per thousand gallons or any part thereof; 
More than 76,000 gallons 	$5.15 per thousand gallons or any part thereof. 
 
The rates in subsection (b) above shall be effective on all bills for services rendered after October 1, 2016. 
(c)	Cap on monthly sewer charges for individually metered single-family dwelling units with a three-quarter-inch water meter. The monthly charges established in subsections (a) and (b) above shall not exceed those accrued at a consumption level of fifteen thousand (15,000) gallons for any individually metered single-family dwelling unit with a three-quarter-inch water meter, regardless of the number of gallons of water consumed at the dwelling unit during the monthly billing period. 
(d)	Sewer only customers. Every owner, landlord, tenant, or other party responsible to pay for sewer service to residential or commercial customers not connected to Cocoa city water shall pay a monthly charge for the sewer service at the premises based upon the bathroom facilities, to-wit: 
Bathroom Facilities 	Monthly Sewer Service Charge 
1 Bathroom 	$25.00 (minimum) 
1½ Bathrooms 	28.25 
2 Bathrooms 	31.30 
For Each Additional Bathroom 	3.40 
 
The rates above shall be effective on all bills for services rendered after September 30, 2005. 
(e)	Sewer deposit required. Each customer opening a new or transferred account with the City of Cocoa for water service to premises that are connected to the City of Rockledge Sewer System, and for which a monthly water bill shall be rendered for water furnished by the City of Cocoa, and the owner or occupant of any premises having a private water supply, which premises hereafter become connected to the Rockledge Sewer System, shall pay a sewer service deposit based on the size of the service meter or water line from the private water source serving the facility, in accordance with the following schedule: 
Meter Size 
 (inches) 	Fee 
 ¾ 	$   40.00 
 1 	    80.00 
 1½ 	   160.00 
 2 	   256.00 
 3 	   640.00 
 4 	  1,000.00 
 6 	  1,600.00 
 8 or larger 	2,560.00 (minimum) 
 
This deposit shall be paid prior to the commencement of water or sewer service to the premises, and shall be held by the city until such time as the account is terminated. If at that time the sewer account and garbage collection charges due the city have been paid in full, the deposit will be refunded; however, if there is an outstanding balance due the city, either for sewer service or garbage collection, the deposit shall be applied sufficiently to cover same, and any remaining sum due the city shall be paid by the customer. Further, there shall be required of the customer proof that the water account has been closed. 
(Code 1964, § 21-26; Ord. No. 520-79, § 1, 6-20-79; Ord. No. 637-83, § 1, 1-5-83; Ord. No. 683-84, § 1, 3-21-84; Ord. No. 809-86, § 1, 9-17-86; Ord. No. 896-88, § 1, 12-7-88; Ord. No. 902-89, §§ 2, 3, 2-8-89; Ord. No. 903-89, §§ 2, 3, 3-1-89; Ord. No. 950-90, §§ 1, 2, 3-7-90; Ord. No. 1090-94, § 1, 9-21-94; Ord. No. 1112-95, § 1, 9-20-95; Ord. No. 1128-96, § 1, 9-18-96; Ord. No. 1160-98, §§ 1, 2, 7-1-98; Ord. No. 1187-99, §§ 1, 2, 7-21-99; Ord. No. 1280-02, §§ 1, 2, 8-21-02; Ord. No. 1324-03, §§ 1, 2, 9-17-03; Ord. No. 1390-05, §§ 1—3, 10-5-05; Ord. No. 1425-06, § 1, 9-20-06; Ord. No. 1497-08, § 1, 9-3-08; Ord. No. 1524-09, §§ 1, 2, 9-9-09; Ord. No. 1595-2012, §§ 1—3, 8-15-12 ; Ord. No. 1629-2013, §§ 1, 2, 9-4-13 ; Ord. No. 1651-2014 , §§ 1—3, 9-3-14; Ord. No. 1673-2015 , § 1, 9-9-15; Ord. No. 1691-2016 , § 1, 9-7-16)  
Sec. 17-13. - Surcharge to consumers outside city limits. 
In addition to the basic monthly rates, fees and charges for city sewer service established by the provisions of section 17-12 above, a surcharge of twenty-five (25) percent of such basic monthly rates, fees and charges shall be charged and collected by the city for sewer service provided to any premises located outside the municipal boundaries of the city. As to each premises located outside the city limits being provided with city sewer service, the basic monthly charge for sewer service shall first be determined in accordance with the provisions of section 17-12, and the surcharge of twenty-five (25) percent of such basic monthly charge shall then be computed and added to said basic monthly charge, and the sum of said basic monthly charge and surcharge shall be the total monthly charge for city sewer service provided to each premises located outside the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 551-80, § 2, 4-2-80)  
Sec. 17-14. - Charges for larger users of service. 
(a)	The city reserves the right to enter into contracts with large users of sewer service for the purpose of setting and determining a monthly charge or rate for the use of such sewer system, computed upon a basis different from that set forth in section 17-12. 
(b)	Such contracts may be entered into by means of resolution duly adopted by the city council. 
(Code 1964, § 21-27)  
Sec. 17-15. - Payment; collection of delinquent charges. 
(a)	Bills for monthly sewage disposal charges shall be submitted and shall be paid monthly, along with the monthly water fees and charges where city water is furnished. 
(b)	Any person who shall be delinquent in the payment of sewer service charges for a period of more than thirty (30) days after they shall become due and payable shall be liable to the city for a penalty assessment in the amount of ten (10) percent per month upon the amount which is past due and delinquent, the penalty to be computed from and after the thirtieth day after the charge shall become due. 
(c)	Such penalty shall be charged to the delinquent customer upon the bills for succeeding months, and, in the event the delinquent charge or charges, plus the penalties added thereto, shall not be paid, the same shall be placed in the hands of the city attorney for collection, and the customer shall then be liable for the payment of all costs of collection, including court costs and reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Code 1964, § 21-28)  
Sec. 17-16. - Collection where owner has private water supply. 
Where sewage service fees are not paid in accordance with the provisions of this chapter and where the owner has his own private water supply, the city shall cut off such water supply to the plumbing system, and the owner shall not reconnect his own private water supply until the sewage disposal fees shall have been paid in full. 
(Code 1964, § 21-29)  
Sec. 17-17. - Exemption where owner does not use city's sewer system. 
There shall be no sewer charges levied on the water meter of an ice skating rink in the City of Rockledge where the water usage does not enter the city's sewer system but instead discharges into a retention pond or into the ground. Provided however, that when the reuse system is reasonably and economically available to an ice skating rink within the city it shall connect to the city's reuse system. 
(Ord. No. 1145-97, § 1, 9-3-97)  
Sec. 17-18. - Adjustment of sewer charges based upon extraordinary use. 
The owner or occupant of property may request in writing that the City of Rockledge adjust their sewer charges due to an extraordinary use of water during a specific month's billing cycle. The procedures for obtaining an adjustment are: 
(a)	Residential: Upon receipt of a request for adjustment of sewer charges to a bill for residential property, the city shall: 
(1)	Calculate the average of the last six (6) months sewer charges for the property; 
(2)	Adjust the sewer charges for the property by one-half (½) of the difference between the billed sewer charges and the six (6) month average for the property. 
(3)	The adjustment shall not exceed five thousand (5,000) gallons. 
(4)	This procedure for adjustment of sewer charges may be utilized only once every twelve (12) months. 
(5)	This provision does not include sewer charges that are the result of filling a swimming pool, and does not affect water charges which are the purview of the water utility. 
(b)	Commercial: Upon receipt of a request for adjustment of sewer charges for commercial property, the city shall: 
(1)	Perform the steps set out in subsections (a)(1)—(2) of this section. 
(2)	The adjustment in gallons is unlimited for commercial properties. 
(3)	Subsections (a)(4) and (5) of this section are applicable to commercial properties. 
( Ord. No. 1620-2013, § 1, 5-1-13 )  
Secs. 17-19—17-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - RECLAIMED WATER REUSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 1409-06, § 2(Exh. A), adopted May 3, 2006, repealed the former Art. III, §§ 17-25—17-56, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. The former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1046-93, § 1, 2-3-93; Ord. No. 1084-94, § 1, 8-3-94; Ord. No. 1115-95, § 1, 11-14-95. 
 
Sec. 17-25. - Authority and intent. 
It is the intent of the City of Rockledge, herein referred to as the "city", to make reclaimed water available for irrigation purposes and other authorized uses in certain areas of the city where the city determines that the construction of a reclaimed water distribution system is feasible and economical. The reclaimed water distribution system shall be constructed in sections to provide service to designated areas as determined by the city, pursuant to the terms and conditions set forth herein. It is further the intent of the city to establish a reclaimed water system for irrigation which complies with the rules and regulations set forth by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, which rules appear in Chapter 62-610, Florida Administrative Code or latest version thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-26. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this chapter, the definitions contained in this section shall apply unless otherwise specifically stated. 
Available shall mean that a functioning reclaimed water distribution main is located within one hundred (100) feet of the property to be serviced. 
Backflow prevention device shall mean a device installed at the customer's potable water meter to prevent the flow of any contaminated fluids into the public water system. 
City shall mean the City of Rockledge, Florida. 
Council shall mean the City Council of Rockledge, Florida. 
County shall mean Brevard County, Florida. 
Cross-connection shall mean any physical arrangement whereby a public water supply is connected, directly or indirectly, with any other water supply system, sewer, drain, conduit, pool, storage reservoir, plumbing fixture, or other device which contains or may contain contaminated water, sewage or other waste, or liquid of unknown or unsafe quality which may be capable of imparting contamination to the public water supply as the result of backflow. Bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or changeable devices, and other temporary or permanent devices through which or because of which backflow could occur are considered to be cross-connections. 
Customer shall mean the owner(s) of the property being served, who may also be referred to as the "user." 
Delivery points shall mean the points of connection of the city's reclaimed water system to the user's irrigation system. 
Department shall mean the City of Rockledge Wastewater Treatment and Water Reclamation Department. 
Director shall mean the director of the city wastewater treatment and water reclamation department or his/her designated representative(s). 
Distribution mains shall mean those conduits used to supply reclaimed water to service lines from the pumping station or treatment plant. 
FDEP shall mean the Florida Department of Environmental Protection. 
Irrigation system shall mean an underground system with permanently placed sprinkler devices. Below-ground hose bibs contained in a locked valve box will be permitted in conjunction with an underground sprinkler system for specific purpose. Request for lock box must be made in writing to the wastewater treatment and water reclamation director. Lock box and apparatus must be purchased from the wastewater treatment and water reclamation department, and installed in accordance with the department's reclaimed water regulations. Aboveground hose bibs (faucets) with hoses and sprinklers shall not constitute an irrigation system. Irrigation systems also include agricultural ditch and swale type systems and other conventional agricultural systems where applicable and as authorized by the director. 
Reclaimed water shall mean wastewater that has received at least advanced secondary treatment, in accordance with Chapter 62-610, Florida Administrative Code, or latest version thereof, and is reusable after flowing out of a wastewater treatment facility and shall hereinafter be referred to as "reclaimed water." 
Reuse shall mean the deliberate application of reclaimed water, in compliance with Florida Department of Environmental Protection rules, for a beneficial purpose. 
Service line shall mean that conduit for reclaimed water from the distribution main to the property line. 
Setback distances shall mean the setback distances between the wetted site area subject to land application of reclaimed water, and surface waters and potable water supply wells, as required by the provisions of Chapter 62-610.471, Florida Administrative Code, or latest version thereof, and in no instance shall the setback distance be less than seventy-five (75) feet. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-27. - Connection to system. 
(a)	Generally. Customers in designated service areas may connect to the reclaimed water system when service is available and upon submission of a proper application and compliance with all other city requirements, subject to the provisions of section 17-35 of this Code. 
Service to subdivisions and multifamily complexes or other defined areas not served at the time of the application will be considered upon the city's receipt of all of the following: 
A petition signed by at least seventy-five (75) percent of the potential users in said subdivision, complex, or other defined area. A non-refundable fee established by resolution of the city council shall be submitted to the city within sixty (60) days of the approval of the petition by the city council by a minimum of fifty (50) percent of the potential users in said subdivision, complex, or other defined area. 
When the above conditions are met, and it is deemed to be in the best interest of the city, as determined by the city council, the city shall endeavor to construct the necessary reclaimed water system necessary to service the particular area. In the event the city deems it to not be in its best interest, as determined by the city council, to service a particular area requesting service, the established connection fee will be refunded to the applicant. 
The city will endeavor to provide reclaimed water service to approved subdivisions, multifamily complexes, and other defined areas in a timely manner but provides no guarantee that service will be available in a particular time frame. 
(b)	Irrigation with potable water prohibited. It shall be unlawful to use potable water for irrigation purposes after reclaimed water is available to a lot or parcel within the city. Customers with existing irrigation systems using potable water shall be required to disconnect from the potable water system and connect to the reclaimed water system for irrigation purposes within (90) days of written notice of availability. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event of reclaimed water shortages or operational problems, the Director shall have the authority to grant temporary variances from the provisions of this subsection and in accordance with any rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to law, and any applicable water shortage orders issued by the St. Johns River Water Management District. 
(c)	Irrigation wells. Customers may continue to use existing irrigation wells for irrigation purposes after reclaimed water is available. The city shall prohibit the installation of new irrigation wells or the rehabilitation of existing wells for irrigation purposes where reclaimed water is available. 
(d)	New irrigation system. All new irrigation systems constructed after the effective date of this article shall be required to connect to the city reclaimed water system upon the earlier of the following two (2) dates: 
(1)	When reclaimed water is not available at the time of construction of the irrigation system, then connection shall be required within (90) days after receipt of written notice from the city that reclaimed water is available; or, 
(2)	When reclaimed water is available at the time of construction of the irrigation system, then connection shall be required immediately and such connection shall be a condition to connection of the improvements on said property to the city's wastewater system. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-28. - Authority to adopt rates, fees and charges. 
The council shall have the authority by resolution or ordinance duly adopted after a public hearing, to establish rates, fees and charges for the reclaimed water system, and to provide terms and conditions for the payment and collection of same. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-29. - Discontinuing service by city. 
The city may discontinue reclaimed water service to any customer due to a violation of the terms of this article or any other city regulation, non-payment of bills, tampering with any service, plumbing of cross-connections with another water source, or the undertaking of any other activity that may be detrimental to the system. The city has the right to cease service until the condition is corrected and all costs due the city are paid. These costs may include delinquent billings, connection charges, and payment for any damage caused to the system. Should discontinued service be restored without authorization, the department shall remove the service and make such additional charges as are established by resolution or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-30. - Interruption of service by city. 
The city reserves the right to temporarily discontinue service to any portion of, or the entire reclaimed water system, as deemed necessary by the director. The director shall have the authority to establish schedules which restrict the use of the reclaimed water system at certain times in order to reduce maximum demands on the system and to regulate usage during periods of limited reclaimed water availability. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-31. - Easement dedications. 
An applicant for reclaimed water service to an irrigation site which does not have public access shall dedicate land or shall grant perpetual easements to the city for reuse transmission and distribution facilities as required to provide reclaimed water service without charge to city. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-32. - Permits. 
The city shall obtain and fulfill, at its expense, all necessary permits and approvals for the construction and operation of the reclaimed water distribution facilities constituting the city's reclaimed water system. Once service is available, any additional permits or approvals required for service to any particular customer, for the customer's benefit, shall be obtained at the sole expense of said customer. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-33. - Priorities for extending reclaimed water service. 
The city council shall determine priorities for reclaimed water line extensions based on technical input from staff and consultants. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-34. - Potable water wells. 
As mandated by the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, the city shall not provide reclaimed water service where wells are used as a source of potable water, and where setback requirements cannot be maintained. It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city to install a well intended for use as a potable water supply within FDEP-mandated setback requirements of existing or known proposed reuse sites. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-35. - Right to service. 
No payment of any costs, submittal of any application or petition, or undertaking of any other act to receive reclaimed water service shall guarantee such service. The city shall have the right, at all times, to refuse to extend service on the basis of a use detrimental to the system, inadequate supply of reclaimed water, lack of payment of required fees, or for any other reason which, in the judgment of the city council will cause the extension not to be beneficial to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-36. - Service outside the city. 
Reclaimed water service may be provided to properties located outside the corporate limits of the city within the county. Such service will be extended on an actual cost basis and may include service to a governmental unit. All applications for service outside the city shall be reviewed by the department and such service shall be approved only if an adequate supply of reclaimed water is and will be available to meet all anticipated needs within the incorporated areas of the city. The director shall review and approve all service line sizes and all other necessary design components. In any event, final approval of reclaimed water service outside the corporate limits of the city must be approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-37. - Service application requirements. 
(a)	Reclaimed water service shall be applied for in the wastewater treatment and water reclamation department by completing and signing an application form, subject to section 17-27 of this article. 
(b)	Applications for all reclaimed water services within any city, county or state maintained right-of-way shall include a dimensional plan showing the location of the requested service line relative to the nearest street intersection, etc., as required by the city, the county or the state department of transportation. 
(c)	Before an application for reclaimed water service will be approved, the customer must have installed a suitable irrigation system. The irrigation system to be provided by the customer will consist of an underground system with permanently placed sprinkler devices. The sprinkler system shall be designed to operate at a maximum of 35 psi at 20 gallons per minute of flow. The city bears no responsibility for any damages to sprinkler systems or property. No system with a cross-connection to the potable water system will be considered for connection to the reclaimed water system. Temporary systems will not be considered for connection to the reclaimed water system. The systems shall not include aboveground faucets or other devices or connections that could permit reclaimed water to be used for any purpose other than irrigation, unless such uses and systems meet City of Rockledge Reclaimed Water Standards and FDEP rules and regulations, and have been approved in writing by the director. 
(d)	All new irrigation systems constructed in areas where the city has determined to make reclaimed water available shall be constructed in accordance with the City of Rockledge Reclaimed Water Standards and the regulations contained in Chapter 62-610, or latest version thereof, Florida Administrative Code. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-38. - Meter requirements. 
All reclaimed water users shall be required to utilize an appropriately sized flow meter. All meters for the reclaimed water system will be installed and owned by the city. No reclaimed water installations will be allowed without the installation of a flow meter. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-39. - Cross-connection control. 
(a)	In all premises where reclaimed water service is provided, the public or private potable water supply shall be protected by an approved backflow prevention device. All devices and material installed for backflow prevention must comply with FDEP criteria and be approved by the city. Where any cross-connection is found, it shall be immediately disconnected. Before reconnection of that service, the public potable water system shall be protected against the possibility of future cross-connections, and additional devices may be required as specified by the director and installed at the customer's expense. 
(b)	To determine the presence of any potential hazards to the public potable water system and for the purposes of perpetual maintenance and repair of reclaimed water system appurtenances, the city shall have the right to enter upon the premises of any customer receiving reclaimed water. Each customer of reclaimed water service shall, by application, give written consent to such entry upon such customer's premises. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-40. - Construction specifications.
