(a)	Pipe shall meet or exceed standards set by the American Water Works Association, the Florida Department of Environmental Protection, and the City of Rockledge Reclaimed Water Standards. 
(b)	Mains in the public rights-of-way shall be located a uniform distance from the curb and the location shall be approved by the director. 
(c)	Vertical and horizontal clearances from potable water lines and sewage collection lines shall be as specified in the applicable Florida Department of Environmental Protection rules. 
(d)	All valves and hose bibs shall be placed in approved tamper-proof boxes. 
(e)	Where irrigation mains are to be turned over to the city, the customer shall submit such documents as are normally required for the dedication of public facilities. 
(f)	"As-built" drawings shall be submitted to the department upon completion of the systems within public right-of-ways and public easements. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-41. - Maintenance by the customer. 
The customer shall be responsible for the maintenance and repair of all irrigation lines and appurtenances on the customer's property, unless said facilities are located within land previously dedicated to the city or land in which the city has been issued and has accepted a license or permit to operate said facilities. The city reserves the right to disconnect the service to any property when the irrigation system and appurtenances are not properly maintained or fail to meet the requirements of Chapter 62-610, or latest version thereof, Florida Administrative Code, and the City of Rockledge Reclaimed Water Standards. In addition, should the customer require reclaimed water at different pressures, or different quality, or in any way different from that normally supplied by the city, the customer shall be responsible for the necessary devices to make these adjustments and for obtaining the approval of the director. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-42. - Maintenance by the city. 
(a)	All facilities that have been conveyed, dedicated or transferred to the city and accepted by the city shall become the property of the city and will be operated, maintained and repaired by the city. No person shall perform any work nor be reimbursed for any work on the system unless written authorization from the city is received prior to the work being commenced. 
(b)	The city shall make a reasonable effort to inspect and keep its facilities in good repair, but assumes no liability for any damage caused by the system that is beyond the control of normal maintenance or due to situations not previously reported to the department. This shall include damage due to breaking of the pipes, poor quality of water caused by unauthorized or illegal entry of foreign material into the system, faulty operation of fire protection facilities, or other reasons 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-43. - Common service lines. 
The director shall have the authority to approve one service line to connect or service two (2) or more customers when sufficient capacity is available. In these cases, each customer shall pay the full connection charges. Common service lines will be sized to provide adequate service to each customer serviced. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-44. - Public easement. 
When reuse lines and appurtenances are initially installed by a person or entity other than the city, said lines and appurtenances shall not be accepted by the city for maintenance unless the facilities are within a dedicated public right-of-way or easement and such facilities are determined by the director to be in good working order. Any new easement, or licensed or permitted area, shall be adequately sized to accommodate construction and maintenance of any reuse system component. No obstruction of whatever kind shall be planted, built, or otherwise created within the limits of the easement, right-of-way, or licensed or permitted area, without the written permission of the director. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-45. - Ownership by city. 
All reclaimed water facilities and appurtenances within dedicated public rights-of-way or easements when constructed or accepted by the city shall become and remain the property of the city. No applicant or customer shall by payment of any charges provided herein, or by causing any construction of facilities accepted by the city, acquire any interest or right in any such facilities or any portion thereof, other than the privilege of having his/her/its property connected thereto for reclaimed water service in accordance with this article. The city shall be sole provider of reclaimed water except as approved by city council for permission by another governmental entity. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-46. - Appeals to the council. 
Any refusal by the director to grant service to an applicant, or any other decision made by the director pursuant to this article, may be appealed to the city council for a final and binding decision. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-47. - Adoption of Chapter 62-610, FAC. 
The rules and regulations appearing in Chapter 62-610, or latest version thereof, Florida Administrative Code, as the same may be amended from time to time, are hereby adopted by reference as though fully set forth within this article. In the event of any variation between the provisions of Chapter 62-610, or latest version thereof, FAC, and the provisions of this article, the more strict provision shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-48. - Transfer of reclaimed water. 
It shall be unlawful and an offense against the city for any person or entity to sell, barter, trade or otherwise transfer reclaimed water to any other person or entity, or to any property other than the authorized irrigation site, after having initially received said reclaimed water from the city, without written authorization from the director. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-49. - Applicability to initial users. 
It is not the legislative intent of the council to, by the enactment of this article, vitiate, invalidate or otherwise render ineffective any term, provision or condition of any reclaimed water supply contract entered into between the city and any initial user herein identified prior to the effective date of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-50. - Reclaimed water services rates, connection fees, non-metered usage. 
(a)	A rate shall be charged to the customers of the water reclamation system as follows: 
(1)	Consumption of thirty thousand (30,000) gallons or less per month, a charge of ten dollars ($10.00) per month, which shall be the base rate; 
(2)	Consumption of more than thirty thousand (30,000) gallons to sixty thousand (60,000) gallons per month, an additional surcharge of forty-five cents ($0.45) for each thousand gallons of usage over the base rate; 
(3)	Consumption of more than sixty thousand (60,000) gallons to one hundred thousand (100,000) gallons per month, an increase in the additional surcharge to seventy cents ($0.70) for each thousand gallons of usage over sixty thousand (60,000) gallons; 
(4)	Consumption of more than one hundred thousand (100,000) gallons per month, an increase in the additional surcharge to one dollar ($1.00) for each thousand gallons of usage over one hundred thousand (100,000) gallons. 
(b)	Connection fees shall be based on the meter size used and are as follows: 
(1)	¾? - $500.00 
(2)	1? - $500.00 
(3)	1½? - $750.00 
(4)	2? - $1,000.00 
(5)	3? - $1,500.00 
(6)	4? - $2,000.00 
(7)	6? - $2,500.00 
(8)	8? - $3,000.00 
(9)	10? - $4,000.00 
(10)	>10? - $5,000.00 
(c)	Non-metered service shall be charged at the following rate: 
(1)	For property of one (1) acre or smaller - Fifteen dollars ($15.00) per month, with an additional fifteen dollars ($15.00) per month for each additional acre serviced. 
(2)	For multi-units of two (2) or more units, a monthly charge of eight dollars ($8.00) per unit. 
(3)	For public property, a fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per connection point, but never less than the charge for the tier usage fees per paragraph (a). 
(4)	For services outside of the City of Rockledge the rate established under paragraph (a) plus an additional twenty-five (25) percent charge. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06; Ord. No. 1575-11, § 1, 3-16-11)  
Sec. 17-51. - Connection charges; capital costs, reconnection; violation; non-consent fees. 
(a)	Connection charges. Connection charges to the reclaimed water systems shall be as specified under section 17-50, reclaimed water service rate. The customer shall be responsible for any charges for the installation of required back-flow prevention devices 
(b)	Meter required. Where reclaimed water is for, or determined to be for commercial usage, or the use of reclaimed water is other than for irrigation purposes, the customer shall be required to pay all costs associated with the purchase of the meter. With approval of the city manager, the director of wastewater treatment may waive the requirement for a meter or meters where a suitable alternative method exists for the calculation of the water usage and where the customer agrees to pay the metered rate for the calculated amount of water usage. 
(c)	[Property of city.] All residential connections shall be required to have a meter and shall become the property of the city after it is installed. 
(d)	Re-connection fee. A customer whose service has been voluntarily disconnected or disrupted for non-payment may resume reclaimed water service after paying any past due amounts and a re-connection fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for voluntary discontinuance and a re-connection fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) for non-payment. 
(e)	Violation. Where service has been disconnected for violation of an ordinance or regulation regarding reclaimed water, such service shall not be reconnected until the director of wastewater treatment or designee, receives adequate assurances and guarantees that such a violation will not recur. 
(f)	Illegal/non-consent fee. When an unauthorized connection is made to the water reclamation system or a connection to the system is made without the prior authorization of the city section 17-54(a) shall prevail and a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00) paid to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-52. - Requirements for developers to provide a water reclamation distribution system. 
(a)	All new developments, including subdivision and platting of residential tracts, shall include reclaimed water distribution systems unless an exemption is granted by the city council due to the likelihood of reclaimed water service not being extended to the area. Plans and specifications for these systems will be processed for project approval in accordance with this and other relevant city ordinances. 
(b)	New commercial developments shall provide irrigation systems for the irrigation of landscaped areas. These irrigation systems will be connected to the reclaimed water distribution systems. Where reclaimed water is not available at the time of completion of the irrigation system, the system is to be constructed to allow connection to the reclaimed water distribution system when such system becomes available. 
(c)	Irrigation systems installed on residential lots in new developments shall be designed for connection to the reclaimed water distribution system in accordance with section 17-37 of this article and with the city's reclaimed water standards. 
(d)	Where trunk mains exist and reclaimed water is available, the connection of distribution mains to the reuse trunks shall be accomplished by the developer at the sole expense of the developer. In the instance that adequate reclaimed water is not available or new developments install distribution systems where no reuse trunk mains exist, the city shall connect the distribution mains to the trunk mains upon the availability of said supply and mains. 
(e)	All taps to the reuse distribution system shall be approved in writing by the director prior to tapping. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-53. - Promulgation/enforcement of water reclamation system and procedures. 
(a)	Promulgation and enforcement. The city manager shall have the authority to promulgate procedures and regulations with respect to the following matters: 
(1)	Application procedures and requirements. 
(2)	Installation requirements and permits, including specification of acceptable materials, devices and regulations to prevent backflow or cross-connection with the city water reclamation system and any other system. 
(3)	Enforcement of the ordinances and regulations pertaining to the water reclamation system including procedures for inspection of the customer's system. 
(4)	Orderly expansion and use of the water reclamation system, public and private. 
(5)	Procedures to insure that all wells located on the property receiving reclaimed water will be completely disconnected from irrigation systems on the property. Wells may be maintained and used for other purposes providing there is not potential physical connection to the water reclamation system. 
(6)	The rendering of bills for service and the collection of charges for all services rendered. 
(7)	Collection of all fees and charges and recording in the public records and liens agreed to by customers of the system. 
(b)	Promulgation and regulations. The city manager may, when necessary for the efficient operation of the water reclamation system or for the health or safety of the general public or the customer, establish regulations regarding the following matters which regulations shall become effective at the time of promulgation without the need for city council approval: 
(1)	The time(s) of day or night and number of days per week during which the reclaimed water may be used by customers. 
(2)	The maximum number and type users of the reclaimed water. 
(c)	Cross connection/non-complying device prohibited. Cross connection of reclaimed water with other sources of water or use for potable purposes is prohibited. Reclaimed water shall not enter a residence or building or within a dwelling unit. No person shall construct, operate, maintain, or allow to remain present on the property owned or controlled, any device or system which is connected to or which controls a device or system connected to the city's water reclamation system and which is not in compliance with all provisions of this Code and the Florida Administrative Code, Chapter 62-610, and with all procedures and regulations promulgated pursuant to this section. The person who owns or controls the property upon which such a non-complying device or system is found shall be liable to the city for the amount by which the cost associated with the securing and/or removal of the non-complying device or system exceeds the cost of a normal discontinuance of service. These excess costs shall constitute a lien against the property upon which the non-complying device or system is located. 
(d)	Device(s) and installation. The required type of device for backflow installation upon the residential and commercial premises to protect the portable water supply where reclaimed water is to be used, shall comply with the potable water supplier's specifications. Installation, testing, and maintenance of the device shall be the responsibility of the customer and the customer shall comply with the potable water supplier's policies, procedures and specifications. Vacuum breakers shall be installed on all outside potable water faucets to prevent back siphonage. 
(e)	Noncompliance liability. Any customer whose water reclamation system is in violation of any city ordinance, regulation, or procedure shall be subject to immediate discontinuance of the customer's reclaimed water service. Such discontinuance of service shall not relieve any person of liability for civil actions of for municipal ordinance violation prosecution. 
(f)	System responsibility. The director will be responsible for the training of city personnel in cross-connection control and inspection to see that the adopted rules are followed. 
(g)	In-ground irrigation and prohibited attachments. All irrigation systems shall be permanently installed and consist of low trajectory water droplet spray heads of inground irrigation design. Hose connections and faucets are prohibited on the water reclamation system. 
(h)	Owners reuse control. A hand control valve must be installed and accessible on the user's side of the city curbside service line. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-54. - Unauthorized work. 
(a)	Unauthorized work prohibited. No person, unless expressly authorized by the director or designee, shall tamper with or in any way alter or damage any city water reclamation facility. This shall include, but is not limited to, opening or closing of city valves, or causing of any water to flow from the system. No unauthorized person shall cut into or make any connections into the system. The offending person(s) or property owner shall be liable for the cost of all charges attributable to the correcting of such tampering, including legal expenses, but payments of or correcting of such damage shall not relieve the offending person from civil penalties the city or a court may impose for a violation of city ordinance. 
(b)	Maintenance required. The owner or controller of the property must maintain the water reclamation system and devices upon the premises. This specifically includes adjustment of heads to avoid excessive overspray onto but not limited to: streets, public sidewalks, canals, swimming pools, hot tubs or wading pools. Also included is maintenance of pipes and valves so as not to cause damage to city streets or utilities. Failure to keep the system in repair shall result in discontinuance of service. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-55. - Inspection rights of the city. 
(a)	City rights. To insure that the provisions of the city ordinances and regulations and procedures are being observed, the city reserves the right and privilege of inspecting and removing devices. 
(1)	Inspections without cause to believe that an ordinance or regulation is being violated shall be at reasonable times and shall not exceed a reasonable frequency. 
(2)	Inspections where there is a reasonable cause to believe that an ordinance or regulation is being violated shall be at such time and shall occur with such frequency as is necessary to establish that an ordinance or regulation is or is not being violated. 
(b)	Consent to inspect. Each customer of the water reclamation system shall, by application, give prior written consent to city personnel to enter upon such premises. Failure of the city to obtain such a written wavier shall not affect the right of the city to proceed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)	Refusing inspection, consequences. Refusing to permit an authorized agent or employee to enter onto the premises for the purposes of inspecting the customer's water reclamation system pursuant to this section of the City Code and shall be grounds for immediate discontinuance of the water reclamation system service by the city to the subject premises. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-56. - Conditions of use. 
Each customer of the water reclamation system shall not have any recourse against the city for the loss of reclaimed water supply due to distribution system down times, or for damage to vegetation or any other damages occasioned by use of the reclaimed water. 
(Ord. No. 1409-06, § 1(Exh. A), 5-3-06)  
Sec. 17-57. - Schedule for usage, restrictions and limitations. 
The St. Johns River Water Management District (District) summer schedule for potable water and irrigation wells, as may be modified from time to time by the district, are adopted and established as the reclaimed water usage schedules within the city. Failure to comply with the usage schedules shall result in the following: 
(1)	First violation - written notice of violation, setting out date and time of violation; 
(2)	Second violation and all subsequent violations may be referred to the code enforcement board for action; 
(3)	Repeat violations may result in termination of service. 
(Ord. No. 1575-11, § 2, 3-16-11)  
Secs. 17-58—17-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - STORMWATER DRAINAGE UTILITY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note—
 
Sec. 17-61. - Creation. 
Pursuant to the home rule power of Article VII, Section 14, Florida Constitution, and Chapter 403, Florida Statutes, and the powers granted in the Charter of the City of Rockledge, the Rockledge City Council does hereby establish a stormwater drainage utility and declare its intention to be responsible for the operation, construction, maintenance and repair of stormwater facilities; for stormwater system planning; and for lake and river water quality management. 
(Ord. No. 1213-00, § 1, 6-7-00)  
Sec. 17-62. - Findings, determinations and powers. 
It is hereby found, determined, and declared that those elements of the system which provide for the collection, treatment and disposal of stormwater and regulation of groundwater are of benefit and provide services to all property within the incorporated city limits, including property not presently served by the storm elements of the system. The beneficiaries of the system include all real properties within the City of Rockledge which benefit by the provision, operation and improvement of the system. Such benefits may include, but are not limited to, the provision of adequate systems of collection, conveyance, detention, treatment and release of stormwater, the reduction of hazard to property and life resulting from stormwater runoff, improvement in general health and welfare through reduction of undesirable stormwater conditions, and improvement to the water quality in the storm and surface water system and its receiving waters. 
The utility, under the direction of the director thereof, shall have the power to: 
(1)	Prepare regulations as needed to implement this article, and forward the same to the city council for consideration and adoption, and adopt such procedures as are required to implement said regulations or carry out other responsibilities of the utility; 
(2)	Administer the acquisition, design, construction, maintenance and operation of the utility system, including capital improvements designated in the comprehensive drainage plan; 
(3)	Administer and enforce this article and all regulations and procedures adopted relating to the design, construction, maintenance, operation and alteration of the utility system including, but not limited to, the quantity, quality and/or velocity of the stormwater conveyed thereby; 
(4)	Inspect private systems as necessary to determine the compliance of such systems with this article and any regulations adopted under this article; 
(5)	Advise the city council, city manager and other city departments on matters relating to the utility; 
(6)	Prepare and revise a comprehensive drainage plan for adoption by the city council periodically; 
(7)	Review plans, approve or deny, inspect and accept extensions to the system; 
(8)	Establish and enforce regulations to protect and maintain water quality within the system in compliance with water quality standards established by state, regional and/or federal agencies as now adopted or hereafter amended; 
(9)	Analyze the cost of services and benefits provided, and the system and structure of fees, charges, fines and other revenues of the utility annually. 
(Ord. No. 1213-00, § 2, 6-7-00)  
Sec. 17-63. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply; words used in the singular shall include the plural, and the plural, the singular; words used in the present tense shall include the future tense. The word "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. The word "may" is permissive. Words not defined herein shall be construed to have the meaning given them by common and ordinary use as defined in the latest edition of Webster's Dictionary. 
Bonds means revenue bonds, notes, loans or other debt obligations issued or incurred to finance the costs of construction. 
Costs of construction means costs reasonably incurred in connection with providing capital improvements to the system or any portion thereof, including but not limited to the costs of (1) acquisition of all property, real or personal, and all interests in connection therewith including all rights-of-way and easements therefor, (2) physical construction, installation and testing, including the costs of labor, services, materials, supplies and utility services used in connection therewith, (3) architectural, engineering, legal and other professional services, (4) insurance premiums taken out and maintained during construction, to the extent not paid for by a contractor for construction and installation, (5) any taxes or other charges which become due during construction, (6) expenses incurred by the city or on its behalf with its approval in seeking to enforce any remedy against any contractor or sub-contractor in respect of any default under a contract relating to construction, (7) principal of and interest of any bonds, and (8) miscellaneous expenses incidental thereto. 
Debt service means, with respect to any particular fiscal year and any particular series of bonds, an amount equal to the sum of (i) all interest payable on such bonds during such fiscal year, plus (ii) any principal installments of such bonds during such fiscal year. 
Developed property means real property other than undisturbed property. 
Director means the director of utilities/public works or his designee. 
Dwelling unit means a single unit or apartment providing complete, independent living facilities for one (1) or more persons including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. 
Equivalent residential unit or ERU means the average impervious area of residential developed property per dwelling unit located within the city and as established by council resolution as provided herein. 
ERU rate means a utility fee charged on each ERU as established by council resolution as provided herein. 
Exempt property means public rights-of-way, public streets, public alleys and public sidewalks, public parks and conservation areas and easements. 
Extension and replacement means costs of extensions, additions and capital improvements to, or the renewal and replacement of capital assets of, or purchasing and installing new equipment for, the system, or land acquisition for the system and any related costs thereto, or paying extraordinary maintenance and repair, including the costs of construction, or any other expenses which are not costs of operation and maintenance or debt service. 
Fiscal year means a twelve-month period commencing on the first day of October of any year, or such other twelve-month period adopted as the fiscal year of the utility. 
Impervious areas means those hard-surfaced areas which either present or retard the entry of water into soil mantle, as it entered under natural conditions prior to development, and/or cause water to run off the surface in greater quantities or at an increased rate of flow from that present under natural conditions prior to development. Common impervious surfaces include, but are not limited to, rooftops, sidewalks, walkways, patio areas, driveways, parking lots, storage areas and other surfaces which similarly impact the natural infiltration or runoff patterns which existed prior to development, including water in ponds or lakes as measured at the normal water level (NWL). 
Non-residential developed property means developed property that is classified by the property appraiser as land use types 10 through 99 using the Florida Department of Revenue Land Use Codes, as amended or supplemented, excluding that portion of land use type 28 to the extent used or usable for residential purposes. 
Operating budget means the annual utility operating budget adopted by the city for the succeeding fiscal year. 
Operations and maintenance means the current expenses, paid or accrued, of operation, maintenance and current repair of the system, as calculated in accordance with sound accounting practice, and includes, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, insurance premiums, administrative expenses, labor, executive compensation, the cost of materials and supplies used for current operations, and charges for the accumulation of appropriate reserves for current expenses not annually incurred, but which are such as may reasonably be expected to be incurred in accordance with sound accounting practice. 
Property appraiser means the office of the county property appraiser. 
Residential developed property means developed property that is classified by the property appraiser as land use types 00 through 09 and 28, to the extent used or usable for residential purposes, using the Florida Department of Revenue Land Use Codes, as amended or supplemented, upon which there is located at least one (1) dwelling unit. 
Revenues means all rates, fees, assessments, rentals or other charges or other income received by the utility, in connection with the management and operation of the system, including amounts received from the investment or deposit of moneys in any fund or account and any amounts contributed by the city, all as calculated in accordance with sound accounting practice. 
Stormwater Management System or System means the existing stormwater management of the city and all improvements thereto which by this ordinance are constituted as the property and responsibility of the utility, to be operated as an enterprise fund to, among other things, conserve water, control discharges necessitated by rainfall events, incorporate methods to collect, convey, store, absorb, inhibit, treat, use or reuse water to prevent or reduce flooding, over-drainage, environmental degradation and water pollution or otherwise affect the quality and quantity of discharge from such system. 
Undisturbed property means real property which has not been altered from its natural state by dredging, filling, removal of trees and vegetation or other activities which have disturbed or altered the topography or soils on the property. 
Undisturbed property rate means the utility fee charged on each acre of undisturbed property, as established by council resolution as provided here. 
Utility Fee means a utility fee authorized by Florida law and this Ordinance which is established to pay operations and maintenance, extension and replacement and debt service. 
Stormwater management utility or utility means the enterprise fund utility created by this Ordinance to operate, maintain and improve the system and for such other purposes as stated in this Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1213-00, § 3, 6-7-00; Ord. No. 1639-2013, § 1, 11-20-13 )  
Sec. 17-64. - Operating budget. 
The city shall adopt an operating budget not later than the first day of each fiscal year. The operating budget shall set forth for such fiscal year the estimated revenues and the estimated costs for operations and maintenance extension and replacement and debt service. The initial operating budget shall be for the fiscal year commencing ____________ . 
(Ord. No. 1213-00, § 4, 6-7-00)  
Sec. 17-65. - Stormwater utility fee. 
(a)	Fee established. Subject to the provisions of this article, there is hereby imposed on each and every undisturbed property, residential developed property and non-residential developed property, other than exempt property, and the owners and non-owner users thereof, a stormwater drainage utility fee. In the event the owner and non-owner users of a particular developed property or undisturbed property are not the same, the liability for each owner and non-owner user for the utility fee attributable to that developed property or undisturbed property shall be joint and several. The utility fee shall be a monthly or annual service charge and shall be determined by the provisions of this Section and the ERU and ERU rate and undisturbed property rate which shall be established and changed from time to time by resolution adopted by the Rockledge City Council. 
(b)	Utility fee for residential developed property. 
(1)	Except as provided in subparagraph 2. hereof, the utility fee for residential developed property shall be the ERU rate multiplied by the number of individual dwelling units existing on the property. In the event of a newly constructed dwelling unit, the charge for the utility fee attributable to that dwelling unit shall commence upon the issuance of the certificate of occupancy for that dwelling unit, or if construction is at least fifty (50) percent complete and is halted for a period of three (3) months, then that dwelling unit shall be deemed complete and the utility fee shall commence at the end of said three (3) month period. 
(2)	The utility fee for a single family dwelling unit on residential developed property existing on a lot which is larger than five (5) acres shall be the ERU rate multiplied by one (1) plus the undisturbed property rate multiplied by the amount of acreage in excess of five (5) acres. In the event of a newly constructed dwelling unit, the charge for the utility fee attributable to that dwelling unit shall commence upon the issuance of the certificate of occupancy for that dwelling unit, or if construction is at least fifty (50) percent complete and is halted for a period of three (3) months, then that dwelling unit shall be deemed complete and the utility fee shall commence at the end of said three (3) month period. 
(c)	Utility fee for non-residential developed property: 
(1)	The utility fee for non-residential developed property shall be the ERU rate multiplied by the numerical factor obtained by dividing the total impervious area of a non-residential developed property by the number of square feet in one (1) ERU, increased by an amount, if any, determined by multiplying the undisturbed property rate times the difference between the total undeveloped area minus 1.25 times the total impervious area. The minimum utility fee for any non-residential developed property shall be equal to one (1) ERU rate. In the event of newly developed non-residential development property, the charge for the utility fee attributable to that development shall commence, or increase in the case of additional development to property which is already developed property, upon the issuance of the certificate of occupancy for such additional development, or in the event that no certificate of occupancy will be issued for that development, or in the event development has halted, then on the date that the director or the director's designee determines in reasonable judgement that said development is substantially complete or has been halted for at least three (3) months. 
(2)	In the event of separately metered non-residential developed property with joint users of common impervious areas, the director shall calculate and allocate the pro rata utility fee among the users. Any owner or non-owner user disagreeing with the director's calculation or allocation may appeal such determination to the director as provided in paragraph f. of this section. 
(d)	Utility fee for undisturbed property. The utility fee for undisturbed property shall be based on the acreage of the undisturbed property and determined by multiplying the acreage times the undisturbed property rate set for undisturbed property as established and modified from time to time by council resolution. 
(e)	Dwelling unit and impervious surface calculation. The director or director's designee shall initially, and from time to time, determine the number of dwelling units located on residential developed property in order to establish the utility fee provided by paragraph b of this section. Non-residential real property in the City of Rockledge shall have its square footage impervious area calculated in order to establish the utility fee provided by paragraph c of this section. Undisturbed property shall have its total acreage calculated in order to establish the utility fee provided by paragraph d of this section. The director or the director's designee shall make the initial calculation and may from time to time change this calculation from such information and data deemed pertinent by the director or the director's designee. 
(f)	Appeal of dwelling unit and impervious surface calculation. Any person disagreeing with the calculation of the stormwater utility fee, as provided in this section, may appeal such determination to the director. Any appeal must be filed in writing and shall include a survey prepared by a registered surveyor showing dwelling units, total property area, impervious area or non-residential developed area, as appropriate. The director may request additional information from the appealing party. Based upon the information provided by the utility and appealing party, the director shall make a final calculation of the stormwater utility fee. The director shall notify the parties, in writing, of the director's decision. If still dissatisfied, a party may request, in writing, a review by the city manager of the director's decision. such request must cite specific error by the director and the calculation which the party feels is correct. The city manager shall review the record presented and render a written decision as soon as practical. The city manager may request additional information from either party. If still dissatisfied, a party may appeal the city manager's decision to the city council in the same manner as preceding. The decision of the city council shall be final. 
(Ord. No. 1213-00, § 5, 6-7-00)  
Sec. 17-66. - Stormwater drainage utility fee collection. 
(1)	The utility fee for metered property shall be billed and collected monthly with the monthly utility bill for those properties utilizing city utilities and billed and collected separately as stormwater drainage utility fees for those properties not utilizing other city utilities. All such bills for utility fees shall be rendered monthly by the finance department. The utility fee for those properties utilizing city utilities is part of a consolidated statement for utility customers which is generally paid by a single payment. In the event that a partial payment is received, the payment shall be applied pro-rata to each account billed on the consolidated statement in the proportion that an individual account bears to the total consolidated statement of all current charges for all accounts. The utility fee for unmetered property shall be billed annually. All bills for utility fees shall become due and payable in accordance with rules and regulations of the finance department pertaining to the collection of the utility fees. 
(2)	Utility fees shall be subject to a five (5) percent per month, not to exceed twenty-five (25) percent, late fee. The city shall be entitled to recover attorney's fees incurred in collecting delinquent utility fees. Any charge due hereunder which shall not be paid when due may be recovered in an action at law by the City of Rockledge. In addition to any other remedies or penalties provided by this or any other ordinance of the City of Rockledge, failure of any user of city utilities within the City of Rockledge to pay said charges promptly when due shall subject such user to discontinuance of utility services and the city manager of the city, or the city manager's designee, is hereby empowered and directed to enforce this provision as to any and all delinquent users. The employees of the city shall, at all reasonable times, have access to any premises served by the city for inspection, repair or the enforcement of the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(3)	All utility fees assessed pursuant to this ordinance shall be a lien upon the property to which such fee is associated from the date said fee becomes due until such fee is paid. The owner of every building, premise, lot, or house shall be obligated to pay the fee for all service provided for his premises, which obligation may be enforced by the city by action at law or suit to enforce the lien in the same manner as the foreclosure of mortgages. In the event of such action, the city shall be entitled to recover all court costs and reasonable attorney fees for such collection. In the case that a tenant in possession of any premises or buildings shall pay said charges, it shall relieve the land owner from such obligation and lien; but the city shall not be required to look to any person whatsoever other than the owner for the payment of such charges. No changes of ownership or occupation shall affect the application of this ordinance, and the failure of any owner to learn that he purchased property against which a lien for utility fees exists shall in no way affect his responsibility for such payment. 
(Ord. No. 1213-00, § 6, 6-7-00)  
Sec. 17-67. - Capital contributions for regional stormwater management facilities. 
(1)	Certain city ordinances presently require or may in the future require construction of on-site stormwater management facilities to control stormwater quantity and quality in the event of development. Implementation of regional stormwater management facilities may, in some cases, render construction of on-site facilities unnecessary. For use in these cases, the city shall adopt procedures and standards to require developers of land to provide a one-time capital contribution toward construction of regional stormwater management facilities in lieu of construction of on-site stormwater facilities. Such one-time capital contribution shall not affect the obligation for payment of any utility fee assessed pursuant to this ordinance. 
(2)	The one-time capital contribution may be available to developments which meet the following conditions: 
(a)	An adopted drainage basin study has identified an area within which the stormwater management facilities normally required to be created on-site are unnecessary; 
(b)	The development is located within an area so identified; and 
(c)	Implementation of regional stormwater management facilities required by the adopted drainage basin study is complete or under construction. 
(3)	For developments which meet the conditions specified in paragraph 7.2 hereof, the director, upon review of the development plans, shall prepare a development agreement which shall be presented for final approval to the city council. 
(4)	The amount of the one (1) time capital contribution shall be based upon that percentage of the regional stormwater management facility capacity which is to be allocated to the development. 
(Ord. No. 1213-00, § 7, 6-7-00)  
Sec. 17-68. - Program responsibility. 
It shall be the duty of the department of utilities/public works to administer the stormwater management utility. The department shall keep an accurate record of all persons using the services and facilities of said stormwater management system of the city and to make changes in accordance with the rates and changes established in this article. 
(Ord. No. 1213-00, § 8, 6-7-00)  
Sec. 17-69. - Stormwater management utility enterprise fund. 
(1)	All stormwater drainage utility fees collected by the city shall be paid into an enterprise fund which is hereby created, to be known as the "stormwater management fund". Such fund shall be used for the purpose of paying the costs of operation, administration and maintenance of the stormwater drainage facilities of the city and to carry out all other purposes of the utility. To the extent that the stormwater management utility fees collected are insufficient to construct the needed stormwater drainage facilities, the cost of the same may be paid from such city fund as may be determined by the city council, but the city council may order the reimbursement of such fund if additional fees are thereafter collected. When the fund has surplus dollars on hand in excess of current needs, the surplus dollars will be invested to return the highest yield consistent with proper safeguards. 
(2)	The fees and charges paid shall not be used for general or other governmental or proprietary purposes of the City, except to pay for the equitable share of the cost of accounting, management and government thereof. Other than as described above, the fees and charges shall be used solely for the purposes stated in paragraph 1 of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1213-00, § 9, 6-7-00)  
Chapter 18 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Special assessments, Subpt. A, Art. VIII; local improvements and special assessments, Subpt. B, Art. 2. 
Cross reference— Drinking alcoholic beverages on streets or sidewalks, § 4-4; community antenna television, Ch. 7; loitering, § 13-7; use of street or right-of-way by peddlers, § 15-26; planning, Ch. 16; taxicab stands on street prohibited, § 20-5; traffic, Ch. 21. 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Obstructing streets. 
No person shall obstruct any public city street by fencing across or into the same, or by willfully causing any other obstruction in or to such street or any part thereof, without permission of the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 23-12)  
Sec. 18-2. - Obstructing railroad street crossings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place any obstruction of any kind whatever in or across any railroad street crossing within the limits of the city, so as to block or obstruct in any way such railroad street crossing for a longer or greater period of time than five (5) minutes at any one time so that it will prevent the free passing of persons or vehicles over, on and across such crossing; provided that obstructions exceeding five (5) minutes may be permitted in specific cases by the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 23-12.1)  
Sec. 18-3. - Display of goods. 
No person shall display or place upon any public street or sidewalk within the city any goods, wares or merchandise without a permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 23-15) 
Cross reference— Peddlers, § 15-12 et seq.  
Sec. 18-4. - Use for storage or sale of vehicles. 
No person shall use any of the streets or sidewalks within the city for the purpose of storing junk, abandoned or used automobiles or motor vehicles, or for temporary storage of vehicles for the purpose of sale. 
(Code 1964, § 23-16) 
Cross reference— Storage of wrecked or dismantled motor vehicles, § 13-15; leaving inoperable motor vehicle on public street, § 21-32.  
Sec. 18-5. - Gates opening over streets or sidewalks. 
The owner or occupant of any lot or parcel of land within the city which shall have any gate opening to any street or sidewalk shall have the gate hung so that it swings inward when open and so that it cannot be swung outward over or toward the street or sidewalk. 
(Code 1964, § 23-14)  
Sec. 18-6. - Driving over sidewalks. 
No person shall drive an automobile, motor truck or other motor vehicle on, upon or across any sidewalk except at permanently established driveways, without first taking all precautions reasonably required to prevent injury to and breaking of such sidewalk, by placing boards or other protective covering of sufficient strength to prevent injury or breakage upon the sidewalks before driving on, upon or across the same. 
(Code 1964, § 23-1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 316.1995.  
Sec. 18-7. - Depositing injurious substances. 
No person shall throw or deposit on or into the streets any nails, wire, scrap metal, glass, crockery or other substance injurious to the feet of persons or animals or to tires of vehicles. 
(Code 1964, § 23-10) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 316.2035(1).  
Sec. 18-8. - Vehicle spilling load. 
No person shall operate or permit the operation of a vehicle upon which ashes, fuel, cinders, sand, gravel, paper, trash, rubbish or other materials are so loaded as to permit such articles to be scattered on the streets. 
(Code 1964, § 23-10) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 316.520(1).  
Sec. 18-9. - Certain trees prohibited along streets. 
No person shall plant or transplant within the area or space between a sidewalk and the adjacent street, in any parkway or right-of-way of any city street or public road, any species of the genus Casuarian, commonly known as Australian Pine and New Zealand Pine; any species of the genus Quercus, commonly known as Oak, Water Oak or Live Oak; any species of the genus Grevillea, commonly known as Silk, Silver or Australian Oak; any species of the genus Schinus terebinthifolius, commonly known as Brazilian Pepper Tree; any species of the genus Melaleuca quinquenervia, commonly known as Melaleuca or Cajeput Tree; any species of the genus Metopium toxiferum, commonly known as Poison Wood; any species of the genus Casuarina glauca, commonly known as Braxilia Oak; or any species of the genus Enterolobium cyclocarpum, commonly known as Ear Tree. 
(Code 1964, § 30-1; Ord. No. 764-85, § 6, 9-4-85)  
Sec. 18-10. - Permit required to plant along streets. 
No person shall plant any tree or shrub within the areas described in section 18-9 without first obtaining a written permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1964, § 30-2)  
Chapter 19 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference— Revenue and taxation, Subpt. A, Art. VII. 
Cross reference— Finances, § 2-171 et seq.; licenses, Ch. 11. 
 
ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Secs. 19-1—19-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - INSURANCE PREMIUM TAXES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Pensions and retirement, § 2-121 et seq.; retirement trust and retirement plan, App. A. 
 
Sec. 19-11. - Casualty insurors. 
(a)	Levied. There is hereby assessed, imposed and levied on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer now engaging in or carrying on, or which shall hereafter engage in or carry on, the business of insuring with respect to casualty risks, as shown by the records of the insurance commissioner of the state, an excise or license tax in addition to any license tax or excise tax now levied by the city which tax shall be in the amount of one percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policyholders on all premiums collected on casualty insurance policies, covering property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)	Due date. The license or excise tax herein levied shall be due and payable annually on March 1 of each year. 
(Code 1964, §§ 26-19, 26-20) 
State Law reference— Premium tax on casualty insurors for police retirement, F.S. § 185.08.  
Sec. 19-12. - Property insurors. 
(a)	Levied. There is hereby assessed, imposed and levied on every insurance company, corporation or other insurer now engaging in or carrying on, or which shall hereafter engage in or carry on, the business of property insurance, as shown by the records of the insurance commissioner of the state, an excise or license tax in addition to any license tax or excise tax now levied by the city, which tax shall be in the amount of two (2) percent of the gross amount of receipts of premiums from policyholders on all premiums collected on property insurance policies covering property within the corporate limits of the city. 
(b)	Due date. The license or excise tax herein levied shall be due and payable annually on March 1 of each year hereafter. 
(Code 1964, §§ 26-21, 26-22) 
State Law reference— Premium tax on property insurors for firemen's pensions, F.S. § 175.101.  
Secs. 19-13—19-22. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - PUBLIC SERVICE TAX[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal public service tax, F.S. § 166.231. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 19-23. - Levied; rate. 
(a)	There is hereby imposed and levied on every purchase of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured), and local telephone service, a tax based upon the charge made by the seller to the purchaser for such utility service or commodities at the rate of ten (10) percent of such charge. 
(b)	The tax imposed by subsection (a) of this section shall not be applied against any fuel adjustment charge, as provided in F.S. § 166.231. 
(c)	The tax on electricity authorized under subsection (a) of this section shall not be levied and collected on the first fifty (50) kilowatt hours per month purchased for residential use. Such exemption shall apply to each separate residential unit, regardless of whether such unit is on a separate or central meter, and shall be passed on to each individual tenant. This exemption is made pursuant to the provisions of F.S. § 166.231(3), and the city shall be reimbursed by the utility for such tax loss in accordance with the provisions of F.S. § 166.231. 
(Ord. No. 579-81, § 1, 2-18-81)  
Sec. 19-24. - Applicability of provisions. 
The provisions of this division shall apply to every person selling or purchasing within the limits of the city any electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured), or local telephone service, regardless of the place of residence or place of business of any such seller or purchaser, and the tax shall apply to each and every purchase of such utility service or commodities in the city except those specifically exempted by this division. 
(Code 1964, § 26-30)  
Sec. 19-25. - Exemption for public agencies. 
The purchase of electricity, gas or telephone service by the United States, the state, the county, the city, the board of public instruction of the county, and any governmental subdivision of any of such governing bodies shall be exempted from the taxes levied under this division. 
(Code 1964, § 26-31) 
State Law reference— Authority to exempt purchases by public bodies, F.S. § 166.231(4).  
Sec. 19-26. - Exemption for churches. 
The purchase of electricity, gas or telephone service by any recognized church exclusively for church purposes shall be exempted from the taxes levied under this division. 
State Law reference— Exemption for churches required, F.S. § 186.231(4).  
Sec. 19-27. - Exclusion of fuel adjustment charge. 
The tax imposed by this division shall not be applied against any fuel adjustment charge, as provided in F.S. § 166.231. 
(Ord. No. 549-80, § 1, 3-31-80) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, F.S. § 166.231(1)(b).  
Sec. 19-28. - Disposition of proceeds. 
All revenues received, collected, or derived from the taxes levied by this division shall be paid by the sellers to the city treasurer and shall be deposited in the general operating account, and shall be used and are hereby appropriated for the payment of the necessary operating expenses of the city, for the payment of the salaries of the officers, agents and employees of the city, and for the purchase of supplies, property, real estate and other articles required for the operation of the city; and no part of such taxes shall be used for the payment of the bonded debt of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 26-32)  
Sec. 19-29. - Tax declared continuing. 
The tax levied by this division shall be a continuing tax, and the appropriation made of the proceeds of such tax by section 19-28 shall be a continuing appropriation, so long as this division shall remain in effect; and the taxes shall be collected from year to year, and shall be disbursed from year to year in accordance with the city's appropriation ordinances or resolutions. 
(Code 1964, § 26-33)  
Sec. 19-30. - Applicability to telephone and telegraph service. 
(a)	The tax levied on sales of telephone service shall apply to all charges made for local telephone service except local messages which are paid for by inserting coins in coin-operated telephones. 
(b)	The total amount of the guaranteed charge on each bill rendered for semipublic coin telephone service shall be subject to such tax. 
(c)	The tax shall not apply to long distance telephone service or to telegraph service. 
(Code 1964, § 26-34)  
Sec. 19-31. - Payment by consumer. 
The tax imposed in this division shall in every case be paid by the purchaser for the use of the city to the seller of such electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured), and local telephone service, at the time of paying the charge therefor to the seller thereof; but not less often than monthly. 
(Code 1964, § 26-35)  
Sec. 19-32. - Duty of seller to collect; reporting, paying to city. 
It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured), or local telephone service, to collect from the purchaser, for the use of the city, the tax levied by this division at the time of collecting the selling price charged for such transaction, and to report and pay over on or before the fifteenth day following the end of the month, either calendar or otherwise at the election of the seller, to the treasurer of the city, all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding month. 
(Code 1964, § 26-36) 
State Law reference— Duty of utility to collect and pay to city, F.S. § 166.231(6).  
Sec. 19-33. - Records required; inspection by city. 
It shall be the duty of every seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured), or local telephone service, to keep complete records showing all purchases within the city of utility service or commodities, which records shall show the price charged upon each purchase, the date thereof, and the date of payment therefor. The records shall be kept open for inspection by the city treasurer or any duly authorized agent of the city during all business hours on all business days. The treasurer, or any duly authorized agent of the city, shall have the right, power and authority to inspect the records and make transcripts thereof during such times as he may elect; provided, that the right of inspection shall be exercised, as far as possible, so as to not interfere with the orderly arrangement and conduct of the books and records of the seller. 
(Code 1964, § 26-37)  
Sec. 19-34. - Computation where collected monthly or more often. 
In every case where the seller of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured) or local telephone service, shall collect the price thereof at monthly periods, or periods of less than one month, the tax levied by this division may be computed on the aggregate amount of the sales during such period; provided, that the tax to be collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Code 1964, § 26-39)  
Sec. 19-35. - Monthly intervals construed. 
In every case where the seller shall collect the price of service for monthly periods, the monthly periods shall be computed on the basis of the calendar month. Any seller may elect to compute the tax on the basis of a monthly period other than a calendar month, if such seller shall file with the city treasurer a written designation of the monthly period to be used by the seller, and upon such designation the seller may use the monthly period so designated as the basis for the computation of monthly charges. Such period may be changed by the seller from time to time by fixing a different monthly period. 
(Code 1964, § 26-40)  
Sec. 19-36. - Failure of seller to collect. 
(a)	No seller shall collect the price for any purchase of electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum gas, or manufactured), or local telephone service without, at the same time, collecting the tax hereby levied in respect to such purchase. 
(b)	Any seller who shall fail to collect such tax at the time of collecting the price of any such purchase shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax in like manner as if the same had been actually paid to the seller. 
(Code 1964, § 26-41)  
Sec. 19-37. - Enforcing payment against seller. 
(a)	If any seller shall fail to pay any taxes collected by him within ten (10) days after he shall be required to pay the same to the city, he shall be liable to and shall pay, in addition to such tax, a penalty equal to one percent per day for each day payment shall be in default after the first ten (10) days. 
(b)	If any seller shall be in default for more than ten (10) days, the city treasurer shall certify the fact of such default to the city attorney, and the city attorney shall thereupon enforce payment from such seller by action at law or suit in equity. If the tax and penalties shall be collected by action or suit the seller shall pay, as an additional penalty, such reasonable attorney's fees as may be fixed by the court in which such action or suit is brought to reimburse the city for the expenses incurred for the services of the city attorney in enforcing collection. In no event shall any seller be liable to the city for the payment of any tax upon any uncollected bills. 
(Code 1964, § 26-42)  
Sec. 19-38. - Failure of purchaser to pay. 
If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay to the seller the seller's charge for the sale to the purchaser of such electricity, metered or bottled gas (natural, liquefied petroleum gas or manufactured), or local telephone service, and the tax hereby imposed on account of the purchase for which such charge is made, the seller shall immediately discontinue further sale or furnishing to any such purchaser of any such utility service or commodities until the tax and the seller's charge shall have been paid in full. 
(Code 1964, § 26-43)  
Sec. 19-39. - Purchaser paying charges without paying tax. 
No purchaser shall pay to any seller the price charged by such seller for the purchase of such utility service or commodities without, at the same time and in the same transaction, paying to the seller the tax levied by this division on such purchase. 
(Code 1964, § 26-44)  
Sec. 19-40. - Penalty for failure of purchaser to pay tax. 
Any purchaser who shall fail to pay the tax imposed by this division, at the same time and in the same transaction with the payment to the seller for the utility service or commodities purchased, shall be liable to the city for a penalty equal to one percent of the total charge for the utility service or commodities for each day of the default, which penalty shall be collected by the seller and paid over to the city. 
(Code 1964, § 26-45)  
Secs. 19-41—19-51. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FUEL OIL[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to tax services competing with those taxed by division 1 hereof, F.S. § 166.231(2). 
 
Sec. 19-52. - Fuel oil defined. 
The term "fuel oil" as used herein shall include fuel oil Grades No. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6, kerosene and coal oil. 
(Code 1964, § 26-47)  
Sec. 19-53. - Levied. 
There is hereby imposed and levied by the city, on each and every purchase of fuel oil in the corporate limits of the city, except those purchases hereinafter specifically excluded and exempted from the operation of this division, a tax in the amount of four cents ($0.04) per gallon of fuel oil sold by the seller to the purchaser, which tax in every case shall be collected from the purchaser of such fuel oil, and paid by said purchaser for the use of the city to the seller of such fuel oil at the time of paying the charge therefor to the seller thereof; but not less than monthly. 
(Code 1964, § 26-46; Ord. No. 550-80, § 1, 3-31-80; Ord. No. 554-80, § 1, 5-7-80; Ord. No. 580-81, § 1, 2-18-81)  
Sec. 19-54. - Limit on tax. 
The tax imposed by this division shall not exceed the amount authorized by law. 
State Law reference— Limit on tax, F.S. § 166.231(2).  
Sec. 19-55. - Applicability of provisions. 
The provisions of this division shall apply to every person selling or purchasing within the limits of the city any fuel oil as herein defined, regardless of the place of residence or place of business of any such seller or purchaser, and the tax shall apply to each and every purchase of such fuel oil in the city except those specifically exempted by this division. 
(Code 1964, § 26-48)  
Sec. 19-56. - Disposition of proceeds. 
All revenues received, collected or derived from the tax levied by this division shall be paid by the sellers to the city treasurer and shall be deposited in the general operating account, and shall be used and are hereby appropriated for the payment of the necessary operating expenses of the city, for the payment of the salaries of the officers, agents and employees of the city, and for the purchase of supplies, property, real estate and other articles required for the operation of the city; and no part of such taxes shall be used for the payment of the bonded debt of the city. 
(Code 1964, § 26-49)  
Sec. 19-57. - Tax declared continuing. 
The tax levied by this division shall be a continuing tax, and the appropriation made of the proceeds of such tax by section 19-56 shall be a continuing appropriation, so long as this division shall remain in effect; and the taxes shall be collected from year to year, and shall be disbursed from year to year in accordance with the city's appropriation ordinances or resolutions. 
(Code 1964, § 26-50)  
Sec. 19-58. - Exemptions. 
There is excluded from the tax levied and imposed under this division: 
(a)	The purchase of special fuels as defined in F.S. Ch. 209; 
(b)	The purchase of not more than five (5) gallons of fuel oil delivered at the seller's place of business into the purchaser's container of not more than five (5) gallons' capacity; 
(c)	The purchase of fuel oil for use in the propulsion of ships, motor vessels, motorboats, aircraft, railroad trains and other media of transportation; 
(d)	The purchase of fuel oil for use as fuel in the operation of internal combustion engines; 
(e)	The purchase of fuel oil by a public or private utility, including municipal corporations and rural electric cooperative associations, for use as fuel in the generation of electricity; 
(f)	The purchase of fuel oil by the United States, the state, the county, the city, the board of public instruction of the county, and any governmental subdivision of any of such governing bodies; 
(g)	The purchase of fuel oil by any recognized church for use exclusively for church purposes. 
(Code 1964, § 26-51) 
State Law reference— Exemptions from tax on fuel oil, F.S. § 166.231(4), (5).  
Sec. 19-59. - Payment by consumer. 
The tax imposed in this division shall in every case be paid by the purchaser for the use of the city to the seller of such fuel oil at the time of paying the charge therefor to the seller thereof; but not less often than monthly. 
(Code 1964, § 26-52)  
Sec. 19-60. - Duty of seller to collect; reporting, paying to city. 
It shall be the duty of every seller of fuel oil to collect from the purchaser, for the use of the city, the tax levied by this division, at the time of collecting the selling price charged for such transaction, and to report and pay over on or before the fifteenth day following the end of the month, either calendar or otherwise at the election of the seller, to the treasurer of the city, all such taxes levied and collected during the preceding month. 
(Code 1964, § 26-53)  
Sec. 19-61. - Records required; inspection by city. 
It shall be the duty of every seller of fuel oil to keep complete records showing all purchases within the city of fuel oil, which records shall show the price charged upon each purchase, the date thereof and the date of payment therefor. The records shall be kept open for inspection by the city treasurer or any duly authorized agent of the city during all business hours on all business days. The treasurer, or any duly authorized agent of the city, shall have the right, power and authority to inspect the records and make transcripts thereof during such times as he may elect; provided, that the right of inspection shall be exercised, as far as possible, so as to not interfere with the orderly arrangement and conduct of the books and records of the seller. 
(Code 1964, § 26-54)  
Sec. 19-62. - Computation where collected monthly or more often. 
In every case where the seller of fuel oil shall collect the price thereof at monthly periods, or periods of less than one month, the tax levied by this division may be computed on the aggregate amount of the sales during such period; provided, that the tax to be collected shall be the nearest whole cent to the amount computed. 
(Code 1964, § 26-55)  
Sec. 19-63. - Monthly intervals construed. 
In every case where the seller shall collect the price of fuel oil for monthly periods, the monthly periods shall be computed on the basis of the calendar month. Any seller may elect to compute the tax on the basis of a monthly period other than a calendar month, if such seller shall file with the city treasurer a written designation of the monthly period to be used by the seller, and upon such designation the seller may use the monthly period so designated as the basis for the computation of monthly charges. Such period may be changed by the seller from time to time by fixing a different monthly period. 
(Code 1964, § 26-56)  
Sec. 19-64. - Failure of seller to collect. 
(a)	No seller shall collect the price for any purchase of fuel oil without, at the same time, collecting the tax hereby levied in respect to such purchase. 
(b)	Any seller who shall fail to collect such tax at the time of collecting the price of any such purchase shall be liable to the city for the amount of such tax in like manner as if the same had been actually paid to the seller. 
(Code 1964, § 26-57)  
Sec. 19-65. - Enforcing payment against seller. 
(a)	If any seller shall fail to pay any taxes collected or assumed by him within ten (10) days after he shall be required to pay the same to the city, he shall be liable to and shall pay, in addition to such tax, a penalty equal to one percent per day for each day payment shall be in default after the first ten (10) days. 
(b)	If any seller shall be in default for more than ten (10) days, the city treasurer shall certify the fact of such default to the city attorney, and the city attorney shall thereupon enforce payment from such seller by action at law or suit in equity. If the tax and penalties shall be collected by action or suit the seller shall pay, as an additional penalty, such reasonable attorney's fees as may be fixed by the court in which such action or suit is brought to reimburse the city for the expenses incurred for the services of the city attorney in enforcing collection. In no event shall any seller be liable to the city for the payment of any tax upon any uncollected bills. 
(Code 1964, § 26-58)  
Sec. 19-66. - Failure of purchaser to pay tax. 
If any purchaser shall fail, neglect or refuse to pay to the seller the seller's charge for the sale to the purchaser of such fuel oil, and the tax hereby imposed on account of the purchase for which such charge is made, the seller shall immediately discontinue further sale or furnishing to any such purchaser of any such fuel oil until the tax and the seller's charge shall have been paid in full. 
(Code 1964, § 26-59)  
Sec. 19-67. - Purchaser paying charges without paying tax. 
No purchaser shall pay to any seller the price charged by such seller for the purchase of such fuel oil without at the same time, and in the same transaction, paying to the seller the tax levied by this division on such purchase. 
(Code 1964, § 26-60)  
Sec. 19-68. - Penalty for failure of purchaser to pay tax. 
Any purchaser who shall fail to pay the tax imposed by this division, at the same time and in the same transaction with the payment to the seller of the fuel oil purchased, shall be liable to the city for a penalty equal to one percent of the total charge for the fuel oil for each day of the default, which penalty shall be collected by the seller and paid over to the city. 
(Code 1964, § 26-61)  
Sec. 19-69. - Other violations. 
Any purchaser willfully failing or refusing to pay the tax herein imposed and levied and any seller willfully violating the provisions of this division, or any officer, agent or employee of any such seller willfully violating the provisions of such division shall be guilty of a violation of this Code. 
(Code 1964, § 26-62)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 21-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known as the Rockledge Traffic Ordinance, and may be so cited. 
(Code 1964, § 28-1)  
Sec. 21-2. - One-way streets and alleys. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, traffic shall move only in the direction indicated below upon the following streets and alleys: 
Name of Street 	Direction of Movement

South Street 	South 
Sweet Street 	West 
Thirty-foot wide unnamed right-of-way which runs along the east boundary of Lot 11 of Block 10, King's Grant, Unit Four, as described in Plat Book 20 at Page 40, of the Public Records of Brevard County, Florida 	North 
 
(Code 1964, § 28-4; Ord. No. 663-83, § 1, 9-21-83; Ord. No. 1260-01, § 1, 9-19-01) 
State Law reference— Local authority to designate one-way streets, F.S. § 316.088(1); obedience to one-way streets, F.S. § 316.088(2).  
Sec. 21-3. - Quiet zones. 
Whenever signs are erected indicating a zone of quiet, no person operating a motor vehicle within such zone shall sound the horn or other warning device of such vehicle, except in an emergency. 
(Code 1964, § 28-9) 
Cross reference— Noise, Ch. 12.  
Sec. 21-4. - Entering Geiger Street from U.S. 1. 
When a sign is erected giving notice thereof, no operator of any motor vehicle shall cause such vehicle to enter onto or upon Geiger Street from U. S. Highway No. 1. 
(Code 1964, § 28-10) 
State Law reference— Authority to regulate or prohibit turns, F.S. § 316.008(1)(i).  
Sec. 21-5. - Trucks on through route prohibited on certain streets. 
(a)	Definition. For the purpose of this section, the term "through route" means any route of travel over, upon or across any street designated in this section by a truck having a load capacity in excess of one and one-half (1½) tons engaged in the rendition of a service for hire, or en route for the delivery or pickup of tangible personal property, and which route has neither its point of origin nor its point of destination at property abutting upon or adjacent to such street. 
(b)	Prohibited on certain streets. Upon erection of signs giving notice thereof, no person shall operate a truck exceeding one and one-half (1½) tons capacity on a "through route," as said term "through route" is defined in paragraph (a) above, over, across or upon any of the following streets within the city: 
Avondale Road 
Barton Avenue 
Bougainvillea Drive 
Cardinal Avenue between Fiske Boulevard and Cedar Street 
Fiske Boulevard 
Floridelphia Avenue 
Howard Street 
Kings Post Road 
Levitt Parkway 
Little John Lane 
Magruder Avenue 
North Palmway Street 
Orange Avenue 
Park Avenue 
Revilla Lane 
Rockledge Avenue 
Rockledge Drive 
Roy Wall Boulevard 
Santa Rosa Drive 
Seminole Drive 
South Fernwood Drive 
South Palmway Street 
Sweet Street 
Westport Drive 
(c)	Penalty. Any person violating any provision of this section shall be deemed guilty of a traffic infraction in the city and upon conviction thereof shall be required to pay a civil penalty as prescribed by Florida Statutes. 
(Code 1964, § 28-19; Ord. No. 541-80, §§ 1, 2, 1-2-80; Ord. No. 613-82, § 1, 5-5-82; Ord. No. 622-82, § 1, 9-1-82; Ord. No. 652-83, § 1, 7-20-83; Ord. No. 776-86, § 1, 1-8-86; Ord. No. 1151-97, § 1, 11-19-97; Ord. No. 1593-2012, § 1, 4-4-12 )  
Sec. 21-6. - Certain size trucks prohibited on designated streets. 
(a)	Purposes and objectives. This regulation is enacted for the purpose of eliminating or at least alleviating serious traffic problems on Seminole Drive and Orange Avenue caused by trucks making deliveries at the loading dock on the east side of Wuesthoff Memorial Hospital, which problems have, and do now, jeopardize the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city by the impeding of normal traffic flow by such trucks, noise pollution, litter, risk of injury or death to pedestrians and schoolchildren, and other detrimental effects. The extent of actual and potential damage to the public welfare is found to be rationally related to the size of trucks using the streets regulated and controlled by this section. The restrictions imposed by this section are established as part of a traffic control study and experimental program designed to provide a reasonable solution to the existent problems herein described. The public is advised of the experimental character of these regulations and that the same are subject to change at any time. This section is enacted as an exercise of the police powers of the city and no person or entity shall obtain any vested right or rights with respect to the use of any size truck upon the streets or portions thereof herein designated by virtue of the enactment of this section. 
(b)	Regulations. Upon erection of signs giving notice thereof, no person shall at any time stop, stand, park or operate a truck exceeding in overall length, from front bumper to rear bumper, the length specified below as the maximum truck length permitted upon the following streets or portions of streets in the city: 
	Street 	Maximum Truck Length 
(1) 	The part of Seminole Drive that lies between Barton Avenue and Orange Avenue 	40 feet 
(2) 	The part of Orange Avenue that lies between U.S. Highway No. 1 and the westerly line of the right-of-way of Maple Street extended northerly across Orange Avenue 	40 feet 
 
(Ord. No. 786-86, § 2, 5-21-86; Ord. No. 796-86, § 1, 7-2-86; Ord. No. 825-87, § 1, 3-18-87)
