Unless a different period of time is expressly provided by the board of adjustment at the time of granting of a variance, any variance granted pursuant to this section will automatically expire and become null and void twelve (12) months after the date of the granting thereof if the right, action or privilege for which the variance is granted is not fully exercised, implemented and completed within said twelve-month period, unless the board for good cause shown extends said twelve-month period. Any variance right, action or privilege granted by said board of adjustment which has been exercised, implemented and completed, and which is thereafter discontinued, revived or otherwise allowed to cease to exist for any continuous period of twelve (12) months shall, upon the expiration of said twelve-month period, automatically expire and be null and void. The provisions of this sub-subsection providing for the automatic expiration of any variance if the variance is not exercised and completed within twelve (12) months from the date of the granting thereof, unless otherwise provided by the board of adjustment, and providing for the automatic expiration of any variance which has been exercised but thereafter removed and discontinued for a continuous period of twelve (12) months, shall not be applicable to any variance granted prior to the effective date of this subsection, nor to any variance which has been removed or discontinued prior to the effective date of this subsection, until the elapse of twelve (12) months after the effective date of this subsection. 
(4)  Under no circumstances except as permitted above shall the board grant a variance to permit a use not generally or by special exception permitted in the zoning district involved or any use expressly or by implication prohibited by the terms of these regulations in the zoning district. No conforming use of neighboring lands, structures or buildings in the same zoning district and no permitted use of lands, structures or buildings in other zoning districts shall be considered grounds for the authorization of a variance. 
(D)  In exercising its powers, the board of adjustment may, upon appeal and in conformity with provisions of these regulations, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of any Zoning Ordinance or regulation adopted pursuant to these regulations, and may make any necessary order, requirement, decision or determination, and to that end shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken. The concurring vote of a majority of all the members of the board shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of any such administrative official or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which the board is required to pass under any such ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 985-90, § 1, 12-19-90) 
23.30. - Appeals. 
(a)  From decision of administrative official. Appeals to the board of adjustment may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any officer, board or bureau of the city council affected by any decision of an administrative official under any Zoning Ordinance enacted pursuant to this Code. Such appeal shall be taken within thirty (30) days after rendition of the order, requirements, decision or determination appealed from by filing with the officer from whom the appeal is taken and with the board of adjustment a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The appeal shall be in the form prescribed by the rules of the board. The administrative official from whom the appeal is taken shall, upon notification of the filing of the appeal, forthwith transmit to the board of adjustment all the documents, plans, papers or other materials constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(b)  Hearing of appeals. The board of adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give public notice thereof, as well as due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. In every appeal for a variance or special exception (conditional use) written notice of the time, place and purpose of such hearing shall be mailed at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing to the last known address of the owner of each lot, piece, parcel or tract of land within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the premises which is the subject of the appeal. Written notice of such hearing shall be mailed to the owners of adjacent property as herein required, even though such adjacent properties are located outside the municipal limits of the City of Rockledge. Appellants may be required to assume such reasonable costs in connection with appeals as may be determined by the city council through action in setting of fees to be charged for appeals. For procedural purposes, an application for a special exception (conditional use) shall be handled by the board of adjustment as for appeals. A fee established by the city council shall be paid to the city clerk at the time any notice of appeal is filed with the board of adjustment. 
23.40. - Stay of work and proceedings. 
    An appeal to the board of adjustment stays all work on the premises and all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the official from whom the appeal was taken shall certify to the board of adjustment that, by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings or work shall not be stayed except by a restraining order which may be granted by the board of adjustment or by a court of record on application, on notice to the officer from whom the appeal is taken and on due cause shown. 
23.50. - Hearings. 
    The board of adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give public notice thereof, as well as due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing, any party may appear in person, by agent, or by attorney. Appellants may be required to assume such reasonable costs in connection with appeals as may be determined by the city council through action in setting of fees to be charged for appeals. For procedural purposes, an application for a special exception shall be handled by the board of adjustment as for appeals. 
23.60. - Judicial review or decisions of the board of adjustment. 
    Any person or persons, jointly or severally, aggrieved by any decision of the board of adjustment, or any officer, department, board, commission or bureau of the city council may apply to the circuit court of Brevard County, Florida, for relief within thirty (30) days after rendition of the decision by the board of adjustment. Review in the circuit court shall be either by trial de novo, which shall be governed by the Florida rules of civil procedure or by petition for writ of certiorari, which shall be governed by the Florida appellate rules. The election of remedies shall lie with the appellant. 
SECTION 24.00. - CODE ENFORCEMENT BOARD 

24.10. - Creation. 
    This section may be cited as the Rockledge Code Enforcement Board Ordinance. 
24.20. - Authority. 
    This section is enacted pursuant to Chapter 162, Florida Statutes. 
24.30. - Intent. 
    It is the intent of this section to promote, protect and improve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the City of Rockledge by creating an administrative board with authority to impose administrative fines and other noncriminal penalties to provide an equitable, expeditious, effective and inexpensive method of enforcing the codes and ordinances in force in the City of Rockledge, where a pending or repeated violation continues to exist, including, but not limited to, occupational license, fire, building, zoning and sign codes. 
24.35. - Applicability. 
    There is hereby created a code enforcement board of the City of Rockledge, Florida, as provided in this section. The code enforcement board may be abolished by ordinance of the City of Rockledge. 
24.40. - Organization. 
(a)  The code enforcement board shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the city council. Members of the code enforcement board shall be residents of the City of Rockledge. 
(b)  Appointments to the code enforcement board shall be made in accordance with applicable law and ordinances on the basis of experience or interest in the fields of zoning and building control. The membership of the code enforcement board shall, whenever possible, include an architect, a businessman, an engineer, a general contractor, a subcontractor and a realtor. 
(c)  The initial appointments to the code enforcement board shall be as follows: 
(1)  Two (2) members appointed for a term of one year each. 
(2)  Three (3) members appointed for a term of two (2) years each. 
(3)  Two (2) members appointed for a term of three (3) years each. 
(d)  Thereafter, any appointment shall be made for a term of three (3) years. A member may be reappointed by the city council. An appointment to fill any vacancy on the code enforcement board shall be for the remainder of the unexpired term of office. 
(e)  Any members of the committee may be removed for cause by the city council. Further, any member who has three (3) consecutive unexcused absence, which are those not approved by the committee chairman prior to the meeting involved, or a total of four (4) absences during any twelve-month period, excused or unexcused, shall automatically be terminated and removed as a member of the committee. The city council shall appoint a replacement for any removed member at its next regularly scheduled meeting in the same manner as other appointment of members for the remainder of such term. 
(f)  The members of the code enforcement board shall elect a chairman and vice-chairman, who shall be voting members, from among the members of the code enforcement board. The presence of four (4) or more members shall constitute a quorum of the code enforcement board. Members of the code enforcement board shall serve without compensation, but may be reimbursed for such travel, mileage and per diem expenses as may be authorized by the city council or as are otherwise provided by law. 
(g)  No member of the board shall be a relative (blood, marriage or adoption) or persons residing in the same household may simultaneously serve on the board at any time. This shall not preclude those individuals from serving on other boards. 
(Ord. No. 1242-2001, § 2(C), 2-7-01; Ord. No. 1343-2004, § 3, 3-24-04) 
24.50. - Legal counsel. 
    The city attorney shall either be counsel to the code enforcement board or shall represent the city by presenting cases before the code enforcement board, but in no case shall the city attorney serve in both capacities. 
24.55. - Jurisdiction. 
    The code enforcement board shall have jurisdiction to hear and decide alleged violations of the codes and ordinances in force in the City of Rockledge, including amendments to such codes and ordinances. 
24.60. - Enforcement procedure. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the code inspector to initiate enforcement proceedings of the various codes and ordinances, and no member of the code enforcement board shall have the power to initiate such enforcement proceedings. 
(b)  Except as provided in paragraph (c), if a violation of the codes or ordinances is found, the code inspector shall notify the violator and give him a reasonable time to correct the violation. Should the violation continue beyond the time specified for correction, the code inspector shall notify the code enforcement board and request a hearing. The code enforcement board, through its clerical staff, shall schedule a hearing, and written notice of such hearings shall be hand delivered or mailed as provided in Section 24.90 to said violator. At the option of the code enforcement board, notice may additionally be served by publication or posting as provided in Section 24.90. If the violation is corrected by the code inspector, the case may be presented to the code enforcement board even if the violation has been corrected prior to the board hearing, and the notice shall so state. 
(c)  If the code inspector has reason to believe a violation presents a serious threat to the public health, safety, and welfare or if the violation is irreparable or irreversible in nature, the code inspector shall make a reasonable effort to notify the violator and may immediately notify the code enforcement board and request a hearing. 
24.65. - Conduct of hearing. 
(a)  Upon request of the code inspector, or at such other times as may be necessary, the chairman, or in his absence the vice-chairman, of the code enforcement board may call a hearing of the code enforcement board. A hearing also may be called by written notice, signed by at least three (3) members of the code enforcement board. 
(b)  Minutes shall be kept of all hearings by the code enforcement board, and all hearings and proceedings shall be open to the public. The city council shall provide clerical and administrative personnel as may be reasonably required by the code enforcement board for the proper performance of its duties. 
(c)  Each case before the code enforcement board shall be presented by the city attorney unless the city attorney is acting as counsel to the code enforcement board, in which event the case shall be presented by a member of the administrative staff of the city. 
(d)  The code enforcement board shall proceed to hear the case on the agenda for that day. All testimony shall be under oath and shall be recorded. The code enforcement board shall take testimony from the code inspector, alleged violator and any witnesses. Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings. 
(e)  Irrelevant, immaterial and unduly repetitious evidence shall be excluded, but all other evidence of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct of their affairs shall be admissible, whether or not such evidence would be admissible in a trial in the courts of this state. Fundamental due process shall be observed and shall govern the proceedings. The burden of proof shall be upon the code inspector to show, by a preponderance of the evidence, that a violation exists. 
(f)  Any member of the code enforcement board, or the counsel to the code enforcement board, may inquire of any witness before the code enforcement board. The alleged violator or his attorney, and the code inspector or counsel to the board, shall be permitted to inquire of any witness before the code enforcement board and to present brief opening and closing statements. 
(g)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the code enforcement board shall issue findings of fact, based on evidence of record, and conclusions of law, and shall issue an order affording the proper relief consistent with powers granted in this section. The finding shall be by motion approved by a majority of those members present and voting, except that at least four (4) members of the code enforcement board must vote in order for the action to be official. The order may include a notice that it must be complied with by a specified date, and that a fine may be imposed if the order is not complied with by said date. 
24.70. - Powers of the code enforcement board. 
    The code enforcement board shall have the power to: 
(1)  Adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings. 
(2)  Subpoena alleged violators and witnesses to its hearings. Subpoenas may be served by the sheriff or any deputy sheriff of Brevard County, or by any police officer of the city. 
(3)  Subpoena evidence. 
(4)  Take testimony under oath. 
(5)  Issue orders having the force of law to command whatever steps are necessary to bring a violation into compliance. 
24.75. - Administrative fines; liens. 
(a)  The code enforcement board, upon notification by the code inspector that an order of the code enforcement board has not been complied with by the set time or upon finding that the same violation has been repeated by the same violator, may order the violator to pay a fine not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for each day the violation continues past the date set for compliance or for each time the violation has been repeated, and a hearing shall not be necessary for issuance of the order. 
(b)  In determining the amount of the fine, if any, the code enforcement board shall consider the following factors: 
(1)  The gravity of the violation; 
(2)  Any actions taken by the violator to correct the violation; and 
(3)  Any previous violations committed by the violator. 
(c)  A certified copy of an order imposing a fine may be recorded in the public records of Brevard County and thereafter shall constitute a lien against the land on which the violation exists and upon any other real or personal property owned by the violator; and it may be enforced in the same manner as a court judgment by the sheriffs of this state, including levy against the personal property, but shall not be deemed to be a court judgment except for enforcement purposes. After six (6) months from the filing of any such lien which remains unpaid, the code enforcement board may authorize the city attorney to foreclose on the lien. No lien created pursuant to the provisions of this section may be foreclosed on real property which is a homestead under Section 4, Article X, of the State Constitution. 
24.80. - Duration of lien. 
    No lien provided under this section shall continue for a period longer than five (5) years after the certified copy of an order imposing a fine has been recorded, unless within that time an action to foreclose on the lien is commenced in a court of competent jurisdiction. The continuation of the lien effected by the commencement of the action shall not be good against credits or subsequent purchasers for valuable consideration without notice, unless a notice of lis pendens is recorded. 
24.85. - Appeals. 
    An aggrieved party, including the city council, may appeal a final administrative order of the code enforcement board to the circuit court. Such an appeal shall not be a hearing de novo, but shall be limited to appellate review of the record created before the code enforcement board. An appeal shall be filed within thirty (30) days of the execution of the order to be appealed. 
24.90. - Notices. 
(a)  All notices required by this section shall be provided to the alleged violator by certified mail, return receipt requested; by hand delivery by the sheriff or other law enforcement officer, code inspector or other person designated by the City Council; or by leaving the notice at the violator's usual place of residence with some person of his family above fifteen (15) years of age and informing such person of the contents of the notice. 
(b)  In addition to providing notice as set forth in paragraph (a), at the option of the code enforcement board, notice may also be served by publication or posting, as follows: 
(1)  Such notice shall be published once during each week for four (4) consecutive weeks (four (4) publications being sufficient) in a newspaper of general circulation in Brevard County. The newspaper shall meet such requirements as are prescribed under Chapter 50, Florida Statutes, for legal and official advertisements. Proof of publication shall be made as provided in Section 50.041 and 50.051, Florida Statutes. 
(2)  If there is no newspaper of general circulation in Brevard County, three (3) copies of such notice shall be posted for at least twenty-eight (28) days in three (3) different and conspicuous places in the county, one of which shall be at the front door of the courthouse in said county. Proof of posting shall be by affidavit of the person posting the notice, which affidavit shall include a copy of the notice posted and the date and places of its posting. 
(3)  Notice by publication or posting may run concurrently with, or may follow, an attempt or attempts to provide notice by hand delivery or by mail as required under paragraph (a). 
(c)  Evidence that an attempt has been made to hand deliver or mail notice as provided in paragraph (a), together with proof of publication or posting as provided in paragraph (b), shall be sufficient to show that the notice requirements of this section have been met, without regard to whether or not the alleged violator actually received such notice. 
24.95. - Provisions of section supplemental. 
    It is the legislative intent of the city council in enacting this section to provide any additional or supplemental means of obtaining compliance with city codes and ordinances. Nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the City of Rockledge from enforcing its codes and ordinances by any other means provided by law. 
SECTION 25.00. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION 

25.10. - Findings. 
(a)  Whereas, there are located within the City of Rockledge, which is the oldest incorporated city in Brevard County, certain buildings, districts, and sites, both public and private, which are reminders of eras, events, and persons important in local history, and which are unique to the city and its neighborhoods, and that provide present and future generations with examples of the physical surroundings in which past generations lived; and 
(b)  Whereas, such historic resources contribute to the health, safety, welfare, and prosperity of the City of Rockledge by enhancing the cultural environment for residents, tourists, and visitors; and 
(c)  Whereas, the preservation of these resources will expand the educational and cultural opportunity available within the City of Rockledge and for its residents; and 
(d)  Whereas, the City Council of the City of Rockledge has adopted a comprehensive plan recommending protection of designated historic resources to the extent that said city council deems appropriate in the premises; and 
(e)  Whereas, the City of Rockledge has engaged the professional services of Historic Property Associates, Inc., as a consulting firm to aid the city in the preparation and adoption of an appropriate historic preservation ordinance, and the Rockledge Planning Commission has held two well advertised public hearings on a proposed historic preservation ordinance prepared by said consulting firm, and said planning commission has submitted its recommendations to the Rockledge City Council; and 
(f)  Whereas, the recommendations of the Rockledge Planning Commission, supported by the great weight and tide of public sentiment in the City of Rockledge, indicates to the Rockledge City Council that the overwhelming majority of Rockledge citizens are opposed to mandatory and compulsory regulations and restrictions for the protection and preservation of historic properties and resources, but favor encouragement of voluntary participation by property owners in the designation and preservation of historic properties and resources; and 
(g)  Whereas, it is the conclusion of the Rockledge City Council that the protection of significant historic resources in the City of Rockledge will be adequately and appropriately achieved through voluntary action and participation on the part of individual owners of historic structures and resources within the city, without mandatory and compulsory compliance requirements; and 
(h)  Whereas, the Rockledge City Council hereby determines that the provisions of this section are consistent and in compliance with the provisions of the Rockledge Comprehensive Plan pertaining to the development and enactment of an historic preservation ordinance. 
(i)  Therefore, the Rockledge City Council deems it to be in the public interest, and for a valid public purpose, to enact the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.15. - Purpose. 
(a)  This ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Ordinance." 
(b)  It is hereby declared that as a matter of public policy the protection, enhancement, and preservation of historic resources are in the interests of the health, prosperity, and welfare of the people of the City of Rockledge. Therefore, this section is intended to: 
(1)  Effect and accomplish the protection, enhancement, and perpetuation of buildings, improvements, landscape features, and archaeological resources of sites and districts that represent distinctive elements of the city's historical, cultural, archaeological, aesthetic, and architectural heritage through educational means designed to encourage, inspire and promote public awareness and appreciation of the value of such heritage and the need for the voluntary preservation of historic properties. 
(2)  Safeguard the city's historical, cultural, archaeological, and architectural heritage, as embodied and reflected in individual historic buildings, sites, and districts through public enlightenment of the value of preserving historical resources. 
(3)  Foster civic pride through neighborhood conservation; 
(4)  Protect and enhance the city's attraction to visitors and residents and thereby stimulate its economic potential; 
(5)  Stabilize and improve property values in neighborhoods and throughout the City; 
(6)  Promote the use of individual sites and districts for the education, pleasure, and welfare of the people of the City of Rockledge; and 
(7)  Protect the rights of property ownership that are extended by federal, state, and municipal law and regulation. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.20. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases in this section shall be interpreted so as to give them the same meaning as they have in common usage and so as to give this section its most reasonable application. 
(1)  Archaeological site: A location that has yielded or may yield information on history or prehistory. An archaeological site contains physical remains of the past. An archaeological site may be found within archaeological zones, historic sites, or historic districts. 
(2)  Archaeological zone: A geographically defined area, designated pursuant to this section, which may reasonably be expected to yield information on local history or prehistory based upon broad prehistoric or historic settlement patterns. 
(3)  Building: an edifice created to shelter any form of human activity. This may refer to a house, barn, garage, church, hotel, or similar building. Buildings may refer to a historically or architecturally related complex, such as a house, jail, or barn. 
(4)  Certificate of approval: A certificate issued by the City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board indicating its approval of plans for major alteration, construction, removal, or demolition of a landmark or of a building within a historic district. 
(5)  Contributing building: A building in a historic district that contributes to the district's historical significance through location, design, setting, materials, workmanship, feeling and association, and which shall be afforded the same consideration as landmarks. 
(6)  Demolition: the complete or constructive removal of a building or any substantial part thereof when same will not be relocated to a new site and when same requires the issuance of a demolition permit. 
(7)  District: A geographically definable area, urban or rural, possessing a significant concentration, linkage, or continuity of sites, buildings, objects, or area, which are united by past events or aesthetically by plan or physical development. A district also may be comprised of individual resources which are separated geographically but are thematically linked by association or history. 
(8)  Economic hardship: A condition resulting from failure to issue a certificate of approval, inflicting excessive financial burden upon the owner and amounting to the taking of the owner's property without just compensation. 
(9)  Historic preservation board: A board of citizens created by this section as described in Section 25.25 and referred to in this section as the "board." 
(10)  Historic property or historic resource: Any prehistoric or historic district, site, building, object, or other real or personal property of historical, architectural, or archaeological value, relating to the history, government, and culture of the City of Rockledge or the State of Florida. The historic property or historic resource must be specifically designated as such under ordinance by the City of Rockledge. 
(11)  Historic site: As designated under ordinance by the City of Rockledge, a single lot or portion of a lot containing an improvement, landscape feature, or archaeological site, or a historically related complex of improvements, landscape features or archaeological sites that may yield information on history or prehistory. 
(12)  Landmark: A building, object, site or structure of the highest historical, cultural, architectural, or archaeological importance and whose demolition or destruction would constitute an irreplaceable loss to the quality and character of the City of Rockledge. The property on which these are located shall be considered historic districts as defined in this section. 
(13)  Major alteration: Any significant construction or change to the exterior of a building, historic site, or historic object. Alteration shall not include ordinary repair and maintenance that does not require a building permit. 
(14)  Non-contributing building: A building, object, or site that neither adds to nor detracts from the sense of time and place and historical development of a historic district created under ordinance by the City of Rockledge. 
(15)  Object: A material thing of functional, aesthetic, cultural, historical, or scientific value that may be by nature or design, movable, yet related to a specific setting or environment. 
(16)  Ordinary repairs or maintenance: Work done to prevent deterioration of a building or decay of or damage to a building or any part hereof by restoring the building as nearly as practicable to its condition prior to such deterioration, decay, or damage. Under the provisions of this section, ordinary repairs or maintenance shall apply only to the visible exterior of a building. 
(17)  Owner of record: The individual listed on the current tax rolls of the Brevard County Property Appraiser as the title holder of a specific property located in the City of Rockledge. 
(18)  Petition for designation: A petition or application submitted to the City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board requesting designation by city resolution of a building, building site, district, or archaeological zone as historically or archaeologically significant. 
(19)  Preservation: The identification, evaluation, recordation, documentation, analysis, recovery, interpretation, curation, acquisition, protection, management, rehabilitation, restoration, stabilization, maintenance, or reconstruction of historic properties. 
(20)  Reconstruction: The authentic reproduction of a building or site that once existed, but disappeared or was demolished. 
(21)  Rehabilitation: The act or process of returning a property to a state of utility through repair or alteration which makes possible an efficient contemporary use while preserving those portions or features of the property that are significant to its historical, architectural, and cultural values. 
(22)  Relocation: The moving of a building from its existing location to a new location. 
(23)  Restoration: The creation of an authentic reproduction beginning with existing parts of an original object or building. 
(24)  Site: The location of an event, activity, building, structure, or archaeological resource where the significance of the location and any archaeological remains outweigh the significance of any existing structures. 
(25)  Structure: A work, constructed by man, made up of interdependent and interrelated parts in a pattern of organization. It may be an engineering project large in scale, such as a bridge, wall, gate, or building, or small in scale, such as a monument or fountain. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.25. - Rockledge Historic Preservation Board. 
(a)  Establishment and appointments. There is hereby created the City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board. The board shall consist of nine (9) members. In the first instance, three (3) shall be appointed for one year, three (3) for two (2) years, and three (3) for three (3) years. Thereafter, all members shall be appointed for two (2) years. The city council shall appoint a member to fill a vacancy occurring on the board for the remainder of the unexpired term, at the earliest possible date. Upon designation of a historic district, the city council shall thereafter give priority consideration to appointment to the board of property owners from within the district or districts in both the original appointments to said board as well as in filling any vacancies that may occur. Members shall be eligible for reappointment and shall hold office until their successors have been duly appointed and qualified. The board shall serve in an advisory capacity to the city council and shall exercise its responsibilities under the direct jurisdiction and legislative control of the city council. 
(b)  Requirements for membership. Each member of the board shall be a resident of the City of Rockledge and shall hold office only for so long as he or she remains a resident and registered voter of the City of Rockledge, Florida. The city council shall make appointments to the board with due regard for their professional qualifications and for the need to achieve a balance among diverse interests within the city in order to encourage historic preservation actions that protect the interests of property owners. To that end, the city council shall consider candidates for the board who are architects, historians, historic archaeologists, real estate agents, real property appraisers, planners, engineers, building contractors, lawyers, landscape architects, or other individuals from the business, financial, and other segments of the community who, by virtue of profession or business, have demonstrated concern for or practical experience in historic preservation. Members of the board shall serve without compensation but shall be reimbursed for necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their official duties, as shall be determined and approved by the city council. A member of the board may be removed from office only by a majority vote of the entire membership of the city council. should a member of the board fail to attend three (3) consecutive meetings, the chairman of the board shall certify the same to the city council. Upon such certification the member shall be deemed to have been removed and the city council shall fill the vacancy by appointment. 
(c)  Officers and staff. The members of the board shall select a chairman and other such officers as may be deemed necessary or advisable who shall serve at the pleasure of the board. The building department shall provide administrative and staff support for the board. Minutes of each board meeting shall be kept and prepared under the supervision and direction of the building official or his designee, and copies of such minutes shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(d)  Rules and regulations. The board shall make and prescribe such rules and regulations necessary and appropriate for the proper administration and enforcement of the provisions of this section. Such rules and regulations shall conform to the provisions of this section and shall not conflict with the Constitution and general laws of the State of Florida, and shall govern and control procedures, meetings, and actions of the board. No such rules and regulations shall become effective until a public meeting has been held upon the proposed rules and regulations, and any amendments or modifications thereto, and the same have been approved by the city council and filed with the clerk of the city council. Upon approval of the city council, such rules and regulations shall have the force and effect of law within the City of Rockledge, Florida. The board shall prescribe forms for use by applicants in compliance with the provisions of this section. In the proper discharge of its duties, the board may authorize any of its members to perform general functions to acquire information when deemed necessary, convenient, or appropriate by a majority of the board. 
(e)  Powers and duties. The City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board shall have the following powers and duties, subject to the approval of the city council: 
(1)  Adopt its own procedural regulations. 
(2)  Conduct an ongoing survey to identify historically, architecturally, and archaeologically significant properties, buildings, and areas that exemplify the cultural, social, economic, political, or architectural history of the nation, state, or city. 
(3)  Recommend to the city council the designation of individual sites, districts, and archaeological zones that are historically or archaeologically significant, and as to which the property owner or owners have applied for and consented to such designation. 
(4)  Encourage the owners of individual sites, districts, and archaeological zones that are historically or archaeologically significant to make proper application for the designation thereof as such. 
(5)  Develop for approval by the city council design guidelines for alterations to landmarks or buildings within historic districts. 
(6)  Issue or deny certificates of approval in accordance with the terms of this section and thereby regulate major alterations, new construction, relocation, and demolitions affecting designated properties. 
(7)  Recommend proposed amendments to the Zoning and building codes and to the comprehensive plan for the City of Rockledge. 
(8)  Recommend for approval by the city council guidelines and criteria for issuance of certificates of approval. 
(9)  Promote public awareness of historical and archaeological preservation. 
(10)  To implement the authority of this section and fulfill the tasks set forth for this board by the city council in this and other ordinances. 
(11)  Maintain records of the board's actions and decisions. 
(12)  Assist citizens and groups in nominating landmark buildings, archaeological sites, and historic districts to the National Register of Historic Places. 
(13)  Keep a register of all landmarks, archaeological sites, historic districts, and contributing buildings within historic districts. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.30. - Designation of historic districts, landmarks, and sites. 
(a)  Criteria for designation. With the property owner's written consent, the board shall have authority to recommend to the city council the designation of areas, places, buildings, landscape features, archaeological sites, and other improvements or physical features, as individual sites, districts, or archaeological zones that: 
(1)  Are significant to the City of Rockledge's history, architecture, archaeology, or culture, and possess an integrity of location, design, setting, materials, workmanship, or association; or 
(2)  Are associated with distinctive elements of the social, political, economic, scientific, religious, prehistoric, and architectural history of the City of Rockledge, the state, or the nation; or 
(3)  Are identified with a person or persons who significantly contributed to the culture and development of the City of Rockledge; or 
(4)  Embody the distinctive characteristics of a type, period, style, or method of construction or work of a master; or that possess high artistic value; or 
(5)  Have yielded or are likely to yield information about the prehistory or history of the City of Rockledge; or 
(6)  Are listed in the National Register of Historic Places. Certain properties, which include cemeteries, birthplaces, properties owned by religious institutions or used for religious purposes, buildings that have been removed from their original locations, properties commemorative in nature, and properties that have achieved significance within the last fifty years, will not normally be considered for designation. Such properties will qualify, however, if they are integral parts of districts that do meet the criteria or if they fall within the following categories: 
(7)  A religious property deriving primary significance from architectural or artistic distinction of historical importance. 
(8)  A building removed from its location but which is primarily significant for architectural value, or is the surviving building most importantly associated with a historic event or person. 
(9)  A birthplace or grave of a historical figure of outstanding importance if there is no other appropriate site or building directly associated with that figure's productive life. 
(10)  A cemetery that derives its primary significance from graves of persons of transcendent importance, from age, distinctive design features, or from association with historic events. 
(11)  A property primarily commemorative in intent if design, age, tradition or symbolic value has invested it with its own historical significance. 
(12)  A property or district achieving significance within the past fifty years if it is of exceptional importance. 
(b)  Procedures for petition of designation. The following procedure shall apply in the petitioning for designation of buildings, districts or sites pursuant to this section: Petition for designation shall be made to the City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board on a form prepared by it and may be initiated only upon verified application in writing by the owner(s) of the property to be designated or their authorized agents. The board shall hold a public meeting on the petition and shall notify the property owner by certified mail at least ten (10) days in advance of the meeting. The petition for designation shall contain the following: 
(1)  The historical, cultural, architectural, and archaeological significance of the property or properties recommended for designation; 
(2)  A drawing or survey identifying all buildings and current setbacks from property lines within a proposed district or site, and classifying each building as contributing or non-contributing, with an explanation of the criteria used in developing the classification; 
(3)  A legal description of the boundaries of the site, building, district, or archaeological zone recommended for designation, an explanation of the reasons for those boundaries, and a map illustrating the boundaries. A map illustrating a historic district shall show contributing and non-contributing properties; 
(4)  Photographic documentation of individual sites and buildings recommended for designation. 
(c)  Notification. Upon preliminary approval by the board of a petition for designation, notice of the proposed designation shall be sent by mail to the owner(s) of record of the property proposed for designation and to each owner of record of property in a proposed district. The notice shall describe the property proposed for designation, shall explain the effect of said designation upon the property or structure, and shall announce a public meeting of the City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board to further consider such petition for designation, to be held within thirty (30) days after mailing of such notice. Unless a property owner consents in writing to said designation at the conclusion of, or after, said public meeting, the board shall not approve the proposed designation and shall take no positive action on recommending it to the city council. 
(d)  Recommendation. Upon approval of the proposed designation and with the written consent of the property owner, the board may recommend the designation to the city council for approval by resolution. 
(e)  Public meeting. The City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board shall hold a public meeting on petitions for designation. At such public meeting, any person may present testimony or documentary evidence concerning the significance of the property under consideration. At the close of the public meeting the board shall vote to recommend in favor of the proposed designation to the city council or shall vote against the proposed designation. 
    If the board votes to recommend in favor of the proposed designation, such action will be reported to the city council by way of official minutes accompanied by a copy of the property owners written consent, and shall be considered by city council at the next regularly scheduled meeting date or not more than sixty (60) days following action by the board. If the board votes against the proposed designation, the decision of the board shall be final and the property shall not be designated by the city council. The board shall take final action either to recommend in favor of the proposed designation or to deny the proposed designation within six (6) months after the petition for designation is filed. 
(f)  Procedures for designation by resolution. The following procedures shall apply to the designation by resolution of the Rockledge City Council of a historic site, building, district, or archaeological zone: 
(1)  After receiving a report from the chairman of the City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board as provided in Section 4(D), the city council may direct the preparation of a resolution providing for the recommended designation. Alternatively, the city council may act to deny the proposed designation without further meeting. The city council shall follow normal procedures of public meeting in the adoption of a resolution providing for such historic designation. The owner or owners of property proposed for designation shall be given written notification, by mail, of the aforesaid public meeting a minimum of ten (10) days before the public meeting. 
(2)  After final adoption of a designation resolution by the city council, buildings, sites, districts, and archaeological zones shall remain designated as historically or archaeologically significant unless such designation is removed by subsequent resolution of the city council in accordance with Section 4(H) of this section. 
(3)  The resolution providing for designation of a building as historically significant shall pertain to the building and not to the site upon which the building is located. The designation resolution may, however, contain conditions to ensure the preservation of the setting in which the building exists if the setting was a significant consideration in the designation of the building. 
(g)  Recording of designated property. The building department shall maintain a historic sites map which shall show the location of sites and buildings designated as landmarks and shall show the boundaries of designated historic districts. Within such districts, the map shall identify contributing and non-contributing buildings. 
(h)  Procedures for removal of designation. The city council may remove the historic or archaeological designation from a building or site by resolution, provided that: 
(1)  The subject property no longer meets applicable criteria for designation found in Section 4(A). 
(2)  Additional information indicates that the subject property does not meet the applicable criteria for designation found in Section 4(A). 
(3)  An error in professional judgment was made in the petition for designation of the subject property. 
(4)  A procedural error occurred in the original designation process. 
(5)  It has been determined by the city council that the property owner has violated a term or condition of a certificate of approval or of a special exception pertaining to the designated property. 
(6)  The owner(s) of the designated property files a written request for removal of the property from designation. 
(i)  Notification of designation action. Within forty-five (45) days of enactment of a designation resolution, the city council shall file with the Brevard County Clerk of Court and property appraiser a certified copy of the designation resolution and a summary explanation of the effect of such designation. Such notification will also be sent to the owner or owners of property designated as landmarks or located within the boundaries of designated historic districts. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.35. - Certificate of approval. 
(a)  Actions requiring a certificate of approval. A certificate of approval shall be required before the following actions affecting a historic landmark or a property in a historic district may be undertaken: 
(1)  Construction and reconstruction. 
(2)  Restoration, rehabilitation, and relocation. 
(3)  Stabilization. 
(4)  Demolition of a building over sixty-five (65) years old. 
(5)  Major alteration. 
(b)  Exterior only. The provisions of Section 25.35 shall apply only to the visible exterior portions of a building that are visible from the public right-of-way and shall in no case apply to the interior of a building. 
(c)  Method of application. The application shall be made on a form provided by the building department and shall be accompanied by such plans, drawings, materials, or photographs as deemed appropriate to describe the proposed alteration and enable the building official to visualize the effect of the proposed alteration on the property and adjacent buildings and streetscapes. If such application involves a designated archaeological site the applicant shall provide full plans and specifications of work that may affect the surface and subsurface of the archaeological site. 
(1)  If the proposed work and materials employed in it, as described in the application, will not, in the building official's opinion, significantly change the exterior appearance of the building, the building official may issue a building permit without a certificate of approval. 
(2)  The appropriate departments of city government shall refer all permits for land or building alteration activity affecting property designated as historically or archaeologically significant pursuant to this ordinance to the building department for a determination of whether a certificate of approval is required. 
(3)  The building department shall develop procedures and forms for making application for a certificate of approval. 
(d)  Standards for review. In considering whether to recommend approval or disapproval of an application for a certificate of approval, the board shall be guided by its adopted standards and the standards of the secretary of the interior. The board shall adopt and may from time to time amend its adopted standards by which applications for a certificate of approval are to be measured and evaluated. In adopting its guidelines and standards, it shall be the intent of the board to promote maintenance, restoration, adaptive reuses appropriate to the property, and compatible contemporary designs that are harmonious with the exterior and landscape features of neighboring buildings, sites, and streetscapes. The guidelines and standards shall also serve as criteria for the board to make decisions regarding applications for certificates of approval. The board shall make a copy of its adopted standards and guidelines available through the appropriate office of city government. In reviewing an application for certificate of approval and in adopting its own standards and guidelines, the board shall consider the following architectural criteria: 
(1)  Building height. The height of any proposed alteration or new construction should be visually compatible with adjacent properties. 
(2)  Proportion of openings. The width and height of windows, doors, and entries should be visually compatible with the style and character of those found in surrounding buildings. 
(3)  Relationship of masses and spaces. The relationship of a building within a historic district to the open space between it and adjoining buildings should be visually compatible to the district. 
(4)  Roof shape. The shape of the roof should be compatible with the shape and type of roof found on neighboring buildings in the historic district. 
(5)  Scale. The size and mass (or shape) of the building after alteration or construction should be compatible with the character of surrounding buildings. 
(6)  Landscaping. Landscaping should be compatible with the architectural character and appearance of the historic district in which the landscaping occurs. 
(7)  Architectural details. Architectural details, including color, materials, and texture, should be treated so as to make the building compatible in its original architectural style and character and to preserve or enhance the architectural style and character of the historic district in which it is located. 
(e)  Determination by the board. Based on the guidelines and standards for preservation, the designation report, a complete application for certificate of approval, additional plans, drawings, or photographs that describe the proposed major alteration, and any other guidelines the board may deem necessary, the board shall, within thirty (30) days from the date a complete application has been filed, approve or deny the application for a certificate of approval by the owner or owners of a designated property or property within a designated district. The findings of the board shall be mailed to the applicant within seven (7) days of the board decision and shall be accompanied by a certificate of approval in case of an approval. 
(f)  Denial of a certificate of approval. A denial of a certificate of approval shall be accompanied by a statement of the reason(s) for such denial. The board shall make recommendations to the applicant concerning changes, if any, in the proposed action that would cause the board to reconsider its denial and shall confer with the applicant and attempt to resolve as quickly as possible the differences between the owner and the board. The applicant may resubmit an amended application or reapply for a building or demolition permit that takes into consideration the recommendations of the board; or the applicant may appeal the decision of the board to the city council, as provided for in Section 25.75 of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.40. - Archaeological site review. 
    If the Rockledge City Council shall hereafter deem it in the best interests of the city that a survey be conducted by a professionally qualified archaeologist to determine the existence of archaeological sites or zones within the city, and if such survey discloses the existence of any such archaeological sites or zones, the same shall be defined on an archaeological zone map to be maintained by the building department. The following procedures shall apply before a permit is issued for excavation, landscaping, or other below-grade activity requiring such a permit: 
(1)  A project undertaken within an archaeological zone shall require a preliminary study made by a qualified archaeologist to determine the effect that any such project may have on the site. Where no effect or adverse effect is found, the project shall proceed following other procedures set forth in the City Code. Where an effect or adverse effect is found, the building department shall refer the information to the Rockledge Historic Preservation Board at the board's next regularly scheduled meeting with a recommendation for treatment. In making its recommendation, the board shall consider measures to avoid, reduce, or mitigate the effect on cultural or historic sites while taking into consideration the current needs of the property owner and reasonable methods for carrying out the recommended plan. 
(2)  A project undertaken in an area not defined as an archaeological zone does not require review by a qualified archaeologist before a permit is issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.45. - Permit for demolition. 
    When passing upon a certificate of approval for the issuance of a permit for demolition of a building or structure that is designated as a historic building or structure, the City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board shall consider the following criteria: 
(1)  The historic or architectural significance of the building. 
(2)  The importance of the building to the ambiance of a district, if applicable. 
(3)  The difficulty or impossibility of reproducing such a building because of its design, texture, material, detail, or unique location. 
(4)  Whether the building is one of the last remaining examples of its kind in the neighborhood or in the city. 
(5)  The future utilization of the site. 
(6)  Whether reasonable measures can be taken to save the building. 
(7)  Whether the building is capable of earning a reasonable economic return on its value and whether the perpetuation of the building, considering its physical condition, its located and the anticipated expense of rehabilitation would be economically feasible. 
(8)  Whether the condition of the building is deteriorated or damaged to an extent that its rehabilitation is not economically feasible. 
(9)  Whether denial of a demolition permit will present economic hardship to the owner of the property. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.50. - Maintenance and repair of landmarks, landmark sites and property in historic districts. 
(a)  Every owner of a designated landmark, designated landmark site, or property in a designated historic district, shall keep in good repair: 
(1)  All of the exterior portions of such buildings. 
(2)  All interior portions thereof which, if not so maintained, may cause such buildings to deteriorate or to become damaged or otherwise to fall into a state of disrepair. 
(3)  The archaeological integrity of the site, if the property is designated as a historic site by virtue of its archaeological significance. 
(b)  The board may refer violations of this section to the building official for enforcement proceedings on any building designated under this chapter to the end that such a building or buildings shall be preserved in accordance with the purposes of this chapter. 
(c)  The provisions of this chapter shall be consistent with the provisions of the building code requiring such buildings to be kept in good repair, and the secretary of the interior's standards for rehabilitation. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.55. - Ordinary maintenance. 
(a)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to prevent the ordinary maintenance or repair of any exterior feature of a historic building that does not involve a significant change in its outer appearance or damage the building's historic integrity or character. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall prevent the alteration, construction, reconstruction, repair, or demolition of a designated building on an emergency basis when the appropriate City of Rockledge Building Official or his designee certified in writing that such work is necessary for the purpose of correcting conditions determined to be dangerous to life, health, or property. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.60. - Economic hardship. 
(a)  Application for a certificate of economic hardship shall be made on a form prepared by the board. The board shall schedule a public meeting concerning the application, and any person may testify at the meeting concerning economic hardship. 
(b)  The board may solicit expert testimony or require that the applicant for a certificate of economic hardship make submissions concerning any or all of the following information before it makes a determination of the application: 
(1)  Estimate by the owner of the property of the cost of the proposed construction, alteration, demolition, or removal and an estimate of any additional cost that would be incurred to comply with the recommendations of the board for changes necessary for the issuance of a certificate of approval; 
(2)  Estimated market value of the property in its current condition; 
(3)  In the case of a proposed demolition, an estimate from an architect, developer, engineer, real estate consultant, appraiser, or other real estate professional as to the economic feasibility of rehabilitation or reuse of the existing building on the property; 
(4)  If the property is income-producing, the annual gross income from the property for the previous two years; itemized operating and maintenance expenses for the previous two years; and depreciation deduction and annual cash flow before and after debt service, if any, during the same period; 
(5)  Any appraisals obtained by the owner or applicant in connection with the purpose, financing, or ownership of the property; 
(6)  Assessed value of the property according to the two most recent assessments; 
(7)  Real estate taxes for the previous two years; 
(8)  Form of ownership or operation of the property, whether sole proprietorship, for-profit or not-for-profit corporation, limited partnership, joint venture, or other; or 
(9)  Any other reasonable information considered necessary by the board to a determination as to whether the property does yield or may yield a reasonable return to the owners. 
(c)  The board shall review all the evidence and information required of an applicant for a certificate of economic hardship and make a determination within thirty (30) days of receipt of the application whether the denial of a certificate of approval has deprived, or will deprive, the owner of the property of reasonable use of, or economic return on, the property. Written notice of the determination shall be provided in the same manner as required by Section 25.30(c). 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.65. - Incentives for preservation of historically significant buildings. 
    The following incentives shall apply to historically significant properties: 
(1)  Buildings which have been designated as historically significant pursuant to this article shall be exempt from the provisions of the zoning code concerning limitations upon the repair of nonconforming buildings. 
(2)  Buildings located in a district which has been designated as a historic district pursuant to this article shall be exempt from the provisions of the zoning code concerning limitations upon the repair of nonconforming buildings, provided that such buildings have been classified as contributing. 
(3)  Buildings designated as historic buildings or landmarks, and buildings which are located in a designated historic district and which have been classified as contributing, shall qualify for the exemption accorded to special historic buildings under the appropriate sections of the Southern Standard Building Code and accumulated revisions, provided that the building meets all other requirements of that section to the satisfaction of the City of Rockledge Building Official. This exemption shall be applied only to buildings described in this section. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.70. - Owner's consent required. 
    Anything in this section to the contrary notwithstanding, no piece, parcel or tract of land in the City of Rockledge shall be designated, classified, categorized nor deemed to be a landmark, historic site, historic property, historic resource or archaeological site, nor be included as part of any historic district or archaeological zone, unless all owners of the fee simple title to any such piece, parcel or tract of land shall first make application for such designation or inclusion in writing, by a verified petition signed by such owner or owners and filed with the Rockledge Historical Preservation Board, and also consent in writing to such designation or inclusion after the public meeting on said petition, as provided in Subsections 25.30(B) and 25.30(C). 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.75. - Appeals. 
    Within thirty (30) days of the written decision of the board, an aggrieved party may appeal the decision by filing a written notice of appeal with the clerk of the city council. The notice of appeal shall state the decision which is being appealed, the grounds for the appeal, and a brief summary of the relief which is sought. Within thirty (30) days of the filing of the appeal or the first scheduled meeting of the city council, whichever is later in time, the city council shall conduct a public meeting at which time it may affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the board. Nothing contained herein shall preclude the city council from seeking additional information prior to rendering a final decision. The decision of the city council shall be in writing and a copy of the decision shall be forwarded to the board and the appealing party. 
    Within the time prescribed by the appropriate Florida Rules of Appellate Procedure, a party aggrieved by a decision of the Rockledge City Council may appeal an adverse decision to the Circuit Court in and for Brevard County, Florida. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
25.80. - Fees and penalties. 
    The City of Rockledge Historic Preservation Board may recommend for approval by the city council an appropriate schedule of reasonable processing fees for the review of applications for designation, certificates of approval, and certificates of economic hardship. Any person who undertakes or causes a major alteration, construction, demolition, or removal of any designated landmark or property within a designated historic district shall require a certificate of approval or a certificate of economic hardship. Failure to comply with the provisions of this section shall be considered a violation of Rockledge Code of Ordinances and be enforced under Section 24.60 of the Rockledge Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 1030-92, §§ 1, 2, 2-19-92) 
SECTION 26.00. - DEVELOPMENT REVIEW COMMITTEE (DRC) ESTABLISHMENT AND APPOINTMENTS 
(a)  [Established.] There is hereby created the City of Rockledge Development Review Committee (DRC). Development review committee means a committee formed by the city manager to review site plans, subdivision plats, or other development applications deemed necessary in his/her discretion. At a minimum, the DRC shall consist of a member of the following department/divisions of the city: Building, planning, public works, wastewater, police, and fire. On projects within the designated community redevelopment district, the redevelopment agency director shall be a participating member of the DRC. Other personnel may be added at the city manager's discretion. 
(b)  Officers and procedures. The chairman of the development review committee shall be the planning director/zoning official. The city manager shall appoint a secretary to the development review committee to keep a record of its findings, decisions and recommendations, which shall be maintained in the office of the chairman. The meetings of the development review committee shall be held at the call of the chairman upon receipt of applications for development orders as defined herein, or by the city manager or other department representatives, and/or at such times as the development review committee shall determine. The applicant shall be notified of the day and time of the meetings and shall be present when the project is being discussed. 
(c)  Powers and duties. 
(1)  The development review committee shall have the power to review applications for subdivision plats, site plans, planned development projects, developments of regional impact, and other applications submitted for development order approval which in the opinion of the city manager should be reviewed by the committee. 
(2)  All proposed development order requests, specifically for site plans, planned developments, mixed use developments, rezoning/comprehensive plan amendments, developments of regional impact or other applications deemed appropriate for review by the city manager within the community redevelopment district shall be reviewed by the DRC. 
(3)  Proposed development order requests outside the community redevelopment district may, at the request of the developer, city manager, or other department representative, be submitted to the DRC for review and recommendation. 
(4)  In reviewing such applications, the development review committee shall make a recommendation for approval, denial or approval with conditions, amendments or modifications. 
(5)  The DRC shall transmit recommendations to the appropriate reviewing authority as necessary, including but not limited to, the planning commission and city council. 
(6)  The powers and duties of the development review committee shall include other responsibilities that may be assigned from time to time by the city manger or city council. 
(7)  The DRC shall have final approval authority of all applications for site plans for residential, commercial, or industrial development projects within the community redevelopment district that are on three (3) acres or less, except where bonuses are requested. 
(d)  General considerations by the development review committee. The development review committee has the authority to consider the following in its recommendations: 
(1)  Whether an application and/or a plan is consistent with applicable goals, objectives, policies, standard and proposals in the Comprehensive Plan. 
(2)  Whether all public facilities and services necessary to serve the proposed use shall be available concurrent with the actual impact of the use in question. 
(3)  Whether the established level of service of public facilities necessary to serve the development or phase thereof shall be adversely impacted by the proposed use or activity. 
(4)  Whether the project promotes or furthers special area plans for a district in which it is located. 
(5)  Whether the proposed project is entitled to receive density or height bonuses within the Redevelopment Mixed Use District as proscribed in the land development regulations. 
(6)  Whether the project is compatible with the adjacent surroundings. 
(7)  Whether the proposed project meets the requirements of the land development regulations. 
(e)  Application processing: 
(1)  The city manager shall cause an application form to be created that will outline the required submittal documents. 
(2)  Upon receipt of an application for subdivision plats, site plans, planned development projects, developments of regional impact and other applications submitted for development order approval outside of the community redevelopment district, the city manager, chair, or other department representative, or upon request by the developer shall cause a meeting of the DRC to occur no later than fifteen (15) working days of receipt of the application. For projects within the designated community redevelopment district, a meeting shall be called not later than ten (10) working days of receipt of an application. The results of the review shall be scheduled by the city manager for the planning commission and city council meetings. 
(Ord. No. 1376-2005, § 7, 5-4-05) 

26.01. - Review of eminent domain waivers, exceptions and variances by DRC. 
(a)  Findings of fact. The Rockledge City Council finds that the acquisition of private property by various governmental or public agency entities, so authorized by law through the eminent domain process through trial or negotiations prior thereto, is an extremely costly and burdensome process. Allowing the appropriate city staff, pursuant to established guidelines, procedures and criteria, to grant waivers and exceptions from certain city land development regulations or to apply for variances on behalf of affected property owners, serves a valid public purpose and promotes the general safety and welfare of the citizens and landowners of the city. 
(b)  Intent. It is the intent of this section to establish a fair procedure by which the appropriate city staff can grant waivers and exceptions to city land development, signage, and engineering regulations, or to seek such waivers or variances before the appropriate boards, in order that property owners who have been subjected to the condemnation process have a viable and fair alternative in preventing any adverse impact upon their property as a result of the condemnation process and allow the continued use of their property in a manner similar to its pre-condemnation condition. Further, it is the intent of this section to establish procedures which will reduce the cost of acquisitions of real property needed for public improvements. 
(c)  Authority of development review committee. The DRC, which oversees land development, signs and engineering codes, ordinances, regulations, or resolutions, shall have the authority to grant waivers or exceptions, or to seek variances on behalf of owners of property from applicable codes, ordinances, regulations, or resolutions. The chairman of the DRC shall provide a copy of the determination letter to the city attorney's office if the property is in a condemnation lawsuit, or to the real estate management department in pre-suit negotiations, that the waiver or exception does not adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(d)  Application for waivers, exceptions and variances. 
(1)  The condemning authority, or the landowner, may apply in writing to the DRC for a determination that the granting of the waiver or exception will not result in a condition which adversely affects the health, safety or welfare of the general public. 
(2)  The DRC shall, within thirty (30) days of receipt of the application, issue a signed letter to all parties granting or denying the waiver or exception. 
(3)  If the waiver or exception is denied by the DRC, the owner or condemning authority may apply for, at no cost to the owner, a variance before the board of adjustment. 
(e)  Waivers, exceptions and variances. If, as a result of a governmental taking either by negotiation or condemnation, existing lots, parcels, structures, or uses of land become nonconforming with the provisions of the land development regulations, the following provisions shall apply: 
(1)  Existing characteristics of use which become nonconforming or increase in nonconformity as a result of a taking, including, but not limited to, minimum lot size, setbacks, open space, off-street parking, landscape requirements, drainage and retention shall be required to meet code requirements to the greatest extent possible, to the satisfaction of the appropriate department manager or his designee. Thereafter, the existing characteristics of use shall be deemed conforming. Any further expansion or enlargement thereof shall be in accordance with all applicable code requirements. 
(2)  In granting any waiver or exception to code requirements, the DRC shall: 
a.  Determine that the requested exception or waiver will not adversely affect visual, safety, aesthetic or environmental concerns of neighboring properties. 
b.  Determine that the requested exception or waiver shall not adversely affect the safety of pedestrians or operators of motor vehicles. 
c.  Preserve code-required off-street parking requirements to the greatest extent practicable. The reconfiguration, reduction, or removal of landscape and/or open space requirements may be considered to preserve off-street parking. 
(3)  If any legally existing structures (principal or accessory) or vehicular use area must be relocated as a direct result of the governmental taking, or as a result of safety concerns, if allowed to remain after the taking, then the appropriate department manager, or his designee, and the building official may allow the relocation of the structure on the remaining property, so as to comply with all applicable regulations to the greatest extent practicable, as determined by the appropriate department manager or designee. If the relocation results in substandard characteristics of use, it shall be deemed thereafter to be conforming. Any future expansion or enlargement thereof shall be in accordance with all applicable code requirements. 
(4)  Legally existing structures (principal or accessory) or vehicular use areas that become nonconforming or increase in nonconformity according to subsection (1), which are thereafter damaged or destroyed, other than by voluntary demolition, to an extent of more than seventy-five (75) percent of assessed value at the time of destruction can be restored but only to pre-destruction condition. Any expansion or enlargement that does not increase the nonconformity of a characteristic of use shall be permitted in accordance with all applicable code requirements. Where expansion or enlargement increases the nonconformity of a characteristic of use, relief from appropriate city board(s) is necessary. 
(5)  If the structure to be relocated harbors a nonconforming use, DRC may permit the relocation pursuant to this section, if it is determined that public harm will not result. 
(6)  Where part of a principal structure is taken, the reconstruction of the taken structure (same size and use) may be permitted. The reconstruction must meet code to the greatest extent possible, to the satisfaction of the majority of the DRC. The reconstructed structure shall thereafter be deemed conforming. 
(7)  Any alterations, repairs or rehabilitation work necessitated by a governmental or public agency acquisition or condemnation of real property may be made to any existing structure, building, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system without requiring the building, structure, plumbing, electrical, mechanical or gas system to comply with all the requirements of the technical codes, provided that the alteration, repair or rehabilitation work conforms to the requirements of the technical codes for new construction. The DRC shall determine the extent to which the existing system shall be made to conform to the requirements of the technical codes for new construction. 
(f)  Signs. A sign which is located on a parcel that is subject to condemnation action by a governmental or public agency may be allowed to be relocated on the remaining portion of the parcel in accordance with the following: 
(1)  The sign is to be relocated on the remaining parcel in such a manner as to meet the setback and distance separation requirements. If, due to the size and/or configuration of the remaining parcel, setback and distance separation requirements cannot be met, subject to the discretion of the DRC, the sign may be relocated so as to comply with such regulations to the greatest extent practicable as determined by the DRC. 
(2)  Any existing nonconformity of a sign, other than setback or distance separation, shall not be increased upon relocation. 
(3)  If the sign to be relocated is a nonconforming sign, upon proof submitted by the applicant and subject to the determination by the DRC that public harm would not occur, then such sign may be relocated pursuant to this subsection. Such sign shall be considered conforming upon the granting of a waiver or variance. 
(g)  Authority for staff to testify at judicial proceedings on the likelihood of variances. 
(1)  The chairman of the development review committee is hereby authorized to testify in judicial proceedings as to the likelihood of whether a variance from city's land development regulations would be granted or the reasons the department manager has granted the waiver or exception. 
(2)  In testifying, the department manager or his designee is specifically authorized to employ the following criteria:
