a.  History of similar variances, waivers or exceptions being granted by the appropriate boards in and for the City of Rockledge, Florida. 
b.  Analysis of why the variance, waiver or exception would not adversely affect surrounding property owners. 
c.  Analysis of the hardship imposed by the condemnation action initiated by the governmental or public agency. 
d.  Analysis of any and all other criteria normally considered by the appropriate boards or departments in granting similar variances, waivers or exceptions and how those criteria relate to the subject and neighboring properties. 
e.  That the granting of a variance, waiver or exception would not adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare. 
(h)  Code violations threatening public health, safety and welfare. 
(1)  The provisions of this section shall not be interpreted to allow for the continued existence of building or other safety code violations that are determined to be an immediate threat to the public health, safety or welfare. 
(2)  The appropriate building officials and inspectors are hereby authorized to take any and all necessary steps to enforce all applicable building and safety codes, even though the subject property is part of a condemnation action. 
(Ord. No. 1549-2010, § 1, 5-19-10) 
Part III - PROCEDURES AND PROCESSES 
SECTION 30.00. - PERMITS/APPROVALS REQUIRED[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 30.00 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. 

30.10. - Legislative approvals required. 
    The following actions require the approval of city council after review and recommendation by the planning and zoning commission: 
(a)  Annexations; 
(b)  Amendments to adopted Goals, Objectives and Policies of the Comprehensive Plan of the City of Rockledge; 
(c)  Amendments to the Future Land Use Map (Land Use Plan Amendment or LUPA); 
(d)  Amendments to the Future Traffic Circulation Map; 
(e)  Zoning or rezoning applications; 
(f)  PUD applications for: 
(1)  Conceptual plan; 
(2)  Preliminary plan and zoning; 
(3)  Final plan and plat; 
(g)  Major/minor subdivision approval for: 
(1)  Conceptual plan (optional); 
(2)  Preliminary plat; 
(3)  Final Plat; 
(h)  Development of any tract, piece or parcel of land consisting of five (5) acres or more of land in a commercial zoning district; 
(i)  The development of any tract, piece or parcel of land consisting of ten (10) or more acres of land in an industrial zoning district; 
(j)  Any structure [which] when completed will have over fifty thousand (50,000) square feet of floor area; 
(k)  Any multi-family residential structure having twenty-five (25) or more units; 
(l)  Mixed use projects within the community redevelopment district; 
(m)  Projects seeking approval for density, floor area ratio and height bonuses in the community redevelopment district; 
(n)  Other actions as may be determined from time to time by resolution or ordinance of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1376-2005, § 1, 5-4-05) 
30.20. - Administrative approvals required. 
    The following activities require approval or issuance of a development order (permit) by the building department, and are under the implementation authority of the building Official: 
(a)  Building permits in compliance with these regulations; 
(b)  Sign permits; 
(c)  Determination of compliance and issuance of a certificate of occupancy (C.O.); 
(d)  Issuance of occupational licenses; 
(e)  Application and collection of fees. 
(Ord. No. 1376-2005, § 2, 5-4-05) 
30.21. - Activities requiring approval. 
    The following activities require approval or issuance of a development order (permit) by the City of Rockledge pursuant to procedures outlined within these land development regulations. They fall under the implementation authority of the city manager, who may delegate them as needed to the planning director/zoning official: 
(a)  Annexation requests; 
(b)  Site plans; 
(c)  Subdivision plats; 
(d)  Planned unit development projects; 
(e)  Mixed-use projects within the redevelopment district; 
(f)  Interpretation of land uses where deemed appropriate; appeals of decisions may be made to the city manager; 
(g)  Determination of consistency with the comprehensive plan and concurrency management system as an individual determination, or as part of the issuance of a development order; 
(h)  Fees shall be determined by resolution of the city council and collected by a designee of the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1376-2005, § 3, 5-4-05) 
30.30. - Permits required. 
    No use of property or substantial change to same, including clearing, grubbing, grading or excavation, shall be commenced, nor shall buildings or other substantial structures be constructed, erected, moved or substantially altered without first obtaining a permit or approval as set forth in Section 30.10 and 30.20 above. 
30.35. - Issuance of building permits. 
    The following requirements must be complied with: 
(A)  Except as otherwise specifically authorized in this Code, no building permit shall be issued for, nor shall any building or structure hereafter be moved, erected, altered, added to or enlarged upon, any lot, tract of parcel of land in the City of Rockledge unless at least twenty-five (25) feet of such lot, tract or parcel of land abuts on a public street, road or easement which has been dedicated to the public or to the City of Rockledge for public road purposes and which has been accepted and specifically declared opened to the public for road and street by resolution of the City Council of the City of Rockledge, except that no such resolution shall be required with respect to the dedicated streets within any duly recorded subdivision. No more than two flag lots shall be located adjacent to each other. The minimum lot width for the narrow extension of a flag lot from the buildable lot area to the right-of-way shall be no less than twenty-five (25) feet. The length and the narrow extension shall not exceed four hundred (400) feet, and will not be included in measuring setbacks or lot area. 
    A building permit may be issued for improvement of a lot, plot, tract or parcel of land which does not abut on a public street, road, alley or easement dedicated and accepted as hereinabove provided, if said lot, plot, tract or parcel of land abuts upon a limited access private street and is located in a planned residential development, subject to the conditions outlined below; and provided, that the limited access private road on those instances meets all the requirements and specifications for paved roadways in the City of Rockledge, Florida. Once the private road is fully constructed and approved, or required surety provided to the Rockledge City Council, a building permit may be issued for construction on said lot, plot, tract or parcel which abuts said approved limited access private road. 
    In order for building permits to be issued for improvement of lots abutting a limited access private street in a planned residential development, the following conditions shall apply: 
(1)  The subdivision shall be a minimum of twenty (20) acres in size. 
(2)  The Rockledge City Council in determining the need for a limited access private street shall consider the following factors: 
(a)  The character and type of development and the adjacent area. 
(b)  Projected traffic flow on such street. 
(c)  Overall density of development of the subdivisions. 
(d)  Geological characteristics of the property and special need for the security of the residents. 
(3)  The Rockledge City Council shall find that the limited access private street, by virtue of its location, length or physical characteristics, would serve no purpose as a public right-of-way and would serve no purpose as a public right-of-way and would not prohibit public access to any parcel of property adjacent to the subdivision or access to any planned public street system in the area. 
(4)  Said limited access private street shall have the required right-of-way as specified in the Rockledge Subdivision Regulations deeded fee simple to a homeowners' association composed of the owners of lots in the subdivision who will be responsible for maintenance of said limited access private street. Furthermore, said street and other public utilities shall be constructed in accordance with the Rockledge Subdivision Regulations having periodic inspections during construction by the city subdivision inspector and a certificate of completion issued by the city subdivision inspector. 
(5)  Homeowners' documents providing for maintenance of the limited access private street by a homeowners' association shall be approved by the Rockledge City Council after receiving recommendations from the city attorney, but this provision for approval by the city council shall not create nor impose any duty upon the city with respect to the continued maintenance of said limited access private street or streets. 
(6)  Public officials, in the performance of their duties, public utilities, and emergency vehicles shall be granted use of said limited access private street at all times. 
(7)  No subdivision having a limited access private street shall have any public streets. 
(8)  The limited access private street, if approved, shall be maintained to city standards. If the limited access private street is ever offered to the city by dedication or otherwise, it shall be required that said street be brought to standards prior to dedication to the city. 
(B)  No building permit shall be issued for any building, structure or use on a lot, plot, tract or parcel in a subdivision unless the public street or road upon which said property abuts shall be constructed to grade height, and unless electric service and approved sanitary sewer system and potable water system are available and installed to the lot, plot, tract or parcel in a subdivision prior to the issuance of the building permit; subject, however, to the following exception, i.e., the foregoing restriction on the issuance of building permits shall be waived by the city in any instance wherein the proposed improvement is to be situate upon a lot, plot, tract or parcel in a subdivision which does not abut on a street, road or easement dedicated to and accepted by the City of Rockledge as described in subsection (A)(7) of this section, provided the stormwater treatment system and the road base and top coat are installed and substantially completed. The building official shall consult with the subdivision inspector before the issuance of any building permit. The builder, owner and developer of the subdivision shall enter into a written agreement with the city, in form and content satisfactory and acceptable to the city, providing as follows: 
(1)  The builder, owner and developer herein referred to collectively as the "applicants" bind themselves and their successors, heirs and assigns not to occupy nor permit any occupancy of the improvements described in the building permit prior to an approved and satisfactory final inspection of the improvements by the city building official and the issuance by the city of a certificate of occupancy. 
(2)  No final inspection or certificate of occupancy shall be requested by the applicants nor granted by the city until the public roads, streets or easements have been accepted by the city's subdivision inspector and a certificate of completion has been issued stating that all improvements have been completed in conformity with the requirements of the city subdivision ordinance and the approved construction plans and specifications. 
(3)  The applicants fully release the city from any and all damages which may ensue or be sustained by applicants, their successors, heirs or assigns, separately and severally, in consequence of the refusal and failure of the city to perform the final inspection and issue a certificate of occupancy prior to completion of the roads, streets, utilities and public improvements aforesaid. 
(4)  The applicants, separately and severally, shall indemnify and agree to hold harmless the city from any and all claims, damages, suits, actions, judgments, costs and expenses, including reasonable attorney's fees, in consequence of the city's failure or refusal to perform said final inspection or issue a certificate of occupancy prior to completion of the roads, streets, utilities and public improvements aforesaid. 
(5)  The applicant shall be limited to two (2) model homes per subdivision, before the issuance of the certificate of completion for the subdivision. 
(C)  No building or structure shall be constructed, altered, repaired, enlarged or moved until a building, plumbing, electrical and/or an HARV permit shall have been obtained from the building official and the appropriate fee paid. 
(D)  Prior to the issuance of a building permit, the building official shall ensure that such construction shall comply with these regulations, or any other applicable law, and may require a certified survey of said property. 
(E)  The acceptance of a building, plumbing, electrical or HARV permit by any person shall be deemed consent to the inspection of said property by any agent of the City of Rockledge at any time in order to ascertain compliance with these regulations, 
(F)  Each application for a building permit shall be accompanied by a plat in duplicate, drawn to scale, showing the actual dimensions of the lot to be built upon, the size, shape and location of the building to be erected and such other information as may be necessary to provide the enforcement of this chapter. 
(G)  A record of such applications and plats shall be kept in the office of the building official. 
(H)  Where application is made to enlarge an existing nonconforming use, the application shall be accompanied by an affidavit giving the description of the premises owned at the date of passage of this section. 
(Ord. No. 1079-94, § 1, 6-15-94; Ord. No. 1186-99, §§ 1, 2, 7-21-99; Ord. No. 1308-2003, § 1, 6-18-03) 
30.40. - Permits applicable to land. 
    All development orders or permits shall be issued in the name of the applicant but shall apply to the land, lot, parcel or site described in said permit, except for the occupational licenses which apply to the individual. 
30.50. - Burden of presenting evidence; burden of persuasion. 
(a)  The burden of presenting a complete application to the permit-issuing body shall be upon the applicant. The building official shall determine if an application is complete before processing same. 
(b)  Once a completed application has been submitted, the burden of presenting evidence that the application should be denied for any reason shall be upon the party or parties urging this position. 
(c)  The burden of persuasion on the issues of whether the development will comply with the requirements of these regulations remains at all times on the applicant. The burden of persuasion on the issue of whether the applicant should be denied, rests on the party or parties urging that the requested permit should be denied. 
SECTION 31.00. - APPLICATION/FORMScustom>[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 31.00 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. 

31.10. - The applicant. 
    Application for a development order or permit approval will be accepted only from persons having the legal authority to take action in accordance with the permit or the development order approval sought. Application should be made by the owner or lessees of property, or their agents, or persons who have contracted to purchase property contingent upon their ability to acquire the necessary permits under this these regulations, or the agents of such persons (who may make application in the name of such owners, lessees, or contract vendees). The Building Official may require an applicant to submit evidence of his authority to submit the application whenever there appears to be a reasonable basis for questioning this authority. The application must also contain a legal description of the property seeking the development order, this may involve lot, block, section, parcel, township and range or a legal description prepared by a title company or surveyor. 
31.11. - Application must be complete. 
    Applications shall be made on forms provided by the Building Department and must be complete, including all plans and attachments required by these regulations, before the Building Official is required to consider said application. The Building Official shall receive all applications and have the authority to determine the completeness of an application based on whether it contains all the information that is necessary for the permit-issuing authority to decide whether or not the development, if completed as proposed, will comply with all of the requirements of these regulations. 
31.12. - Required information and forms. 
    The Building Official shall make every effort to develop application forms, instructional sheets, checklists, or other techniques or devices to assist applicants in understanding the application requirements and the form and type of information that must be submitted. Where a minimal amount of information is necessary to enable the Building Official to determine compliance with these regulations, such as applications for zoning concerning permits to construct single-family or two-family houses, or applications for sign permits, the Building Official shall develop standard forms that will expedite the submission of the necessary plans and other required information. 
31.13. - Reference to standards. 
    Detailed or technical design requirements and construction specifications relating to various types of improvements (streets, sidewalks, etc.) are set forth in the Performance Requirements, Part IV and V and in Part VII, Appendix/Illustration. It is not necessary that the application contain the type of detailed construction drawings that would be necessary to determine compliance with these appendices, so long as the plans provide sufficient information to allow the permit-issuing authority to evaluate the application in the light of the substantive requirements set forth in this text of these regulations. However, whenever these regulations require a certain element of requirements set forth in one or more of these regulations, then no construction work on such element may be commenced until detailed construction drawings have been submitted to and approved by the Building Official. Failure to observe this requirement may result in permit revocation, denial of final subdivision plat approval, or other penalty. 
31.14. - Staff consultation before application. 
(a)  In all circumstances when an application for development is submitted to the city, the applicant is encouraged to arrange for a preliminary staff consultation prior to actual submittal. This may be a simple review of the data and information on the forms provided or a required preliminary conceptual plan review. This action is intended to minimize development planning cost, avoid misunderstandings or misinterpretations and promote compliance with requirements of these regulations. 
31.14.1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this section is to establish procedures and standards for the preparation, review and approval of plans to construct, reconstruct or alter structures in all zoning districts. 
Editor's note- At the direction of the city, former §§ 25-381-25-386 of the Code of Ordinances have been included herein as §§ 31.14.1-31.14.6. 
31.14.2. - Procedures. 
    The plans prepared according to the requirements presented herein shall be submitted to the building official for his review and approval. Plans may be disapproved if they do not meet the intent or the requirements of this section and of these regulations. 
Note- See the editor's note following § 31.14.1. 
31.14.3. - Site plan. 
    A site plan covering the entire tract proposed for ultimate development, indicating existing conditions and development for an additional area including at least three hundred (300) feet from the boundaries of such tract, or such greater distance as may be indicated by the circumstances of the case, shall be submitted to the building official. Before a permit is issued for construction, six (6) copies of the site plan of the area, at a scale no smaller than one inch to one hundred (100) feet, shall be filed with the building official setting forth, identifying and locating the following: 
(a)  A map indicating the property boundary and the proposed or existing lotting and street system. 
(b)  All public and private right-of-way and easement lines located on and adjacent to the property which are proposed to be continued, created, relocated or abandoned. 
(c)  Existing topography with a maximum of one-foot contour point intervals. 
(d)  The location of the proposed buildings, driveways, parking lots and other uses. 
(e)  A description of the uses proposed in sufficient detail to indicate the effects of those uses on producing air pollution, water pollution, fire or safety hazards, or other factors detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the area. 
(f)  Engineering plans or description, prepared and sealed by a professional engineer, for the handling of any problems of the type outlined in subparagraph (e) above, including a designation of sewers to be used and necessary plans for controlling of smoke or other nuisances such as those enumerated in the same above-referenced paragraph. 
(g)  Location and dimension of all curb cuts, driving lanes, off-street parking and loading and/or unloading areas including number of spaces. 
(h)  All walks, malls and other open area. 
(i)  Location of all walls, fences and screen planting. 
(j)  Size, height and orientation of all signs. 
(k)  All existing and proposed water and sanitary sewer lines with plans prepared at a scale no greater than one inch to one hundred (100) feet, sealed by a professional engineer. 
(l)  A drainage plan, prepared and sealed by a professional engineer, of the area showing size and location of each existing and proposed structure, the approximate volume of run-off generated by development of the subject area and the proposed method of managing said water. Provisions shall be included for retention of the first one inch of rainfall on-site and for adequate control of erosion sedimentation, indicating the proposed temporary and permanent control practices and measures. 
(m)  A copy of the restrictive covenants (if any) to be included in the deeds by the developer. 
(n)  Such other information with regard to the development area as may be required by the building official to determine conformance with these regulations. 
Note- See the editor's note following § 31.14.1. 
31.14.4. - Approval process. 
(a)  Except with respect to the developments and structures described in paragraph (b) hereof, the building official shall approve, or approve subject to conditions, or reject such plans. All development and/or site plans approved shall be binding upon the applicants, their successors and assigns, and shall limit the development of all conditions and limitations established in such plans. All unauthorized deviation from the approved site plan shall be deemed a violation of these regulations. Changes from the approved site plan shall be processed for approval in the same manner as the original approval. Any existing use of land or building that fails to meet the requirements of these regulations shall be considered to be nonconforming and shall be controlled by Section 60.05. 
(b)  With respect to the following described developments of land or erection of structures no building permit or development order shall be issued by the city until after the Rockledge Building Official has transmitted the required site plan and his recommendations with respect thereto to the Rockledge Planning Commission for said commission's study and recommendations to the city council with respect to the site plan's compliance with the Rockledge Code of Ordinances, and said site plan has been approved by the city council, to wit: 
(1)  The development of any tract, piece or parcel of land consisting of five (5) or more acres of land in a commercial zoning district. 
(2)  The development of any tract, piece or parcel of land consisting of ten (10) or more acres of land in an industrial zoning district. 
(3)  Any structure which when completed will have over fifty thousand (50,000) square feet of floor space. 
(4)  Any multiple-family residential structure having twenty-five (25) or more units. 
Note- See the editor's note following § 31.14.1. 
31.14.5. - General conditions which may be attached. 
    In reviewing the proposed site plan, the building official may condition approval on specified changes in the proposal. Where conditions are attached, approval will be withheld except upon written agreement by the applicant to conform to such conditions. In particular, where the site plan indicates potential adverse effects on neighboring property, the building official may require rearrangement of the plan, increased yard width, walls, fences or other requirements. 
Note- See the editor's note following § 31.14.1. 
31.14.6. - Binding site plans voluntarily submitted with a request for a zoning district change or a special exception. 
(a)  An applicant for a change of zoning district or a special exception may voluntarily submit a binding site plan in support of such change or special exception request. Said binding site plan shall be submitted a minimum of five (5) days prior to the public hearings(s). Said binding site plan shall be deemed to have been relied upon by the boards and/or city council in rendering decisions on zoning changes and special exceptions. 
(b)  If the site plan is accepted as a condition of the zoning change or special exception, it shall be considered as binding upon the lot, parcel or tract of land affected by the site plan, even though said plan imposes greater or stricter standards on said lot, parcel or tract of land than do other provisions of this Code for other lots, tracts or parcels of land in like land use classifications. Such greater or stricter standards shall be deemed appropriate when unique or peculiar site development and locational characteristics are evident and shall be deemed to exist when such site plan is considered in rendering recommendations and decisions by the planning commission, board of adjustment, and the city council. A site plan voluntarily submitted will be deemed binding on the applicant, his assigns, heirs and successors in title or possession to the lot, tract or parcel of land, and the following shall apply to any such voluntarily submitted binding site plan: 
(1)  Site plans shall be prepared in accordance with Section 31.14.3, with exceptions as permitted by the building official. Conceptual plans may also be included, but only under guidelines established by the building official and approved by the board of adjustment, planning commission and city council. 
(2)  The provisions of this section authorizing the voluntary submission of a binding site plan in conjunction with an application for zoning, rezoning or a special exception shall be applicable and available in all zoning districts of the city. 
(3)  Minor deviations from the approved plans which result from a more detailed study or plan of drainage, topography, traffic flow or engineering requirements may be allowed by the building official. If such change to the binding site plan is deemed substantial by the building official, a new public hearing shall be required. 
Note- See the editor's note following § 31.14.1. 
31.15. - Site plan review procedure/responsibility. 
(a)  In all cases where a site plan submittal is necessary the following conditions apply: 
[(1)]  It shall be the responsibility of the owner, developer or other party submitting a site plan of a subdivision (commercial or residential), PUD, commercial, multifamily, or townhouse development to the City for review and approval, to progress and pursue with reasonable diligence the performance and completion of the various requirements for site plan approval and issuance of the building permit for the development within the time period herein specified. Any person or party submitting a site plan shall complete all procedures and requirements for final site plan approval, and obtain the issuance of a valid building permit for the improvements described on the site plan, within a period of not more than one hundred eighty (180) days following the date of initial submission of the site plan to the City and payment of the site plan review fee; provided however, that in any instance wherein final site plan approval and issuance of the building permit is delayed beyond said time period due to reason or cause beyond the applicant's control, and which is not the result of applicant's negligence, procrastination, inaction, or lack of due diligence, the Building Official may administratively extend said time period for not more than an additional sixty (60) days beyond the expiration of said one hundred eighty (180) day period. In any instance wherein an owner, developer, or other applicant fails to obtain final site plan approval and issuance of the building permit for the development within the time period herein specified, the site plan review process shall upon expiration of said period automatically terminate and development cease to be under consideration by the City unless, within ten (10) days after written notice of such termination to the applicant by the City, the applicant satisfactorily demonstrates to the Building Official that applicant's failure to complete the site plan review requirements and obtain the building permit was not due to applicant's neglect, procrastination, inattention, inaction, or failure to exercise due diligence. If the applicant makes such satisfactory demonstration to the Building Official within said ten (10) day period, the Building Official may administratively grant the applicant a reasonable extension of time to complete the process and obtain the building permit. Any owner, developer or other applicant for site plan review whose development has been terminated, must recommence a new site plan review process as an original proceeding, and pay another site plan review fee, as required, if such owner, developer, or applicant wishes to resubmit the same or a new site plan after termination of a prior site plan review procedure. 
[(2)]  Within thirty (30) days after the date of enactment of this section, the building official shall notify in writing each owner, developer or other party who has submitted a site plan which has not been approved, and for which a building permit has not been issued, that they must complete the site plan approval process and obtain a building permit within one hundred eighty (180) days after the date of such written notice, or their application for site plan approval will be withdrawn from further consideration. 
31.20. - Required submittal for single-family and duplex permits. 
    [Required submittals for single-family and duplex permits are as follows:] 
(a)  All requirements of Sections 31.10 and 31.12. 
(b)  Names of sub-contractors with correct State Licensing Numbers (Certification/Registration) must be duly noted along with address and name. 
(c)  Letters of authorization from all the named sub-contractors must be attached, signed and notarized, on the Rockledge Authorization Form. 
(d)  Owner builder permits: Requires an Owner Builder Affidavit. 
(e)  Certificate of Insurance showing proof of Workers Compensation. 
(f)  Two (2) sets of building plans meeting the requirements of Section A103.2 of Appendix "A" of the Standard Building Code. 
(1)  If applying for a model home, attach one set of plans. 
(g)  Two (2) sets of site plans. Site plan may be hand drawn, but must show the location by noting all setbacks of proposed structure(s) and existing buildings or structures on the site or lot. 
(h)  A completed Rockledge Elevation and Drainage Plan Acknowledgement Form. 
(i)  Current Florida Energy Calculations. 
(j)  Brevard County Impact Form accompanied by a paid receipt for Impact Fees. 
(k)  Areas where individual sewage disposal systems are approved, a copy of Brevard County Septic Tank Permit is required. 
(l)  Areas where road side swales and culverts are required, an approval from the Rockledge Public Works Department is required before issuance of a building permit. 
(m)  For Timbers West, Phase I and River Ridge Subdivisions only: A courtesy letter of plan approval from the Homeowners Association is required. 
(n)  Approval of Historic District Review Design Committee (if applicable). 
    The Building Official may require additional information to confirm compliance to these regulations. 
31.21. - Required submittal for commercial permit (commercial, multi-family, hotel, motel, and industrial projects). 
    [Required submittals for commercial permits are as follows:] 
(a)  Completed Building Permit Application. 
(b)  Completed Concurrency Evaluation Form. 
(c)  Site Plan Review Fee to be paid prior to Site Plan Submittal. 
(d)  Sealed Site Plans, to include the following: A site plan covering the entire tract proposed for ultimate development, indicating existing conditions and development for an additional area including at least three hundred (300) feet from the boundaries of such tract, or such greater distance as may be indicated by the circumstances of the case, shall be submitted to the building official. Before a permit is issued for construction, six (6) copies of the site plan of the area, at a scale no smaller than one inch to one hundred (100) feet, shall be filed with the building official setting forth, identifying and locating the following: 
(1)  A map indicating the property boundary and the proposed or existing plotting and street system. 
(2)  All public and private right-of-way and easement lines located on and adjacent to the property which are proposed to be continued, created, relocated or abandoned. 
(3)  Existing topography with a maximum of one-foot contour point intervals. 
(4)  The location of the proposed buildings, driveways, parking lots and other uses. 
(5)  A description of the uses proposed in sufficient detail to indicate the effects of those uses on producing air pollution, water pollution, fire or safety hazards, or other factors detrimental to the health, safety and welfare of the area. 
(6)  Engineering plans or descriptions, prepared and sealed by a professional engineer, for the handling of any problems of the type outlined in subparagraph (e) above, including a designation of sewers to be used and necessary plans for controlling of smoke or other nuisances such as those enumerated in the same above-referenced paragraph. 
(7)  Location and dimension of all curb cuts, driving lanes, off-street parking and loading and/or unloading areas including number of spaces. 
(8)  All walks, malls and other open area. 
(9)  Location of all walls, fences and screen planting. 
(10)  Size, height and orientation of all signs. 
(11)  All existing and proposed water and sanitary sewer lines with plans prepared at a scale no greater than one inch to one hundred (100) feet, sealed by a professional engineer. 
([11]a)  A drainage plan, prepared and sealed by a professional engineer, of the area showing size and location of each existing and proposed structure, the approximate volume of run-off generated by development of the subject area and the proposed method of managing said water. Provisions shall be included for retention of the first one inch of rainfall on-site and for adequate control of erosion sedimentation, indicating the proposed temporary and permanent control practices and measures. 
(12)  A copy of the restrictive covenants (if any) to be included in the deeds by the developer. 
(13)  Such other information with regard to the development area as may be required by the building official to determine conformance with these regulations. 
(e)  Two (2) sets of sealed Tree Surveys. 
(f)  Two (2) sets of sealed Landscaping Plans. 
(g)  Completed Erosion/Sedimentation Control Permit Application (See Public Works). 
(h)  Three (3) sets Erosion/Sedimentation Control Plans. 
(i)  Legal Description or Copy of Recorded Deed. 
(j)  Four (4) sets sealed Construction Plans. 
(k)  Two (2) sets sealed Construction Specifications. 
(l)  Two (2) sets sealed Energy Calculations. 
(m)  One (1) Condominium Document (if applicable). 
(n)  One (1) copy St. Johns River Water Management District Permit. 
(o)  Soil Test. 
(p)  D.E.R. Permit (if applicable). 
(q)  D.O.T. Permit (if applicable). 
(r)  Brevard County Consumer Health Department Permit (if applicable). 
(s)  Sub-Contractors Permit Authorization. 
(t)  Proof of Workers Compensation. 
(u)  Brevard County Impact Fee Form and a Prepaid receipt to be attached. 
    The Building Official may require additional information to confirm compliance to these regulations. 
31.25. - Subdivision submittal required. 
    See Part VII. 
31.30. - Required submittal for annexations. 
    Before submission of a petition for voluntary annexation the owner will be will advised to meet with the city manager, the building official and subdivision inspector, the city attorney, and such other personnel as may be necessary to determine the feasibility and suitability of the application. This step is encouraged so that the owner may obtain preliminary information and guidance from city personnel before incurring substantial expense. 
31.31. - Petition for consent of annexation; contents. 
    Every petition submitted to the City of Rockledge by a party seeking to have land annexed into the City of Rockledge pursuant to Section 171.044, Florida Statutes, 1981, shall be in writing and shall contain and include information and material, and be executed, as follows: 
(a)  The petition shall bear the original signature or signatures of all owners of the property involved, and describe their respective ownership interests. 
(b)  The petition shall include an accurate metes and bounds legal description of the property involved, said description to be drafted so that the courses and calls thereof can be coordinated into and with the legal description of the municipal boundaries of the city, and will proceed in directional sequences consistent with the direction in which the calls and courses of the legal description of the city boundary runs in areas contiguous to the property proposed to be annexed. 
(c)  The petition shall include a declaration of the type of development, if any, which petitioner proposes to make of the property if it is annexed, and a copy of the proposed plat of such development and engineer's drawings and architect's renderings applicable thereto, if such are in existence at the time of the filing of the petition. 
(d)  The petition shall include a statement of the particular zone district in which applicant desires the property to be classified, if any. 
(e)  The petition shall include a statement detailing, to the best of applicant's knowledge and belief, how the area involved is susceptible of municipal benefits, and why it is to the best interests of the City of Rockledge that such area should be annexed to the corporate limits thereof. 
31.32. - Additional information required for annexation. 
    [Petitions for annexations shall be accompanied by the following:] 
(a)  A boundary and topographical survey prepared by a surveyor licensed to do business in the State of Florida and bonded as required by law, which survey will include a legal description of the property proposed to be annexed, and will comply with the requirements of Subsection 31.31 of this section. 
(b)  An opinion in writing signed by an attorney at law licensed in the State of Florida, or a certificate of an abstract company or title insurance company engaged in business in Brevard County certifying the names of all of the owners of the fee simple title to the property sought to be annexed and their respective interests therein, as of a specific date not more than ten (10) days prior to presentation of the application and accompanying material to the city. 
31.33. - [Reports on impact on municipal services.] 
    Reports on impact on municipal services, which shall include the following information, [are required in accordance with this section.] Before any hearings are conducted with respect to any petition by either the city planning commission or city council, the Rockledge city manager shall prepare and submit to each [of] such boards the following: 
(a)  A written report describing the impact and effect the proposed annexation would have on the municipal services being rendered by the city. 
(b)  A written statement of the city's minimum elevation requirements, if any, for development of areas in the city immediately adjacent to the property sought to be annexed. 
(c)  A map showing current location of the property and what jurisdiction it is located in and what zoning provision the property has as well as its current identification on the Future Land Use Map of the jurisdiction involved. 
(d)  A map showing the nearest sewer trunk line, lift station, road access, police station, fire station, and water system trunk line. 
(e)  A completed Annexation Information Form, supplied by the City. 
31.40. - Submittal required for variances. 
    [Required submittals for variances are as follows:] 
(a)  A Variance Request form, supplied by the City. 
(b)  If the applicant is other than all the owners of the particular property, written consent signed by all owners of the particular real property shall be attached. 
(c)  An application for any variance shall be submitted in duplicate, on a form prescribed by the city and shall contain a complete legal description of the premises as to which the variance is requested. Each application shall be accompanied by a survey or plot diagram indicating setbacks and proposed construction; a list of the names and addresses of the owners of all properties within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the land for which the variance is requested; and a certified survey or that portion of the map maintained by the tax assessor showing the boundaries of each parcel of land within said five hundred (500) feet and the relationship of each of said parcels to the land for which the variance is requested. 
(d)  If an application is disapproved by the board of adjustment, thereafter the board shall take no further action on another application for substantially the same proposal on the same premise until after twelve (12) months from the date of such last disapproval. 
[(e)  Reserved.] 
(f)  Fees shall be paid per fee schedule established by the city council. 
31.41. - Time restraints for submittal of variances. 
    Completed variance request forms must be submitted to the building department by the last day of the month in order to be heard on the meeting following the next scheduled meeting (example: submittal on January 31, will be heard in mid-March). 
31.50. - Submittals required for special exceptions. 
    The petitioner shall fill out a form provided by the building department, the following steps are to be followed in applying for a special exception (conditional use): 
(a)  A petition for a special exception shall be submitted in duplicate containing an adequate legal description of the premises as to which the special exception is requested; the names and addresses of the owners or tenants in possession of such premises; the names and addresses of the owners of all properties within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the land for which the special exception is requested; a certified survey or that portion of the map maintained by the tax assessor showing the boundaries of each parcel of land within said five hundred (500) feet and the relationship of each of said parcels to the land for which the special exception is requested; a description of the special exception desired which shall specifically and particularly describe the type, character and extent of the proposed special exception; the reason for requesting the special exception; and any other pertinent data which may be requested by the board of adjustment. The petition shall be signed by the applicant or the applicant's authorized agent or attorney. 
(1)  The submitted map and names of property owners within five hundred (500) feet shall be numbered in correlation with each other. 
(b)  Upon receipt of such petition, the request will be placed on the agendas of the next meetings of the board of adjustment and the planning commission. The planning commission shall study each request for a special exception and make a report to the board of adjustment, in writing, including its recommendations pertaining to the application. The report of the planning commission shall state specific reasons and findings of fact upon which its recommendation is based. Said report and recommendation shall be presented to the board of adjustment within thirty (30) days. 
(c)  It will be the responsibility of the city clerk to publish the required legal notices of public hearing prior to the dates of such public hearings. 
(d)  Due public notice shall be given of the public hearing by the board of adjustment on an application for a special exception. 
(e)  The board of adjustment shall at such public hearing consider the application for special exception permit and the planning commission's report and recommendations thereon, as well as the comments of citizens attending such hearing and any other pertinent data and information available, and the board of adjustment shall either deny or authorize the issuance of such special exception permit. 
(f)  The board of adjustment may, as a condition precedent to the granting of an application for special exception permit, impose such conditions, restrictions or limitations in the use of such premises, or upon the special exception thereof as requested in the application, as the board of adjustment may deem appropriate and in the best interest of the city, taking into consideration matters of health, safety and welfare of the city, protection of property values and other considerations material to good zoning principles and concepts. 
(g)  Any special exception permit granted by the city shall permit only the specific use or uses described in the application as the same may be limited or restricted by the terms and provisions of the permit, and no other; any expansion or extension of the use of such premises beyond the scope of the terms of the special exception permit shall be unlawful and deemed a violation of these regulations. 
(h)  The board of adjustment may suspend or revoke a special exception permit at any time the board of adjustment determines that such special exception has become a public or private nuisance because of an improper, unauthorized or other unlawful use of such premises. 
(i)  If a petition for a special exception permit is denied by the board of adjustment, thereafter the board of adjustment shall take no further action on another petition for substantially the same special exception on the same premises until after twelve (12) months after the date of such last denial. 
(j)  Fees. For all petitions for a special exception, a fee schedule shall be established by the city council. 
31.51. - Public information. 
    This section is to provide the public with information regarding actions pending within the city involving real property. This is not intended to effect or attach additional requirements to any statutory or other public notice requirement. This section cannot be utilized to contest an ordinance in any way for failure to comply herewith. 
1.  Annexation. 
(A)  Notices. A notice setting forth the date(s), time(s), and place(s) of the planning commission hearing and the subsequent public hearing before the city council at which the annexation request will be considered, and including in the notice a map indicating the area to be affected, shall be mailed at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the planning commission meeting indicated in the notice to the last known address of owners of property whose land is within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the land that is the subject of the meeting or hearing. 
(1)  The petitioner shall provide the city clerk with a list of property owners, utilizing the records and map maintained by the tax assessor, showing the boundaries of each parcel of land within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the land that is the subject of the annexation. 
(2)  The city clerk shall provide certification of the date the notices were mailed. 
(B)  Advertisement. The notice prescribed in subsection (A) above, exclusive of the map, shall be published one time as a legal advertisement in a newspaper of general daily circulation in the area at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the first public meeting or hearing indicated in the notice. 
(C)  Posting. Posting of the property involved in the annexation shall be accomplished in accordance with subsection 7. of this section. 
2.  Comprehensive plan amendment. 
(A)  Notices. A notice setting forth the date(s), time(s), place(s) and purpose of public meetings and hearings, and including in the notice a map indicating the area to be affected, shall be mailed at least fifteen (15) days prior to the first meeting or hearing indicated in the notice to the last known address of owners of property whose land is within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the land that is the subject of the meeting or hearing. 
(1)  The list of property owners shall be provided by the applicant, utilizing the records and map maintained by the tax assessor showing the boundaries of each parcel of land within said five hundred (500) feet. 
(2)  The city clerk shall provide certification of the date the notices were mailed. 
(B)  Reserved. 
(C)  Posting. Applications limited to site-specific amendments shall be subject to posting, which shall be accomplished in accordance with subsection 7. of this section. 
3.  Preliminary plat. 
(A)  Notices. A notice setting forth the date(s), time) (s), and place(s) of the planning commission public hearing and the subsequent city council meeting at which the preliminary plat will be considered, and including in the notice a map indicating the area to be affected, shall be mailed at least fifteen (15) days prior to the planning commission hearing indicated in the notice to the last known address of owners of property whose land is within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the land that is the subject of the meeting or hearing. 
(1)  The list of property owners shall be provided by the applicant, utilizing the records and map maintained by the tax assessor showing the boundaries of each parcel of land within said five hundred (500) feet. 
(2)  The city clerk shall provide certification of the date the notices were mailed. 
(B)  Advertisement. The notice prescribed in subsection (A) above, exclusive of the map, shall be published one time as a legal advertisement in a newspaper of general daily circulation in the area at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the first public meeting or hearing indicated in the notice. 
(C)  Posting. Posting of the property involved in the preliminary plat shall be accomplished in accordance with subsection 7 of this section. 
4.  Special exception. 
(A)  Notice. A notice setting forth the date(s), time(s), and place(s) of the planning commission meeting and the subsequent public hearing before the board of adjustment at which the special exception will be considered, and including in the notice a map indicating the area to be affected, shall be mailed at least fifteen (15) days prior to the planning commission meeting indicated in the notice to the last known address of owners of property whose land is within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the land that is the subject of the hearing. 
(1)  The list of property owners shall be provided by the applicant, utilizing the records and map maintained by the tax assessor showing the boundaries of each parcel of land within said five hundred (500) feet. 
(2)  The city clerk shall provide certification of the date the notices were mailed. 
(B)  Advertisement. The notice prescribed in subsection (A) above, exclusive of the map, shall be published one time as a legal advertisement in a newspaper of general daily circulation in the area at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the first public meeting or hearing indicated in the notice. 
(C)  Posting. Posting of the property involved in the special exception shall be accomplished in accordance with subsection 7. of this section. 
5.  Variance. 
(A)  Notices. A notice setting forth the date, time, and place of the board of adjustment hearing, and including in the notice a map indicating the area to be affected, shall be mailed at least fifteen (15) days prior to the board of adjustment meeting indicated in the notice to the last known address of owners of property whose land is within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the land that is the subject of the hearing. 
(1)  The list of property owners shall be provided by the applicant, utilizing the records and map maintained by the tax assessor showing the boundaries of each parcel of land within said five hundred (500) feet. 
(2)  The city clerk shall provide certification of the date the notices were mailed. 
(B)  Advertisement. The notice prescribed in subsection (A) above, exclusive of the map, shall be published one time as a legal advertisement in a newspaper of general daily circulation in the area at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the board of adjustment meeting or hearing indicated in the notice. 
(C)  Posting. Posting of the property involved in the variance shall be accomplished in accordance with subsection 7. of this section. 
6.  Zoning district amendment. 
(A)  Notice. A notice setting forth the date(s), time(s), and place(s) of the planning commission hearing and the subsequent public hearing before the city council at which the zoning district amendment will be considered, and including in the notice a map indicating the area to be affected, shall be mailed at least fifteen (15) days prior to the planning commission meeting indicated in the notice to the last known address of owners of property whose land is within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the land that is the subject of the hearing. 
(1)  The list of property owners shall be provided by the applicant, utilizing the records and map maintained by the tax assessor showing the boundaries of each parcel of land within said five hundred (500) feet. 
(2)  The city clerk shall provide certification of the date the notices were mailed. 
(B)  Advertisement. The notice prescribed in subsection (A) above, exclusive of the map, shall be published one time as a legal advertisement in a newspaper of general daily circulation in the area at least ten (10) days prior to the date of the first public meeting or hearing indicated in the notice. 
(C)  Posting. Posting of the property involved in the zoning district amendment shall be accomplished in accordance with subsection 7. of this section. 
7.  Posting requirements. 
(A)  Signs to be purchased from city. In order to maintain visual and regulatory consistency, signs to be used expressly for posting of property shall be purchased from the city by the applicant at the cost prescribed in Section 39.00. 
(B)  Signs. Signs shall be no smaller than three (3) square feet, with a minimum width of twenty-four (24) inches and a minimum height of eighteen (18) inches. 
(C)  Sign information. The sign shall contain large lettering indicating the type of change being considered; the assigned case number; the name of the owner(s) of the property; the action(s) requested; the dates and times of associated meetings and public hearings; and the city hall address and telephone number for acquisition of additional information. 
(D)  Posting location. One sign shall be posted on each portion of the property that is adjacent to an existing right-of-way. The sign shall be situated not less than five (5) feet from the right-of-way and at the approximate center of the right-of-way frontage. If it is determined by the city that a sign is not suitably located or negatively impacts traffic visibility, the applicant or property owner shall relocate the sign within twenty-four (24) hours of verbal notification. 
(E)  Posting period. Signs shall be posted by the applicant at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date of the meeting indicated on the sign(s), and must be removed within twenty-four (24) hours of the final disposition of the applicant's petition. 
(1)  Affidavit of compliance. Within twenty-four (24) hours of posting, the applicant shall deliver to the city a notarized "Affidavit of Compliance with Posting Requirements" on a form provided by the city. Accompanying each affidavit shall be a photograph of the posted sign(s) and a map indicating the location of the sign(s). 
8.  Noncompliance. Failure of the applicant to comply with any or all of the foregoing requirements shall result in withdrawal of the applicant's petition from the agenda until such time as compliance is achieved. 
(Ord. No. 1276-2002, § 1, 7-3-02; Ord. No. 1331-2003, § 1, 11-19-03; Ord. No. 1447-2007, §§ 1-3, 5-16-07) 
31.52. - Project procedures and submittals for the community redevelopment district (CRD). 
(a)  All persons desiring to perform improvement, rehabilitation/redevelopment, construction or other development projects within the community redevelopment district shall have a pre-application meeting with the redevelopment director and planning director. 
(b)  Applications for approval of those projects shall be submitted to the planning director/zoning official, who shall review and certify that all required documents are submitted and the applications are complete. 
(c)  Within no more than ten (10) working days, the planning director shall convene the development review committee (DRC) to review the application and all submittals and render a decision or recommendation. 
(d)  The DRC shall review said project and make recommendations for approval, approval with conditions, or denial of the project. 
(e)  The planning director shall schedule those projects required to obtain planning commission and city council review and approval for the next available meeting of the planning commission, upon receipt of any required supplemental information or changes based upon the recommendations of the DRC. 
(f)  For projects requesting waivers of provisions of the land development regulations, the planning director/zoning official shall convene the DRC within no more than five (5) working days from receipt of the request. 
(Ord. No. 1376-2005, § 9, 5-4-05) 
SECTION 32.00. - TREE REMOVAL PERMIT/REQUIREMENTS 
(1)  Generally: 
(a)  No person, directly or indirectly, shall cut down, destroy, remove or move, or effectively destroy through damaging any tree located on any property within the City of Rockledge without first obtaining a permit, unless otherwise provided herein. 
(b)  Tree permits authorized by this section may be obtained by making application for permit to the building official on a form to be supplied by the city, indicating the type tree and how it is proposed to be cut, destroyed or removed, who will perform the work, and such other information as may be required by the building official to effectively enforce the provisions of this section. A separate application shall be filed for each site upon which tree removal is requested. 
(2)  Exceptions. The following types of trees shall be exempt from the provisions of this section, and no permit or fees shall be required for the removal, cutting down or destruction of these trees: 
(a)  Melaleuca quinquenervia (Cajaput or Paperbark). 
(b)  Melaleuca leucadendra (Punk). 
(c)  Casuarina (spp), (Australian Pine), (Brazilian Oak). 
(d)  Schinus terebinthinfolius (Brazilian Pepper). 
(e)  Araucaria excelsa (Norfolk Island Pine). 
(f)  Eucalyptus (all varieties except Eucalyptus Cinerea). 
(g)  Bischofia javanica (Bishopwood, Bischofia). 
(h)  Ricinus communis (Castorbean). 
(i)  Metopium toxiferum (Poison Wood). 
(j)  Melaiceae asedarach (Chinaberry). 
(k)  Enterolobium (spp), (Eartree). 
(l)  Trees located in state-licensed and governmental plant or tree nurseries or botanical gardens in which the trees are planted and growing for the sale or intended sale to the general public in the ordinary course of business or for some public purpose and which are sold. 
(m)  Trees which are required to be removed by law. 
(n)  Trees which, due to natural circumstances, are no longer viable, are in danger of falling, are too close to existing structures so as to endanger such structures, interfere with utility services, create unsafe vision clearance or constitutes a safety hazard. 
(o)  Trees located within three (3) feet of a survey line cut or cleared by a licensed land surveyor acting in the course of his profession or located within three (3) feet of any public utility main, pipe, wire, line or conduit. 
(p)  Trees on a single-family residential lot or on a two-family residential lot; provided, that after such removal the lot will contain a minimum of at least four (4) trees of any type or types listed in Appendix A of Ordinance No. 929-89; or, if after the removal the lot will contain less than four (4) trees listed on Appendix A, a substitute tree of any type or types listed on Appendix A, of Ordinance 929-89, is planted for each tree to be removed, such planting to be performed within thirty (30) days prior to the removal. 
(3)  Application for tree removal permit: 
(a)  Predevelopment: The removal of any tree or trees from real property in the City of Rockledge which has not been previously developed pursuant to an approved site plan is hereby prohibited, except that no tree removal permit shall be required for removal of any of the exempt and excepted trees described in subsection (2) of this section. An application pursuant to the requirements in subsection (2) shall be completed and a permit required. 
(b)  During construction: Application for a tree removal permit during construction shall be required as a part of the site plan submittal, except that no tree removal permit shall be required for removal of any of the exempt and excepted trees described in subsection (2) of this section. The applicant shall submit a legible, reproducible plan, drawn to scale and indicating the following information for the entire site: 
1.  Location, shape and spatial arrangements of all existing and proposed buildings, walls or fences, or other improvements and structures. 
2.  Identification of uses on adjacent properties. 
3.  Location, shape and spatial arrangement of all parking areas and access roads. 
4.  Existing and proposed utility services. 
5.  Existing and proposed elevations. 
6.  Setbacks, yard requirements and location of easements. 
7.  Existing and proposed wells. 
8.  All sink holes, rock outcroppings and historical sites. 
9.  A tree survey certified by a landscape architect, land surveyor or land planner overlaid directly upon the site plan, and indicating the location referenced to structures, of all protected trees as defined in this section. The survey shall distinguish existing trees which are proposed to be destroyed, relocated, replaced or preserved at their present location. Said survey shall show the location of all existing trees as defined in this section. Tree information shall be summarized in a legend form and shall contain the variety, trunk diameter, height and location referenced to structure of all trees shown on the survey. Groups of trees less than three (3) feet apart may be designed as clumps, with the exception that any tree with a trunk diameter of eight (8) inches or more must be specifically designated. For sites on which tree removal activity is to occur on less than the entirety of the site, the building official shall provide that the tree survey may exclude those portions of the site which it determines will not be affected by the tree removal or clearing activity. 
10.  Trees not affected by tree removal or clearing activity shall be properly identified by means of surveying tape or noninjurious painting. 
(c)  Post-development. An application for a tree removal permit shall be required for removal of any tree on real property previously developed and for which a certificate of occupancy has been issued, except that no tree removal permit shall be required for removal of any of the exempt and excepted trees described in subsection (2) of this section. The following information shall be required on an application for removal of a nonexempt tree from such previously developed property: 
1.  Site plan showing all structures, sidewalks, driveways, etc. 
2.  Location on site plan of trees to be removed, and replacement location of tree from Appendix A or B to Ordinance No. 929-89. 
(4)  Criteria for issuance of tree removal permits. Tree removal permits shall be issued in accordance with this subsection (C) when the building official has been satisfied that the application meets all of the following criteria: 
(a)  The subject tree is located within the area where any building, roadway, pavement, retention pond or other improvement is proposed to be constructed, or where a grade change necessary to proposed development of the site will be made which is too severe for the tree to survive, and such proposed improvements or grade change cannot be relocated upon the site so as to further maximize the preservation of the existing trees upon the site while not unreasonably restricting the permitted use of the property. 
(b)  If it is in the welfare of the general public that the tree be removed for a reason other than set forth above. 
(c)  Appropriate arrangements for disposal of trees and tree parts have been provided that will comply to the Landfill Ordinance (Ordinance No. 922-89, adopted August 2, 1989) [Section 43.00]. 
(5)  Relocation or replacement: 
(a)  As a condition to the granting of a tree removal permit under this section, the applicant may be required, where practical, to: 
1.  Relocate those trees which would otherwise be destroyed to another location upon the site; or 
2.  Replace those trees which will be destroyed with suitable replacement trees elsewhere within the site. Such replacement trees shall be of a variety listed in Appendix A of Ordinance No. 929-89, or of any other variety approved by the building official. 
(b)  In determining the required relocation or replacement of trees, the building official or agency shall consider the needs of the intended use of the property, including all lands dedicated to public use, together with an elevation [evaluation] of the following: 
1.  Existing tree coverage on the site and in the immediate surrounding area. 
2.  Number of trees or trees to be removed on the entire site. 
3.  The type, size and condition of the tree or trees to be removed. 
4.  The feasibility of relocating that particular tree or trees. 
5.  Topography and drainage of the site. 
6.  The extent to which the tree or trees contribute to the aesthetic, economic and environmental integrity of the surrounding area. 
7.  No person shall plant or transplant any tree or shrub within the area or space between a sidewalk and the adjacent street, in any parkway or right-of-way, without first obtaining a written permit from the city manager, subject to the list of prohibited species of trees. 
(6)  Procedure for permitting tree removal: 
(a)  Upon receipt of a completed application containing all the information as required by this section, the building official shall review said application. The review procedure shall determine the adequacy and accuracy of content, and determine whether the application meets the requirements of this subsection, and whether the applicant has taken all necessary and reasonable steps to preserve existing trees and to otherwise enhance the aesthetic appearance of the proposed development by incorporation of trees into the design process. 
(b)  Following approval of the application, the building official shall issue the appropriate permits. 
(c)  Upon the issuance of a tree removal permit under this subsection, a copy of said permit shall be prominently displayed on the site prior to the removal, relocation or replacement of any trees. Tree removal permits shall be included with all other permit cards and shall be displayed alongside them on the site. 
(d)  No final certificate of occupancy shall be issued nor electrical power connection authorization given until any relocation or replacement of trees required by the tree removal permit has been completed and a final tree inspection approval has been given by the building official. Trees relocating from one portion of the site to another which do not survive transplantation for at least one year shall be replaced by the owner of the site with a suitable replacement tree. 
(7)  Protection of trees not approved for removal, relocation or destruction. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or cause to be placed, materials, machinery or temporary soil deposits within the drip line of any tree protected by this section and not permitted for removal or destruction, to fail to erect barriers necessary to protect such tree, or to attach anything other than protective wires, braces or other similar noninjurious materials to such tree. Furthermore, no structure or impervious paving shall be located within a three-foot radius of the trunk perimeter of any such tree. A tree of two and one-half (21/2) feet or more in diameter shall require additional space as may be determined by the building official. 
SECTION 35.00. - ZONING/REZONING APPLICATION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 35.00 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. 

35.01. - Change of zoning classification procedure. 
(a)  All applications for change of a zoning classification shall be filed with the zoning official on the proper form which can be obtained at the office of the zoning official, along with the required Rockledge Development Fact Sheet, and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  A statement of the name, residence address and mailing address, if different from the residence address, of each owner of the fee simple title to the real property proposed to be rezoned, accompanied by a copy of such owners' recorded deed, title insurance policy, attorney's opinion of title, or other evidence of ownership. 
(2)  Every application shall be signed by each owner of the property proposed to be rezoned, or by the duly authorized agent or attorney of said owner. As to any agent or attorney signing the application on behalf of the owner, a written power of attorney, or other instrument in writing signed by the owner and authorizing such agent or attorney to apply for the proposed rezoning in behalf of such owner, shall accompany the application for rezoning. 
(3)  The legal description of the particular real property, accompanied by a certified survey or that portion of the map maintained by the tax assessor reflecting the boundaries of the particular real property. 
(4)  The current land use classification, special use classification, with any specified conditions, or conditional use designation, as recorded on the official zoning map. 
(5)  The requested land use classification that constitutes an amendment to the official zoning map. 
(6)  Names and addresses of all property owners within five hundred (500) feet, accompanied by a certified survey or that portion of the map maintained by the tax accessory reflecting the boundaries of the parcels affected. 
(b)  After the duly signed application with all attachments, exhibits, fees and information herein required has been filed with the city and approved as to form and content by the city manager, the request for rezoning and a copy of said application and supporting material will be placed on the agenda of the next meeting of the city council, and the city council shall refer it to the planning commission. The planning commission shall hold at least one public hearing thereon, with due public notice, and shall submit in writing its recommendation on the proposed change to the city council for official action. The recommendation of the planning commission shall state the relationship of the proposed change to the comprehensive plan of the City of Rockledge and shall be made within a reasonable time but no later than within two (2) months after the time of reference. If a recommendation is not made within two (2) months after the time of reference, then the city council may act on the adoption. 
(c)  The city council shall review the recommendations made by the planning commission and hold a public hearing to consider the request. It shall be the responsibility of the city clerk to give due public notice of such public hearing. 
(d)  Following said public hearing, the city council, by ordinance, may modify or change the existing zone classification for the lands of said petitioners or it may deny said petition. In the case of denial of said petition, the city council shall thereafter taken no further action on another application for substantially the same proposal on the same premises until after twelve (12) months from the date of last such disapproval. 
35.02. - Application procedures generally. 
    The city council may from time to time amend, supplement, change or repeal the zoning regulations, restrictions or district boundaries as set out in these regulations. Proposed changes and amendments may be suggested by the city council, the planning commission or by petition of the owners of fifty-one (51) per cent or more of the area involved in a proposed district boundary change. 
Editor's note- At the direction of the city, former § 25-331 of the Code of Ordinances has been included herein as § 35.02. 
SECTION 36.00. - WORK AFFECTING PUBLIC WAYS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Section 36.00 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. 

36.01. - Permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful to open, grade, pave, construct, make any excavation in, disturb the surface of, or do any other work affecting any street, sidewalk, or public way, or any curb or structure or fixture appurtenant to any street, sidewalk, or public way, or to install or construct any underground pipes, sewers, lines or utility installations of any character, without first obtaining a permit therefor from the director of public works. Sidewalks, curbs and driveway aprons located in city-owned rights-of-way shall not be painted or etched or use alternative construction materials or be otherwise modified from existing standards without the express approval of the Rockledge City Manager. 
(1240-2000, § 1, 10-18-00; Ord. No. 1268-2002, § 2, 4-3-02) 
36.02. - Separate permit required for each excavation. 
    An excavation permit shall be obtained for each individual cut. 
36.03. - Application for permit. 
    Any person desiring a permit pursuant to this section shall make written application to the director of public works stating the public way involved, the work to be done, and the time and place when the applicant desires to do the work described in the application. Except in the case of an emergency, said application must be made no less than forty-eight (48) hours in advance of the time of commencement of the work, as stated in the application. 
36.04. - Permit fees. 
(a)  Excavations. Permits for excavation shall be issued by the director of public works after payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or an amount equal to two (2) per cent of the cost of labor and materials anticipated to be extended in completing such work, whichever is greater. The director of public works may require verification of the amount of such construction cost by a certified estimate from the city's consulting engineer, the cost of such certified estimate to be borne by the permittee. 
(b)  For permits applied for after commencement of excavation. The fee for any permit applied for after commencement of an excavation shall be double the amount of the ordinary fee specified in this section. 
(c)  Exemptions. Although a permit will be required in every instance of an excavation, entities that are duly franchised to use the public streets, alleys and ways shall be exempt from payment of the excavation permit fee. 
36.05. - Bond. 
    Prior to obtaining a permit for excavation, a bond shall be posted with the city clerk in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or twenty-five (25) per cent of the cost of labor and materials anticipated to be expended in completing such work, whichever is greater. The director of public works may require verification of the amount of such construction cost by a certified estimate from the city's consulting engineer, the cost of such certified estimate to be borne by the permittee. Said bond shall be refunded only after completion and restoration of the public way, and after inspection and approval by the City of Rockledge. If the work and restoration is not completed according to the terms of the application, and in accordance with the standards and specifications of the city applicable to the type of working being done, and to the satisfaction of the City of Rockledge, then the city may use all or such part of said bond as is necessary to properly complete the work in accordance with applicable city standards and specifications. 
36.06. - Permit issuance. 
    The director of public works, after being satisfied that the work described in the application and the method of performing such work will not be adverse to the public interest, shall thereupon issue a permit to the applicant. 
36.07. - Conformity to application and permit. 
    All work performed pursuant to this section shall be in accordance with the application and permit. 
36.08. - Supervision of work; specifications. 
    All work for which a permit is required by this section shall be done under the supervision of an inspector or engineer appointed by the city for that purpose, and shall be done in compliance with minimum specifications set by law in the city. 
36.09. - Inspection, approval required. 
    All work for which a permit is required by this section shall be subject to inspection and approval by the City of Rockledge, and no such work shall be covered or concealed until such inspection and approval have been requested and obtained. 
36.10. - Inspection authority; interfering with. 
(a)  The authorized representatives of the City of Rockledge shall have the right and duty to go upon any property in the city for the purpose of making inspections required by this section.
