(b)  No person shall interfere with the action of the inspecting official in the proper performance of such duty. 
36.11. - Barricades and lighting required. 
    Any person carrying on or doing any work pursuant to a permit required by this section shall erect and maintain proper, safe and sufficient barricades, and during that period of time between one-half hour after sunset and one-half hour before sunrise shall maintain sufficient lights or flares around such barricades, work or excavations to warn persons of the presence of such excavations and work and to prevent injury to persons and property. 
36.12. - Restoration required. 
    Upon the expiration of any permit granted pursuant to the provisions of this section, the permit holder shall replace the public way or part of public way upon which such construction, excavation or repair work has been performed in the same condition as the public way or part of public way existed prior to the construction, excavation or repair work; and failure to do so shall constitute a misdemeanor against the city by the permit holder. 
36.13. - Authority to stop work. 
    The director of public works may have the work stopped at any time, regardless of the fact that a permit therefor has been issued, if, in his opinion, the manner in which the work is being performed shall result in unforeseen injury to any public way or property. 
SECTION 37.00. - APPEALS/INTERPRETATIONScustom>[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Section 37.00 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. 

37.11. - Forms. 
    Appeals from a Building Code interpretation decision of the Building Official shall be filed on forms provided by the secretary of the Board of Adjustments and Appeals. Any affected property owner or his agent may file an appeal. 
37.12. - Adopted construction code interpretations. 
    Any person aggrieved by any decision of the building official in construing, interpreting or applying any of the terms and provisions of the adopted building codes (Southern Building Code, Standard Plumbing Code, Electrical Code, Fire Safety Code, etc.) of these regulations; or elevation questions; or any of the terms and provisions of any code or codes adopted in these regulations, shall have the right to appeal such decision to the Building Code Board of Adjustments and Appeals established under the provisions of the Standard Building Code. The procedure in all such cases shall be the same as is provided by said Standard Building Code for appeals thereunder to said building code board of adjustments and appeals (example: a disagreement on what is a penthouse and how it should be used to determine the height of a building). 
37.20. - Appeals for the interpretation of Rockledge's land development regulations by any administrative official. [(Reserved)] 
37.30. - Board of adjustments shall hear appeals. 
    In exercising its powers, the board of adjustment may, upon appeal and in conformity with provisions of these regulations, reverse or affirm, wholly or partly, or may modify the order, requirement, decision or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of any Zoning Ordinance or regulation adopted pursuant to these regulations, and may make any necessary order, requirement, decision or determination, and to that end shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken. The concurring vote of a majority of all the members of the board shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of any such administrative official or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which the board is required to pass under any such ordinance. 
37.31. - Appeals procedure. 
(a)  From decision of administrative official. Appeals to the board of adjustment may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any officer, board or bureau of the city council affected by any decision of an administrative official under any Zoning Ordinance enacted pursuant to these regulations. Such appeal shall be taken within thirty (30) days after rendition of the order, requirements, decision or determination appealed from by filing with the officer from whom the appeal is taken and with the board of adjustment a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The appeal shall be in the form prescribed by the rules of the board. The administrative official from whom the appeal is taken shall, upon notification of the filing of the appeal, forthwith transmit to the board of adjustment all the documents, plans, papers or other materials constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(b)  Hearing of appeals. The board of adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give public notice thereof, as well as due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. In every appeal for a variance or special exception (conditional use) written notice of the time, place and purpose of such hearing shall be mailed at least fifteen (15) days prior to the hearing to the last known address of the owner of each lot, piece parcel or tract of land within five hundred (500) feet of the periphery of the premises which is the subject of the appeal. Written notice of such hearing shall be mailed to the owners of adjacent property as herein required, even though such adjacent properties are located outside the municipal limits of the City of Rockledge. Appellants may be required to assume such reasonable costs in connection with appeals as may be determined by the city council through action in setting of fees to be charged for appeals. For procedural purposes, an application for a special exception (conditional use) shall be handled by the board of adjustment as for appeals. A fee established by the city council shall be paid to the city clerk at the time any notice of appeal is filed with the board of adjustment. 
37.32. - Stay of work and proceedings. 
    An appeal to the board of adjustment stays all work on the premises and all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the official from whom the appeal was taken shall certify to the board of adjustment that, by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings or work shall not be stayed except by a restraining order which may be granted by the board of adjustment or by a court of record on application, on notice to the officer from whom the appeal is taken and on due cause shown. 
37.33. - Hearing. 
    The board of adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal, give public notice thereof, as well as due notice to the parties in interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time. Upon the hearing, any party may appear in person, by agent, or by attorney. Appellants may be required to assume such reasonable costs in connection with appeals as may be determined by the city council through action in setting of fees to be charged for appeals. For procedural purposes, an application for a special exception shall be handled by the board of adjustment as for appeals. 
37.34. - Judicial review of decisions of the board of adjustments or board of adjustment and appeals. 
    Any person or persons, jointly or severally, aggrieved by any decision of the board of adjustment, or any officer, department, board, commission or bureau of the city council may apply to the circuit court of Brevard County, Florida, for relief within thirty (30) days after rendition of the decision by the board of adjustment. Review in the circuit court shall be either by trial de novo, which shall be governed by the Florida rules of civil procedure or by petition for writ of certiorari, which shall be governed by the Florida appellate rules. The election of remedies shall lie with the appellant.

39.07. - Building permit valuations. 
    Building permit valuations shall include total cost, such as electrical, gas, mechanical, plumbing and other systems, including materials and labor. If, in the opinion of the building official, the valuation of building, alteration or structure appears to be underestimated on the application, permit shall be denied, unless the application can show detailed cost to meet the approval of the building official. The building official may estimate the permit valuations by using the most current Building Valuation Data Worksheet published by the Southern Building Code Congress International (SBCCI) and the applicable technical code appendices (i.e., plumbing, mechanical, gas, etc.) for suggested fee schedules, or the use of signed contracts, appraisals, and/or other methods approved and allowed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1014-91, § 8, 10-18-91; Ord. No. 1120-96, § 3, 8-14-96)

39.12. - Site plan review fee. 
(a)  Any owner, developer, or other party submitting to the city building department for review or approval a site plan of a commercial, multifamily, or townhouse development, other than a site plan of a subdivision (residential or commercial) or PUD development, shall pay the city at the time of submission of the site plan a non-refundable site plan review fee of one-half (1/2) of the building permit fee for the development, or the sum of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) whichever is the lesser amount. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner, developer or other party submitting a site plan of a subdivision (commercial or residential), PUD, commercial, multifamily, or townhouse development to the City for review and approval, to progress and pursue with reasonable diligence the performance and completion of the various requirements for site plan approval and issuance of the building permit for the development within the time period herein specified. Any person or party submitting a site plan shall complete all procedures and requirements for final site plan approval, and obtain the issuance of a valid building permit for the improvements described on the site plan, within a period of not more than one hundred eighty (180) days following the date of initial submission of the site plan to the City and payment of the site plan review fee; provided however, that in any instance wherein final site plan approval and issuance of the building permit is delayed beyond said time period due to a reason or cause beyond applicant's control, and which is not the result of applicant's negligence, procrastination, inaction, or lack of due diligence, the Building Official may administratively extend said time period for not more than an additional sixty (60) days beyond the expiration of said one hundred eighty (180) day period. In any instance wherein an owner, developer, or other applicant fails to obtain final site plan approval and issuance of the building permit for a development within the time period herein specified, the site plan review process shall upon the expiration of said period automatically terminate and the development cease to be under consideration by the City unless, within ten (10) days after written notice of such termination is furnished to the applicant by the City, the applicant satisfactorily demonstrates to the Building Official that applicant's failure to complete the site plan review requirements and obtain the building permit was not due to applicant's neglect, procrastination, inattention, inaction, or failure to exercise due diligence. If the applicant makes such satisfactory demonstration to the Building Official within said ten (10) day period, the Building Official may administratively grant the applicant a reasonable extension of time to complete the process and obtain the building permit. Any owner, developer or other applicant for site plan review whose development has been terminated, must recommence a new site plan review process as an original proceeding, and pay another site plan review fee, as required in this Section, if such owner, developer, or applicant wishes to resubmit the same or a new site plan after termination of a prior site plan review procedure. 
(c)  Within thirty (30) days after the date of enactment of this Section, the Building Official shall notify in writing each owner, developer or other party who has submitted a site plan which has not been approved, and for which a building permit has not been issued, that they must complete the site plan approval process and obtain a building permit for their development within one hundred eighty (180) days after the date of such written notice, or their application for site plan approval will be withdrawn from further consideration. 
(Ord. No. 1240-2000, § 2, 10-18-00; Ord. No. 1325-2003, § 1, 10-15-03) 
39.13. - Subdivision site plan review fee. 
(a)  Any owner, developer, or other party submitting to the city building department for review or approval a site plan of a subdivision (residential or commercial) or PUD development shall pay the city at the time of submission of the site plan a non-refundable site plan review fee of one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). 
(Ord. No. 1325-2003, § 2, 10-15-03) 
39.14. - Zoning change fee. 
    The fee for a petition for change of zoning classification is five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 4, 8-14-96) 
39.15. - Voluntary annexation fee. 
    [Voluntary annexation fees are as follows:] 
(a)  A one hundred dollar ($100.00) application fee. 
(b)  A five hundred dollar ($500.00) cost deposit from which the city will draw to pay the costs of publishing the annexation ordinance, notices of public hearings, and all other expenses necessary to comply with statutory and ordinance requirements applicable to the proposed annexation. If, in any given instance, the five hundred dollars ($500.00) cost deposit is insufficient to pay all of the aforesaid costs and expenses, the applicant shall furnish the city with the additional funds necessary to complete payment of the same before the final public hearing by the city council on the adoption of the proposed annexation ordinance. Any unexpended portion of a cost deposit remaining in the hands of the city treasurer after completion of the annexation and payment of all costs and expenses applicable thereto, shall be refunded to the applicant making such deposit. Applicants for voluntary annexations shall bear all costs and expenses applicable to the proceeding regardless of whether the annexation is approved or denied by the city council. 
39.16. - Tree removal permit fee. 
(A)  Application fee: The nonrefundable application fee for the tree removal permit authorized under this part shall be fifteen dollars ($15.00) for the first tree and five dollars ($5.00) for each additional tree for which removal is requested on said application, with a maximum fee not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00). An applicant may apply for a fee waiver when the tree to be removed is to be replaced and/or relocated by a tree of any of the types described in Appendix A Ordinance No. 929-89.

B.  Water as required by the City of Cocoa by interlocal agreement or hereby amended by the City of Rockledge. 
C.  Sewer/waste water as follows: Each and every owner, agent or party making connection with the city sewer system shall make such connection at his own expense after securing a permit from the city and paying the following sewer connection charge: 
(a)  Residential: 
(1)  For detached single-family residences, and mobile homes in mobile home subdivisions having: 
Not more than one bathroom ..... $2,000.00 
Not more than one bathroom in Zone A ..... 2,400.00 
Each bathroom in excess of one ..... 1,000.00 
(A half-bathroom or partial bathroom shall, as pertains to the applicable sewer connection charge, be deemed a full bathroom.) 
(2)  For additions to and remodeling of existing residential buildings involving additional bathroom facilities, the party making the connection shall pay the costs of any additional laterals required to be installed, and, in addition thereto, for each additional bathroom ..... 1,000.00 
(3)  For multiple-dwelling units, such as duplexes, triplexes, apartments and condominiums, per dwelling unit having: 
Not more than one bathroom ..... 2,000.00 
Not more than one bathroom in Zone A ..... 2,400.00 
Each bathroom in excess of one ..... 1,000.00 
(4)  For travel trailer parks: 
For each trailer lot ..... 700.00 
For each trailer lot in Zone A ..... 1,100.00 
Plus the established commercial charge for each other facility within the complex receiving sewer service. 
(5)  For motels and hotels: 
Per living unit (motel or hotel unit) ..... 2,000.00 
Per living unit (motel or hotel unit) in Zone A ..... 2,400.00 
Plus the established commercial charge for each other facility within the complex receiving sewer service. 
(b)  Commercial: 
(1)  For restaurants, without cocktail lounges: 
Per seat, on the basis of individual seating capacity in the restaurant ..... 180.00 
(2)  For restaurants, with cocktail lounges: 
Per seat, on the basis of individual seating capacity in the restaurant ..... 180.00 
(3)  For cocktail lounges (whether or not in connection with a restaurant): 
Per seat, on the basis of individual seating capacity in the cocktail lounge ..... 100.00 
(4)  For laundry facilities: 
Per washing machine ..... 700.00 
Plus the established commercial charge for each other facility within the complex receiving sewer service. 
(This connection charge applies to each washing machine situated outside and apart from an individual living unit in condominiums, apartments and multiple-dwelling units.) 
(5)  For office, retail stores: 
Per water closet ..... 2,000.00 
For the first water closet in Zone A ..... 2,400.00 
For each additional water closet in Zone A ..... 2,000.00 
(6)  For other commercial units: 
Per water closet ..... 2,000.00 
For the first water closet in Zone A ..... 2,400.00 
For each additional water closet in Zone A ..... 2,000.00 
In addition, for those uses which generate additional effluent discharge the following fees will be added to the water closet fee: The amount of the connection charge will be two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for the first three hundred (300) gallons per day of the commercial sewage flow, plus one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each additional two hundred (200) gallons per day, as determined from actual daily flow of water, or the daily flow as estimated by the building official. 
If the connection charge is based upon an estimate of the daily flow, the building official shall take into consideration such factors as meter size, the nature and extent of plumbing facilities, the type of business involved and the experience of comparable users; and the owner or agent shall have the right to appeal the estimate of the building official to the city council whose decision shall be final. 
An additional four hundred dollars ($400.00) (per equivalent residential unit, based on three hundred fifty (350) gpd rate), based upon an engineer's estimate of flow, will be added to the total sewer connection charge for all commercial facilities built in Zone A. 
(c)  Industrial: 
Per water closet ..... 2,000.00 
For the first water closet in Zone A ..... 2,400.00 
For each additional water closet in Zone A ..... 2,000.00 
In addition, for those uses which generate additional effluent discharge the following fees will be added to the water closet fee: two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for the first three hundred (300) gallons per day of industrial waste equivalent to domestic sewage, plus one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each additional two hundred (200) gallons per day, as determined from the actual daily flow of water, or the daily flow as estimated by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 1013-91, § 1, 10-2-91; Ord. No. 1098-95, §§ 1-4, 5-3-95; Ord. No. 1120-96, § 5, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1268-2002, § 3, 4-3-02) 
39.17.1. - Exemption from connection charge. 
(a)  [Generally.] No sewer connection charge shall be required with respect to the following: 
(1)  Property or structures for which a sewer connection charge has already been paid. 
(2)  Residential structures replaced with similar residential structures or commercial units replaced with similar commercial units. 
(3)  A structure located on property hereafter annexed to the city which structure is connected to an existing sewer system, either city owned or subsequently acquired by the city. 
(b)  Connection charge for property already paying service charges. With respect to existing structures as to which the owner or occupant has paid the regular monthly sewer service charge imposed pursuant to Section 17-44 [of the Code of Ordinances], the connection charge shall be one-half (1/2) of the connection charge required under Section 39.17 of this Code. 
(c)  Additional charge when use of property changed. If the use of any property served by the city sewer system changes so as to change its classification for the purpose of computation of the connection charge, or so as to increase the number of equivalent units over the number of such units at the time of payment of the last connection charge or February 6, 1974, whichever is later, then an additional charge resulting from the change in property use shall be due and payable at the time of the change in property use, regardless of whether any connection charge was ever imposed or paid at the time of initial connection to the system. The increased charge imposed by this section shall be included on and payable as part of the property owner's next sanitary sewer service bill. 
(d)  Payment of sewer connection charge. 
(1)  At or prior to the time of approval by the Rockledge City Council of the plat of any residential subdivision after May 8, 1986, the owner of the proposed subdivision will pay to the City of Rockledge, and the city clerk shall collect, a sum equal to the product obtained by multiplying one-half of the sewer connection charge required for a one bathroom dwelling unit in the zoning district where the proposed subdivision is located, times the total number of sewer connections that are allocated by the city and Florida Department of Environmental Regulation for the proposed subdivision, which payment shall be referred to as the "sewer connection deposit," and such deposit shall be ratably apportioned among all buildable lots in the subdivision, with the part of such deposit that it allocated to each separate lot being credited as part payment of the sewer connection charge for the dwelling unit to be constructed on that lot, and the owner or developer shall pay to the city, and the city clerk shall collect, the remaining part of the sewer connection charge required for each dwelling unit thereafter constructed in the subdivision at or prior to the time of issuance of the building permit for construction of the dwelling unit. 
(2)  For improvements other than dwellings in platted residential subdivisions, and for which improvements the owner or developer is required to obtain a Florida Department of Environmental Regulation (DER) permit to connect the proposed improvements to the Rockledge sewer system, one-half (1/2) of the total sewer connection charge applicable to said improvements, which payment shall be referred to as the "sewer connection deposit," shall be paid to the city prior to the city's endorsement of the application to the Florida Department of Environmental regulation for such permit, and the remaining one-half (1/2) of the sewer connection charge shall be payable at the time of application to the city for a building permit for the improvements. 
(3)  As to all premises other than those described in subsections (a) and (b) above, the city clerk shall collect the required sewer connection charge in full prior to issuance of a building permit, and no building permit will be issued until after the connection charge has been paid in full. 
(4)  All sewer connection deposits paid with respect to residential subdivisions at the time of plat approval, and all sewer connection deposits paid at the time of making application for a Florida Department of Environmental Regulation (DER) wastewater treatment connection permit, shall be deposited in the sewer capital improvement fund and used for the purposes described in this Code. All sewer connection charges collected at the building permit stage shall be allocated between the sewer capital improvement fund account and the renewal and replacement fund account and deposited in the relative proportions specified in subsection 39.17.1(h)(5). 
(e)  Expiration of sewer connection reservations. Any reservation of sewer connections made by the city in conjunction with approval of a residential subdivision plat shall expire one year after the date of approval of such plat by the Rockledge City Council unless within said one-year period construction of the streets, sewer lines, water lines, and other public improvements for said subdivisions have been completed and accepted by the city. Said expiration date may be extended by the city council for successive periods, each period not to exceed one year, if the owner or developer demonstrates to the city council that his failure to complete the public improvements within the prescribed time is due to hardship caused by war, act of God, market conditions, governmental restrictions, supply shortages, unavailability of necessary utilities, or other such reasonable cause for granting the extension. An application for continuance or extension of a sewer connection reservation must be made to the city prior to the expiration date of the reservation. The city shall have no responsibility, obligation or duty to make any sewer connection or to provide municipal sewer service for any improvement for which a sewer connection reservation has expired. 
(f)  Refund of sewer connection deposit in certain cases. Within one year after date of expiration of any sewer connection reservation, an owner may obtain a refund of his sewer connection deposit previously paid provided such owner shall first complete to the satisfaction of the city the following: 
(1)  File with the city a written application for refund annexing thereto evidence of the completion of these requirements for refund. 
(2)  Vacate the official plat of the subdivision for which the deposit was made. 
(3)  Obtain from the Florida Department of Environmental Regulation a written release and cancellation of the sewer connections that said department has charged off against the capacity of the city's wastewater treatment plant. 
(4)  Evidence in writing of such owner's intention not to proceed with the subdivision development. 
(5)  Furnish the city satisfactory evidence of such owner's entitlement to the refund. 
(6)  Adequately indemnify the city against loss resulting directly or indirectly because of the payment of such refund to the owner. 
    No interest shall accrue in favor of any owner, developer or other person with respect to any sewer connection deposit paid to or held by the city. 
(g)  Forfeiture of sewer connection deposit. Unless an owner or developer demonstrates his entitlement to a refund of his sewer connection deposit as provided above within one year following the date of expiration of the sewer connection reservation, the sewer connection deposit applicable to the sewer connection reservation that has expired shall stand and be deemed forfeited in full to the city by such owner or developer, and such owner or developer shall have no further right to a refund or other rights or entitlement with respect to the deposit, and the deposit shall be used by the city as other sewer connection fees are used. 
(h)  Application and use of sewer connection charges. 
(1)  The term "sewer connection charge," as used in this section, means the charge payable under the provisions of this section and for each separate and individual unit or facility for which a connection charge is specified. 
(2)  The city has established and shall continue to maintain an account designated "sewer capital improvement fund," and all funds now and hereafter deposited in said account, and any interest or income thereon, shall be expended and used only for the expansion and enlargement of the capacity of the existing sewer plant and wastewater treatment facility, or for the construction of a new sewer plant and wastewater treatment facility, as authorized by the city council, or to retire debts, including principal and interest, incurred in funding same. No part of such revenue shall be budgeted nor used for the operating expenses of the sewer system. 
(3)  The city has established and shall continue to maintain an account designated as the "renewal and replacement fund," and, except as provided in paragraph (4) hereof, all funds now and hereafter deposited in said account, or any interest or income thereon, shall be expended and used only for renewals and replacements to the existing sewer plant and for such acquisitions, additions and extensions of sewer lines and apparatus pertaining to the existing sewer system as will enhance the effectiveness, efficiency and operation of said system and wastewater treatment plant, as authorized by the city council. No part of such fund shall be budgeted nor used for the operating expenses of the sewer system. 
(4)  At any time that the balance in the renewal and replacement fund exceeds the sum of two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00), then, in such event, the Rockledge City Council may authorize funds in the renewal and replacement fund account exceeding two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00) to be transferred to and deposited in the sewer capital improvement fund account and appropriated by the city council to defray necessary capital improvement costs and debt services, including principal and interest. 
(5)  Of each sewer connection charge involving a new or additional connection (tap in) into the sewer collection system, $500.00 thereof shall be deposited in the Renewal and Replacement Fund, and the portion in excess thereof shall be deposited in the Sewer Capital Improvement Fund. In situations involving additions to or remodeling of an existing structure where additional bathroom facilities are installed, for which a connection charge is imposed by the provisions of this Code, but no new or additional connection (tap in) is made into the sewer collection system, the entire connection charge shall be deposited in the Sewer Capital Improvement Fund. 
(6)  Of each sewer connection charge involving a new or additional connection (tap-in) into the sewer collection system in Zone A as shown on Exhibit "A" to this chapter, nine hundred dollars ($900.00) thereof shall be deposited in the renewal and replacement fund, and the portion in excess thereof shall be deposited in the sewer capital improvement fund. In situations involving additions to or remodeling of an existing structure where additional bathroom facilities are installed, for which a connection charge is imposed by the provisions of this Code, but no new or additional connection (tap-in) is made into the sewer collection system, the entire connection charge shall be deposited in the sewer capital improvement fund. The city council may amend this tap-in provision and fees for Zone A from time to time by resolution, as it sees fit. 
(i)  Effect of conflict with bond ordinances. In the event any provision of this section shall conflict with any provision of any current bond ordinance of the city then the provisions of such bond ordinance shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 1013-91, § 2, 10-2-91; Ord. No. 1098-95, § 5, 5-3-95) 
39.18. - Application fee for comprehensive plan amendment. 
    Application for amendment of the Comprehensive Plan, or for other action which necessitates amendment of the Comprehensive Plan shall require a one thousand five hundred dollar ($1,500.00) deposit for Small Scale Comprehensive Plan amendments and two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) for regular Comprehensive Plan amendments to cover costs of newspaper advertisements, postage, printing and other costs of processing the proposed amendment. If the deposit is insufficient to cover all costs the applicant shall pay the city the balance of the costs exceeding the deposit. If separate amendments proposed by two (2) or more applicants are combined and processed in a single proceeding for the amendment of a regular Comprehensive Plan Amendment, a two thousand five hundred dollar ($2,500.00) cost deposit shall be paid by each applicant and costs incurred in the amendment process shall, insofar as possible, be allocated and apportioned equitably between the different applicants by the city clerk's office for the purpose of determining the amount of refund or additional payment required." 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 6, 8-14-96) 
39.19. - Concurrency review fee. 
    The City of Rockledge has the right to set fees for concurrency review on all facilities it operates or monitors. All other service providers and monitors have the right to set review fees only with agreement with the Rockledge City Council. 
39.20. - Burn permit required. 
    The burning of garbage, trash, yard trash or any other open or containerized burning is prohibited in the city limits, except as approved by the city council on recommendation of the fire chief. If such approval is granted, there shall be a one hundred dollar ($100.00) administrative fee payable in advance of the issuance of a burning permit. 
Part IV - ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND CONSERVATION 
General Provisions Ensuring Environmental Protection 
GENERAL PROVISIONS ENSURING ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION 
A.  [City declared bird and wildlife sanctuary.] The City of Rockledge has been declared a bird and wildlife sanctuary. All property within the city is hereby declared to be a bird and wildlife sanctuary. 
B.  Polluting Indian River generally. No person shall deposit, place or throw, wrapped or unwrapped, in packages or in boxes or in any other manner or method into the waters of the Indian River or upon the shores or banks thereof within the city, any dead animals, fowls, fish or parts thereof, or any vegetables or parts thereof, or any fruit or parts thereof, or any rubbish, filth, trash, waste, weeds or any noxious matter whatsoever. 
C.  Sewage pipes draining into Indian River. No person shall construct or maintain any sewage pipes which drain into the Indian River. 
D.  Wetlands or hydrologically sensitive areas. No person or persons shall in any single or successive land filling, excavation or site preparation work or operation affect any change in elevation of land to the extent described in these regulations, nor be entitled to a building permit for the improvement of said property unless they have first complied with the following requirements: 
(a)  The property owner(s) or his/their representative shall submit documentation certifying the subject parcel is not considered to be either a wetland or hydrologically sensitive area, as defined by any of the following authorities that have jurisdiction to make such a determination over the property, i.e., St. Johns River Water Management District (SJRWMD), Florida Department of Environmental Regulation (DER), U.S. Army Corps of Engineers (ACOE) or Florida Department of Natural Resources (DNR); or 
(b)  If the parcel contains wetlands or hydrologically sensitive areas, the property owner(s) or his/their representative shall submit a copy of the required permits indicating regulatory agency approval of the project and the scope of work. 
SECTION 40.00. - PROTECTION OF AND REMOVAL OF TREES AND OPEN SPACE PRESERVATION 
(A)  Purpose and intent: 
(1)  The purpose of this section is to provide protective regulations for trees, landscaping, open space and soil conservation in the City of Rockledge. 
(2)  It is the intent of this section to promote the community appearance and assist in the natural control of solar heat, soil conservation, flooding, water conservation and recharge, air pollution and noise. In addition, trees offer a haven for community wildlife and provide citizens with psychological relief from the increasing complexities of a man-made urban environment. Further, it is the intent of this section to enhance the community and its citizenry, not to be punitive or to cause a hardship to any individual or public or private company which uses reasonable care and diligence to protect trees and indigenous plants and open space within the City of Rockledge. 
(B)  Tree protection: 
(1)  Generally: 
(a)  No person, directly or indirectly, shall cut down, destroy, remove or move, or effectively destroy through damaging any tree located on any property within the City of Rockledge without first obtaining a permit, unless otherwise provided herein. 
(b)  Tree permits authorized by this section may be obtained by making application for permit to the building official on a form to be supplied by the city, indicating the type tree and how it is proposed to be cut, destroyed or removed, who will perform the work, and such other information as may be required by the building official to effectively enforce the provisions of this section. A separate application shall be filed for each site upon which tree removal is requested. 
(2)  Exceptions. The following types of trees shall be exempt from the provisions of this section, and no permit or fees shall be required for the removal, cutting down or destruction of these trees: 
(a)  Melaleuca quinquenervia (Cajaput or Paperbark). 
(b)  Melaleuca leucadendra (Punk). 
(c)  Casuarina (spp), (Australian Pine), (Brazilian Oak). 
(d)  Schinus terebinthinfolius (Brazilian Pepper). 
(e)  Araucaria excelsa (Norfolk Island Pine). 
(f)  Eucalyptus (all varieties except Eucalyptus Cinerea). 
(g)  Bischofia javanica (Bishopwood, Bischofia). 
(h)  Ricinus communis (Castorbean). 
(i)  Metopium toxiferum (Poison Wood). 
(j)  Melaiceae asedarach (Chinaberry). 
(k)  Enterolobium (spp), (Eartree). 
(l)  Trees located in state-licensed and governmental plant or tree nurseries or botanical gardens in which the trees are planted and growing for the sale or intended sale to the general public in the ordinary course of business or for some public purpose and which are sold. 
(m)  Trees which are required to be removed by law. 
(n)  Trees which, due to natural circumstances, are no longer viable, are in danger of falling, are too close to existing structures so as to endanger such structures, interfere with utility services, create unsafe vision clearance or constitutes a safety hazard. 
(o)  Trees located within three (3) feet of a survey line cut or cleared by a licensed land surveyor acting in the course of his profession or located within three (3) feet of any public utility main, pipe, wire, line or conduit. 
(p)  Trees on a single-family residential lot or on a two-family residential lot; provided, that after such removal the lot will contain a minimum of at least four (4) non-noxious non-invasive trees of any type or types listed in the City of Rockledge recommended tree species, use and characteristics list (Tree list) if after the removal the lot will contain less than four (4) trees listed on the tree list, a substitute tree of any type or types listed on the tree list is planted for each tree to be removed, such planting to be performed within thirty (30) days of the removal. PUD (Planned Unit Development) zoned lots having fifty (50) feet or less of width will be required to have only three (3) trees. 
(q)  The relocation of existing trees on-site. 
(3)  Application for tree removal permit: 
(a)  Predevelopment. The removal of any tree or trees from real property in the City of Rockledge which has not been previously developed pursuant to an approved site plan is hereby prohibited, except that no tree removal permit shall be required for removal of any of the exempt and excepted trees described in subsection (B)(2) of this section. An application pursuant to the requirements in subsection (B)(2) shall be completed and a permit required. 
(b)  During construction. Application for a tree removal permit during construction shall be required as a part of the site plan submittal, except that no tree removal permit shall be required for removal of any of the exempt and excepted trees described in subsection (B)(2) of this section. The applicant shall submit a legible, reproducible plan, drawn to scale and indicating the following information for the entire site: 
1.  Location, shape and spatial arrangements of all existing and proposed buildings, walls or fences, or other improvements and structures. 
2.  Identification of uses on adjacent properties. 
3.  Location, shape and spatial arrangement of all parking areas and access roads. 
4.  Existing and proposed utility services. 
5.  Existing and proposed elevations. 
6.  Setbacks, yard requirements and location of easements. 
7.  Existing and proposed wells. 
8.  All sink holes, rock outcroppings and historical sites. 
9.  A tree survey certified by a landscape architect, land surveyor or land planner overlaid directly upon the site plan, and indicating the location referenced to structures, of all protected trees as defined in this section. The survey shall distinguish existing trees which are proposed to be destroyed, relocated, replaced or preserved at their present location. Said survey shall show the location of all existing trees as defined in this section. Tree information shall be summarized in a legend form and shall contain the variety, trunk diameter, height and location referenced to structure of all trees shown on the survey. Groups of trees less than three (3) feet apart may be designed as clumps, with the exception that any tree with a trunk diameter of eight (8) inches or more must be specifically designated. For sites on which tree removal activity is to occur on less than the entirety of the site, the building official shall provide that the tree survey may exclude those portions of the site which it determines will not be affected by the tree removal or clearing activity. 
10.  Trees not affected by tree removal or clearing activity shall be properly identified by means of surveying tape or non-injurious painting. Each tree preserved shall be protected by fencing around the drip line of the canopy. 
(c)  Post-development: An application for a tree removal permit shall be required for removal of any tree on real property previously developed and for which a certificate of occupancy has been issued, except that no tree removal permit shall be required for removal of any of the exempt and excepted trees described in subsection (B)(2) of this section. The following information shall be required on an application for removal of a nonexempt tree from such previously developed property: 
1.  Site plan showing all structures, sidewalks, driveways, etc. 
2.  Location on site plan of trees to be preserved, removed, and replacement location of tree from the tree list. 
(d)  Application fee. The nonrefundable application fee for the tree removal permit authorized under this section shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) for the first tree and ten dollars ($10.00) for each additional tree for which removal is requested on said application, with a maximum fee not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). An applicant may apply for a fee waiver when the tree to be removed is to be replaced and/or relocated by a tree of any of the types described in the tree list. 
(4)  Criteria for issuance of tree removal permits. Tree removal permits shall be issued in accordance with this subsection (B) when the building official has been satisfied that the application meets all of the following criteria: 
(a)  The subject tree is located within the area where any building, roadway, pavement, retention pond or other improvement is proposed to be constructed, or where a grade change necessary to proposed development of the site will be made which is too severe for the tree to survive, and such proposed improvements or grade change cannot be relocated upon the site so as to further maximize the preservation of the existing trees upon the site while not unreasonably restricting the permitted use of the property. 
(b)  If it is in the welfare of the general public that the tree be removed for a reason other than set forth above. 
(c)  Appropriate arrangements for disposal of trees and tree parts have been provided that will comply to the Landfill Ordinance (Ordinance No. 922-89, adopted August 2, 1989) [Section 43.00]. 
(5)  Relocation or replacement: 
(a)  As a condition to the granting of a tree removal permit under this section, the applicant may be required, where practical, to: 
1.  Relocate those trees which would otherwise be destroyed to another location upon the site; or 
2.  Replace those trees which will be destroyed with suitable replacement trees elsewhere within the site. Such replacement trees shall be of a variety listed in the tree list or of any other variety approved by the building official. 
(b)  In determining the required relocation or replacement of trees, the building official or agent shall consider the needs of the intended use of the property, including all lands dedicated to public use, together with an evaluation of the following: 
1.  Existing tree coverage on the site and in the immediate surrounding area. 
2.  Number of trees or trees to be removed on the entire site. 
3.  The type, size and condition of the tree or trees to be removed. 
4.  The feasibility of relocating that particular tree or trees. 
5.  Topography and drainage of the site. 
6.  The extent to which the tree or trees contribute to the aesthetic, economic and environmental integrity of the surrounding area. 
7.  No person shall plant or transplant any tree or shrub within the area or space between a sidewalk and the adjacent street, in any parkway or right-of-way, without first obtaining a written permit from the city manager, subject to the list of prohibited species of trees. 
(6)  Procedure for permitting tree removal: 
(a)  Upon receipt of a completed application containing all the information as required by this section, the building official shall review said application. The review procedure shall determine the adequacy and accuracy of content, and determine whether the application meets the requirements of this subsection (B), and whether the applicant has taken all necessary and reasonable steps to preserve existing trees and to otherwise enhance the aesthetic appearance of the proposed development by incorporation of trees into the design process. 
(b)  Following approval of the application, the building official shall issue the appropriate permits. 
(c)  Upon the issuance of a tree removal permit under this subsection (B), a copy of said permit shall be prominently displayed on the site prior to the removal, relocation or replacement of any trees. Tree removal permits shall be included with all other permit cards and shall be displayed alongside them on the site. 
(d)  No final certificate of occupancy shall be issued nor electrical power connection authorization given until any relocation or replacement of trees required by the tree removal permit has been completed and a final tree inspection approval has been given by the building official. Trees relocating from one portion of the site to another which do not survive transplantation for at least one year shall be replaced by the owner of the site with a suitable replacement tree. 
(7)  Protection of trees not approved for removal, relocation or destruction. It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or cause to be placed, materials, machinery or temporary soil deposits within the drip line of any tree protected by this section and not permitted for removal or destruction, to fail to erect barriers necessary to protect such tree, or to attach anything other than protective wires, braces or other similar non-injurious materials to such tree. Furthermore, no structure or impervious paving shall be located within a three-foot radius of the trunk perimeter of any such tree. A tree of two and one-half (21/2) feet or more in diameter shall require additional space as may be determined by the building official. 
(Ord. No. 1174-98, § 1, 11-4-98; Ord. No. 1332-2003, § 1, 12-17-03; Ord. No. 1385-2005, § 1, 8-17-05) 
SECTION 40.10. OPEN SPACE AND PRESERVATION CREDITS FOR LANDSCAPING 
    Open space as referred to in this section shall mean those unimproved portions of development site plans for Single-family, multi-family, commercial and industrial projects with the main intent to preserve trees and habitat. Preservation of these open space areas will result in reduced infrastructure construction cost and reduction of landscaping cost and by offering credits and incentives to developers to increase these areas beyond what is required by code. 
1.  Tree preservation credits. Trees to be preserved on site will receive the following credits to the landscaping requirements found in Section 40.30.

2.  Preservation incentives. Those development sites which offer to preserve more trees than are required by the landscape code for parameter and interior trees may request the following incentives in the order presented: 1) reduction in required building setback distance (up to twenty (20) per cent on non-residential sides) 2) reductions in parking space requirements (up to a ten (10) per cent reduction); 3) increase lot coverage requirements (up to an additional ten (10) per cent of coverage based upon the zoning district requirements); 4) reduction in storm water retention standards (no greater than ten (10) per cent and no less than the requirements of St. Johns River Water Management District) and 5) a possible density bonus of one unit per acre for residential projects. 
3.  Incentives process. 
(a)  Applicant shall submit a site plan in accordance with the provisions of Section 40.30, showing the tree survey and those trees and open space proposed to preserved. The plan shall also show proposed retention areas, building footprints ingress/egress points and parking areas. 
(b)  Staff will calculate the trees required for the site and determine if the applicant can request preservation bonuses and incentives. 
(c)  Staff report will be faxed and/or given to the applicant and the applicant will have ten (10) working days to decide if they will be requesting preservation bonuses or incentives. 
(d)  The applicant will request what types of incentives/bonuses they will be requesting, which will be forwarded to the planning commission and city council for their review and approval. 
(e)  The final site plan shall be engineered to meet the approved incentives given by the Rockledge City Council. 
(f)  The final landscaping plan shall reflect the preservation credits and will be binding on the applicant and will automatically comply with the landscaping requirements of the city. 
(g)  Those projects exceeding the tree preservation landscaping requirements, will be exempt from the tree removal fees and permitting.

(b)  Applicant will be required to protect of preservation trees on-site during the construction phase and ensure their viability for the first year. 
(c)  Preserved trees dying during the first will be replaced using the credit chart in reverse. 
(Ord. No. 1332-2003, § 1, 12-17-03) 
SECTION 40.11. - TREE PROTECTION AND CONSERVATION AND CARE DURING DEVELOPMENT 
    During the clearing of land for development purposes, protected trees and accompanying under-story shall be conserved on the development site wherever and whenever reasonably possible. This requires protection of vegetation from mechanical damage and soil compaction during construction. The developer shall include on the site plan how existing trees shall be preserved, mitigated on site, or mitigated to another site selected by the City of Rockledge. It is required that all reasonable effort be made to save major trees. Reasonable effort shall include, but not be limited to, alteration of building design; alternate location of building, parking area, water retention, drainage pipes; micro-siding of buildings or improvements; or relocation of utilities. All retained, re-located, or replaced trees must be protected by temporary barriers around them to prevent parking or storage of materials. To the extent that protected trees are lost or destroyed as a result of the clearing of a development site, the developer shall mitigate for their loss or destruction by the planting of replacement trees as follows: 
(a)  Credits. (See section 40.10) 
(b)  All pruning must be done following the American National Standard for Tree Care Operations Tree, Shrub, and Other Wood Plant Maintenance-Standard Practices (available from the International Society of Arboriculture, P. O. Box GG, Savoy, IL 61874-9902. The Code specifically prohibits: 
Topping tree limbs over a three-inch caliper or trimming them into little round balls of foliage. 
Excessive thinning of the tree crown. 
Removing lower limbs higher than seven (7) feet above the ground level on the trunk (unless this is necessary for the safe passage of large vehicles such as fire or garbage trucks). 
(c)  The required amount of replacement trees shall be planted, established and nurtured on the development site to the extent determined practicable by the developer, provided that such trees shall be at least two (2) caliper-inches and shall be planted no closer than ten (10) feet to any other tree. 
(Ord. No. 1385-2005, § 2, 8-17-05) 
SECTION 40.20. - SOIL CONSERVATION 
(1)  Scope and exclusions. This section shall apply to any land-disturbing activity undertaken by any person on any lands, except for the following: 
(a)  Minor land-disturbing activities such as home gardens and individual home landscaping, repairs, maintenance work, or other related activities which result in minor soil erosion. 
(b)  The construction of single-family residences when they are constructed by or under contract with the owner for his own occupancy, excluding residential accessory modifications (i.e., sheds, pools, driveways, etc.) 
(c)  Any activity for which bids have been let or construction contract signed prior to the date of adoption of this section; provided, that the activity is completed within six (6) months after the effective date of this section. 
(2)  Procedure for permitting land-disturbing activity: 
(a)  No person shall perform any land-disturbing activity without first obtaining an erosion and sedimentation control permit from the building official after certification by the city engineer to perform such activity. Such permit shall be in addition to any other permits or approvals required for the project by any other ordinances, rules and regulations in effect. 
1.  All commercial, industrial, manufacturing and subdivision projects must receive approval from the St. Johns River Management District. 
(b)  Application for an erosion and sedimentation control permit must be made to the city engineer on an application form provided by the city, and must be accompanied by an erosion and sedimentation control plan. The applicant's erosion and sedimentation control plan shall include, as a minimum, the following information for the entire tract of land to be disturbed, regardless of whether the tract will be developed in stages: 
1.  A narrative description of the overall project. This narrative shall include: 
a.  Anticipated starting and completion dates for each sequence and stage of land disturbing activities and the expected date the final stabilization will be completed; and 
b.  A description of the sediment control program and sediment control practices; and 
c.  An adequate description of general topographical and soil conditions of the tract; and 
d.  A description of the zoning classification of adjacent property and a general description of existing structures, building and other fixed improvements located within a perimeter of two hundred (200) feet of the boundary line of applicant's property; and 
e.  A description of the maintenance program for sediment control facilities including inspection programs, re-vegetation of exposed soils, method and frequency of removal and disposal of solid waste material removed from control facilities and disposition of temporary structural measures. 
2.  The city engineer or his designee shall approve the erosion and sedimentation control plan upon finding that the requirements of this section have been met. 
3.  If the tract is to be developed in phases, then the building official may issue a separate permit for a master plan or for each phase. 
4.  The permit may be suspended, revoked or modified by the building official or his designee upon a finding that the holder is not in compliance with this section or has violated any of the provisions or conditions of the permit. 
5.  No building permit shall be issued until any required erosion and sedimentation control permit certifying approval of the erosion and sedimentation control plan is obtained in accordance with this section. 
(3)  Maintenance. Maintenance of all soil erosion and sedimentation control practices, whether temporary or permanent, shall be at all times the responsibility of the owner. 
(4)  Penalty for violation: 
(a)  Any person who directly or indirectly willfully causes any land-disturbing activity without first obtaining an erosion and sedimentation control permit from the building official and in violation of any provisions of this section shall, and upon being found in violation of this Code, maybe fined in an amount not to exceed one dollar ($1.00) per square foot of property disturbed. 
(b)  All fines shall be imposed by the code enforcement board in the same fashion as other code violations. The defenses of accident or ignorance may be raised and can be, but are not absolute, defenses to the imposition of the fine. 
(Ord. No. 1332-2003, § 1, 12-17-03) 
SECTION 40.30. - LANDSCAPING 
    The provisions of this section shall apply to all future development of property within the city and shall be the minimum requirements to promote the public health, safety and general welfare by providing for installation and maintenance of certain landscaped areas; to protect the character and stability of residential, business, manufacturing, institutional and industrial areas; and to conserve the value of land and buildings on surrounding properties and neighborhoods. 
(1)  Landscaping plan required: 
(a)  No new non-residential or multi-family site plans or projects classified as substantial improvements shall be approved unless accompanied by a landscaping plan drawn to a scale of not less than one inch equals fifty (50) feet, showing the required off-street parking facilities and landscaping. Nor shall a permit be issued for the improvement of a parking area to serve as an accessory use to an existing building or buildings until a landscaping plan has been approved in accordance with the provisions herein set forth. Prior to approval, the landscaping plan will be reviewed by the building official in order to ensure that all requirements have been met. 
(b)  The landscaping plan shall describe the following: 
1.  The plant material proposed for use listed according to species, variety, quality and size. Existing native drought resistant plant material is encouraged to be retained wherever possible and credit will be allowed for the retention of viable plant material on the site. 
2.  Provision for water efficient irrigation systems, with rain sensor devices, to provide deep watering of the roots of the plant material and sod, to encourage deeper root growth, which will promote a healthier more drought tolerant landscaping plan. 
3.  Access aisles, driveways, water efficient irrigation systems, and water outlet location and storm water retention areas and structures and utility systems whether underground or aerial, shall be illustrated on the landscape plan. 
(2)  Landscaping design standards: 
(a)  Commercial, professional, multifamily, manufacturing, institutional and industrial zoning: 
1.  Landscaping for yard areas adjacent to abutting properties. Landscaping shall be provided in accordance to the following example illustrated below (see Figure 1): 
a.  Off-street parking or other vehicular use areas which are not entirely screened visually by an intervening building or structure from the abutting property shall be provided with a wall, fence or landscaped barrier not greater than six (6) feet in height or less than three (3) feet in height. Such barrier shall form a continuous barrier between the off-street parking area or other vehicular use area and the abutting property. This barrier shall be located along the common lot line. Should this barrier consist entirely of planted materials, the planting strip shall not be less than seven (7) feet in width. 
b.  One tree shall be provided for each thirty (30) linear feet or fraction thereof of lot perimeter. 
c.  When the abutting property is zoned or used for single- or two-family uses, the required landscaping area shall meet the applicable yard requirement of the adjacent property. 
FIGURE 1 

Figure 1
2.  Landscaping for yard areas adjacent to public rights-of-way. Landscaping shall be provided in accordance with the following: 
a.  A landscaping area at least ten (10) feet in width shall be provided between the abutting rights-of-way and the vehicular use or parking lot area. The ten-foot landscaped area is to be part of the developed private property and shall not include any public property or street right-of-way. A flowering hedge or other durable native drought tolerant landscape screen not less than two (2) feet or greater than three (3) feet in height shall be planted in the yard area. Planting size (3 gallon containers and spacing no greater than three feet apart). 
b.  One tree shall be planted for each thirty (30) linear feet of lot frontage or fraction thereof. 
c.  That portion of any public right-of-way which abuts property regulated by this subsection must be sodded or make use of an approved ground cover by the owner or the applicant up to the back of the curb or edge of the pavement, whichever is applicable. 
d.  Necessary and approved accessways through the landscaped area may be subtracted from the linear dimension used to determine the number of trees required. 
3.  Interior parking area landscaping. Off-street parking areas shall have at least ten (10) square feet of interior landscaping for each parking space excluding those spaces abutting a perimeter for which landscaping is required by other part of this subsection (E). Such interior landscaping shall maintain the following standards: 
a.  Each separate landscaped area shall contain a minimum of two-hundred fifty (250) square feet landscaping materials, each landscape area shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet in width. 
b.  Each separate landscaped area shall contain at least one tree having a clear trunk of at least five (5) feet in height as measured from the average grade level with the remaining area adequately landscaped with shrubs, ground cover or other authorized landscaping material. 
c.  Each separate landscaped area shall be located in such a manner as to divide and break up the expanse of paving and at strategic points to guide traffic flow and direction. 
d.  All planting areas may be protected with a continuous curb or be part of an on-site water retention or drainage system. 
e.  If the specific application of the interior landscape requirements will seriously limit functions of the building site, the building official shall have authority to permit consolidation and relocation of these landscaped areas on the building site. 
f.  One additional interior tree for every fifteen (15) parking spaces. 
4.  Visibility at intersections. Landscaping shall not obstruct the visibility of automobiles at intersections. No landscaping, flowering hedges, or plantings shall be placed or allowed to obstruct the clear vision of street intersections in violation of the provisions of Section 52.23 of this Code. 
5.  Internal landscaping regulations: 
a.  Off-street parking areas. The owner, tenant and/or agent of an off-street parking or other vehicular use area shall landscape within the internal off-street parking area as described below. All parking areas and other paved ground surface areas used for vehicular use shall have internal landscaping to provide visual and climatic relief from broad expanses of pavement and to channelize and define logical areas for pedestrian and vehicular circulation. Prior to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy by the building official, the following landscaping requirements shall be met: 
i. A minimum landscape buffer strip of four (4) feet in width where tiers of parking are utilized. Examples of such tiers are illustrated below (See Figure 2): 
FIGURE 2 

Figure 2
This is a minimum requirement and cannot be utilized as the overhang area for a car. Curbing shall be placed in each space at least two (2) feet away from the edge of the four-foot buffer strip adjoining a parking area to prevent vehicle overhang onto the four-foot wide buffer area; and the two (2) feet of ground surface between the curbing and/or wheel stops, and the edge of the four-foot buffer strip, shall be covered with lawn grass or native drought tolerant ground cover rather than pavement. The relationship of the curbing and/or wheel stops and the two-foot grassy areas between the curbing and/or wheel stops and the edge of the four-foot buffer strip is illustrated below (see Figure 3): 
FIGURE 3 

Figure 3
ii. A native drought tolerant hedge or other durable landscape screen shall be installed at least two (2) feet six (6) inches in height, immediately upon planting in said area except as provided in subparagraph 5.1.iii [5.a.iii] below. The hedge shall be continuous except as provided in subparagraph 5.a.iv of this subsection. Planting size (three-gallon containers and spacing no greater than three (3) feet). 
iii. If the durable screen is of nonliving material, the provision of subparagraph 5.a.iv of this subsection shall be followed. 
iv. A pedestrian cross accessway shall be installed within the four-foot buffer area. Such accessways shall be provided as follows: 
(a) If the four-foot buffer strip is between eighty (80) and one hundred (100) feet in length, one pedestrian cross accessway shall be provided. 
(b) If the four-foot buffer strip is between one hundred (100) and two hundred (200) feet, two (2) pedestrian cross accessways shall be provided. 
(c) If the four-foot buffer strip is greater than two hundred (200) feet, two (2) pedestrian accessways shall be provided, plus one additional accessway shall be provided for each two hundred (200) feet or fraction thereof in addition to the two hundred (200) feet. 
v. Landscaping for I-P zoning district: 
(a) Except as otherwise provided, all open portions of any lot and all parking areas shall be graded, drained and landscaped with trees and shrubs planted in ground cover. One tree for every one thousand (1,000) square feet of non-paved open area shall be planted. This is in addition to the interior landscaping requirements. 
(b) All parking areas shall have internal landscaping to provide visual and climatic relief from broad expanses of pavement and to channelize and define logical areas for pedestrian and vehicular circulation. Interior landscaping shall account for a minimum of ten (10) per cent of parking areas. A tree shall be planted for each two hundred (200) square feet of required interior landscaping. All interior landscaping shall be protected from vehicular encroachment by curbing and/or wheel stops. Landscaping dividing strips, with or without walkways, shall be used to subdivide parking areas into parking bays with not more than thirty (30) spaces; provided, that no more than fifteen (15) spaces shall be in an uninterrupted row. 
b.  Minimum landscaping for newly developed single-and two-family residential lots. 
i. A minimum of four (4) trees must exist or be planted on each newly developed lot. Trees planted must be of a variety which is compatible with the existing soil and drainage condition and must be provided with an efficient water and nutrient source to encourage growth. Trees shall be planted in locations so as not to cause danger or interference with existing structures at the time of maturity. 
ii. Residential lots must use one or a combination of the following: be fully sodded; or make adequate use of ground covers; or native drought tolerant vegetation to present a finished appearance. In no case shall more than fifteen (15) per cent of the residential lot contain non-living vegetative materials (i.e.: mulch, rock, etc.) 
iii. That portion of any public right-of-way which abuts property regulated by this subsection must be sodded by the owner or the applicant up to the back of the curb or edge of the pavement, whichever is applicable. 
iv. When adequate ground cover or sod is not available, the applicant may post a bond with the building official to satisfy requirements of above within six (6) months of receipt of a certificate of occupancy. 
(3)  Plant materials and planting procedures: 
(a)  The total number of trees required for any development shall be of the species listed. No less than seventy-five (75) per cent of the required trees shall be native trees. Fifty (50) per cent of the trees planted must be of a canopy type and no more than one palm tree species may be used in the total tree requirement. No more than thirty (30%) per cent of any one type of tree species in each category shall be planted on each development. 
(b)  Plant material used in conformance with provisions of this section shall equal or exceed the standards for Florida No. 1, as given in "Grades and Standards for Nursery Plants. 1973," State of Florida, Department of Agriculture, Tallahassee, and any amendments thereto. Grass sod shall be clean and reasonably free of weeds and noxious pests or diseases. 
(c)  The required landscaping shall be installed according to accepted commercial planting procedures. All elements of landscaping shall be installed so as to meet all other applicable ordinances and code requirements of the City of Rockledge. Landscaped areas shall require protection from vehicular encroachment as herein provided. The building official shall inspect all landscaping, and no certificate of occupancy or similar authorization shall be issued prior to landscaping conforming to the requirements herein provided. 
(d)  Trees shall be of a species capable of growing in the Central Coastal area of Florida with an overall height of a minimum of fifteen (15) feet. When planted, trees must be at least eight (8) to ten (10) feet in height. (no less than a twenty-five-gallon container) Trees having an average mature spread of crown less than fifteen (15) feet may be substituted by grouping the same as to create the minimum fifteen (15) feet crown spread. Trees of species providing roots known to cause damage to public roadways or other public works shall not be planted closer than twelve (12) feet to such public works, unless the tree root system is completely encased within a container for which the minimum interior dimension shall be five (5) feet square and five (5) feet deep. 
1.  Trees planted near utility lines, both underground and aerial, will not be allowed to be planted within the specific distances as shown on tree list. 
(4)  Landscaping maintenance standards and responsibilities: 
(a)  Landscaping shall be maintained in a manner so as to not obstruct the visibility of automobiles at intersections or at points of ingress and egress to the public right-of-way. 
(b)  All landscaping required under the provisions of this section shall be maintained by the owner in a viable, neat and orderly condition. Nonviable landscaping shall be replaced to satisfy the requirements of this section at the developer's or owner's expense. 
(c)  The applicant shall provide each landscaped area with a water efficient irrigation system, with rain sensor devices that provide coverage to all landscaped areas. Priority shall be given to use of nonpotable water sources (i.e., shallow wells, reuse lines, recycled water, etc.). 
(d)  Trees and shrub pruning shall be done in accordance with American National Standard Institute requirements for Tree Care Operations as amended from time to time. 
(5)  Hazardous trees and landscaping. The building official may require the removal of any tree or landscaping which is a nuisance and constitutes eminent danger to the safety of the public under the provisions of the Rockledge City Code. 
(6)  Appeals. Any decision of the building official regarding the interpretation of any portion of the provisions of this section may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any office or bureau of the governing body of the city affected thereby to the board of adjustment under Section 28.00 [Section 23.00] of this Code. 
(7)  Penalty for violation: 
(1)  Any person who directly or indirectly willfully causes any tree located within the City of Rockledge to be cut down, removed or effectively destroyed in violation of any provisions of this section shall, upon being found in violation violators maybe fined in an amount not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) per diameter inch of the each tree destroyed. The unlawful cutting down, removal or effective destruction of each tree shall be deemed a separate offense punishable as herein stated. 
(a)  All fines shall be imposed by the code enforcement board in the same fashion as other code violations. The defenses of accident or ignorance may be raised and can be, but are not absolute, defenses to the imposition of the fine. 
(2)  Whenever the provisions of this section require the performance of any act or thing, or the submission of any documentation or other condition precedent to the issuance of a tree removal permit or other form of permit, no such permit shall be issued until the required performance is completed or required documentation is received in compliance with this section. 
(3)  The provisions of this section may also be enforceable by proceedings before the Rockledge Code Enforcement Board, or by suit for prohibitory or mandatory injunctive relief, or by any other lawful remedy existing at law or in equity for the enforcement of municipal ordinances. 
(8)  One year maintenance bond for all non-residential projects. 
(a)  All required landscape materials on the site, whether preserved or newly planted, must demonstrate health and viability one year after issuance of certificate of completion, except for individual single-family lots. For multi-family, commercial and industrial projects, the city may perform a courtesy inspection of the landscaping within ninety (90) days after the issuance of certificate of occupancy or certificate of completion. If the vegetation appears to be under stress, the staff shall notify the property owner. A second inspection may be performed six (6) months after the issuance of the certificate of occupancy or certificate of completion. If the vegetation is not viable at that inspection, notice shall be given to the property owner and the property owner shall be responsible for replacing that dead vegetation with equivalent points of landscaping material. Failure to have viable landscaping materials consistent with the approved landscape plan in place at the twelve-month inspection from the date of the issuance of the certificate of occupancy or certificate of completion shall constitute a violation as described under Section 40.30. A maintenance bond, cash bond or letter of credit shall be required to be collected at the time a certificate of occupancy is issued for multi-family, commercial, and industrial projects (two (2) acres or more in size), equal to twenty-five (25) per cent of the cost of vegetation other than sod. This maintenance bond, cash bond, or letter of credit shall be foe a period of one year and forfeited if required vegetation is not maintained in a viable state. The city reserves the right to cross property in order to make the necessary inspections. 
(b)  The maintenance bond requirement may be appealed in whole or part by the property owner or tenant to the city council for a hardship waiver. Should the city council determine that an economic hardship exist, they may waive either in full or in part, the bond requirement which would cause the hardship.
