(7)  Electromagnetic radiation: 
(a)  Requirements. All uses shall be controlled to prevent any intentional source of electromagnetic radiation which does not comply with the current regulations of the Federal Communications Commission regarding such sources of electromagnetic radiation. Further, any operation in compliance with Federal Communications Commission regulations shall not be permitted if such radiation causes an abnormal degradation in performance of other electromagnetic radiators or electromagnetic receptors of quality and proper design because of proximity, primary field, blanketing, spurious reradiation, conducted energy in power or telephone systems or harmonic content. 
(b)  Method of measurement. For the purpose of determining the level of radiated electromagnetic interference, standard field-strength measuring techniques for interference transmitted or conducted by power or telephone lines, a suitable turntable peak reading radio frequency voltmeter shall be used. This instrument shall, by means of appropriate isolation coupling, be alternately connected from line to line and from line to ground during the measurement. 
(c)  Determination of electromagnetic interference. The determination of "abnormal degradation in performance," and of "quality and proper design" shall be made in accordance with good engineering practices as defined in the latest principles and standards of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers, the Institute of Radio Engineers, and the Radio Manufacturer's Association. In case of any conflict between the latest standards and principles of the above groups, precedence in the interpretation shall be in the following order: 
1.  American Institute of Electrical Engineers; 
2.  Institute of Radio Engineers; and, 
3.  Radio Manufacturer's Association. 
(d)  Maximum allowable levels. For purposes of determining the maximum allowable level of radiated electromagnetic interference and electromagnetic interference transmitted or conducted by power or telephone lines, maximum allowable levels will be adopted by the city council upon recommendation of the planning commission and qualified electrical engineers. 
(8)  Heat and humidity. Any use producing humidity in the form of steam or moist air, or producing heat, shall be carried on in such a manner that steam, humidity or heat is not perceptible at any lot line. 
(9)  Environmental liability surety bond: 
(a)  Every business now or hereafter conducted in the City of Rockledge which generates, produces, stores, processes, reuses, recycles, or handles any "hazardous waste" as hereinafter defined, such business being herein referred to as a "regulated business," is hereby required to post with the City of Rockledge an environmental liability surety bond in form and content approved by the City unless exempt under the later provisions of this Section. 
(b)  Every owner of a regulated business in existence and in operation in the City of Rockledge at the time of enactment of this Section shall comply with the provisions of this Section by furnishing the required environmental liability surety bond on or before October 1st, 1991, if engaged in such regulated business at that time. 
(c)  Every regulated business commencing operation in the City of Rockledge after date of enactment of this Section shall furnish the required environmental liability surety bond before being issued an occupational license. 
(d)  Every environmental liability surety bond will run in favor of the City of Rockledge as the Obligee, and the conditions of the bond will be that the Obligor comply with all Florida State and Federal statutes, rules and regulations applicable to hazardous waste on the business site, and that in the event of an accidental, unauthorized or unlawful release, spill, or escape of a hazardous waste product, the obligor will timely and expediently complete all environmental recovery, rehabilitation, cleanup and restoration work and activities in accordance with applicable state and federal requirements. 
(e)  The surety on every environmental liability surety bond required by this Section shall be an insurance company duly authorized and licensed to transact insurance business in the State of Florida. 
(f)  Every environmental liability surety bond will be for a term of one (1) year and will contain an express provision that the bond cannot be cancelled or terminated by either the principal or surety named therein without notice thereof in writing to the City at least thirty (30) days in advance of the date of such cancellation or termination. 
(g)  Every business required to have an environmental liability surety bond will evidence to the City of Rockledge at the time of renewal of its annual occupational license, the payment of its bond premium by furnishing to the City a paid receipt evidencing such payment. Failure to timely evidence to the City the payment of bond premium will result in revocation of the occupational license. 
(h)  The occupational license tax issued by the City to any regulated business shall immediately be revoked by the City in the event such regulated business shall cease to have a valid environmental liability surety bond in force and effect. 
(i)  In the interpretation and enforcement of this Section the term "hazardous waste" shall mean any substance, gas, element, or matter identified as hazardous waste in Chapter 40 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 261.31 through 261.33, which provisions of said Code of Federal Regulations are by this reference incorporated herein and made a part hereof. 
(j)  The amount of environmental liability surety bond to be posted by a regulated business shall be in accordance with the following classification schedule:

(k)  Any business may reduce its bond classification one (1) category by producing proof to the Rockledge Fire Department of its entitlement to the next lower category and the business site is free of contamination. The City may revoke the reduced bond classification if the business is later found to exceed the hazardous waste limits of the lower classification. No business shall be entitled to have its bond classification reduced more often than one (1) time in any two (2) year period. 
(l)  A regulated business having an environmental liability surety bond may obtain permission from the City to cancel its environmental liability surety bond upon furnishing the City satisfactory proof, at the expense of the business, that the business site is in an exempt classification, and is free of all contamination. 
(Ord. No. 1491-2008, § 2, 8-20-08) 
SECTION 50.50. - PROVISIONS FOR FLOOD HAZARD REDUCTION 

50.51. - General standards. 
    In all areas of special flood hazard the following provisions are required: 
(a)  New construction and substantial improvements shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement of the structure. 
(b)  Manufactured homes shall be anchored to prevent flotation, collapse or lateral movement. Methods of anchoring may include, but are not limited to, use of over-the-top or frame ties to ground anchors. This standard shall be in addition to and consistent with applicable state requirements for resisting wind forces. 
(c)  New construction and substantial improvements shall be constructed with materials and utility equipment resistant to flood damage. 
(d)  New construction or substantial improvements shall be constructed by methods and practices that minimize flood damage. 
(e)  Electrical, heating, ventilation, plumbing, air conditioning equipment and other service facilities shall be designed and/or located so as to prevent water from entering or accumulating within the components during conditions of flooding. 
(f)  New and replacement water supply systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the system. 
(g)  New and replacement sanitary sewage systems shall be designed to minimize or eliminate infiltration of floodwaters into the systems and discharges from the systems into floodwaters. 
(h)  On-site waste disposal systems shall be located and constructed to avoid impairment to them or contamination from them during flooding. 
(i)  Any alteration, repair, reconstruction or improvements to a structure which is in compliance with the provisions of this section shall meet the requirements of "new construction" as contained in these regulations. 
(j)  Any alteration, repair, reconstruction or improvement to a building which is not in compliance with the provisions of this section, shall be undertaken only if said nonconformity is not furthered, extended, or replaced. 
(Ord. No. 1054-93, § 3, 6-16-93) 
50.52. - Specific standards. 
(A)  Special flood hazard areas where base elevation data provided. In all areas of special flood hazard where base flood elevation data has been provided, the following provisions are required: 
(1)  Residential construction. In all new construction or substantial improvement of any residential structure (or manufactured home/mobile home), the elevation of the lowest horizontal structural member, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities and basement, but excluding footings, pilings, columns, pile caps, nonstructural slabs, bracing and grade beams, shall not be lower than the level of the highest of the following described elevations to wit: 
(a)  Twelve (12) inches above base flood elevation; or 
(b)  Eighteen (18) inches above the crown of the public street, road or highway upon which the property site of such residence fronts; or 
(c)  Such height or elevation as may be necessary to cause all surface, storm, flood and other waters to adequately and suitably drain from the residence site into a drainage facility serving the locale of the residence at the time of such construction or substantial improvement. 
Should solid foundation perimeter walls be used to elevate a structure, openings sufficient to facilitate the unimpeded movements of floodwaters shall be provided in accordance with standards of subsection (A)(3) below. 
(2)  Non residential construction. New construction or substantial improvement of any commercial, industrial or other nonresidential structure (or manufactured home/mobile home) shall have the lowest floor, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities and basement, elevated no lower than the elevation required for residential construction as specified in subsection (1) of this paragraph (A), or structures and their attendant utility and sanitary facilities located in all A Zones may be flood proofed in lieu of being elevated; provided, that all areas of the structure below the elevation required for residential specified in subsection (1) of this paragraph (A) are watertight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and use structural components having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and effects of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the standards of this paragraph are satisfied. Such certification shall be provided to the official as set forth in this section. 
(3)  Elevated buildings. New construction or substantial improvements of elevated buildings that include fully enclosed areas formed by foundation and other exterior walls below the base flood elevation shall be designed to preclude finished living space and designed to allow for the entry and exit of floodwaters to automatically equalize hydrostatic flood forces on exterior walls. 
(a)  Designs for complying with this requirement must either be certified by a professional engineer or architect or meet the following minimum criteria: 
(1)  Provide a minimum of two (2) openings having a total net area of not less than one (1) square inch for every square foot of enclosed area subject of flooding; 
(2)  The bottom of all openings shall be no higher than one (1) foot above grade; and 
(3)  Openings may be equipped with screens, louvers, valves or other coverings or devices provided they permit the automatic flow of floodwaters in both directions. 
(b)  Electrical, plumbing and other utility connections are prohibited below the base flood elevation; 
(c)  Access to the enclosed area shall be the minimum necessary to allow for parking of vehicles (garage door) or limited storage of maintenance equipment used in connection with the premises (standard exterior door) or entry to the living area (stairway or elevator); and 
(d)  The interior portion of such enclosed area shall not be partitioned or finished into separate rooms. 
(4)  Floodways. Located within areas of special flood hazard established, are areas designated as floodways. Since the floodway is an extremely hazardous area due to the velocity of floodwaters which carry debris, potential projectiles and has erosion potential, the following provisions shall apply: 
(a)  Prohibit encroachments, including fill, new construction, substantial improvements and other developments, unless certification (with supporting technical data) by a registered professional engineer is provided demonstrating that encroachments shall not result in any increase in flood levels during occurrence of the base flood discharged. 
(b)  If subsection (4)(a) above is satisfied, all new construction and substantial improvements shall comply with all applicable flood hazard reduction provisions of this section. 
(c)  Prohibit the placement of manufactured homes (mobile homes), except in an existing manufactured homes (mobile homes) park or subdivision. A replacement manufactured home may be placed on a lot in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision provided the anchoring standards of Section 50.52(6)(b), and the elevation standards of subsection (A)(1) above are met. 
(5)  Street, road and highway construction. New construction of any street, road or highway shall have the crown of such street, road or highway elevated to or above the level of the highest of the following described elevations, to wit: 
(a)  Nineteen (19) feet above mean sea level; or 
(b)  Such height or elevation as may be necessary to cause all surface, storm, flood and other waters to suitably and adequately drain from said street, road or highway into an off-site drainage facility serving the locale of such street, road or highway at the time of the construction thereof; or 
(c)  Six inches (6?) above the mean base flood elevation on the property as determined by FIRM Map or a certified land surveyor. 
(6)  Standards for manufactured homes and recreational vehicles. 
(a)  All manufactured homes placed, or substantially improved, on individual lots or parcels, in expansions to existing manufactured home parks or subdivisions, in a new manufactured home park or subdivision or in substantially improved manufactured home parks or subdivisions, must meet all the requirement for new construction, including elevation and anchoring. 
(b)  All manufactured homes placed or substantially improved in an existing manufactured home park or subdivision must be elevated so that: 
(1)  The lowest floor of the manufactured home is elevated no lower than specified in subsection (A)(1) of this section above the level of the base flood elevation, or 
(2)  The manufactured home chassis is supported by reinforced piers or other foundation elements of at least an equivalent strength; of no less than thirty-six (36) inches in height above the ground. 
(3)  The manufactured home must be securely anchored to the adequately anchored foundation system to resist flotation, collapse and lateral movement. 
(4)  In an existing manufactured home park or subdivision on which a manufactured home has incurred "substantial damage" as the result of a flood, any manufactured home placed or substantially improved must meet the standards of Section 50.52, subsection (A)(6)(b)(1) and (3), above. 
(c)  All recreational vehicles placed on sites must either: 
(1)  Be fully licensed and ready for highway use (a recreational vehicle is ready for highway use if it is on its wheels or jacking system, is attached to the site only by quick disconnect type utilities and security devices and has no permanently attached additions), or; 
(2)  Meet all the requirements for new construction, including anchoring and elevation requirements of Section 50.52, subsection (A)(6)(a) or (b)(1) and (3), above, or; 
(3)  Be on the site for fewer than one hundred eighty (180) consecutive days. 
(7)  Certification of elevation. In all new construction or substantial improvements of residential and nonresidential structures, including prefabricated or manufactured homes, the elevation of the lowest horizontal structural member, including basement, but excluding footings, pilings, columns, pile caps, nonstructural slabs, bracing and grade beams, shall be preliminarily field-certified by a professional surveyor licensed in the State of Florida, as being at or exceeding the one-hundred-year flood elevation for the applicable flood hazard zone. Such certification shall take place after the completion of the foundation or slab for the intended structure and no further construction shall take place pending submission and review of the filed certification. The building official, or his authorized agent, shall authorize continuation of construction provided that said certification indicates that the elevation of the lowest horizontal structural member, including basement, but excluding footings, pilings, columns, pile caps, nonstructural slabs, bracing and grade beams of the structure is not lower than the designated one-hundred-year flood elevation of the applicable flood hazard zone. 
(8)  Critical facility. Construction of new critical facilities shall be, to the extent possible, located outside the limits of the special flood hazard area (SFHA) (100-year floodplain). Construction of new critical facilities shall be permissible within the SFHA if no feasible alternative site is available. Critical facilities constructed within the SFHA shall have the lowest floor elevated three feet or more above the level of the base flood elevation at the site. Floodproofing and sealing measures must be taken to ensure that toxic substances will not be displaced by or released into floodwaters. Access routes elevated to or above the level of the base flood elevation shall be provided to all critical facilities to the extent possible. 
(B)  In all areas of the city, including those areas which may hereafter be annexed by the city, the following provisions are required to assure adequate drainage: 
(1)  Residential construction. In all new construction or substantial improvement of any residential structure, (or manufactured home/mobile home), the elevation of the lowest horizontal structural member, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities and basement, but excluding footings, pilings, columns, pile caps, nonstructural slabs, bracing and grade beams, shall not be lower than the level of the highest of the following described elevations to wit: 
(a)  For lot drainage designed to flow from the rear of the lot to the street curb, twenty-two (22) inches above the crown of the street, road or highway upon which the property site of such residence fronts. 
(b)  For lot drainage to be split, where the front half of the lot is designed to flow to the street curb and the rear half of the lot is designed to flow to another appropriate drainage facility, eighteen (18) inches above the crown of the street, road or highway. 
(c)  Such height or elevation as may be necessary to cause all surface, storm, flood and other waters, as determined by a Florida registered engineer and approved by the public works department, to adequately and suitable drain from the residence site into a drainage facility serving the locale of the residence site at the time of such construction or substantial improvement and will prevent flooding (caused by sheetflowing or other factors) of adjoining properties. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the standards of this paragraph are satisfied. Such certification shall be provided to the building official as set forth in Section 42.33(a)(3). 
(2)  Nonresidential construction. In all new construction or substantial improvement of any commercial, industrial or other nonresidential structure (or manufactured home/mobile home), the elevation of the lowest horizontal structural member, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities and basement, but excluding footings, pilings, columns, pile caps, nonstructural slabs, bracing and grade beams, shall not be lower than the level of the highest of the following described elevations to wit: 
(a)  Six (6) inches above the crown of the street, road or highway upon which the property site of such nonresidential construction fronts; or 
(b)  Such height or elevation as may be necessary to cause all surface, storm, flood and other waters to adequately and suitable drain from the construction site into a drainage facility serving the locale of the construction site at the time of such construction or substantial improvement; or, together with attendant utility and sanitary facilities, be floodproofed so that below the minimum construction and improvements elevation level for nonresidential construction, as specified above in this paragraph, the structure is water tight with walls substantially impermeable to the passage of water and with a structural component having the capability of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic loads and effects of buoyancy. A registered professional engineer or architect shall certify that the standards of this paragraph are satisfied. Such certification shall be provided to the building official as set forth in Section 42.33(a)(3). 
(Ord. No. 1022-91, §§ 3-8, 12-18-91; Ord. No. 1054-93, §§ 4-7, 6-16-93; Ord. No. 1322-2003, §§ 5-11, 9-17-03; Ord. No. 1357-2004, §§ 1-4, 9-22-04; Ord. No. 1386-2005, § 1, 8-17-05) 
50.60. - Standards for subdivision proposals. 
(a)  All subdivision proposals shall be consistent with the need to minimize flood damage. 
(b)  All subdivision proposals shall have public utilities and facilities, such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems, located and constructed to minimize flood damage. 
(c)  All subdivision proposals shall have adequate drainage provided to reduce exposure to flood hazards. 
(d)  Base flood elevation data shall be provided for subdivision proposals and other proposed development (including manufactured home parks and subdivisions). 
(e)  Areas of special flood hazard shall be delineated on tentative and final subdivision plats. 
(f)  Residential building lots shall be provided with adequate buildable area outside the regulatory floodway. 
(g)  All subdivision proposals and other developments within the area of special flood hazard shall include with proposals data showing base flood elevations on each lot within the area of special flood hazard. 
(Ord. No. 1022-91, § 9, 12-18-91) 
SECTION 51.00. - STREETS, ROADS AND THOROUGHFARES-GENERAL PROVISIONS 

51.10. - Street classification. 
    Street [is defined as] a public or private thoroughfare which affords the principal means of access to abutting property. "Street" includes any lane, place, way or other means of ingress or egress regardless of the term used to describe it. In order for a privately owned thoroughfare to be deemed a "street" for purposes of meeting city zoning, subdivision or building regulations, such privately owned thoroughfare must first be approved as a street by the Rockledge city council. The term "street" includes, but not in way of limitation, the following types and classes of streets: 
(a)  Highways: Those traffic routes officially designated as federal or state highway routes. 
(b)  Arterial: Those routes intended to carry heavy volumes of traffic for major distances within the city, which provide a through traffic function rather than providing direct access to property. 
(c)  Collector street: A street which carries traffic from minor streets to arterial streets, including a street which would serve as the principal entrance street of a residential subdivision or could provide for traffic circulation within a subdivision. 
(d)  Local roads: A street of limited continuity used primarily for access to abutting property. 
(e)  Cul-de-sac or dead-end street: A minor street with only one (1) outlet terminating at one (1) end with a circular turnaround. 
(f)  Marginal access streets: A street that is parallel and adjacent to a major arterial street or highway and which provides access to abutting property. 
(g)  Alley: A minor way which is used primarily for vehicular service access to the back or the side of properties otherwise abutting on a street. 
51.11. - Road and street design standards. 
(a)  All roads or streets shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the minimum cross-sections as set forth elsewhere in this Code. The construction work and the construction materials shall conform to the specifications for the subgrade, base and wearing surface provided by this section. 
(b)  Care shall be exercised in making the street layout so as to prevent excessive grades, extreme cuts and fills, or other changes in the natural topography which would induce rapid and unwarranted storm water runoff, thereby causing washing and erosion or diversion of storm water over private or adjoining property. 
51.12. - Design of streets. 
(A)  Access to public streets required. Every unit within a subdivision shall have approved access to a street dedicated to public use which has been accepted and maintained by the City of Rockledge. Where a proposed subdivision does not immediately abut such a street, the applicant shall provide access from the subdivision to a street in accordance with the requirements set forth within the provisions of these regulations. All lots or units within a proposed subdivision shall have direct access to a street or road dedicated and accepted by the city unless the lots or units are within PUD or RCE zoning districts per Section 51.13. PUD and RCE zoning districts lots or units must comply with access requirements in the Zoning Ordinance. 
(B)  Street design standards. Required pavement and right-of-way widths are shown below. 
(1)  Street right-of-way widths, depending on the type of road drainage indicated, shall not be less than the following:

(3)  The right-of-way width and pavement widths described in subsections (B)(1) and (B)(2) above constitute the minimum required widths. Upon the recommendation of the city's engineering coordinator, modifications in width may be granted if the change is consistent with the projected traffic volume of the road, the anticipated speed and safety needs of the traffic load, the physical conditions affecting traffic, drainage requirements and good engineering practices. 
(4)  All streets and highways which the applicant installs shall comply with the standards in the Manual of Uniform Minimum Standards for Design, Construction, and Maintenance for Streets and Highways, published by the Florida Department of Transportation. 
(C)  Relation of proposed streets to existing streets. The pattern of streets in new subdivisions shall provide for the continuation of existing streets from adjoining areas, or for their proper projection where adjoining land is not subdivided. Where street extends [extensions] into adjacent undeveloped land are necessary to ensure a coordinated street system, provisions for such future street or streets shall be made. Where a subdivision abuts or contains an existing or proposed arterial street, vehicular access from subdivisions to highways and arterial roads shall be limited and controlled to provide safe access according to traffic volume, speed limits and other conditions affecting traffic safety. 
(D)  Required access. Every unit of land in a subdivision shall have direct access to a public road or public street, except as provided in Section 51.13. 
(E)  Entire right-of-way required. If a street proposed for dedication in a new subdivision will connect with an existing dedicated and accepted street, the entire street right-of-way for the proposed street shall be platted within the subdivision. 
(F)  Dead-end streets and cul-de-sac. See Exhibit 2.

(1)  Culs-de-sac, with one (1) end permanently closed, shall not exceed one thousand (1,000) feet. 
(2)  All cul-de-sacs shall terminate with a circular right-of-way having a minimum diameter of one hundred five (105) feet. The wearing surface of the cul-de-sac shall have a minimum diameter of eighty (80) feet. The right-of-way of the cul-de-sac shall be at least one hundred (100) feet from the nearest road or street or the nearest plat boundary. Where a street is to be temporarily dead-ended at a property line and is to be continued when adjacent property is subdivided, either [sic] a temporary turnaround having an outside diameter of eighty (80) feet [shall be provided]. 
(3)  Dead-end roads and streets. There shall be no permanent dead-end streets. Temporary dead-end streets shall comply with subsection (F)(2) above. 
(G)  Right-of-way radius. Rights-of-way at intersections shall be rounded with a minimum twenty-five-foot (25) radius. 
(H)  Intersections and street jogs. Streets shall be arranged to intersect at right angles. Curved streets shall have a minimum tangent of one hundred (100) feet at intersections unless otherwise approved by the city's engineering coordinator. (I)  Intersections with arterial routes. Acceleration and deceleration lanes along arterial routes, if found necessary by the city's engineering coordinator, shall be provided at intersections of arterial streets and entrance roads to subdivisions. 
(J)  Street names. New streets which are extensions of existing streets shall bear the name of the existing street. All street names shall be continuous except at distinct corners, lots or break points, as determined by the city. 51.13. - Conditions for limited access. 
(a)  Frontage. All lots shall front on a public street dedicated and accepted by the city council of the City of Rockledge, except lots in PUD and RCE subdivisions. In PUD or RCE subdivisions, limited access private roads may be proposed under the following conditions: 
(1)  That the proposed limited access private road would not prohibit or interrupt any planned public street system in the area. 
(2)  Said limited access private roads shall have the required right-of-way as specified in these regulations deeded fee simple to a homeowners' association composed of the owners of lots in the subdivision who will be responsible for maintenance of said limited access private road or street. The construction plans and specifications shall comply with the requirements contained herein. The subdivision inspector shall make inspections of the construction and the Public Works Director shall issue a certificate of completion prior to the issuance of any building permits. 
(3)  That the homeowners' association's documents, which provide for the maintenance of limited access roads and streets, shall be subject to review by the Public Works Director and subject to approval by the city council. The road shall be maintained to city standards. 
(4)  That PUD or RCE subdivisions cannot mix public streets and limited access roads or streets. 
(5)  That emergency vehicles and all official public vehicles shall be granted use of the limited access streets at all times. 
51.14. - General construction methods. 
(A)  General construction methods. All design and construction methods shall conform to the following manuals published by the Florida Department of Transportation, latest editions, and [such manuals] shall serve as reference guides and standards of construction for the construction of all improvements. Said manuals are hereby declared to be good engineering practice for the construction of improvements and shall be used by the city as the engineering standard for the purpose of making inspections, approved items of construction and approving construction plans and specifications: 
Subject Florida Department of Transportation Manual Drainage design Drainage Manual and City Specifications Construction techniques Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction Road design standards Manual of Uniform Minimum Standards for Design, Construction and Maintenance for Streets and Highways, 1976  
(B)  Construction plans and specifications generally. All construction plans and specifications shall include a topographical map showing not less than one-foot contours on the North American Vertical Datum 1988 (NAVD), not only of the development tract but also of such necessary adjacent land to indicate the method of final disposal of surface water and shall also contain the following information: 
(1)  A street layout plan showing all necessary elevations, treatment of intersections, designed grade of pavement, the width and type of pavement and details showing the final disposal of all street draining. Sufficient topographic information shall be shown on existing outfall ditches, major drainage channels to validate drainage designs, and other drainage facilities. 
(2)  Typical sections showing details of proposed pavements, wearing surfaces, curbs, swales, canals, shoulders, slopes drainage structures and other items of major construction. 
(3)  Profile sheets of all streets to be constructed, together with elevations shown for connection to existing streets. 
(4)  Current Rockledge Public Works and Wastewater Departments technical specification sheets. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 7, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1554-2010, § 2, 8-18-10) 
51.15. - Minimum requirements for roads and streets. 
(A)  Specifications-Constitute minimum standards; other standards: 
(1)  The specifications contained in this section are the minimum standards acceptable to the city covering street and road construction. 
(2)  The developer, if he so desires, may submit to the city other detailed specifications covering other types of pavement prepared by a registered engineer, and accompanied by reports from recognized testing laboratories outlining in detail the differences between the submitted specifications and the city's minimum standards, and the opinion of the testing laboratory that the submitted specifications are equal to or of higher standards than the city's. The city at its option, may submit such specifications to its consulting engineer for approval. 
(3)  The minimum grade for street construction shall be 0.3%. 
(B)  Same-Scope. The work specified under this section shall consist of clearing and grubbing, grading, construction of the base course, construction of curbs and gutters and construction of the wearing surface, so that these items conform to lines, grades and cross sections as shown on the plans, or [as] are specified in this section, or as established by the city's consulting engineer. 
(C)  Equipment required. Adequate and sufficient equipment to properly perform the work specified shall be furnished at the project site. This equipment shall have been approved by the city's engineering coordinator or consulting engineer prior to the start of construction. 
(D)  Clearing and grubbing; protecting trees, etc.: 
(1)  The entire right-of-way area shall be completely cleared and grubbed of all trees, brush, stumps, roots and other obstructions, except such trees and shrubs as may be designated by the city manager to remain. Branches of trees extending over the proposed paved area shall be trimmed as directed to give a clear height of fifteen (15) feet above the proposed paving area. The street right-of-way shall be cleared and grubbed so as to properly facilitate grading and planting. Trees shall be allowed to remain in park areas. 
(2)  Special attention shall be given to saving, protecting and preserving existing trees, shrubs or other vegetation designated by the city's Public Works Director or consulting engineer to be preserved. Such trees, shrubs, etc. shall be neatly trimmed as directed. Particular care shall be exercised in both the clearing and grubbing operations and the grading work to prevent damage to such growths by construction equipment or otherwise, if considered necessary. If so directed by the city's engineering coordinator or consulting engineer, the developer (or contractor) shall furnish and erect temporary posts or construct temporary fences around the areas or trees to be preserved. Slopes may be made variable and other than shown on standard sections to protect and save existing growth as the city's engineering coordinator or consulting engineer may direct. 
(E)  Preparation of subgrade: 
(1)  The work of preparing the subgrade shall consist of bringing the bottom of excavations and top of embankments of the roadway between lines two (2) feet out from the edges of the proposed paving to a surface conforming to the grades, lines and cross sections shown on the plans, of uniform and acceptable density, ready to receive the base or paving course. 
(2)  All soft or yielding material and other portions of the subgrade which will not compact readily shall be removed and replaced with suitable material and the whole subgrade brought to line and grade and to a foundation of uniform compaction and supporting power. Where the subgrade is of a compacted nature as determined by the city's engineering coordinator, it shall be plowed to a depth of not less than six (6) inches for the full width of the subgrade. The loose materials shall then be spread and manipulated so as to bring all the material to a uniform density. 
(3)  All submerged stumps, roots or other perishable matter encountered in the preparation of the subgrade shall be removed to a depth of two (2) feet. 
(4)  The top six inches (6?) of the subgrade, in both cut and fill sections, shall be compacted to a density of not less than one hundred per cent (100%) of the maximum density, as determined by the AASHO Method T 180. Mix four inches (4?) of coquina rock or limerock with top four inches (4?) on subbase with a mechanical mixer creating a stabilized subbase to an LBR ratio of fifty (50) and compacted by ninety-eight per cent (98%) of maximum density by the AASHO Method T 180. Where specified by the City's consulting engineer, any aggregate materials overlying the subgrade (bottom of proposed base or pavement) shall be bladed aside in order to compact the subgrade. Unless the subgrade material at the time of compacting contains sufficient moisture to permit proper compaction, it shall be moistened as necessary and then compacted. The subgrade shall be shaped prior to making the density tests. The required density shall be maintained until the base or pavement has been laid, or until the aggregate materials for the base or pavement course have been spread in place. 
(5)  After the subgrade has been prepared, as specified in this section, the developer (or contractor) shall maintain it free from ruts and depressions and all damage resulting from the hauling or handling of materials, equipment. tools, etc. Ditches and drains shall be constructed and maintained along the completed subgrade section if necessary. A completed subgrade equal to the length of base of pavement to be laid the next working day shall be maintained at all times. 
(6)  After the subgrade has been prepared and forms set true to line and grade, and immediately before any base or paving course is laid, the subgrade shall be tested as to crown and elevation by the use of an approved subgrade template furnished by the developer (or contractor). The subgrade template shall be so constructed that its lower or testing edge will just come to the true position of the subgrade when the template is riding on the forms or grade stakes. Testing of the subgrade elevation shall be done by moving the template back and forth on the forms or grade stakes without tilting or lifting. The template shall be drawn along just ahead of the point where the materials for base or paving course are being deposited and shall always be kept in position while materials are being placed. If the subgrade is found not to be at the proper elevation at all points, material shall be removed or added as the condition necessitates and compacted to bring all portions of the subgrade to the correct elevation and to the specified density. 
(7)  Where the subgrade is more than twenty-four (24) feet in width it shall be tested in strips twenty-four (24) feet or less in width by the use of crown stakes, temporary forms or other means approved by the city's engineering coordinator or consulting engineer. Where no forms are required for the work the subgrade shall be tested by the use of elevation stakes and other means approved by the city's engineering coordinator or consulting engineer. 
(F)  Construction of curbs and gutters: 
(1)  The work specified in this section consists of the construction of curbs, curbs and gutters or valley gutters of Portland concrete. Such work [is] to be constructed in accordance with these specifications and in conformity with the lines, grades, dimensions and notes as shown on the plans, or as ordered by the city's engineering coordinator or consulting engineer. 
(2)  Unless otherwise shown on the plans, the concrete shall be Class A and of materials and proportions as required by the city's engineering coordinator or consulting engineer, with the following additions and exceptions: 
(a)  The coarse aggregate in the mix shall be 3,000 PSI minimum. 
(b)  For white concrete curb, the coarse aggregate shall be either gravel or light-colored stone. The fine aggregate shall be white sand, and the cement shall be white Portland cement. 
(3)  Where the plans call for steel reinforcement to be placed in the curb or gutter, such reinforcement shall conform to the requirements of the ASTM for like reinforcement. 
(4)  Forms for construction of curbs and gutters shall be made of wood or metal. They shall be straight, free from warp or bends and of sufficient strength, when staked, to resist the pressure of the concrete without springing. If of wood, they shall be of two-inch-surfaced plank; if of metal, they shall be of approved section. Forms shall have a depth equal to the plan dimensions for the depth of the concrete being deposited against them. Forms for combination curbs and gutters shall be so constructed as to ensure fastening of the forms to each other. 
(5)  Excavations shall be made to the required depth and the subgrade or base upon which the curbs, curbs and gutters or valley gutters is to be set shall be compacted to a firm even surface. 
(6)  The concrete shall be mixed as specified by the city's consulting engineer. It shall be placed in the forms to the depth specified in layers of not more than six (6) inches, and tamped and spaded until mortar entirely covers its surface. The top of the curbing or gutter shall be floated smooth and the edges rounded to the radius shown on the plans. 
(7)  Unless otherwise shown on the plans, the curbs, curbs and gutters and valley gutters shall be constructed in uniform sections ten (10) feet in length except where shorter sections are necessary for closures, but no section shall be less than four (4) feet. These sections shall be separated by sheet metal templates set perpendicular to the face and top of the curbing. The templates shall be held firmly during the placing of the concrete and shall be allowed to remain in place until the concrete has set sufficiently to hold its shape, but shall be removed while the forms are still in place. 
(8)  The forms shall be removed within twenty-four (24) hours after the concrete has been placed, and minor defects filled with mortar composed of one (1) part of Portland cement to two (2) parts of fine aggregate. Plastering shall not be permitted on the face of the curb and all rejected curbs, curbs and gutters or valley gutters shall be removed and replaced without additional compensation. The top of the curb and the face from the top to eight (8) inches below shall be finished while the concrete is still green by wetting a soft brick or a wood block and rubbing the surface until it is smooth. A liberal amount of water shall be used, either by dipping the brick or block in water, or by throwing water on the curb with a brush. After the concrete has been rubbed smooth, it shall be rubbed again until a uniform color is produced, using in place of water a thick grout composed of one (1) part of Portland cement and one part of fine aggregate. 
(9)  When completed, the curbs, curbs and gutters and valley gutters shall be covered with suitable material and kept moist for a period of three (3) days or longer, if necessary, [and] shall be protected in a satisfactory manner from the elements until thoroughly hardened. 
(10)  After the concrete has set sufficiently, the spaces in front and back of the curb shall be refilled to the required elevation with suitable material, which shall be tamped in layers of not more than six (6) inches until firm and solid. Where bases are to be constructed adjacent to the curbs or gutters, the curbs, curbs and gutters or valley gutters shall be properly backfilled and shall set for a period of not less than fourteen (14) days before any base material is placed against it. 
(G)  Base course-Lime rock base: 
(1)  Applicable specifications. Florida State Road Department specifications and other specifications, standards and publications referred to in this section shall form a part of this section. 
(2)  Materials. The materials used shall conform to the Florida State Road Department specifications, Section 503, "Base Course Materials." 
(a)  Lime Rock-Miami Oolite Formation, Paragraph 503.1. 
(b)  Lime Rock-Ocala Formation, Paragraph 503.2. 
(3)  Equipment: 
(a)  In general. All equipment necessary for the proper construction of this work shall be on the project, in first class working condition, and shall have been approved by the city's consulting engineer before construction is started. 
(b)  Scarifiers. Scarifiers shall have two (2) rows of teeth with teeth not more than eight (8) inches apart, and the rows shall be staggered so that the paths of the teeth will not be more than four (4) inches apart. 
(c)  Road machines. Road machines shall weigh not less than three (3) tons, and shall have a wheel base not less than fifteen (15) feet, and a blade not less than ten (10) feet. Road machines shall not be pulled with rollers. 
(4)  Forms. Forms shall be either: 
(a)  Two-inch lumber square edge and sound end of sufficient width to extend from the top to bottom of the loose spread lime rock; 
(b)  Steel sections meeting the approval of the city's consulting engineer; 
(c)  The forms shall be set true to line and grade and substantially staked in place to ensure stability during the spreading and rolling operations. 
(5)  Correction of the elevation of manhole frames. Before spreading lime rock, all manhole frames encountered in the course of preparation of the subgrade shall be raised, by the use of brick and cement mortar, to the elevation of the finished pavement. 
(6)  Transporting lime rock: 
(a)  Lime rock shall be transported to the point where it is to be used, over rock previously laid, and dumped on the end of the preceding spreading. In no case shall the rock be dumped directly on the subgrade. 
(b)  No hauling over the subgrade shall be done except with written approval of the city's consulting engineer, in which case the subgrade shall be protected by planing for a distance of at least one hundred fifty (150) feet from the point where lime rock is being dumped. 
(7)  Spreading lime rock. Lime rock shall be spread uniformly with shovels or forks, or by means of bulldozers or other equipment approved by the city's consulting engineer. 
(8)  Compacting and finishing base: 
(a)  After spreading is completed, the entire surface shall be scarified and shaped so as to produce the exact grade and cross section after compaction. 
(b)  The base course shall be compacted to an average of ninety-five (95) per cent, for each day's operations, of the maximum density as determined by AASHO Model T 180, modified as follows: "The weight of the tamper shall be ten (10) pounds and it shall be dropped from a height of eighteen (18) feet, and the sample shall be compacted in five (5) equal layers. The density for individual tests shall be not less than ninety (90) per cent of the maximum density." 
(c)  During final compacting operations, if blading of any area is necessary to obtain the true grade and cross section, the compacting operations for such area shall be completed prior to making the density determinations on the finished base. Finished base shall be compacted to ninety-eight (98) per cent or the maximum density as determined by AASHO Method T 180. 
(d)  In order to permit the specified density to be obtained, it may be necessary to add moisture if the rock is too dry, or to aerate and reduce the moisture. 
(e)  At least three (3) density determinations shall be made on each day's final compaction operations, and at more frequent intervals if so directed by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator. 
(f)  Immediately prior to the application of the prime coat, the surface shall be "hard planed" with a blade grader so as to remove the thin glazed or cemented surface of the base. This hard planing shall be done in such a manner that only the glazed or cemented surface will be removed, leaving a granular or porous condition which will allow free penetration of the prime material. The materials planed from the base shall be removed from the base area. 
(g)  If at any time the subgrade material becomes churned up or mixed with the base course material, the contractor or developer should see that the mixture is dug up and removed, the subgrade reshaped and compacted, and the materials removed replaced with clean lime rock, reshaping and compacting to be done as specified in this section. 
(h)  Where cracks or checks appear in the base, either before or after priming, which in the opinion of the city's consulting engineer will impair the structural efficiency of the base course, such cracks or checks shall be removed by rescarifying, reshaping, adding lime rock where necessary, and recompacting. 
(9)  Testing the surface: 
(a)  The finished surface of the base course shall be checked with a template cut to the required crown, and with a fifteen-foot (15) straight edge laid parallel to the center line of the road. All irregularities greater than one-quarter (1/4) inch shall be corrected by scarifying to a depth of not less than four (4) inches, and removing or adding work as may be required, after which the entire area shall be recompacted as specified in this section. 
(b)  In testing the surface, measurements shall not be taken in small holes where individual pieces or rock have been pulled out by the grader. 
(10)  Opening to traffic and maintaining: 
(a)  The completed base course shall be opened to traffic for a sufficient period of time, as determined by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator, to allow the base to become thoroughly cured before the prime coat is applied. 
(b)  Traffic shall be distributed so as to properly cure the entire area of the base. 
(c)  The developer (or contractor) shall maintain the base to a true and satisfactory surface and the specified density, until the wearing surface is laid. 
(d)  After the base has been under traffic the required curing period, and immediately preceding the application of the prime coat, the base shall again be tested as provided in subsection (9) of this section, and if the base shall be found to meet all the requirements, the hard planing, as specified in subsection (8)(f) of this section, shall then be done. 
(11)  Thickness determinations: 
(a)  The thickness of the base shall be measured at intervals of not more than two hundred (200) feet. Measurements shall be taken at various points on the cross section. 
(b)  The measurement shall be taken by core borings, not less than one and one-half (11/2) inches in diameter. 
(c)  Where the base is more than five-eighths ( 5/8 ) inch less than the required compacted thickness, the developer (or contractor) shall correct such area by scarifying and adding rock. The base shall be scarified and rock added for a distance of seventy-five (75) feet in each direction from the edge of the deficient area. The affected areas shall then be brought to the required thickness and cross section. 
(d)  The average thickness of the base shall be determined from all measurements taken within each city block. 
(12)  Method of measurement: 
(a)  The quantity to be paid for under this section shall be the number of square yards of lime rock base compacted and accepted. 
(b)  The square yards of base shall be the product of the length, as actually measured on the completed work, and the width, which shall be the width of the base actually constructed within the neat lines on the drawings, or designated by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator. 
(H)  Same-Alternative. Coquina shell base may be used as a substitute for lime rock when applied according to Florida Department of Transportation Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction. 
(I)  Bituminous prime and tack coats: 
(1)  The work specified in this section consists of an application of bituminous material on a previously prepared base in accordance with the specifications herein contained and in conformity with the lines, grades, dimensions and notes shown on the plans. 
(2)  A pressure distributor shall be used and shall be equipped with pneumatic tires having a sufficient width of rubber in contact with the road surface to avoid breaking the bond of or forming a rut in such surfacing. The distance between the centers of openings of the outside nozzles of the manifold shall be equal to the width of the application required within an allowable variation of two (2) inches. The outside nozzle at each end of the manifold shall have an area of opening not less than twenty-five (25) per cent nor more than seventy-five (75) per cent in excess of the other nozzles which have uniform openings. 
(3)  The bituminous material to be used shall conform to the Florida State Road Department Specifications Section 300, 311, or as amended. (Water emulsified Prime Coat of a approved grade may be used) 
(4)  Before any bituminous material is applied, all loose material, dust, dirt, caked clay and foreign material which might prevent proper bond with the existing surface shall be moved to the shoulders to the full width of the treatment by means of revolving brooms or approved mechanical sweepers and by mechanical blowers, of approved types, supplemented by hand sweeping. Dust and other loose materials not removed by mechanical means shall be removed with hand brooms. Particular care shall be taken to clean the outer edges of the strip to be treated in order to ensure that the prime or tack coat will adhere. Sweeping and blowing shall be continued until all the loose dirt and dust is removed from the surface. 
(5)  Where the prime or tack coat is applied adjacent to curbs and gutters, valley gutters or any other concrete pavement surface, such concrete surfaces (except where they are to be covered with bituminous wearing course) shall be protected by means of heavy paper or other material approved by the city's consulting engineer, while the prime or tack coat is being applied. Any bituminous material deposited on such concrete surfaces shall be removed immediately. 
(6)  No bituminous material shall be applied when the temperature of the air is less than sixty (60) degrees Fahrenheit in the shade, or when, in the opinion of the city's consulting engineer, the weather conditions or the conditions of the existing surface are unsuitable. 
(7)  The surface to be treated shall be clean and dry. The temperature of the prime material shall be between one hundred (100) and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit. The exact temperature shall be such as will ensure uniform distribution and shall be designated by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator. The material shall be applied by means of a pressure distributor. The amount applied shall be at the rate of approximately 0.15 to 0.25 gallons per square yard, to be determined by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator, and will be dependent on the character of the surface, but shall be sufficient to coat the surface thoroughly and uniformly without having any excess to form pools or to flow off the base. 
(8)  The prime shall be allowed to stand without sanding for a period of at least one (1) hour, unless otherwise ordered by the city's consulting engineer. 
(9)  If so ordered by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator, a light, uniform application of clean sand shall be applied prior to opening the primed base to traffic, in which case the sand shall be rolled with a traffic roller in conjunction with traffic, to cure the prime coat. After the sand covering has been applied the surface may be opened to traffic. 
(10)  If warranted by traffic conditions, in the opinion of the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator, the application shall be made on only one-half (1/2) the width of base at one time, care being taken to secure the correct amount of bituminous material at the joint. If deemed necessary, the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator may require that the base be lightly sprinkled with water in advance of the application of the prime. 
(11)  Where a bituminous surface is to be laid and a tack coat is required, it shall be applied as herein specified. On newly constructed base courses the application of the tack coat shall follow the application of the prime coat, immediately prior to placing the wearing surface. When the wearing surface is to be laid over an old pavement and a prime coat is not required, the tack coat shall be applied to the surface without the prime coat as shown on the plans. The tack coat shall be applied with a pressure distributor except that on small jobs, if approved by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator, the application may be made by other approved mechanical methods or hand methods. The bituminous materials shall be heated to a suitable consistence as designated by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator. The rate of application shall be between 0.02 and 0.08 gallon per square yard. The exact rate shall be designated by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator, who shall also designate the curing period for the tack coat. The tack coat shall be applied sufficiently in advance of the laying of the wearing surface to permit drying, but shall not be applied so far in advance or over such an area as to lose its adhesiveness as a result of being covered with dust or other foreign material. The tack coat surface shall be kept free from traffic until the wearing surface is laid. 
(J)  Wearing surfaces-In general. Asphalt wearing surface shall be Type I placed at a thickness of one and one-half (11/2) inches and compacted to one and one-quarter (11/4) inches. Asphalt resurfacing shall be Type III with areas to be determined by the public works department. Hot-plant-mixed asphalt wearing surface shall be the construction preferred by the city, and in accordance with the Florida State Road Department Specification Sections 330, 331, or as amended. 
(K)  Same-Asphalt concrete, Type S-I: New construction. 
(1)  Job mix: In accordance to the Florida State Road Department Specifications in accordance with Sections 331 and 333.4, or as amended. 
(2)  Transportation of mixture: 
(a)  The mixture shall be transported in tight vehicles previously cleaned of all foreign materials, and when directed by the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator, each load shall be covered with waterproof canvas cover of sufficient size to protect it from weather conditions. The inside surface of the truck bodies may be thinly coated with soapy water, or a mixture of water with not more than ten (10) per cent of lubricating oil, but an excess of either shall not be used. After coating, the bodies shall be raised so that all excess water will drain out before placing any mixture therein. Kerosene, gasoline or similar products shall not be used. 
(b)  No mixture shall be sent out so late in the day as to prevent spreading, finishing and compacting the mixture during daylight. 
(3)  Weather limitations. No mixture shall be laid when, in the opinion of the city's consulting engineer or engineering coordinator, weather conditions are unsuitable, or when the air temperature in the shade is below forty (40) degrees Fahrenheit, except by written permission of the city's consulting engineer. 
(L)  Same-Bituminous surface treatment: 
(1)  The work specified in this section consists of a wearing surface composed of a single application of bituminous material covered with a single application of cover material or a double application of bituminous material covered with a double application of cover material. The wearing surface shall be applied in accordance with the Florida State Road Department Specifications contained in Section 310. 
(Ord. No. 1022-91, §§ 11, 12, 12-18-91) 
51.16A. - Signs and pavement markings for street systems. 
    Required signs must be in place prior to city acceptance of the street. All signing and pavement marking shall be in accordance with the Florida Department of Transportation manual entitled "Uniform Traffic Control Devices for Streets and Highways," and shall be approved by the Public Works Director. If at any time prior to final acceptance, an unforeseen need becomes apparent for signing or pavement markings that were not shown on the approved plans, the city reserves the right to require the additional sign(s) or marking(s) in the interest of public safety and as a condition of city acceptance. 
(a)  Street name signs. Street name signs shall be provided by the city at the expense of the developer. 
(b)  Regulatory. All regulatory signs including "Stop" signs, shall be required and provided by the city at the expense of the developer at the appropriate location at every street intersection as a condition for acceptance of subdivision paving and drainage improvement and shall be in place prior to final inspection. Assignment of right-of-way will be made utilizing a logical estimate of which street will carry the higher volume of traffic, based on the geometry and lot layout of the subdivision. The street determined to have the right-of-way shall not be stopped; the other street(s) shall be regulated by a "Stop" sign. In case of question, the city's engineering coordinator will assist. The developer shall furnish and erect twenty-miles (20) per hour speed limit signs at every entrance to the subdivision unless a higher speed limit is indicated for an arterial street by the city's engineering coordinator. In larger subdivisions, additional speed limit signs shall be erected as required. "Stop" signs shall not be used primarily for speed control purposes. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 8, 8-14-96) 
51.16B. - Minimum road elevations. 
    Minimum road elevations at the lowest point shall be nineteen (19) feet above mean sea water table. Flood insurance rate maps may set a higher minimum road elevation for particular subdivision areas. (See Flood Prevention.) 
51.17. - Restrictions for industrial park streets. 
(A)  Street and access design: 
(1)  All streets within an IP industrial park district shall be paved with rights-of-way as follows: 
R/W 
(feet) Pavement 
(feet) Major Collector 106 48 (4 lane) with 20-foot median Minor Collector  66 32  
(2)  Major collector. This road collects industrial traffic from minor collector streets and conducts it to a major arterial roadway. 
(3)  Minor collector. The primary purpose of this street is to provide access to individual industrial sites. Consequently, it is not conducive to through traffic. Traffic volumes are low because the street seldom serves more than fifteen (15) industrial sites. 
(4)  Streets may utilize either curbs and gutters or open swales for drainage. 
(5)  All improvements shall include comprehensive drainage facilities for positive drainage based on the twenty-five year design standards. Drainage plans and specifications shall be prepared by a registered professional engineer. Open swales, ditches or other waterways shall require complete engineering design data pertinent to its design and its effect within the particular drainage area to establish its adequacy. 
(6)  Each industrial or other permitted use shall have not more than two (2) access points to any one (1) street and there must be at least one hundred (100) feet between access points. 
(7)  Cul-de-sac streets are not normally desirable in an industrially developed area; however, any cul-de-sac shall have a minimum of a sixty (60) foot radius and a maximum length of five hundred (500) feet. The minimum radius of the pavement in the cul-de-sac area shall be forty-four (44) feet. 
51.18. - Acceleration/deceleration lane requirements. 
    Development of sites that use frontage for vehicular access on collector or arterial streets, as defined in the comprehensive plan, shall be required to construct acceleration and deceleration lanes in accordance with the State of Florida Department of Transportation Standards and the City of Rockledge specifications for roadways and streets as identified in this section. 
51.19. - Location of curb cuts along streets. 
(a)  Curb cuts shall not be located within acceleration or deceleration lanes, and shall not be located closer than thirty (30) feet to an intersection with another arterial road. 
(b)  In the event the city council finds that a hardship is created by the terms hereof and that public safety would not be impaired by variance from the terms hereof, the city council may grant a variance from the provisions hereof by resolution, upon submission of plans for ingress and egress by the landowner and approval thereof by the city council. 
51.20. - Protection of rights-of-way. 
    The front setback requirement on all properties fronting urban collector, urban minor arterials and urban major/principle arterials must be maintained, to preserve the financial burden on taxpayers in the future, if and in the event further widening is needed on those roadways. Special consideration shall be given to those applicants requesting variances on those properties when requesting reductions to any setback, only the rear setback may be revised when hardships are shown and a variance is granted. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 9, 8-14-96) 
SECTION 52.00. - SIDEWALK STANDARDS 

52.10. - [Generally.] 
    Sidewalks [shall be] designed and constructed for public use according to the standards and requirements of this section, except as provided for in Low Density Subdivisions. 
52.11. - Time for construction of sidewalks. 
    No person shall occupy, inhabit or dwell in any structure on any lot or parcel of land in a subdivision until after the developer of the subdivision, or the owner of such lot or parcel of land, shall have first constructed and installed in the right-of-way of any public street or streets abutting such lot or parcel of land, and on the side of such street or streets nearest such lot or parcel of land, a sidewalk extending the entire distance that such lot or parcel of land abuts the public street or streets. The sidewalk shall be constructed in accordance with the specifications and requirements of these regulations applicable to the construction of sidewalks within subdivisions, and shall conform in all respects to the applicable portion of the plans and specifications for construction of public improvements in the subdivision submitted by the developer prior to approval of the plat by the governing body of the city. No certificate of occupancy shall be granted or issued for the occupancy of any structure on any lot, piece or parcel of land in a subdivision until after the sidewalk required by this section has been installed as herein required and finally inspected and approved by the Rockledge Building Official. 
52.12. - Extended time for construction of sidewalks. 
    The developer shall be responsible for constructing sidewalks and such sidewalks shall be installed prior to the final city inspection and approval of the public improvements in the subdivision as required for the issuance of a certificate of completion; provided, however, that a developer desiring to defer construction of the sidewalks until dwellings have been constructed on the subdivision lots may extend the time for construction of the sidewalks for a period of time not to exceed two (2) years from the date the subdivision has received its certificate of completion from the city, provided the subdivision developer shall, prior to final plat approval by the city council, obtain the city council's consent to such an extension and to the posting by the developer with the city of a bond or other form of security, hereinafter referred to as "performance security," in form and amount satisfactory to the city, guarantying and securing the developer's timely completion of construction of the sidewalks in accordance with city specifications, requirements and regulations. Such bond or security shall be in the amount of fifty (50) per cent of the estimated material and labor cost of constructing the sidewalks, such estimated cost being that set forth in the engineering estimate approved by the city. Said performance security shall be accompanied by a written sidewalk construction agreement executed and acknowledged by the developer in form and content satisfactory to the city and delivered to the city with the performance security before the subdivision receives its certificate of completion. The sidewalk construction agreement shall contain, but not in way of limitation, substantially the following provisions: 
(a)  That no part of said performance security shall be refunded to the developer until all sidewalks in the entire subdivision are constructed and completed in accordance with city specifications; 
(b)  That if said sidewalks are not completed by the developer or his designee within said two-year period, all performance security shall automatically stand forfeited to the city; 
(c)  That the developer shall be liable to the city for all costs, expenses and damages incurred and sustained by the city, including reasonable attorney's fees and court costs in the event of the developer's default in any provision of said sidewalk construction agreement; and 
(d)  In the event the developer fails to complete construction of the sidewalks and the performance security is forfeited, the city may elect to take all or any of the following actions: 
(1)  Complete construction of some or all of the sidewalks, utilizing city employees and materials. 
(2)  Contract for completion of the construction of some or all of said sidewalks. 
(e)  In the event the developer fails to complete the construction of the sidewalks within the required timeframe and all performance security is forfeited to the city, the city shall not be liable to any party to continue the sidewalk improvements after said performance security has been exhausted toward that end. 
(Ord. No. 1066-93, § 1, 10-6-93) 
52.13. - Design of sidewalks. 
    Sidewalks shall be provided on each side of all highways, roads and streets, and on each side of marginal access streets located within a subdivision, except for subdivisions where all lots are one (1) acre or greater in size. All sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete and at least four (4) feet in width, four (4) inches thick, six (6) inches thick in driveways, and at least six (6) feet from the toe of the road pavement. Each sidewalk shall extend to a curb cut which shall provide access for wheelchair occupants at street intersections. All sidewalks shall not be less than six (6) inches from the property line. 
52.14. - Conformity with city policies. 
    The subdividing and development of any areas subject to these regulations shall conform to the adopted general goals and objectives of the council with respect to the physical development of the city as set forth in various elements of the Rockledge Comprehensive Plan and other policy statements including those in the Zoning Ordinance. 
52.23. - Clear view of intersecting streets (sight triangle). 
(A)  [In general.] 
(1)  In order to provide clear view of intersecting streets to the motorist, there shall be a triangular area of clear vision maintained at each corner of intersecting streets as hereinafter described. The size of the clear vision triangle area for a particular corner of a street intersection is based upon the functional road classifications of the intersecting streets, as determined by the Florida Department of Transportation, in the manner hereinafter described. 
(2)  No owner, occupant or person in possession of a triangular area of clear vision adjacent to a street intersection, as described and illustrated in this Section, shall cause, allow or permit anything to be erected, placed, maintained, planted, or allowed to grow within said triangular area in such a manner as to materially impede vision between a height of three (3) feet and eight (8) feet above grade level at the point of intersection of the center lines of the two streets comprising the intersection. 
(3)  The triangular area of clear vision shall be formed by three (3) lines, two (2) of which lines shall extend outwardly from the point of intersection of the centerlines of the two (2) intersecting streets along the respective centerlines of said streets for the distances stated below, and the third line of said triangle shall connect the outermost termini of the first two (2) lines aforesaid. The length of the line running along the centerline of the street shall be one hundred (100) feet for a local road, one hundred sixty (160) feet for a collector road, and two hundred (200) feet for a highway or arterial road. 
Functional Road Classification Distance from Street
Centerline Intersection
(feet)Local 100 Collector 160 Highways and Arterial 200  
Subdivision signs are permitted in medians, provided the care and maintenance of the medians and subdivision sign are the responsibility of the subdivision's Homeowners Association or other party, and if the median is setback a minimum of twenty (20) feet from the road right-of-way of the intersecting road, and the sign is no closer than thirty (30) feet from the intersecting right-of-way, and the subdivision sign does not impair the clear sight distance, as determined by the location of the stop bar with the intersecting roadway. 
(4)  The diagram below is an example of the formation of a sight triangle at the Southeast corner of the intersection of two local roads: 
(5)  Violation of this Section shall be deemed a public nuisance, hazardous to the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of Rockledge, and may be enforced by proceedings before the Rockledge Nuisance Abatement Board, proceedings before the Rockledge Code Enforcement Board, or by suit for injunctive relief. 
(B)  Determination; Notice to alter or remove. 
(1)  Whenever the Rockledge Building Official, after investigation, shall determine that the owner, occupant or other person in possession of a triangular area of clear vision as described in this Section is in violation of this Section, he shall cause to be served upon such person or party a written notice requiring such person or party to remove the obstruction so as to comply with the provisions of this Section. 
(2)  The notice shall be served upon the owner, occupant or other persons in possession of the triangular area and shall require such person or party to comply with the directions contained therein within fifteen (15) days after service thereof. 
(3)  Such notice may be served by personal delivery to the addressee, or by mailing same by certified mail to the addressee's last known postal address as indicated on the records of the Brevard County Property Appraiser, or by placing a copy thereof at a conspicuous place upon the triangular area abutting or adjacent to the intersection. 
(C)  Appeal to nuisance abatement board. Any person affected by the notice authorized by this Section may, within the time specified in the notice, appeal to the Rockledge Nuisance Abatement Board, and until said Board shall act upon such appeal, the appellant shall not be required to comply with the notice. 
(D)  Abatement by City. If, after service of notice, the owner or occupant does not comply with nor appeal the directions contained in the notice within the time herein specified, or thereafter fails to comply with an order of the Nuisance Abatement Board within the time specified therein, the Building Official shall cause the necessary action to be taken to remove and terminate the unlawful obstruction and all cost of such abatement by the City shall constitute a lien upon the property in favor of the City which lien shall be levied, enforced and collected by the City in the same manner as is provided for the recovery by the City of its costs and liens for the abatement of nuisances found to exist by the Rockledge Nuisance Abatement Board. 
(E)  Exemptions. Nothing contained in this Section shall prohibit the owner of any property from erecting or maintaining a building or permanent structure permitted by this Code, however, no plants, shrubs, hedges, foliage, or movable structures, whether existing at the time of enactment of this Ordinance or hereafter, shall be exempt from this Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1018-91, § 1, 11-20-91; Ord. No. 1098-95, § 6, 5-3-95) 
SECTION 53.00. - BLOCKS [AND LOTS] 

53.10. - Design of blocks. 
(a)  Generally. The lengths, widths and shapes of blocks shall be determined with due regard to: 
(1)  Provision of adequate building sites suitable to the special needs of the use contemplated. 
(2)  Zoning requirements as to lot size and dimensions. 
(3)  Such access, circulation, control and safety of street traffic as deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety and welfare as approved by the city's Public Works Director. 
(b)  Length. Residential blocks shall not exceed one thousand five hundred (1,500) feet in length, nor shall they be less than five hundred (500) feet in length. 
53.20. - Design of lots. 
(a)  Generally. Lot arrangement and design shall be such that all lots will provide satisfactory and desirable building sites, appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated. See Exhibit 5 to determine building setback lines. 
(b)  Frontage. All lots shall front on a public street dedicated and accepted by the city council of the City of Rockledge, except lots in PUD and RCE country estate subdivisions. In PUD or RCE country estate subdivisions, limited access private roads may be proposed under the following conditions: 
(1)  That the proposed limited access private road would not prohibit or interrupt any planned public street system in the area.
