(2)  Said limited access private roads shall have the required right-of-way as specified in these regulations deeded fee simple to a homeowners' association composed of the owners of lots in the subdivision who will be responsible for maintenance of said limited access private road or street. The construction plans and specifications shall comply with the requirements contained herein. The engineering coordinator or his designee shall make inspections of the construction and issue a certificate of completion prior to the issuance of any building permits. 
EXHIBIT 5. DETERMINING BUILDING SETBACK LINES 
BUILDING SETBACK LINE 
Where the lot frontage is less than the minimum lot width required by the zoning resolution, the building setback distance is the minimum required by the zoning resolution, or the distance to the point where the lot width equals the minimum width required by the zoning resolution, whichever is greater. Lot width must be measured at a right angle to the lot depth line. The lot depth line is a line connecting the midpoint of the front line with the midpoint of the rear lot line. 
Where the lot frontage exceeds the minimum lot width required by the zoning resolution, the building setback is the minimum required by the zoning resolution, and the setback line runs parallel to the front lot line. 
(3)  That the homeowners' association's documents, which provide for the maintenance of limited access roads and streets, shall be subject to review by the Public Works Director and subject to approval by the city council. The road shall be maintained to city standards. 
(4)  That PUD or RCE country estate subdivisions cannot mix public streets and limited access roads or streets. 
(5)  That emergency vehicles and all official public vehicles shall be granted use of the limited access streets at all times. 
(c)  Double-frontage lots. Lots having double street frontage shall be avoided where the streets are essentially parallel unless it is necessary to provide separation of residential development from railroads or arterial roads and streets. In such cases, provision shall be made either for marginal access streets or for lots to back up to the arterial rights-of-way. In the case of lots proposed to be backed up to said arterial, additional lot depth of twenty (20) feet, plus screen planting that will reach six (6) feet in height in twelve (12) months from date the subdivision is complete, shall be required. Vehicular access to the rear of a double-frontage lot shall be prevented. 
(d)  Corner lots. Corner lots, except for lots of one-half (1/2) acre or more in size, shall have a width at least fifteen (15) per cent larger than the width of interior lots along both adjacent streets. 
SECTION 54.00. - PUBLIC STREETS AND PRIVATE ROADS IN SUBDIVISIONS 
(1)  Generally. 
(a)  All subdivisions shall be designed in conformity with the requirements of these regulations. All proposed subdivisions shall conform to the adopted Rockledge Comprehensive Plan and Rockledge Zoning Ordinance. An applicant must obtain a construction permit prior to constructing any improvements or portion of an improvement. 
(b)  All roads or streets shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the minimum cross-sections as set forth elsewhere in these regulations. The construction work and the construction materials shall conform to the specifications for the subgrade, base and wearing surface provided by this Code. 
(c)  Care shall be exercised in making the street layout so as to prevent excessive grades, extreme cuts and fills, or other changes in the natural topography which would induce rapid and unwarranted storm water runoff, thereby causing washing and erosion or diversion of storm water over private or adjoining property. 
(d)  In addition to the specifications furnished to apply specifically to this construction, all required storm sewers or culverts, sanitary sewers and water lines, where such occur in the paved portion of the street, shall be installed prior to the final grading of the base. 
(e)  Water services may be jacked under the pavement where the water main has been installed on the opposite side of the street from where the services are needed. 
SECTION 55.00. - PARKING REQUIREMENTS 

55.10. - General requirements. 
    There shall be provided at the time of the erection of any main building or structure, or at the time any main building or structure is converted for the below listed uses, enlarged or increased in capacity by adding dwelling units, guest rooms, floor area or seats, minimum off-street automobile parking space, which shall be stabilized and paved with asphalt, concrete or other surface approved by the parking board, with adequate provisions for ingress and egress in accordance with the following requirements. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 10, 8-14-96) 
55.11. - Interpretation. 
    In the interpretation of this section, the following rules shall apply: 
(a)  The floor area of a building or structure shall be the sum of the gross horizontal area of every floor of a building, using exterior wall dimensions. 
(b)  The seating capacity is the number of seating spaces permitted by the fire code and approved by the fire chief. 
[(c)  Reserved.] 
(d)  Fractional numbers shall be increased to the next whole number if the fraction is five-tenths (0.5) or more, and when the fraction is less than five-tenths (0.5), the next lower whole number shall apply. 
55.12. - Detailed parking space requirements. 
    [Parking space requirements are as follows:] 
(a)  Auditoriums, theaters or other places of assembly. One and one-half (11/2) spaces for each four (4) seats. 
(b)  Automobile care (detailers, stereo installers, window tinting, headliners, etc.) and automobile repair shops (transmissions, engines, air conditioners, brakes, tires, etc.) Five (5) parking spaces for every inside repair or work area bay. All other portions of the structure (office or storage) shall be calculated separately, using the guidelines found in this section." 
(c)  Bowling alleys. Four (4) spaces for each alley. 
(d)  Business or commercial buildings. One (1) space for each two hundred (200) square feet of gross floor area, or fraction thereof. 
(e)  Clubs or lodges. One (1) space for each four (4) seats or one (1) space for each two hundred (200) square feet of gross floor area, or fraction thereof, whichever is greater. 
(f)  Dwelling structures: Two (2) spaces for each single-family residence, townhouse or dwelling unit in a duplex. Each attached or detached single-family dwelling unit built after January 1, 2000, shall have a garage or carport for at least one (1) automobile. Conversion of an existing garage or carport to living area is not permitted unless a new garage or carport with at least one (1) parking space is provided as a replacement. All existing converted garage or carport spaces will be considered a conforming grand-fathered use, if such conversion had a valid building permit issued before January 1, 2000. The minimum parking space within any garage shall be not less than an area measuring eight (8) feet by eighteen (18) feet. In such parking space there may not be placed any appliance (washer/dryer, etc.), air-conditioner or other item, which cannot be readily moved, nor are items which require a utility hookup of any kind allowed within the clear space of the garage. Two and one-half (21/2) spaces for each dwelling unit within a multiple-family complex of three (3) dwelling units or more. Group care facilities having more than three (3) clients, adult congregate living facilities (ACLF), and treatment and recovery facilities shall have one (1) off-street parking space for every three (3) beds in the facility. 
(g)  Furniture and major appliance stores. One (1) space per five hundred (500) square feet of floor area devoted to storage for the first four thousand (4,000) square feet, and one (1) space per seven hundred fifty (750) square feet of floor area of the remaining storage area, plus one (1) space per two hundred (200) square feet of floor area devoted to any use other than for storage. 
(h)  Hospitals, sanitariums. Three (3) spaces for each bed. 
(i)  Hotels. One (1) space for each suite or sleeping unit. 
(j)  Libraries, museums. One and one-half (11/2) spaces for each three hundred (300) square feet of gross floor area, or fraction thereof, or one and one-half (11/2) spaces for each four (4) seats, whichever is greater. 
(k)  Major retail commercial facility of 100,000 square feet gross lease space, or greater. One (1) space per each three hundred (300) square feet of gross retail space; and one (1) space for every five hundred (500) square feet of garden storage, warehouse and accessory office use. In addition, the following provisions may be used for these facilities only: 
(1)  A maximum of ten (10) per cent of the required off-street parking spaces may be designated as compact car spaces. Each such space shall have a minimum stall width of eight (8) feet and a minimum stall depth of eighteen (18) feet. Such spaces shall be signed and designated "compact cars only", and shall not be located in high turnover areas which are in close proximity to main building entrances. 
(2)  Each regular parking space (excluding parallel parking spaces) shall contain a striped rectangular area at least eighteen (18) feet in depth and nine (9) feet in width. Lines demarcating parking spaces may be drawn at various angles in relation to curbs and aisles, so long as the parking spaces so created contain within them the rectangular area required by this section. 
(3)  Front to front parking spaces shall be designed with a minimum length of thirty-six (36) feet, tire stops or green space area must be set back two (2) feet from the center, providing a four (4) foot buffer between vehicles. 
(4)  One (1) bicycle parking space per ten thousand (10,000) square feet of building area, shall be provided. 
(l)  Manufacturing and industrial uses. One (1) space for each two hundred (200) square feet of gross floor area, or fraction thereof. 
(m)  Marinas, commercial docks and piers. Two (2) parking spaces for each boat docking slip or mooring accommodation provided by the marina, plus the required spaces for the marina building or buildings associated therewith. 
(n)  Medical or dental clinics. One (1) space for each two hundred (200) square feet of gross floor area, or fraction thereof, plus one and one-half (11/2) spaces for each three (3) employees. 
(o)  Mortuaries. One and one-half (11/2) spaces for every four (4) seats. 
(p)  Motels. One (1) space for each unit plus one (1) space for manager or owner. 
(q)  Nursing or convalescent homes. One (1) space for each two (2) beds, plus one and one-half (11/2) spaces for every three (3) employees on the largest shift. 
(r)  Office and professional buildings. One (1) space for each two hundred (200) square feet of gross floor area, or fraction thereof. 
(s)  Restaurants or other eating places. One (1) space for each two (2) seats, chairs or stools. 
(t)  Rooming, boardinghouses. Two (2) spaces for each apartment. 
(u)  Schools. One (1) space for every thirty (30) students, plus one (1) space for every two (2) employees. 
(v)  Warehouse (other than mini-warehouse). One (1) space per each four hundred (400) square feet. 
(w)  Warehouse (mini-warehouse). When used for storage with no live occupancy, a minimum twenty-four-foot driveway. 
(x)  Uses not specifically named. The requirements for off-street parking for any use or uses not specifically named in this section shall be the same as provided in this section for the named use most similar in nature and character, it being the intent of the city council to require all uses to provide off-street parking. If a material controversy arises regarding the number of off-street parking spaces required to be provided for a particular use of property, the required number shall be determined and fixed by a board comprised of the building official, city manager and fire chief of the city, which board shall appear and be governed by the following guidelines and criteria in making such determination: 
(1)  Off-street parking requirements for similar uses of property in the city. 
(2)  Off-street parking requirements for buildings and improvements having similar physical characteristics. 
(3)  Intensity of vehicular and pedestrian traffic in the area. 
(4)  Foreseeable requirements for police, fire and other emergency vehicle services to and in the vicinity of the property. 
(5)  The size and physical characteristics of abutting streets. 
(6)  Availability of alternative parking areas. 
(7)  Foreseeable requirements for deliveries and public services to and in the vicinity of the property. 
(8)  The aesthetic quality of the property and its vicinity. 
(9)  Other considerations involving the health, safety and welfare of occupants of the property and citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1174-98, § 2, 11-4-98; Ord. No. 1186-99, § 5, 7-21-99; Ord. No. 1211-2000, § 4, 4-5-00; Ord. No. 1356-2004, § 1, 9-22-04; Ord. No. 1379-2005, § 1, 6-1-05; Ord. No. 1515-2009, § 1, 1-7-09) 
55.13. - Parking requirements within the community redevelopment district. 
    Within the area of the Rockledge Community Redevelopment District as defined by Resolution 2002-481 and Ordinance 1277-2002, there exists an overlay provision which empowers, upon request by a developer or staff on all new or remodeled properties, the reduction of parking requirements upon the unanimous approval of the City Manager, Building Official and Chairman of the Rockledge Community Redevelopment Agency. Any structure given modified parking shall automatically become conforming structures. 
(Ord. No. 1326-2003, § 3, 10-15-03; Ord. No. 1376-2005, § 6, 5-4-05) 
55.14. - Off-street parking specifications. 
(a)  Construction requirements: 
(1)  All parking areas shall be stabilized and paved with asphalt, concrete or other surface approved by the parking board, adequately drained and maintained in a dust-proof condition as long as the use is continued. 
(2)  Parking space dimensions shall be a minimum of ten (10) feet by twenty (20) feet. 
(3)  The minimum width for one-way driveway aisles shall be fourteen (14) feet and the minimum width for two-way driveway aisles shall be twenty-four (24) feet. 
(4)  Projects which are required to have more than fifty (50) parking spaces may have up to twenty-five (25) per cent of those parking spaces constructed as "grass parking" using a cellar confinement system, and installed in accordance with manufacturers' recommendations. Grass parking areas shall be located at the furthest distance from the principle structure of the project. Such areas shall be kept mowed and maintained with a grass covering. 
(b)  Location: 
(1)  Parking spaces for all dwellings shall be located on the same property with the main building to be served, where feasible. 
(2)  Parking spaces for uses other than dwellings shall be located on the same property with the main building to be served by such parking facilities, or not more than two hundred (200) feet distant from the nearest lot line of the property upon which said main building is situate, such distance to be measured along the center line of the right-of-way of the shortest and most direct route by public street between the street frontage line of the property constituting the off-street parking site. 
(3)  Parking requirements for two (2) or more uses of the same or different types may be satisfied by the allocation of the required number of spaces of each use in a common parking facility. 
(4)  Off-street parking spaces required for a use or uses other than dwellings, and which parking spaces are not on the same lot, parcel or tract of land with the main building to be served by such spaces, shall not be situate or located upon property in an R1, R2, R2A, R3, RCE, MH, or TH zoning district. 
(c)  Off-street loading. The following off-street loading spaces shall be provided for the uses indicated: 
(1)  Every hospital, institution, motel, single-occupancy commercial or industrial building or similar use having a floor area in excess of ten thousand (10,000) square feet, requiring the receipt or distribution by vehicles of materials and merchandise, shall have at least one (1) permanent maintained off-street loading space for the first ten thousand (10,000) square feet, and one (1) additional space for each twenty thousand (20,000) square feet of gross floor area or fraction thereof, over and above the first ten thousand (10,000) square feet. 
(2)  Single-occupancy retail operations, wholesale and industrial operations with a gross floor area of less than ten thousand (10,000) square feet shall provide sufficient receiving space on the property so as not to hinder the face movement of vehicles and pedestrians over a sidewalk, street or alley. 
(3)  Each space shall have direct access to an alley or street and shall have the following minimum dimensions: Length, twenty-five (25) feet; width, twelve (12) feet; height, fourteen (14) feet. 
(4)  Each location requiring an off-street loading space shall prepare a circulation plan layout sheet during the site plan approval process which shall include the following elements: all points of ingress and egress; location of driving lanes; layout of all off-street loading and unloading areas; required parking spaces; and on-site maneuvering and turn around area, which avoids interference with public use of the streets or alleys and specifies the route city garbage trucks will take to empty dumpsters on site. 
(d)  Reduction of off-street parking and loading areas. Areas reserved for off-street parking or loading in accordance with paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) hereof shall not be reduced in area or changed to any other use unless the permitted use which it serves is discontinued or modified, except where equivalent parking or loading space is provided to the satisfaction of the board of adjustment. 
(Ord. No. 1016-91, § 3, 11-20-91; Ord. No. 1120-96, § 11, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1174-98, § 3, 11-4-98) 
55.15. - Parking regulations in residential districts. 
    The following regulations shall apply to all residential districts as defined and designated on the official zoning map of the city: 
(A)  Definitions: 
(1)  Boat or cargo trailer. A trailer which is used for or is designed for use in carrying or transporting boats or other cargo. 
(2)  Commercial vehicle. Any truck, bus, trailer, portable equipment, machinery or similar vehicle or combination thereof used or intended to be used for any commercial enterprise or business purpose, or a vehicle which has over four (4) wheels, or more than two (2) axles, or a height greater than eight (8) feet from ground level, or an overall length of more than twenty-two (22) feet, excluding any self-propelled roadway vehicles having a net weight of less than three thousand (3,000) pounds. A legal presumption shall exist that any self-propelled commercial vehicle having a net weight in excess of three thousand (3,000) pounds, or more than four (4) wheels, or more than two (2) axles, or a height greater than eight (8) feet from ground level, or an overall length of more than twenty-two (22) feet, is a commercial vehicle as herein defined. 
(3)  Truck tractor. A motor vehicle designed and used primarily for drawing another vehicle or non self-propelled vehicle from one (1) destination to another. 
(4)  Horse van. A trailer which is used for or is designed for use in carrying horses. 
(B)  Motor vehicles prohibited or restricted in residential districts: 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, agent, operator, or person in charge of any truck, truck tractor or other commercial vehicle, boat, boat trailer, cargo trailer or horse van to park, stop, store or keep same on any public street, avenue, alley or other thoroughfare, or on any right-of-way thereof within any residential district in the City of Rockledge for a cumulative period of time exceeding one (1) hour in any twenty-four (24) hour period, unless such parking or stopping is for the specific purpose of providing a lawful commercial service to the owner or occupant of property in a residential district between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. in which case the service provider shall be permitted to park a commercial vehicle in the residential district for such period of time as is necessary to provide or perform the commercial service between 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any owner, lessee or occupant of real property in any residential district in the city to park on, cause to be parked on, or allow to be parked on such residential real property any truck, truck tractor, horse van or other commercial vehicle of greater than one-and-one-half ton capacity for a cumulative period of time exceeding one (1) hour in any twenty-four (24) hour period, unless such vehicle is parked in an enclosed garage. The provisions of this subsection shall not be construed to prohibit such parking between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. of a commercial vehicle by a service provider engaged in performing a lawful commercial service to property in a residential district as described in the preceding subsection. This restriction shall also apply to the owner, agent, operator or person in charge of any such vehicle in the event such person is not the owner or lessee or occupant of such real property. 
(C)  Delivery and construction vehicles; emergency repairs: 
(1)  The restrictions of paragraph (B) of this section shall not apply to the temporary parking of such vehicles on private property in residential districts whereon construction is underway, for which a current and valid building permit has been issued by the city and such permit is property displayed on the premises. 
(2)  The restrictions of paragraph (B) of this section shall not apply to a situation where such vehicle becomes disabled and as a result of such emergency is required to be parked within a residential district for longer than one (1) hour. However, such vehicle shall be removed from the residential district within twenty-four (24) hours by wrecker towing, if necessary, regardless of the nature of the emergency. 
(D)  Permissive parking: 
(1)  A panel, pickup or similar type of truck or commercial vehicle that is less than twenty (20) feet in overall length, and is designed and rated by the manufacturer to have a carrying capacity of not more than three thousand (3,000) pounds, may be parked on the premises of a private residence in a residential district provided that said vehicle is in operable condition and regularly used by a resident of the premises where it is parked, and not more than one such vehicle is parked on said premises at any one (1) time. Vehicles, as stated above, bearing vehicle street graphics that cover a surface area of the vehicle greater than ten (10) square feet in total area must be parked within a carport or garage on the residential premises, or in an area of the premises where the vehicle will not be visible to persons on any public street abutting the residential premises. 
(2)  The provisions of subsections (A) and (B) of this section prohibiting the parking of buses in residential districts of the city shall not apply to public and private school buses, including church school buses, when parked on school or church property." 
(3)  Official vehicles and equipment parked at the private residence of an employee of city, county, or state government, or employee of a public utility company, when it is a job requirement of such employee that the official vehicle or equipment be used as transportation to and from the employees place of work. 
(4)  Major recreational equipment other than boats and boat trailers, including, but not limited to, recreational vehicles, motor homes, recreational trailers, travel trailers, camper trailers, pickup trailers or coaches, topper campers, and slideout campers, shall not be parked, kept or maintained within any front yard of premises in a residential zone; however, any such major recreational equipment other than boats and boat trailers may be parked in the side yard behind the front building line or in the rear yard of premises in a residential district; provided, that: 
(a)  Said equipment is owned by the owner or occupant of the property upon which said equipment is stored for the personal use of such owner or occupant rather than for rent or hire. 
(b)  Said equipment is not used for residential, office or commercial purposes while so parked or stored. 
(c)  Said equipment is not used for sleeping, housekeeping or living quarters while so parked or stored. 
(d)  Said equipment is located or stored to the rear of the front building line and on corner lots behind the side building line or is located in a garage or carport. 
(e)  Said equipment is not located or stored on any part of any road right-of-way. 
(f)  Said equipment must be located on the property of an established residence and may not be parked or stored on vacant residential property. 
(g)  Said equipment may not be connected or hooked up to water or electricity, except for purposes of filling water tanks and recharging battery systems, while parked or stored on the premises. 
(h)  Said equipment is parked on an improved parking surface which shall consist of asphalt, crushed stone, crushed shell, paving bricks or other such nonconcrete improvements which would render the parking surface sufficiently dust free. No such improved parking surface will be deemed to constitute a "structure" which is prohibited within a side yard setback area. 
(i)  Not more than one (1) recreational vehicle shall be stored on or located within any one (1) lot or parcel of land in a residential district. 
Major recreational equipment may be parked anywhere on residential premises for a period not to exceed twenty-four (24) hours during loading or unloading. Major recreational equipment may be parked in a driveway in the front yard of premises in a residential district for a period not to exceed seventy-two (72) continuous hours during any one (1) period of thirty (30) consecutive days if the person in possession and control thereof is a visitor of the owner or occupant of the residential premises during the entire period of parking, and the equipment is not parked within five (5) feet of a right-of-way line of any public road or street. 
(5)  Boats and boat trailers: 
(a)  Exceeding twenty-four (24) feet in length (inclusive of boat, motor and trailer). No boat exceeding twenty-four (24) feet overall in length, or boat trailer capable of carrying a boat exceeding twenty-four (24) feet overall in length shall be parked or kept on premises in a residential zone except in the rear yard of such premises, or in the side yard of such premises if parked or kept within a garage or other opaque structure enclosed on at least three (3) sides. In no case shall such boat and/or boat trailer block or impair pedestrian travel on any sidewalk. 
(b)  Not exceeding twenty-two (22) feet in length. Boats not exceeding twenty-two (22) feet overall in length, and boat trailers designed to carry a boat not exceeding twenty-two (22) feet overall in length, shall not be parked or kept in the front or side yard of premises in a residential zone except under the following conditions and restrictions: 
1.  The boat or boat trailer must be parked on a concrete or paved driveway or surface and in no event shall any such boat or boat trailer be allowed to encroach on a street or thoroughfare. 
2.  The boat or boat trailer shall not be parked on any premises so as to impair or obstruct the visibility or line of sight of the operator of any motor vehicle traveling upon any street or thoroughfare. 
3.  All open and interior areas of the boat must be kept covered with an opaque cover of canvas, nylon, plastic or similar sturdy material securely fastened to the boat in such a manner as to effectively prevent ready or easy access into the boat by children under ten (10) years of age, and so as to prevent visibility into the interior of the boat by persons traveling on public property. "Open and interior areas of the boat" shall mean areas of the boat, other than decks and exterior walkways, designed to be occupied by passengers and operators of the boat. 
4.  The boat must bear a current and valid state boat registration number and decal. 
5.  The boat trailer must bear a current and valid state license plate. 
6.  The boat must be used primarily for recreational purposes. 
7.  The boat and boat trailer must be kept and maintained in a reasonably neat and clean appearance so as not to be or become an eyesore detracting from the aesthetic quality of the premises and neighborhood. 
(E)  Conditional waivers: 
(1)  The Rockledge Board of Adjustment may, upon application by the owner or occupant of premises located in a residential zoning district of the city, grant such owner or occupant a conditional waiver of any parking restriction imposed by subsection (D)(3) of this section with respect to the parking of a recreational vehicle at such premises, subject to the following conditions, limitations and restrictions: The owner or occupant of the premises must submit an application for conditional waiver to the Rockledge Board of Adjustment, together with a fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), the application to contain the following: Applicant's name, address and telephone number; legal description of the premises involved; name and address of the owner of the premises; name and address of the persons in possession and control of the recreational vehicle; a description of the recreational vehicle; a diagram or survey of the premises with the location indicated thereon where the recreational vehicle is desired to be kept; the reason and basis why applicant cannot comply with the provisions of subsection (D)(3) of this section; the period of time for which the waiver is requested; the names and addresses of owners and occupants of all property located within a distance of five hundred (500) feet from the premises where the recreational vehicle is to be kept; a statement signed by not less than seventy-five (75) per cent of the owners and occupants of property within five hundred (500) feet of applicant's premises consenting to the granting of the requested waiver. 
(2)  The board of adjustment shall conduct a public hearing on each application after written notice to the owners and occupants of all property located within a distance of five hundred (500) feet of applicant's premises. At the public hearing the board of adjustment shall consider the following: The reasons and basis assigned by applicant for the granting of the waiver; the extent and degree to which the requested waiver varies from the general requirements of subsection (D)(3); various alternatives which would not require a waiver; the term for which the waiver is requested; comments of all interested persons; the probable effects upon occupants of adjoining and adjacent properties from the granting of the requested waiver; the practicality of the requested waiver; the number of other outstanding waivers in existence and their proximity to applicant's premises; and the probable effects of issuance of the waiver upon the health, safety, welfare, and aesthetics of the community. 
(3)  Any waiver granted shall represent the slightest deviation from the general regulations that is practicable under existent circumstances and for the shortest term necessary to accomplish a just result. 
(4)  No waiver shall permit the parking of a recreational vehicle within five (5) feet of any public road or street right-of-way, nor in any location that will create a safety hazard by obstructing the view of persons entering a public right-of-way from premises adjacent to those for which the waiver is requested. 
(5)  As a prerequisite to the granting of a waiver, the board of adjustment must determine that strict compliance with the provisions of subsection (D)(3) of this section would constitute an unreasonable burden and hardship to the applicant due to the size or configuration of the premises or the improvements thereon, physical handicap of the applicant, or other reasons assigned by the applicant as a basis for granting the waiver; however, in no instance shall the applicant's financial hardship constitute a sufficient basis for the granting of a conditional waiver. 
(6)  Any waiver shall stand revoked automatically upon cessation of the reason or basis for which it was granted. 
(7)  The holder of any waiver shall notify the city of the cessation or termination of the cause or basis for which the waiver was granted within seventy-two (72) hours after the cessation or termination of such reason or basis. 
(8)  Any waiver granted may be revoked by the Rockledge Board of Adjustment at any time said board shall determine that the reason or basis for a waiver has ceased to exist, or that the holder of the waiver has violated any provision, condition or term of the waiver, or that a continuation of the waiver would be contrary to the health, safety, welfare or aesthetics of the community. The board of adjustment shall not revoke any waiver without first conducting a public hearing after reasonable notice in writing to the holder of the waiver. 
(9)  No waiver shall be assignable nor transferable by the holder thereof. 
(10)  Special provisions for the handicapped. If an application for a conditional waiver alleges that the applicant is a physically handicapped person and the holder of a current valid exemption entitlement parking permit issued by the Florida Department of Highway Safety and Motor Vehicles pursuant to Section 320.0848, Florida Statutes, and that applicant's handicap necessitates his use of major recreational equipment as herein described for transportation purposes, and that a conditional waiver is necessary because of applicant's inability to comply with the provisions of subsection (D)(3) of this section due to his handicap, then the following provisions will apply: 
(a)  No fee shall be payable with respect to the application. 
(b)  The application need not contain the names and addresses, nor consents, of owners and occupants of property located within five hundred (500) feet of the premises for which the conditional waiver is sought, but must contain the names and addresses of the owners and occupants of properties abutting and adjoining the premises for which the conditional waiver is requested. 
(c)  No notice of public hearing as required by subsection (E)(2) above need be published nor furnished to owners or occupants of property within five hundred (500) feet of the premises for which the conditional waiver is sought, but reasonable notice of the public hearing on the application shall be furnished by mail to the owners and occupants of properties lying within a distance of one hundred (100) feet of the premises for which the conditional waiver is requested. 
(d)  If the board of adjustment determines at the public hearing that the allegations of the application are true and well founded, the board shall grant the minimum conditional waiver to the applicant consistent with the limitations and conditions set forth in this subsection. 
(F)  Enforcement: 
(1)  Nothing contained in paragraph (B) of this section permitting the parking of one (1) truck-type vehicle, one-and-one-half-ton rated capacity or less, on a plot in a residential district shall be considered permission to engage in any type of commercial activities from any location within a residential district unless otherwise permitted in these regulations. 
(2)  The chief of police of the city, or his duly authorized designee, may issue, upon proper application therefor by the owner, or his authorized representative, to the police department, a permit extending the parking time limits set forth in paragraph (B) of this section up to, but not exceeding twenty-four (24) hours upon establishing that such permit is requested in good faith for a reasonable cause shown or demonstrated to the chief of police, or his designee, and not for the purpose of avoiding the intent or objectives of this section. 
(3)  This section is primarily for the purpose of protecting the residential property in the city against the lingering presence of commercial vehicles and the protection of property values in such districts. Therefore, any provisions of this Code or other ordinance of the city or laws of this state providing for the regulation of motor vehicles are in addition to this section and whenever any provision of this Code or other ordinance or applicable statute, whether primarily for the regulation of motor vehicles or for purposes of zoning, imposes more stringent requirements, regulations, restrictions or limitations than are imposed or required by the provisions of this section, then the more stringent requirements, regulations, restrictions or limitations shall apply. 
(4)  The nonconforming use provisions of these regulations shall not apply to this section. 
(5)  This section shall not be construed as authorizing trucks to utilize any street or other public thoroughfare of the city over which such vehicular traffic is now or hereafter prohibited by the provisions of this Code or other ordinance or lawful order of the police department. 
(6)  Any violation of this section shall constitute an offense against the city punishable upon conviction by fine or imprisonment or both, not exceeding the maximum penalty prescribed by Section 1-9 of the City Code. In addition to the punishment hereinabove authorized, or as an alternate thereto, the provisions of this section may be enforced through the powers and authority of the Rockledge Code Enforcement Board. 
(Ord. No. 1059-93, §§ 1-3, 8-18-93; Ord. No. 1240-2000, § 3, 10-18-00) 
Editor's note- At the direction of the city, former § 25-286 of the Code of Ordinances has been included herein as § 55.15. 
SECTION 56.00. - UTILITIES/EASEMENTS 

56.10. - Utility structures. 
    Except for antennas and towers which are regulated by the terms of Section 82.00 of these regulations, structures or uses required for private or public utilities such as gas, water, electric, sewage or telephone can be located within any district upon recommendation of the planning commission and approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1098-95, § 7, 5-3-95) 
56.20. - Placement of utilities. 
(a)  Except as expressly provided hereinafter, all utility lines, including, but not limited to, those required for electrical power distribution, telephone and telegraph communication, street lighting, and television signal service, shall be installed underground. Electrical power lines shall be installed at an underground depth of not less than twenty-four (24) inches below grade level, and telephone, telegraph and television cable lines installed not less than eighteen (18) inches below grade level. This section shall apply to all cables, conduits or wires forming part of a local electrical distribution system including service lines to individual properties but shall not apply to main distribution feeder electric lines delivering power to local distribution systems, nor to wires, conductors or associated apparatus and supporting structures whose exclusive function is in transmission of electrical energy between generating stations, substations and transmission lines of other utility systems. Appurtenances such as transformer boxes, pedestal-mounted terminal boxes, and meter cabinets may be placed aboveground. 
(b)  Purpose of width of utility easements. Utility easements shall be not less than five (5) feet wide on all side lot lines, and not less than ten (10) feet wide on the front lot lines for each lot and seven and one-half (71/2) feet wide on the rear lot line for each lot, as needed, and approved by the City Council during the platting process. Utility easements shall be of sufficient size to allow utility vehicles access to construct, maintain and repair all utilities. 
(c)  The City Manager may authorize the Building Official to issue permits which would allow above-ground utility drops in any pre-existing and approved subdivision, which currently has above ground utilities already in place. 
(d)  All utility poles installed within the City of Rockledge shall be constructed of concrete, except in designated Historic Districts. All existing wooden utility poles when moved or replaced for any reason shall be replaced with concrete poles. Any exception to this requirement may only be authorized by the City Manager or his designee. 
(Ord. No. 1186-99, § 6, 7-21-99; Ord. No. 1240-2000, § 4, 10-18-00) 
56.25. - Developer to pay city for street lighting poles. 
    Every developer who develops a subdivision within the city shall pay to the city one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each concrete street lighting pole within said subdivision. Said payment shall be made prior to time that the city approves installation by electrical franchise holder. 
56.30. - Location of easements. 
(a)  Utility easements shall be centered on rear and side lot lines. If utility or access easements are planned adjacent to the subdivision boundary, the full width necessary shall be provided within the proposed subdivision. Utility easements shall be identified on the plat as such with an accurate description of the nature of such easement. 
SECTION 57.00. - DRAINAGE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 57.00 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. Provisions originally numbered as § 57.00 have been renumbered as § 57.01. 

57.01. - Drainage facilities required. 
(a)  Drainage and water management facilities [shall be] designed and constructed according to the standards and requirements of this section. The term "drainage," where appropriate, shall include, but not be limited to, swales, ditches, storm sewers, seepage basins, culverts, sidedrains, retention or detention basis, crossdrains and canals. 
Note- See the editor's note to the title of § 57.00. 
57.10. - General construction methods. 
    All design and construction methods shall conform to the St. Johns River Water Management District, the City of Rockledge Specifications and following the methods published by the Florida Department of Transportation, latest editions, and (such manuals) shall serve as reference guides and standards of construction for any improvements. Said methods and manuals are hereby declared to be good engineering practice for the construction of improvements and shall be used by the city as the engineering standard for the purpose of making inspections, approved items of construction and approving constructions plans and specifications. 
(Ord. No. 1554-2010, § 3, 8-18-10) 
57.11. - Construction plans and specifications generally. 
    All construction plans and specifications shall include a topographical map showing not less than one-foot contours on the NAVD of 1988, nor only of the subdivision tract but also of such necessary adjacent land to indicate the method of final discharge of surface water and shall also contain the following information: 
(1)  A street layout plan showing all necessary elevations, treatment of intersections, designed grade of pavement, the width and type of pavement and details showing the final disposal of all street draining. Sufficient topographic information shall be shown on existing outfall ditches, major drainage channels to validate drainage designs, and other drainage facilities. 
(2)  Typical sections showing details of proposed pavements, wearing surfaces, curbs, swales, canals, shoulders, slopes, drainage structures and other items of major construction. 
(Ord. No. 1554-2010, § 4, 8-18-10) 
57.12. - Construction and design requirements for water control. 
    A system shall be provided for draining all projects requiring a development order from the city including the lots, roads and streets in the subdivision. Soil types shall be considered for percolation rates and approved land usage in the engineering design. Stormwater system design shall be for thirteen (13) inches of rainfall for the one hundred (100) year twenty-four (24) hour pre vs. post event. Any facility not having an effective positive outfall shall design the stormwater management facility to retain the one hundred (100) year storm of twenty-four (24) hour event as predicted for Brevard County. Stormwater treatment systems in a community redevelopment district (CRA designated) may design to a twenty-five (25) year twenty-four (24) hour pre vs. post storm event. The system shall be designed for fifty-year life, low maintenance costs, and ease of maintenance methods. 
(a)  Off-site easements. Any off-site easements or rights-of-way which are needed to make the drainage system function shall be included in the proposal for development and made a criterion for development approval. 
(b)  Phased development. The drainage system for each phase of a development shall be capable of standing on its own if subsequent areas planned for development are not developed. 
(c)  Acceptable methodologies: 
(1)  Construction plans shall be accompanied by a comprehensive study of proposed site and stormwater drainage system. 
(2)  Upon approval of the city's public works director or his designee, professionally accepted models for calculating stormwater runoff may be used. 
(3)  The storm drainage plan may include the use of street curbs and gutters, and roadside swales as transportation arteries for the stormwater; provided, that the length and grade of the flow canal is such that the velocity flow does not exceed three (3) feet per second. (See subsection (h) hereof.) The use of swales are not allowed in the construction of new residential development, except for those shown on the individual lot grading plan, for on-site drainage, on development construction plans. 
(4)  Outfall of the development surface or storm drainage system, after satisfying all design standards for on-site retention, shall be one of the following: 
a.  Proper connection between the new development drainage system and the existing city drainage system, if, in the opinion of the city's public works director or his designee, the existing city system is adequate. 
b.  Proper connection from the new development to existing natural drainage, such as a creek, river or low wetland area is adjacent to the subdivision may be approved, if, in the opinion of the city's public works director or his designee, the existing natural system is adequate. 
c.  Proper connection from the new stormwater facility to an existing drainage ditch or canal of the city, county or water management district may be approved, provided written permission has been secured from the agency having jurisdictional control of such drainage connection. 
d.  In the event none of the methods of disposal of the stormwater from the development outlined above are readily accessible to the development, it shall be the responsibility of the developer to provide a suitable outfall for the stormwater of the new site by securing permanent easements or the purchase of additional property for the construction of roadside swales or underground storm drain through private property, so as to connect the development storm drainage system with a satisfactory disposal area. In addition, the cost of obtaining and installing such drainage conveyance and structures shall be the responsibility of the developer. 
e.  Lots shall be designed to transfer stormwater runoff to a centralized water retention area within the development in a manner acceptable to the city. 
(d)  Submission of subsoil investigation: A subsoil investigation report shall be submitted with the construction plans and shall include: 
(1)  Test borings on a minimum of five-hundred-foot intervals to a depth sufficient to locate the groundwater table in the development. 
(2)  Providing the city's public works director or his designee with such additional information may be required to ensure that the soil is suitable for the proposed development. 
(e)  Material specifications for culverts and storm sewers: 
(1)  The following pipe materials are acceptable: High density double wall polyethylene pipe, aluminum pipe and reinforced concrete pipe. 
(2)  Workmanship and pipe materials shall conform to DOT Standard Specifications, latest edition. All drainage pipes under driveways or roadways shall be concrete, unless approved by the city's public works director or his designee. 
(3)  Only reinforced concrete pipe shall be used under pavements into saltwater outfalls. Concrete for reinforced concrete box culverts shall conform to FDOT Standard Specifications, latest edition. 
(4)  Outfall retention devices shall be of reinforced concrete and aluminum materials constructed to adequately meet the outfall requirements. 
(f)  Culvert design: 
(1)  The minimum pipe size shall be twenty-four (24) inches diameter on all highways, arterials and collector streets. Local roads, marginal access streets and alleys shall require a minimum eighteen-inch (18) diameter pipe. Equivalent elliptical pipe sizes may be substituted. 
(2)  The minimum clearance between the bottom of roadway base and the top of all pipe culverts shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's specifications for the design load projected. All utility installations shall be a minimum of thirty-six (36) inches below the roadway base. 
(g)  Sizing culverts. The design velocity to be used will be in accordance with Florida Department of Transportation design standards. Minimum size for a driveway culvert is eighteen (18) inches or equivalent elliptical size unless approved by the city's public works director or his designee. 
(h)  Swales. 
(1)  A swale is a manmade trench which: 
a.  Contains contiguous area of standing or flowing water only following a rainfall event; 
b.  Is planted with or has stabilized vegetation suitable for soil stabilization, stormwater treatment flows and nutrient treatment; and 
c.  Is designed to take into account the soil percolation, slope length, and drainage so as to prevent erosion and reduce pollutant concentration of any discharge. 
d.  Is designed to take into account the soil erodability, soil percolation, slope, slope length, and drainage so as to prevent erosion and reduce pollutant concentration of any discharge. 
All swales shall be so designed as to adequately meet the particular drainage requirements of the development. 
(i)  Underdrains. In cases where there is a prevalence of soils that exhibit adverse water table characteristics, underdrains and/or fill will be required. See Exhibit 10. 
EXHIBIT 10. STANDARD DESIGN FOR SUB-SURFACE DRAINAGE SYSTEMS 

(1)  Finished roads are to be constructed with a minimum crown elevation of twenty-four (24) inches above the ground water table. 
a.  Wherever road construction or lot development is planned in areas of the proposed development having soil types with unacceptable water table characteristics, underdrains and/or fill shall be provided and shown on the engineering plans. Underdrains must be designed with free gravity outlet at carefully selected discharge points. Erosion-control measures shall be provided as needed at all discharge points. 
b.  Wherever road cuts in otherwise suitable soils indicate that the finish grade swill result in a road surface-to-water table relationship that adversely exceeds the degree of limitation stated above, underdrains will be required. 
c.  Wherever roadway construction reveals unexpected water bearing strata that would cause deterioration of the pavement, underdrains will be required even though not shown on the plans. 
d.  Filtering media shall consist of stone, gravel or slag, and shall contain no friable materials. 
(j)  Required submittals. The applicant shall include in the construction plans a master drainage map showing all existing and proposed features. The map is to be prepared on a twenty-four-inch by thirty-six-inch sheet on a scale not less than one (1) inch equaling sixty (60) feet. Size and scale may be adjusted for the larger development based on the approval of the city's public works director or his designee. Said drainage map shall reflect inclusion of the following criteria and features: 
(1)  On-site retention of the first inch of runoff. 
(2)  Drainage drawings shall show: 
a.  All areas draining to the proposed development and all area tributaries to proposed structures. 
b.  Topographical information with sufficient elevations to verify the locations of all ridges, streams and other water resources. 
c.  Notes pertaining to existing standing water, areas of heavy seepage or springs. 
d.  Existing drainage features such as swales, roadways and ponds. 
e.  Proposed development layout. 
(Ord. No. 1022-91, § 10, 12-18-91; Ord. No. 1120-96, §§ 12-15, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1240-2000, § 5, 10-18-00; Ord. No. 1554-2010, § 5, 8-18-10) 
57.13. - Obstruction of drainage facilities prohibited. 
    No person shall obstruct the flow of storm water by obstructing any ditch or drain on the several alleys and streets of the city in any manner whatsoever, or any natural drain whatsoever, located within the city. 
57.14. - Erosion control. 
    Seeding, mulching and/or sodding shall be performed as required to prevent undue erosion during all construction activities. The developer shall be required to keep accumulations of sand and earth out of the curb and gutter. Temporary siltation basis [basins] may be required during construction. Maintenance shall be provided by the developer for the two-year period of the road guarantee and for each lot until final inspection is passed. 
57.15. - Retention area standards. 
    All retention areas in the city shall be wet retention areas, except in unusual circumstances where it would not be viable for the stormwater drainage system to use wet retention and an alternative retention method is approved by the Saint Johns River Water Management District, a licensed Florida Engineer, and the City of Rockledge. The City of Rockledge shall have final determination of the system to be used, if not wet retention. 
(1)  Fencing: All dedicated public retention areas shall be fenced by a chain link fence six (6) feet in height with an access gate of sufficient size to allow easy ingress and egress by municipal maintenance vehicles and equipment. Any private retention area that has side slopes steeper than a 1 to 5 slope/grade ratio (meaning one (1) foot of vertical descent for each five (5) feet of horizontal extension), shall be fenced in a like manner as stated above. 
(2)  Slope requirements: The slope/grade ratio of all sides of private retention areas shall not be greater (steeper) than 1 to 5 from the outer boundary of the retention area to an imaginary line two (2) feet below the normal water level. From a point two (2) feet below normal water level to the bottom of the retention area the slope/grade ratio shall be no steeper than 1 to 2. A minimum depth from the bottom of the retention area to the normal water level shall be five (5) feet. 
(3)  Retention area designations: The entire area holding retained water from the normal water level inward toward the center of the retention area shall be identified as a separate easement/tract area known as "stormwater retention area easement/tract" on construction drawings and on any final linens. The area extending outward from the stormwater retention area easement/tract to the outer perimeter of the entire approved surface stormwater management system shall hereinafter be described as a drainage maintenance access easement which shall be deemed another separate easement/tract to be known as a "drainage maintenance access easement/tract," which will radiate out a minimum of sixteen (16) feet from the outer edge of the stormwater retention area easement/tract, and have a minimum of one (1) maintenance access route, having a width of not less than sixteen (16) feet, connected to a dedicated public road right-of-way as part of the drainage maintenance access easement/tract. Both of the aforementioned easement/tract areas shall be titled to or given to a homeowners association or other legal entity which shall expressly assume liability and responsibility for the maintenance and upkeep thereof. All drainage maintenance access easement/tract areas shall be kept free of all structures, including but not limited to fences, docks, trees, and seawalls, except common areas as approved by the City of Rockledge during the site plan review process. Both easement/tract areas described above may be identified as one (1) "surface stormwater retention area easement/tract" on the face of any proposed final linen, subdivision plat, or commercial project. 
(4)  Docks and amenities: Docks may be allowed in a stormwater retention area easement/tract provided the developer has included in such an easement/tract a common area titled in the homeowners association or other legal entity for the specific use of constructing a dock or other structure allowed by this Code or the stormwater retention easement/tract has been identified and included in by ownership title to the upland lot or property. Such structures shall not be constructed until after obtaining the correct permits from the City of Rockledge. Access routes from a dedicated public roadway to the stormwater retention area easement/tract shall be placed between every common area identified for the construction of a dock or other structure. Common areas will be identified through the site plan review process and be approved by the planning commission and the Rockledge City Council. In no case shall the city allow any fences, seawalls or other non-dock structure to be built in the stormwater retention area easement or tract. 
(5)  Maintenance of retention and access tracts: All private stormwater drainage systems shall be maintained by a homeowners association or other private legal entity. Such maintenance responsibility shall be expressly stated in a declaration of restrictive covenants recorded in the Official Record Books of Brevard County, Florida, pertaining to the subject development. Such language shall state substantially the following: 
    "The undersigned (developer's name) and its successors and assigns hereby expressly assumes full responsibility for the improvement, maintenance and upkeep of any and all stormwater retention areas and drainage maintenance access easement/tracts in this development (plat), and the City of Rockledge has expressly renounced any responsibility, duty or liability on the part of said city for the improvement, maintenance or upkeep of said stormwater retention areas and drainage maintenance access easement/tracts." 
    In addition, the recorded plat of any development having a private stormwater drainage system shall include a statement on the face of the plat disclaiming any responsibility on the part of the City of Rockledge for the construction, maintenance or upkeep of any part of the private stormwater drainage system, and identifying the entity responsible and liable for the maintenance and upkeep of the entire stormwater drainage system in conjunction with the platting process and be approved by city staff. The final linen shall identify the party(ies) responsible for the maintenance and upkeep of the stormwater retention easement/tracts and drainage maintenance access easement/tracts. The use of all easement/tract areas mentioned in this section shall be vested in the legal entity(ies) having responsibility for the maintenance and upkeep thereof. All stormwater retention area easements/tracts and drainage maintenance access easements/tracts as shown on any development or subdivision plat and as shown on any construction drawing, and shall not be used in making a determination of the size of the required minimal lot size, or for setback purposes, as required and identified in each zoning district. Maintenance shall include, but not be limited to, mowing of grass, weed control, aerator repairs, and draw down structure maintenance. 
(6)  Wet detention systems: All wet detention systems shall be of orifice type, except when conditions show the wet detention system would not be viable and an alternative system is approved by the Saint Johns River Water Management District, a Florida Licensed Engineer, and the City of Rockledge. 
(Ord. No. 1039-92, § 1, 9-16-92; Ord. No. 1080-94, § 1, 7-6-94) 
SECTION 57.20. - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION REQUIRED 

57.21. - Definitions. 
    As used in this section: 
    Extra hazard occupancies are occupancies or portions of other occupancies where quantity and combustibility of contents is very high, [or] flammable liquids, dust, lint or other materials are present introducing the probability of rapidly developing fires with high rates of heat release. This class includes occupancies such as: 
Leather goods manufacturing 
Machine shops 
Metal working 
Cold storage warehouses 
Mercantiles 
Flour mills 
Paper and pulp mills 
Cotton picker and opening operations 
Plastics manufacturing and processing 
Feed mills 
    Life safety code means the life safety code promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association and which life safety code is by reference adopted as part of this Code of Ordinances. 
    Light hazard occupancies are those buildings where the quantity or combustibility of the contents is low, and fires with relatively low rates of heat release are expected. This class includes occupancies such as: 
Churches 
Clubs 
Educational 
Institutional 
Residential, other than single family dwellings 
Libraries, except large stack rooms 
Museums 
Offices, including data processing 
Restaurant seating areas 
Theaters and auditoriums, excluding stages and prosceniums 
    The requirements for the installation of automatic wet pipe sprinkler systems in light hazard occupancies shall apply to all light hazard portions of the occupancies listed above or similar light hazard occupancies. 
    Such requirements may also apply to small stores and similar occupancies incidental to the properties listed above; provided, that such occupancies do not individually exceed three thousand (3,000) square feet of floor area. Such occupancies which individually exceed three thousand (3,000) square feet of floor area shall apply the requirements for the installation of automatic wet pipe sprinkler systems. In other areas used for ordinary or extra hazard occupancy, the requirements for such areas shall apply. 
    Mixed occupancies are those buildings where a combination of one (1) or more of light hazard, ordinary, or extra hazard occupancies exist in the same building. 
    Ordinary hazard occupancies are: 
(1)  Group 1. Those buildings where combustibility is low, quantity of combustibles is moderate, stock piles of combustibles do not exceed eight (8) feet and fires with moderate rates of heat release are expected. This class includes occupancies such as: 
Automobile parking garages 
Bakeries 
Beverage manufacturing 
Canneries 
Electronic plants 
Glass and glass products manufacturing 
Laundries 
Dairy products manufacturing and processing 
(2)  Group 2. Those buildings where quantity and combustibility of contents is moderate, stock piles do not exceed twelve (12) feet, and fires with moderate rate of heat release are expected. This class includes occupancies such as: 
Manufacturing 
Cereal mills 
Chemical plants, ordinary 
Cold storage warehouses 
Confectionery products manufacturing 
Distilleries 
Textile manufacturing 
Leather goods manufacturing 
Libraries with large stack room areas 
Mercantiles 
Machine shops 
Metal working 
Printing and publishing 
Tobacco products manufacturing 
(3)  Group 3. Those buildings where quantity or combustibility of contents is high, and fires or high rate of heat release are expected. This class includes occupancies such as: 
Manufacturing 
Feed mills 
Paper and pulp mills 
Paper process plants 
Tire manufacturing 
Exhibition halls 
Piers and wharves 
Warehouses (having moderate to higher combustibility of contents, such as paper, household furniture, paint, general storage, whiskey, etc.) 
    Sprinkler system, for fire protection purposes, is an integrated system of underground and overhead piping designed in accordance with fire protection engineering standards. The installation includes a water supply, such as a gravity tank, fire pump, reservoir or pressure tank or connection by underground piping to a city main. The portion of the sprinkler system above ground is a network of specially sized or hydraulically designed piping installed in a building, structure or area, generally overhead, and to which sprinklers are connected into a systematic pattern. The system includes a controlling valve and a device for actuating an alarm when the system is in operation. The system is usually activated by heat from a fire and discharges water over the fire area. 
    Wet pipe sprinkler system means a system employing automatic sprinklers attached to a piping system containing water and connected to a water supply so that water discharges immediately from sprinklers opened by a fire. 
57.22. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1186-99, § 7, adopted July 21, 1999, repealed Section 57.22 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to light and ordinary hazard occupancies. See the Table of Amendments. 
57.23. - Extra hazard occupancies. 
    Those buildings classified as extra hazard occupancies as defined herein shall be fully protected with an automatic wet pipe sprinkler system, and alarm facilities connected to an approved monitoring company, regardless of height or type of construction of the building. 
(Ord. No. 1144-97, § 2, 8-20-97) 
57.24. - Nursing and convalescent homes and hospitals. 
    All buildings which are utilized as nursing or convalescent homes and all hospitals shall be equipped with an automatic wet pipe sprinkler system and alarm facilities regardless of height or type of construction of the building; except, in such instances where such buildings or hospitals are exempt from the requirements of this section by the state fire marshal or the accrediting agency. 
57.25. - Mixed occupancy. 
    Those buildings classified as mixed occupancy, as defined herein, shall meet the most stringent requirements throughout the building unless the occupancies shall be separated by a fireproof wall of a fire duration period satisfactory to the city fire chief. Such fireproof wall must be able to prevent the spread of flame or smoke from one (1) occupancy to another. 
57.26. - Manner of installing sprinkler systems. 
    Whenever the installation of a sprinkler system, and specifically the installation of a wet pipe sprinkler system, is required by the provisions of this section, such installation shall be done in compliance with the standards, requirements and specifications for the installation of a pipe sprinkler system as prescribed by Volume 6 of the National Fire Codes, 1994 Edition, also known as NFPA No. 13, 1994 Edition. Such standards for the installation of sprinkler systems are by reference adopted as part of this Code by Section 58 of this part. 
(Ord. No. 1144-97, § 3, 8-20-97) 
57.27. - Waivers. 
(a)  For the construction of new buildings, as well as additions or replacement construction as referred to in Section 57.28, the owner of the property, or his authorized agent, may apply to the city fire chief for a waiver of the requirements set forth hereinabove. Such waiver application for new construction shall be made prior to the issuance of a building permit by the city building official. Upon receiving the application for the waiver, the fire chief shall make a determination whether the installation of an automatic wet pipe sprinkler system is required, and, where applicable, whether the installation of alarm facilities is required to provide for safer evacuation of the structure in question. The criteria and standards for the determination of whether the installation of an automatic wet pipe sprinkler system is necessary to provide for the safer evacuation of the structure are those criteria adopted in Section 58.00 of this part. The decision of the fire chief on whether to grant or deny the waiver shall be in writing and shall state the specific reasons which justify the approval or denial of the waiver. Such decision in writing may have exhibits or drawings attached thereto if such exhibits are necessary to illustrate the basis for the decision. In the event a waiver is granted, no change planned shall be permitted without a thorough review of the waiver by the fire chief. 
(b)  The fire chief shall have twenty (20) days from the date the application for the waiver is filed to submit his written decision to the city clerk. The fire chief shall also submit his decision in writing within this twenty (20) day period to the applicant. 
(c)  In the event the fire chief shall disapprove or deny the application for a waiver, or in the event the applicant claims that the provisions of this section do not apply to his structure, or the applicant claims that the true intent and meaning of this section have been misconstrued or misinterpreted by the fire chief, the applicant may appeal such decision of the fire chief to the city council within thirty (30) days from the date the decision is filed with the city clerk. 
57.28. - Compliance when structure enlarged or reconstructed. 
    In the event a structural addition is made to an existing building or in the event such existing building is enlarged or expanded, the owner of such building shall comply with the requirements for the particular type of occupancy as set forth in this section for the addition, expansion or enlargement of the structure. In the event an existing building is destroyed or damaged by any cause, and such damage exceeds fifty (50) per cent of the fair market value of such existing building, then and in such event, the owner of such building shall comply with the requirements for the particular type of occupancy as set forth in this section for the rebuilt, repaired or replaced building. Fair market value for the purpose of this section shall be deemed the valuation of such structure by the county property appraiser in his assessment for the levying of ad valorem taxes for the tax year in which such damage was sustained. 
57.29. - Standpipe and hose systems. 
    All buildings which exceed thirty-six (36) feet in height or three (3) stories, whichever is least, shall be protected with an installed Class III standpipe and hose system as prescribed in standards for the installation of standpipe and hose systems by reference adopted as part of this Code by Section 58.00 of this part. 
    These requirements do not eliminate the provisions for portable fire extinguisher installation as prescribed in the standards adopted by reference as part of this Code by Section 58.00 of this part. 
    In case of mixed occupancies, the most stringent requirements shall be met throughout the building unless the occupancies shall be separated by a fire wall of a time duration satisfactory to the fire chief. Such fire wall must be able to prevent the spread of flame or smoke from one (1) type of occupancy to another. 
57.30. - Water supply. 
    Planning for adequate water supply will be based on the maximum fire load anticipated and shall be installed and operational prior to the start of major construction or the delivery of substantial amounts of combustible materials whichever event first occurs. Water delivery volume and rates shall be determined by the fire chief through utilization of recognized standards, primarily, the National Fire Codes. 
57.31. - Required access. 
    Adequate access to all areas of the construction site and finished facility shall be established in the initial planning and design of the structure. The basic requirements shall include the provision that a water source must be so located that no hose line will be required which will exceed three hundred fifty (350) feet in length. Adequate water supply sources shall not be located further than eight (8) feet from an improved and accessible surfaced roadway. 
57.32. - Alarm system. 
    Fire alarm systems shall be installed in accordance with the Life Safety Code in every apartment building, unless provided with automatic sprinkler protection in accordance with Section 6-4 of the Life Safety Code, or unless provided with automatic fire alarms in accordance with Section 6-3 of the Life Safety Code, if such apartment building is more than three (3) stories in height or more than twelve (12) apartment units. Such alarm systems shall be connected to an approved monitoring company. 
(Ord. No. 1144-97, § 4, 8-20-97) 
57.33. - Emergency lighting. 
    When emergency lighting is required it shall be installed in accordance with requirements of the Life Safety Code. 
(Ord. No. 1144-97, § 4, 8-20-97) 
57.34. - Flammable materials. 
    The use of construction materials which, by their nature, generate undue fire hazard will not be permitted. These materials shall include but are not limited to the following: Flammable fiberglass, flammable plastic and vinyl, interior or exterior finishes which have high flame spread characteristics, wood shakes or shingles or any other roofing material which is easily ignitable or encourages the spread of fire and any flammable decorative materials; provided, that wood shakes or shingles which have been chemically treated to be fire retardant may be used; provided, that the individual desiring to use such wood shakes or shingles shall provide test documents which verify that treatment has been used and that treatment will continue to be effective under the prolonged exposure to the coastal environment in the city. 
57.35. - Elevators. 
    Elevators shall not constitute a required means of exit. When structures are in excess of three (3) stories in height or exceed thirty-six (36) feet in height, whichever is least, and such structures are equipped with automatic elevators, one (1) or more of such elevators shall be designated and equipped for fire emergency use by fire fighters. The key operation shall transfer the elevator operation to a manual operation and bring the elevator to the ground or first floor for use by the fire service. Such emergency elevator shall be situated as to be readily accessible by the fire department. 
57.36. - Fire hydrant location in subdivisions. 
(a)  In all subdivisions with a public water supply, the applicant shall install sufficient fire hydrants in order that fire hydrants are spaced five hundred (500) feet apart (measured from fire hydrant to fire hydrant) or at the discretion of the fire chief. As a minimum standard, fire flows of at least one thousand (1,000) gallons per minute shall be provided in a single-family subdivision, at a residual pressure of not less than twenty (20) pounds per square inch. 
(b)  All standards and requirements of the American Insurance Association (National Board of Fire Underwriters) are hereby adopted. 
SECTION 57.40. - GARBAGE AND TRASH 

57.41. - Definitions. 
    As used in this section: 
(1)  Bundled garden trash means garden trash which is gathered into bundles and tied securely so that each bundle does not exceed four (4) feet in any dimension, weigh more than fifty (50) pounds overall, nor contain any single branch, limb, piece or item which exceeds four (4) inches in diameter. 
(2)  Construction debris means wood, stone, brick, cement, concrete, roofing and other refuse building materials usually left over from a construction, repair or remodeling project, excepting, however, debris from an original construction project. 
(3)  Containerized trash means refuse which is placed in disposable containers and including bundled garden trash, each unit of which shall not exceed three (3) feet in any dimension nor weigh in excess of fifty (50) pounds. 
(4)  Curbside means by the side of the curb of the public street or road upon which a parcel of property fronts, within a distance of five (5) feet from the traveled portion of such public street or road, and on such a location as to not obstruct pedestrian or vehicle passage on such street or road. 
(5)  Curbside placement means the placement of recyclable materials, garbage, bundled garden trash, and other authorized forms of rubbish and at the times, [and] as prescribed by the provisions of this section. 
(6)  Disposable trash containers means plastic bags and cardboard boxes which shall be nonreturnable and shall be collected and packed into the truck as is. 
(7)  Duplex residential unit means a dwelling unit in a building designed and constructed to be occupied as the separate residences of (2) single-families. 
(8)  Garbage means all vegetable and animal matter, food and other refuse from a kitchen, market, store or elsewhere, including all matter that decays, attracts flies or creates disagreeable odors. 
(9)  Hazardous waste means solid waste, or a combination of solid wastes, which, because of its quantity, concentration, or physical, chemical or infectious characteristics, may cause, or significantly contribute to, an increase in mortality or an increase in serious irreversible or incapacitating reversible illness or may pose a substantial present or potential hazard to human health or the environment when improperly transported, disposed of, stored, treated or otherwise managed. 
(10)  Miscellaneous refuse means small items of refuse which are incident to the ordinary conduct of the household, not included in the definitions of "garbage," "rubbish," or "trash" herein. 
(11)  Multiple residence complex means the building or buildings comprising a separate and identifiable multiple-family residential complex designed and constructed to be occupied as the separate residences of more than three (3) single-families, including but not in way of limitation, apartment houses, hotels, motels, townhouses, condominiums and cooperatives. 
(12)  Plastic bag means a polyethylene or other heavy-duty plastic bag with securing twist tie. An untied plastic bag shall not be an approved container. 
(13)  Recyclable materials means any material which can be recovered from the solid waste stream and reused in manufacturing, agriculture, power production or other processes and which include at a minimum the following: 
(a)  Newspapers (daily newspapers, no phone books, or magazines); 
(b)  Glass jars and bottles (clear, brown and green glass, food and beverage jars or bottles); 
(c)  Plastic bottles (milk, water and soft drink bottles); and 
(d)  Aluminum cans (soft drink and beer cans). 
(14)  Recycling container means a portable container or bin approved by the City, used for the storage, curbside placement and collection of recyclable materials, and identifying the recyclable materials at curbside. 
(15)  Recycling program means the program designated by the Rockledge City Council for meeting the solid waste reduction goals as mandated by the Solid Waste Management Act of 1988, Section 403.706 Florida Statutes, and any subsequent amendment thereto.
