(16)  Rubbish means tree limbs, tree trunks, tree stumps, bushes, boxes, planks, boards, old furniture, junk, scrap iron, tin and other articles of similar nature and large in size, excepting, however, materials discarded in the clearing of a heretofore uncleared lot. 
(17)  Single residential unit means any dwelling place occupied by one (1) family. 
(18)  Trash means yard clippings, grass cuttings, leaves and all other accumulations of similar nature and small in size. 
(19)  Triplex residential unit means a dwelling unit in a building designed and constructed to be occupied as the separate residences of three (3) single families. 
(20)  Wheeled container means an eighty (80) gallon plastic covered container permanently attached to a wheeled tubular steel cart designed for use by residential units for storage and curbside placement of garbage. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 1, 1-9-91) 
57.42. - Penalties. 
    Violation of any provision of this section shall constitute an offense against the city punishable upon conviction by fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisonment for a period not exceeding sixty (60) days or by both such fine and imprisonment, for each offense, and when a violation occurs in, on or upon private property in which the violator owns a proprietary interest the provisions of this section shall also be enforceable by proceedings before the Rockledge Code Enforcement Board or before the Rockledge Nuisance Abatement Board. 
57.43. - Accumulation prohibited. 
    An owner or occupant of property within the city shall not allow garbage, trash, debris, refuse or rubbish to accumulate thereon, which would likely become a breeding place for snakes, rats, flies, gnats, mosquitoes or other harmful or dangerous creatures or insects, or be likely to cause personal injury or property damage by human illness or fire, or which may become a hazard to traffic on the public highways and streets of the city, or to permit any accumulation thereon of garbage, trash, refuse, debris or rubbish except during periods between city pickups. 
57.44. - Commercial, residential, business and institutional property maintenance. 
    All owners, lessees, tenants or occupants of commercial, residential business or institutional establishments shall maintain their premises (property) in a clean and litter-free manner, including sidewalks, parking lots, grass strips and contiguous alleys, curbs or rights-of-way up to the pavement edge of any public street. No person shall sweep into or deposit in or on any street or on any sidewalk litter from any building or property. 
57.45. - Correction of violations of Sections 57.43 or 57.44. 
    Any owner or occupant of property who permits the same to become in the condition described in Sections 57.43 or 57.44 shall be proceeded against as for the maintenance of a nuisance as provided by this Code. 
57.46. - Offensive deposits. 
    No person shall deposit or cause to be deposited on any land, public square, street, alley, vacant lot or unoccupied lot, the waters of the Indian River, or any other watercourse or ditch within the city, any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish or other noxious, malodorous or offensive matter. 
57.47. - Permitting scattering from premises. 
    No person who shall own or occupy a premise or premises in the city shall permit garbage, trash, refuse, debris or rubbish to be scattered from such premise or premises into the public streets or alleys of the city. 
57.48. - Burying garbage prohibited. 
    No garbage shall be buried upon premises upon which such garbage was accumulated, or elsewhere, within the city. 
57.49. - Construction and demolition sites. 
(a)  Receptacles required. It shall be unlawful for any construction and/or demolition contractor to fail to provide bulk, detachable or other type containers on the construction or demolition site sufficient for the storage and collection of loose debris, paper, building material waste, scrap material and other trash produced by those working on the construction/demolition site. All such material shall be containerized. The number of containers required at the work site and the frequency of disposal shall be determined by the volume of refuse produced. 
(b)  Adjacent areas. Dirt, sand, construction materials or other debris cast upon any adjacent public or private property (nonconstruction site) as a result of construction or demolition activities shall be removed by the construction/demolition site contractor no later than the end of the workday of the incident or earlier if said material shall cause a public nuisance. 
57.50. - Litter from loads on vehicles. 
(a)  Proper vehicle loading. No vehicle shall be driven or moved on any roadway in the city unless the vehicle is so constructed or loaded as to prevent any of its load from dropping shifting, leaking, blowing or otherwise escaping therefrom, except that sand may be dropped only for the purpose of securing traction, or water or other substances may be sprinkled on the road surface for cleaning or maintenance purposes. 
(b)  Covering loads on vehicles. It is the duty of every owner and driver, jointly and severally, of any vehicle hauling upon any public road or highway in the city dirt, sand, gravel, silica, or other similar aggregate, or trash, garbage, debris, or yard trash, and tree branches to prevent such material from falling, blowing or in any way escaping from such vehicle. Covering and securing loads with a close-fitting tarpaulin or other appropriate cover of adequate size is required. 
(c)  Vehicular spillage. Any person operating a vehicle traveling on a public right-of-way from which vehicle any objects have fallen or escaped causing unsightly litter, potential obstruction to motorists or damage to vehicles shall immediately cause the public property to be cleaned of debris or litter or shall pay for any cleaning costs incurred by the city. 
57.51. - Prohibiting unauthorized deposits in containers of others. 
    No person shall place or deposit any garbage, trash, refuse, substance or material in any container, dumpster or other form of garbage or trash receptacle on the private property of another without the prior consent of the owner or party having lawful possession of the real property upon which the container, dumpster or receptacle is located. 
57.52. - Responsibility of city; private collection, disposal or transportation. 
    The city by and through its proper departments shall be responsible for the collection and disposal of all garbage, trash, refuse, recyclable materials, debris and rubbish within the city, and no person shall collect and dispose of or transport over the streets of the city any garbage, trash, refuse, recyclable materials, debris or rubbish without first obtaining a written permit from the city to do so. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 2, 1-9-91) 
57.53. - Enforcement of collection procedures. 
    The city manager or his designated representatives are assigned the responsibility for enforcement of waste collection and recycling program procedures enumerated herein. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 2, 1-9-91) 
57.54. - Time schedule for city collection. 
    The time schedule for the collection of garbage, trash, refuse, recyclable materials, debris and rubbish in various parts of the city shall be established by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 2, 1-9-91) 
57.55. - Wheeled container and recycling container required. 
    The city shall not collect or remove any garbage or recyclable materials from any single family dwelling, duplex unit or triplex unit unless such garbage is placed at curbside in a wheeled container, or unless such recyclable material is placed at curbside in a recycling container, as required by this section. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 2, 1-9-91) 
57.56. - Containers declared property of city. 
    All wheeled garbage containers and recycling containers furnished on accordance with this section shall at all times remain the property of the city. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 2, 1-9-91) 
57.57. - Fee for container. 
    No building permit for the construction of any new single family dwelling, duplex or triplex shall be issued unless the applicant therefor shall first pay to the city at the time of the filing of the application for such permit, in addition to any other fee or charge properly payable under the ordinances of the city, a fee computed at the rate of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per dwelling unit described in the application. Such fee shall entitle the applicant to delivery and right to use for garbage collection and recycling purposes only one (1) wheeled garbage container and one (1) recycling container at each dwelling unit described in the application. When the certificate of occupancy is issued for such new residential construction the city shall deliver one (1) wheeled container and one (1) recycling container to the premises of each dwelling unit for which the said sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) has been paid, said containers to be used only for the collection of garbage and recyclable materials at said premises. In the event a wheeled container and/or recycling container furnished by the city for use at any premises shall become lost, stolen, or unavailable for use due to any reason other than normal wear and tear, the occupant of such premises shall forthwith pay the city the sum of the replacement cost, plus a reasonable administrative fee for a new wheeled garbage container and/or recycling container to replace the one which has become lost, stolen or otherwise unavailable. If the occupant is not the owner of the premises and the occupant shall fail to pay the replacement cost plus a reasonable administrative fee for the replacement container, then the owner of such premises shall pay for the replacement container. No such replacement container shall be issued or delivered to any premises within the city until such replacement fee and reasonable administrative fee have been paid to the city. 
(Ord No. 989-91, § 2, 1-9-91) 
57.58. - Containers for commercial and professional establishments, multiple residence premises. 
(a)  The owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of each commercial and professional establishment with the city, and the owner, lessee, condominium or cooperative association or corporation, or other head of the management and operation of each multiple residence premises within the city, shall provide and maintain, without expense to the city, a refuse container as hereinafter described and shall cause all garbage, trash and other refuse of such commercial or professional establishment, and all garbage, trash and other refuse of the persons residing in such multiple residence premises, to be deposited in said refuse container. Said refuse container shall be maintained in a position and location designated by the city manager on the premises of each establishment and multiple residence premises so as to be readily accessible to the city's pickup truck and equipment. 
(1)  The refuse container shall be enclosed on three (3) sides by an opaque fence or wall six (6) feet in height, constructed, erected and maintained at the property owner's expense. The enclosure may be constructed of PVC, concrete or chain link with slats. 
(2)  Wood construction materials should not be used for the enclosure. 
(3)  The area within the enclosure shall be kept clean and free of litter and the lid(s) of the container shall be kept closed at all times. 
(b)  The refuse container to be provided and maintained as aforesaid by commercial and professional establishments having a volume and quantity of refuse which can be contained in one thirty-two (32) gallon container pending pickup by the city under the city's routine schedule of pickup service shall be a thirty-two (32) gallon galvanized metal garbage can with two (2) handles and a lid. 
(c)  The refuse container for all other commercial and professional establishments and all multiple residence complexes within the city shall be a Dempster Dumpster compatible with the city's pickup equipment, and of a size to be determined by the city manager. As criteria for determining the size of the Dempster Dumpster to be provided and maintained by a commercial or professional establishment or by a multiple residence complex, the city manager shall take into consideration the commercial or residential character of the premises involved; the volume of refuse-producing activities carried on or to be carried on at the premises; the city's past history and experience, if any, with refuse collection at the premises; the anticipated, projected or proposed refuse collection requirements for the premises; the city's policies, schedules and program for the pickup of refuse at the location of the premises; the recommendations of the owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of the commercial or professional establishment involved; the recommendations of the owner, lessee, condominium association, cooperative corporation or other head of the management and operation of the multiple residence complex involved; the recommendations of the head of the city's sanitation department; and any other facts material and pertinent to a fair and reasonable determination of the size of the Dempster Dumpster. 
(d)  The decision of the city manager, based upon the criteria herein set forth, shall be conclusive and final in any issue arising as to the adequacy of a thirty-two (32) gallon garbage can to contain the refuse of a particular commercial or professional establishment, or as to the necessity for a commercial or professional establishment to obtain a Dempster Dumpster, or as to the size of the Dempster Dumpster to be required in any instance. 
(e)  The city sanitation department may refuse to collect refuse from any commercial or professional establishment or multiple residence complex in the city which fails to provide and maintain a refuse container in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(f)  Commercial business or institutional establishments shall store their trash in containers so as to eliminate wind-driven debris and unsightly litter in and about their establishment. Approved methods of containerization include, but are not limited to, bulk containers. All containers must have lids or covers. Covers must be kept closed at all times. Spillage and overflow must be cleaned up immediately and shall be the responsibility of the owner or lessee of the premises. 
Editor's note- It should be noted that section 2 of Ord. No. 1275-2002 states that all properties affected by Section 57.58(a) shall be brought into compliance therewith by October 31, 2004, after which they shall be subject to code enforcement action. 
(Ord. No. 1275-2002, § 1, 7-3-02) 
57.59. - Containers to be clean, covered, in good repair. 
    No person shall fail or neglect to keep all containers required by this section clean and sanitary, tightly covered and in good repair. 
57.60. - Use of unauthorized containers. 
    No person shall use a container other than those herein defined as a receptacle for garbage, trash, refuse, or recyclable materials, except containerized trash bundles as herein defined. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 3, 1-9-91) 
57.61. - Interference with containers or waste placed for collection. 
    No person shall overhaul, molest or interfere with any container or the contents thereof, or adjacent containerized trash, set out for collection or for emptying or removal by the city, unless by permission of the superintendent of public works. 
57.62. - Manner of disposal for city collection. 
(a)  All recyclable materials as herein defined shall be separated from other garbage and placed in a recycling container at curbside at designated times for collection by the city. Recyclable materials shall be washed, free of liquids, and have the lids and caps removed from all items placed within the recycling container. 
(b)  All garbage other than recyclable materials shall be free of liquids, bagged separately from other trash, refuse and waste materials, and be deposited in a covered wheeled or other container approved by the city, and placed at curbside in accordance with the city's garbage collection schedule. 
(c)  Trash shall be placed and kept in a container provided for such purpose, which container shall always be kept covered. 
(d)  Trash in excess of the capacity of a wheeled container shall only be collected as "containerized trash" (as defined in Section 57.41) when placed adjacent to a wheeled container at curbside on regular collection days. 
(e)  Rubbish or debris shall not be placed or kept in a wheeled container, but shall instead be placed for collection as follows: 
(1)  Small items of rubbish and debris shall be placed at curbside in the form of containerized trash or bundled garden trash; and 
(2)  Items of rubbish and debris not susceptible of containerizing or bundling as herein defined shall be stacked at curbside. Trees and limbs shall not be over four (4) inches in diameter, and shall be cut in lengths not exceeding four (4) feet long. Tree stumps shall be cut up into sections not exceeding fifty (50) pounds in weight per section. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 4, 1-9-91) 
57.63. - Location of containers; placement, removal for collection. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the occupant of each single residential unit, duplex residential unit and triplex residential unit to place the wheeled container and recycling container provided by the city for the collection of refuse, on the assigned collection day, at front curbside location within a distance of five (5) feet from the travelled portion of the public street or road adjacent to such premises in such a manner as not to obstruct pedestrian or vehicular passage; except that the superintendent of public works may require the wheeled container or recycling container to be placed on any side of a property for reasons of topography or efficiency. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the occupant of each single residential unit, duplex residential and triplex residential unit to place the wheeled container or recycling container at appropriate curbside location prior to 7:00 a.m. on the morning of the scheduled arrival date of the sanitation truck. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the occupant of each single residential unit, duplex residential and triplex residential unit to remove the wheeled container or recycling container from curbside location to storage location, which storage location shall be nearer to the residential unit located on the premises than to any street abutting such premises; such removal shall be accomplished not later than 7:00 p.m. on the day the contents thereof are emptied and collected. 
(d)  Any person who is a full-time resident of a residential unit who is disabled to the extent that he is incapable of moving the wheeled container or recycling container and [who] because of such disability shall obtain a certificate of exemption from the city manager or the superintendent of public works, shall not be required to place the wheeled container or recycling container at curbside as required by the provisions of this section. This subsection shall not apply unless all of the persons in a residential unit capable of moving the wheeled container are disabled and obtain such exemption certificate. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 5, 1-9-91) 
57.64. - Repair of damaged containers; charge authorized. 
    The owner or occupant of every improved premises within the city which is furnished a wheeled container or recycling container by the city, shall be liable for any damage to the aforesaid container and shall be liable for the expense of repairs which shall be required other than normal wear and tear. Such repair shall be made by the city and billed to the occupant. If for any reason an occupant shall fail to pay such charges, then the owner of such improved premises shall be liable for the payment thereof. The charges shall be the actual cost of labor and materials. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 5, 1-9-91) 
57.65. - Notice, picking up of container when premises vacated. 
    The owner or occupant of a single residential unit, duplex residential unit or triplex residential unit within the city, who intends to vacate such residential unit and who has previously been issued a wheeled container, or recycling container, shall notify the city sanitation department of such intent prior to vacating such residential unit and the city sanitation department will pick up the wheeled container and recycling container and issue a receipt to such owner or occupant. 
(Ord. No. 989-91, § 5, 1-9-91) 
57.66. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1323-2003, § 1, adopted September 17, 2003, deleted § 57.66. Formerly, such section pertained to garbage collection fees and derived from Ord. No. 989-91, § 5, 1-9-91; Ord. No. 1029-92, § 1, 2-19-92; Ord. No. 1042-92, § 1, 12-2-92; Ord. No. 1251-2001, § 1, 9-5-01; Ord. No. 1281-2002, § 1, 8-21-02. See Section 9-18 of the Rockledge Code of Ordinances for new provisions. 
SECTION 57.70. - WASTE WATER TREATMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The provisions to implement Sections 57.70 through 57.79 is entitled the "Requirements and Standards for Direct and Indirect Discharges into the Wastewater Collection and Treatment System of the City of Rockledge." and is attached to Ordinance 1129-96 as an Exhibit "A". Ordinance 1129-96 and Exhibit "A" are on file and available for inspection in the Office of the City Clerk. 
Editor's note- Section 57.70 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. Provisions originally numbered as § 57.70 have been renumbered as § 57.70.1. 

57.70.1. - Septic tank required. 
    Unless connected with the municipal sewer system as required by this Code, every residence or place of business within the city shall be equipped with a septic tank and connections of a capacity and efficiency to safety dispose of all body excreta and refuse which may be deposited therein. 
Note- See the editor's note to the title of § 57.70. 
57.71. - Inspection of septic tanks: correction of defects. 
(a)  The building official shall inspect all septic tanks as often as necessary to ascertain the disposal efficiency, and in cases of defects therein or violations hereof, the official shall forthwith notify the owner or occupant in writing. 
(b)  Where the owner or occupant shall fail to comply with the written notice within a time to be specified therein, but not to exceed thirty (30) days, the official shall cause the defect or violation to be corrected and the cost shall constitute a lien on the property and shall be collected in the manner provided by law. 
57.72. - Sewer connection or septic tank required. 
    Every residence and building in which human beings reside, are employed or congregate, shall have a sanitary water closet that is connected with either the city sewer system or an approved type of septic tank. 
57.73. - Septic tanks to be approved type. 
    No septic tank other than those approved by the state department of health and rehabilitative services shall be constructed within the city. 
57.74. - Allowing improper disposal. 
    No person shall permit the disposal of any human excreta on any property leased or rented by him, or as the agent therefor, except as provided by this section. 
57.75. - Responsibility for maintenance of house sewer. 
    Every owner of the property shall be responsible for maintaining and keeping clean the sewer pipe leading and connecting from the plumbing system to the city sewers. 
57.76. - Discontinuing water for failure to maintain house sewer. 
(a)  Failure of the owner of any property to maintain and keep clean the pipe leading from the plumbing system to the city sewer shall give the city the right to cut off the water to the property. The water shall not be reconnected until the sewer pipe is cleaned and maintained properly. 
(b)  Where the owner of property has his own private water supply, the city shall have the right to cut off such water supply to the plumbing system, and the owner shall not reconnect the supply until the sewer pipe leading from the plumbing system to the city main has been maintained and cleaned and put into proper condition. 
57.77. - Obstructing sewers generally. 
    No person shall do any act or thing which may impair or obstruct the flow of any public sewer or clog up any appurtenance thereof, or place therein any substance, solid or liquid, other than the waste products for which the sewers are provided. 
57.78. - Harmful wastes prohibited. 
    No person shall make or maintain any connection with any public or private sewer or appurtenance thereof, whereby there may be conveyed into the same any suffocating, corrosive, inflammable or explosive liquids, gas vapor, substances or material. 
57.79. - Disposal of institutional, commercial and industrial wastes. 
(a)  Treatment of institutional, commercial and industrial wastes. The economy and desirability of the combined treatment of institutional, commercial and industrial wastes and sanitary sewage is recognized. However, not all types and quantities of industrial wastes can be so treated. Hence, it shall be the established policy to admit the types and quantities of institutional, commercial and industrial wastes that are not harmful or damaging to the structures, processes, or operation of the city sewage works. 
(b)  Prohibited wastes generally. No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any storm water, surface water, roof run-off, groundwater, swimming pool water, subsurface drainage, cooling water of any type, or institutional, industrial or commercial process water into any sanitary sewer. 
(c)  Enumeration of prohibited wastes. Except as otherwise provided by this sections, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following described wastes or waters to any sanitary or storm sewer: 
(1)  Water or liquid waste containing more than fifty (50) parts per million parts at any one (1) time or that exceeds a dial average of twenty-five (25) parts per million parts when sampled three (3) consecutive times within a twenty-four-hour period, of any grease or oil or any oily substance. 
(2)  Gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas. 
(3)  Waters containing a toxic or poisonous substance in sufficient quantity to interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a hazard to humans or animals or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant. 
(4)  Garbage that has not been properly shredded, which shall mean that the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food must be shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle size greater than one-half (1/2) inch in any dimension. 
(5)  Waters having a pH lower than 6.0 or higher than 8.5 and having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment or personnel of the sewage works. 
(6)  Waters or wastes containing toxic substances in quantities in excess of the limits prescribed by Section 17-3.091 of Chapter 17-3 of the Florida Administrative Code, measured at the point of discharge into the sewer system, or any substance that will pass through the sewage treatment plant and exceed applicable federal requirements. 
(7)  Waters or wastes containing suspended solids, BOD or COD of such character and quantity that unusual attention or expense is required to handle such material at the sewage treatment plant. 
(8)  Toxic radioactive isotopes. 
(9)  Noxious gases. 
(10)  Ashes, metals, cinders, rags, mud, straw, glass, feathers, tar, plastics, wood or other interfering or obstructing solids. 
(d)  Approval required for institutional, commercial and industrial wastes. In order to control the admission of institutional commercial and industrial wastes, the discharge into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having the following characteristics shall be subject to review, study and examination by the superintendent of waste water, in consequence of which the superintendent of waste water shall either approve, disapprove, or approve subject to prescribed conditions, the admission of such wastes: 
(1)  A five-day, twenty-degree centigrade BOD greater than two hundred (200) parts per million parts. 
(2)  A suspended solids content greater than two hundred (200) parts per million parts. 
(3)  COD greater than two hundred seventy-five (275) parts per million parts. 
(4)  A chlorine demand greater than fifteen (15) parts per million parts. 
(5)  An hourly flow rate greater than two (2) per cent of the average hourly flow rate of the treatment facility. 
(6)  Toxic substances, and wastes which are considered by the superintendent of waste water to offer possibilities of harm to structures, processes, or operations of the plant. 
(e)  When pretreatment required. Each user of the city sewer system shall provide at his expense such preliminary treatment or handling as may be necessary to modify the objectionable characteristics, or constituents, and to cause the same to come within the limits set forth in this section. 
(f)  Right of entry. The right to use the Rockledge Sewer System and enjoy the benefits and conveniences thereof is hereby declared to be a privilege, and not a matter of right. By connection to said sewer system and exercising the aforementioned privilege, each user of said system shall be deemed to thereby consent and grant approval to the Rockledge Superintendent of Waste Water, and his duly authorized representatives, to enter the private premises of such user for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in accordance with the provisions of this section. In all instances, other than emergencies (the decision of the superintendent of waste water as to what constitutes an emergency being conclusive), wherein an inspection, measurement, sampling or testing is to be performed by city employees upon the private premises of a user, the superintendent of waste water shall furnish such user written notice of the date and time of the scheduled entry upon the premises of such user not less than twenty-four (24) hours in advance of such scheduled entry, and any user who considers the date and time of such scheduled entry as stated in said notice to be unreasonable shall, not less than twelve (12) hours prior to the time of such scheduled entry, notify the superintendent of waste water in writing of an alternate date and time for the inspection, which alternate date and time shall not be more than forty-eight (48) hours after the user's receipt of the initial notice from the city. 
(g)  Violations. In the event the superintendent of waste water determines that any user of the Rockledge Sewer System is in violation of this section, said superintendent shall furnish such user written notice of the violation, the curative measures necessary to correct the violation, and the time within which such violation must be corrected. If any user shall fail to correct the violation in the manner and time prescribed by the superintendent of waste water, the city may, without further notice, discontinue and suspend sewer service to such user until such user has complied with the curative measures prescribed by the superintendent of waste water, and has paid to the city any costs, expense or damages sustained by the city in consequence of said user's failure to comply with the curative measures prescribed in the city's initial notice of violation. 
(h)  Control manhole. As a condition precedent to the restoration of sewer service to any user to whom service has been discontinued or suspended, the city, through its superintendent of waste water, may require such user to construct and maintain at his own expense a suitable control manhole, or manholes downstream from any treatment, storage or other approved works. to facilitate observations, measurement and sampling of all wastes, including domestic sewage from the premises. The control manhole or manholes shall be constructed at suitable and satisfactory locations and built in a manner approved by the city waste water treatment department and include a flow measuring device. The control manhole shall be accessible to the city at all times for sampling. 
(i)  [Grease interceptors.] Grease interceptors (grease traps) are not required for residences. However, one (1) or more grease interceptors are required on any premises where food is commercially prepared for sale, or where there is a commercial kitchen, including, but not in way of limitation, restaurants, churches, recreation halls, schools, convenience stores, hospitals, factories, nursing homes, public institutions, wholesale and retail food outlets. 
(1)  At any time additions or alterations are made to an existing establishment that is required to have a grease interceptor, and such addition or alteration will result in an increase of flow, or change of effluent characteristics, the grease interceptor at such establishment must at that time be modified and adjusted to meet all of the requirements of this section. 
(2)  Any change of ownership of an establishment that is required to have a grease interceptor shall require an inspection of the grease interceptor, which shall at that time be upgraded, if necessary, to meet the requirements of this section. 
(3)  All grease interceptor systems shall be located and installed so that, with proper maintenance, the system functions in a sanitary manner and does not create a sanitary nuisance or health hazard. Waste and effluent from any on-site grease interceptor system shall not be discharged onto the ground surface or into ditches, drainage structures, surface waters or aquifers. 
(4)  Grease interceptors must be located to provide easy access for routine inspection, cleaning and maintenance. Grease interceptors shall be cleaned at appropriate intervals to ensure that at least fifty (50) per cent of the grease retention capacity of the tank is maintained. 
(5)  Any person owning or controlling property upon which an on-site grease interceptor is installed shall be responsible for the maintenance of the grease interceptor system. 
(j)  Monitoring facilities. The city shall require monitoring facilities to be provided and operated at the user's own expense, to allow for inspection, sampling and flow measurement of the grease interceptor's discharge. 
(1)  Monitoring facilities shall be located on private property, ahead of connection to the city's sewer system and not more than twenty (20) feet from the grease interceptor, with no minimum distance limitation. 
(2)  There shall be eight (8) inches of freefall between the discharge from the grease interceptor to the monitoring facility and the monitoring facility's discharge for sample collection. 
(3)  The monitoring facility's discharge pipe shall be at the bottom of an invert, sloped to four (4) inches on the sides. The facility shall be a standard manhole-type structure, constructed in a manner approved by the city's waste water treatment department, with inspection covers and rings to road grade. 
(4)  Standard grade (0.4%) shall be maintained from the monitoring facility to the city's line. 
(k)  Construction of grease interceptor. The sizing of the grease interceptor is to be determined as follows, except that the minimum volume shall be one thousand (1,000) gallons plus fifteen (15) per cent freeboard: 
For restaurants: S × G × H/12 × LF 
Where: 
S = Number of seats in dining area. G = Gallons per seat (use 25). H = Hours of operation per day. LF = Loading factor. (Use 1.0 for recreation areas) (Use 0.8 for main highways) (Use 0.5 for other roads)  
For other establishments with commercial kitchens: M × G × LF 
Where: 
M = Number of meals prepared per day. G = Gallons per meal (Use 5). LF = Loading factor. (Use 1.0 with dishwashing) (Use 0.5 without dishwashing)  
(1)  There must be a minimum of one (1) baffle per grease interceptor, approximately centered, extending two (2) inches to four (4) inches above the water line and to within eight (8) inches to ten (10) inches of the bottom of the tank. 
(2)  The grease interceptor inlet and discharge pipes must be vented. The inlet pipe may be vented through the building's system. 
(3)  The grease interceptor's discharge device must extend below the water level approximately one-half the water depth. 
(4)  The grease interceptor shall be constructed in a manner approved by the city's waste water treatment department, with inspection covers and rings to road grade. 
57.80. - Responsibility for costs of extending or enlarging city system. 
    Each and every owner of property requesting an extension of the city's sewer collection system shall pay the cost of extending the sewer collection system to his property or the proportionate share of the cost of extending such system with adjacent property owners benefitted by such extension paying their proportionate share. If a major user is connected to an existing system causing the need for enlargement of the existing line, the new user shall pay the cost of such enlargement. The city council shall have the right to vary the aforementioned policy upon unusual circumstances. All extensions made shall be done in accordance with plans and specifications as required by the city manager or his designated representative. 
57.81. - Sewer connections required; exceptions. 
    The owner of each lot or parcel of land within the city, upon which any building or trailer is now situated or shall hereafter be situated, for either residential, commercial or industrial use, shall connect or cause such building or trailer to be connected with the public sewer system of the city, unless the same is already connected, and use the facilities of such system; provided, however, that no connection shall be required if the line of the city sewer collection system does not extend to the property line of the lot, parcel or tract of land upon which the building or trailer is located or is to be located. 
57.82. - Consent of city required. 
    No person shall connect the plumbing system of any property to the city sewer without the written consent of the city. 
57.83. - Specifications for making. 
    All connections to the sewer collection system of the city shall be of a permanent character and shall conform with the plans and specifications as required by the city manager and shall be under the direction of the city manager or his designated representative. 
57.84. - Supervision by city. 
    Every connection of a private plumbing system with the city sewer system shall be made only under the direction and supervision of the city. 
57.85. - Connection by city when owner fails to act; lien. 
(a)  If the owner of any lot or parcel of land within the city shall fail or refuse to connect with and use the facilities of the sewer system of the city after notification by the city clerk, the city shall make such connection, entering on or upon any such lot or parcel of land for the purpose thereof. 
(b)  The city shall recover the cost of making such connection, together with reasonable penalties and interest and attorney's fees, by suit in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(c)  In addition and as an alternative means of collecting the cost of making such connections, the city shall have a lien upon the lot or parcel of land for such cost, which lien shall be of equal dignity with any other lien except for state and county taxes. Such lien may be foreclosed by the city in the same manner provided by the Laws of Florida for the foreclosure of mortgages upon real estate. 
57.86. - Connection of old plumbing. 
    Whenever it is desirable to connect old plumbing with the city sewer main, the owner or plumber contemplating such work shall notify the plumbing inspector who will inspect the old plumbing and notify the owner or plumber what alterations will be necessary to place the facilities in an acceptable condition for connection with the sewer main. 
57.87. - Connections outside city. 
    After June 30, 1968, there shall be no further connections to the sewer system of the city outside the city limits, except as approved by city council. A petitioner requesting sewer hookup shall submit to the city one of the following: 
(1)  A legally binding agreement to annex property where sewer service is provided upon the time when such property becomes contiguous to the city; 
(2)  An interlocal agreement with another local government to provide sewer service to a specific service area; 
(3)  A legally binding agreement to provide sewer service to a specific property pursuant to an agreement between the property owner, another unit of government, and the City of Rockledge. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 16, 8-14-96) 
57.88. - Connection charges established. 
    Each and every owner, agent or party making connection with the city sewer system shall make such connection at his own expense after securing a permit from the city and paying the following sewer connection charge: See Part III. 
57.89. - Sewer connection distance. 
    All developed property within the city limits of Rockledge is required to be connected to the Rockledge Sanitary Sewer System. Property owners in areas which are more than one-quarter (1/4) mile from a force main or gravity sanitary sewer conveyance line and have proposed lot sizes larger than one-half (1/2) acre (twenty-one thousand, seven hundred eighty (21,780) s.f.) may apply to the department of environmental protection for a waiver from the mandatory sewer system connection. The application for waiver shall not occur without first obtaining comments from the planning commission and approval by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 17, 8-14-96) 
B. - BUILDING PERFORMANCE STANDARDS 
SECTION 58.00. - FIRE CODES AND STANDARDS 

58.01. - Life Safety Code adopted. 
    The 1994 Edition of the Life Safety Code, also known as NFPA No. 101, 1994 Edition, or Volume 5 of the National Fire Codes, promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference by the city as part of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 18, 8-14-96) 
58.02. - Standard Fire Prevention Code adopted. 
    The 1997 Edition of the Southern Standard Fire Prevention Code, promulgated by the Southern Building Code Congress International, Inc., is hereby adopted by reference by the city as part of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1048-93, § 1, 4-21-93; Ord. No. 1120-96, § 18, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1153-97, § 1, 12-17-97) 
58.03. - Conflicts between Standard Fire Prevention Code and Life Safety Code. 
    If any provision of the aforesaid Southern Standard Fire Prevention Code conflicts with the aforesaid Life Safety Code, the provisions of the Life Safety Code shall govern. 
58.04. - Standards for installation of sprinkler systems adopted. 
    The 1994 Edition of Standards for the Installation of Sprinkler Systems, also known as NFPA No. 13, 1994 Edition, or Volume 1 of the National Fire Codes, promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference by the city, as part of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 19, 8-14-96) 
58.05. - Standards for installation of standpipe and hose systems adopted. 
    The 1993 Edition of Standards for the Installation of Standpipe and Hose Systems, also known as NFPA No. 14, 1994 Edition, or Volume 1 of the National Fire Codes, promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference by the city, as part of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 19, 8-14-96) 
58.06. - Standards for installation of portable fire extinguishers adopted. 
    The 1994 Edition of Standards for the Installation of Portable Fire Extinguishers, also known as NFPA No. 10, 1994 Edition, or Volume 1 of the National Fire Codes, promulgated by the National Fire Protection Association, be and the same is hereby adopted by reference by the city as part of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 19, 8-14-96) 
58.07. - Conflicts between Code and adopted codes or standards. 
    If provisions of this Code conflict with the aforesaid Life Safety Code, Standard Fire Prevention Code, Standards for Installation of Sprinkler Systems, Standards for Installation of Standpipe and Hose Systems or Standards for Installation of Portable Fire Extinguishers, the provisions of this Code shall govern. 
58.08. - Certain provisions hereof inapplicable to existing buildings. 
    The provisions of Sections 58.11, 58.12, 58.13, 58.14, 58.17, 58.20, 58.21 and 58.23 [Sections 57.22, 57.23, 57.24, 57.25, 57.29, 57.32, 57.33 and 57.35] of this part shall not be enforced with respect to any building or structure which has been or is erected prior to January 8, 1975, on account of any noncompliance with the aforesaid sections existing on January 8, 1975; provided, that any fire protection devices and facilities required by the aforesaid sections which are actually incorporated in any building which has been or is erected prior to January 8, 1975, shall continue to be maintained in compliance with the provisions of this part; and provided further, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to prevent the enforcement of the aforesaid sections with respect to additions, expansions or enlargements of existing structures, or the rebuilding, replacement or repair thereof, as described in Section 57.28 of this part. 
58.09. - Violations. 
    Any violation of Section 57.20 or Section 58.00 shall constitute an offense against the city punishable upon conviction by fine or imprisonment, or both, not exceeding the maximum penalty prescribed by this Code. 
SECTION 58.10. - ADOPTED BUILDING CODES AND STANDARDS 

58.11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 1268-2002, § 5, adopted April 3, 2002, repealed § 58.11. Formerly, such section pertained to buildings and construction regulations. 
58.11.1. - All structures. 
    All structures constructed, altered, repaired, enlarged, moved or demolished shall be accomplished in accordance with the Standard Building Code, including Standard Plumbing Code, Standard Mechanical Code, Standard Housing Code and Standard Swimming Pool Code, as it may be subsequently amended, and the National Electric Code, as it may be subsequently amended. This section shall be administered by the Rockledge building and zoning official. 
Editor's note- At the direction of the city, former § 25-372 of the Code of Ordinances has been included herein as § 58.11.1. 
58.12. - Office of building official created; appointment, term. 
    The office of building official is hereby established. The building official shall be appointed by the city council at its first regular meeting after the annual election each year, and shall hold office until his successor is duly appointed and qualified. 
58.13. - Interference with building official. 
    No person shall hinder or interfere with the building official or any of his assistants or subordinates in the discharge of their duties. 
58.14. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by any decision of the building official in construing, interpreting or applying any of the terms and provisions of this part, or any of the terms and provisions of any code or codes adopted in this part, shall have the right to appeal such decision to the Building Code Board of Adjustments and Appeals established under the provisions of the Standard Building Code. The procedure in all such cases shall be the same as is provided by said Standard Building Code for appeals thereunder to said building code board of adjustments and appeals. 
58.15. - Building code adopted. 
    Adoption of the Building Code. The Florida Building Code, as published by the Florida Building Commission, shall be known as the Rockledge Building Code, as may hereafter be amended from time to time, and is hereby adopted by reference and is incorporated herein, as if fully set out. 
    The following appendix to the Florida Building Code is hereby adopted as Appendix A establishing exposure categories, wind speeds and wind borne debris areas for Rockledge. 
    Appendix A. The City of Rockledge is in a 125 mph, tree-second gust, Exposure Category B, and is considered a wind-borne debris region, pursuant to Section 1606 of the Florida Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 1014-91, § 1, 10-16-19; Ord. No. 1048-93, § 2, 4-21-93; Ord. No. 1120-96, § 20, 8-14-96; Ord. No. 1153-97, § 2, 12-17-97; Ord. No. 1269-2002, § 6, 4-3-02) 
58.16. - Definitions for code to conform to zoning definitions. 
    Any definition set forth in Chapter II of the standard Building Code of an abbreviation, term, phrase, word or derivative that is also defined in the Zoning Ordinance of the city is hereby amended to read the same as the definition of the same abbreviation, term, phrase, word or derivative appearing in the Zoning Ordinance of the city. 
58.17. - Amendments to building code. 
    The Florida Building Code adopted by reference as part of this Code is hereby amended, modified, changed and enlarged in the following respects: 
Administration 
    Section 101-General. 
    101.3.3 Permitting and inspection. The inspection or permitting of any building, system or plan by the jurisdiction under the requirements of this Code shall not be construed in any court as a warranty of the physical condition of such building, system or plan or their adequacy. Neither the jurisdiction nor any employee thereof shall be liable in tort for damages for any defect or hazardous or illegal condition or inadequacy in such building, system or plan, nor for any failure of any component of such, which may occur subsequent to such inspection or permitting, unless the employee or jurisdiction is found to have acted in bad faith or with malicious purpose in a manner exhibiting wanton and willful disregard of the safety, health and welfare of the public. 
    101.4.2 Building. 
    101.4.2.3.2 Unsafe buildings shall be abated using the Standard Unsafe Building Abatement Code, 1997 edition, promulgated by the Southern Building Code Congress International, Inc., subject to all amendments, modifications or deletions hereinafter contained. 
    101.4.13 Rules of Construction. The rules set out in this section shall be observed, unless such construction is inconsistent with the manifest intent of this chapter. The rules of construction and definitions set out here shall not be applied to any section of this chapter which contains any express provisions excluding such construction, or where the subject matter or content of such section would be inconsistent with this section. 
    104.4.13.2 Generally. All provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this division shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the administration of the jurisdiction may be fully carried out. Terms used in this division, unless otherwise specifically provided, shall have the meanings prescribed by the statutes of this state for the same terms. 
    101.4.13.2 Text. In case of any difference of meaning or implication between the text of this division and any figure, the text shall control. 
    101.4.13.2 Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the building official or some other officer or employee to do some act or perform some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the building official or other officer to designate, delegate and authorize professional level subordinates to perform the required act or duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
    101.4.13.4 Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    101.4.13.5 Shall, may. The word "shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive. The word "shall" takes precedence over "may". 
    101.4.13.6 Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures whether by printing or otherwise. 
    101.4.13.7 Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year, unless a fiscal year is indicated. 
    101.4.14 Words not defined. 
    101.4.14.1 Words not defined herein shall have the meaning stated in the Florida Statutes or other nationally recognized codes, or other documents, manuals or standards adopted elsewhere in this chapter. Words not defined in those documents shall have the meaning stated in the Webster's Ninth New Collegiate Dictionary, as revised. 
    101.4.14.2 In case of a conflict in definitions or codes, the appropriate definition (or code) to be applied shall be the one (1) applicable to the trade in question. In case of a conflict between different parts of this chapter; conflicts within the same code; or conflicts between code; the more stringent requirements shall be applicable. 
    101.4.15 Words Defined. 
    Abandon or abandonment. (1) Termination of a construction project by a contractor without just cause or proper notification to the owner including the reason for termination. (2) Failure of a contractor to perform work without just cause for ninety (90) days. (3) Failure to obtain an approved inspection within one hundred eighty (180) days from the previous approved inspection. 
    Appraised value. For the purpose of this section, appraised value is defined as either (1) one hundred and twenty (120) per cent of the assessed value of the structure as indicated by the County Property Appraiser's Office or (2) the value as indicated in a certified appraisal from a certified appraiser. 
    Assessed value. The value of real property and improvements thereon as established by the County Property Appraiser. 
    Authorized agent. A person specifically authorized by the holder of a certificate of competency to obtain permits in his stead. 
    Basic Wind Speed Line. The basic wind speed line for the jurisdiction shall be as established by the wind speed contour map attached to, and made part of, this chapter if applicable. 
    Board. The appropriate City or County Board of Adjustment and Appeals, unless otherwise specifically stated. 
    Building component. An element or assembly of elements integral to or part of a building. 
    Building shell. The structural components that completely enclose a building, including, but not limited to, the foundation, structural frame, floor slabs, exterior walls and roof system. 
    Building system. A functionally related group of elements, components and/or equipment, such as the electrical, plumbing and mechanical systems of a building. 
    Certification. The act or process of obtaining a certificate of competency from the state or municipality through the review of the applicant's experience and financial responsibility as well as successful passage of an examination. 
    Certificate of competency (certificate). An official document evidencing that a person is qualified to engage in the business of contracting, subcontracting or the work of a specific trade. 
    Certificate of experience. An official document evidencing that an applicant has satisfied the work experience requirements for a certificate of competency. 
    Certificate of occupancy (C.O.). An official document evidencing that a building satisfies the requirements of the jurisdiction for the occupancy of a building. 
    Certificate of contractor. Any contractor who possesses a certificate of competency issued by the Department of Professional Regulation of the State of Florida. 
    Change of occupancy. A change from one (1) Building Code occupancy classification or subclassification to another. 
    Commercial building. Any building, structure, improvement or accessory thereto, other than a one- or two-family dwelling. 
    Cumulative construction cost. The sum total of costs associated with any construction work done to a building or structure either at one (1) time or at different times within a specified period of time. 
    Demolition. The act of razing, dismantling or removal of a building or structure, or portion thereof, to the ground level. Examination. An exam prepared, proctored and graded by a recognized testing agency unless otherwise implied in context or specifically stated otherwise. 
    FCILB. The Florida Construction Industry Licensing Board. 
    Imminent Danger. Structurally unsound conditions of a structure or portion thereof that is likely to cause physical injury to a person entering the structure; or due to structurally unsound conditions, any portion of the structure is likely to fall, be carried by the wind, or otherwise detach or move, and in doing so cause physical injury or damage to a person on the property or to a person or property nearby; or the condition of the property is such that it harbors or is inhabited by pests, vermin, or organisms injurious to human health, the presence of which constitutes an immediate hazard to people in the vicinity. 
    Inspection warrant. A court order authorizing the official or his designee to perform an inspection of a particular property named in the warrant. 
    Intensification of use. An increase in capacity or number of units of a residential or commercial building. 
    Interior finish. The preparation of interior spaces of a commercial building for the first occupancy thereof. 
    Licensed contractor. A contractor certified by the State of Florida or the local jurisdiction who has satisfied all the state or local requirements to be actively engaged in contracting. 
    Market value. As defined in floodplain regulations of this Code. 
    Owner's agent. A person, firm or entity authorized in writing by the owner to act for or in place of the owner. 
    Permit. An official document authorizing performance of a specific activity regulated by this chapter. 
    Permit card or placard. A document issued by the jurisdiction evidencing the issuance of a permit and recording of inspections. 
    Qualifying agent, primary. A person who possesses the requisite skill, knowledge, experience and certificate of competency, and has the responsibility to supervise, direct, manage, and control the contracting activities of the business organization with which he is associated; who has the responsibility to supervise, direct, manage and control construction activities on a job for which he has obtained a permit; and whose technical and personal qualifications have been determined by investigation and examination and is evidenced by his possession of a certificate of competency. 
    Qualifying agent, secondary. A person who possesses the requisite skill, knowledge, experience and certificate of competency, and has the responsibility to supervise, direct, manage and control construction activities on a job for which he has obtained a permit, and whose technical and personal qualifications have been determined by investigation and examination and is evidenced by his possession of a certificate of competency. 
    Reciprocity. To accept a verified affidavit from any municipality or county of the State of Florida that the applicant has satisfactorily completed a written examination in its jurisdiction equal in content with the examination required by this chapter. 
    Registered contractor. A contractor who has registered with the Department of Professional Regulation of the State of Florida pursuant to fulfilling the competency requirements of the local jurisdiction. 
    Registration. The act or process of registering a locally obtained certificate of competency with the state, or the act or process of registering a state issued certificate of competency with the municipality. 
    Remodeling. Work which changes the original size, configuration or material of the components of a building. 
    Residential building. Any one- or two-family building or accessory. 
    Spa. Any constructed or prefabricated pool containing water jets. 
    Specialty contractor. A contractor whose services do not fall within the categories specified in Section 489.105(3), Florida Statutes, as amended. 
    Start of construction: 
    Site. The physical clearing of the site in preparation for foundation work including, but not limited to, site clearing, excavation, dewatering, pilings and soil testing activities. 
    Building. The removal, disassembly, repair, replacement, installation or assembly of the building, structure, building system or building components in whole or parts thereof. 
    Stop work order. An order by the building official, or his designee, which requires the immediate cessation of all work and work activities described in the order. 
    Structural component. Any part of a system, building or structure, load bearing or non-load bearing, which is integral to the structural integrity thereof, including but not limited to walls, partitions, columns, beams and girders. 
    Structural work or alteration. The installation or assembling of new structural components into a system, building or structure. Also, any change, repair or replacement of any existing structural component of a system, building or structure. 
    Substantial completion. Where the construction work has been sufficiently completed in accordance with the applicable city, state and federal codes, so that the owner can occupy or utilize the project for the use for which it is intended. 
    Value. Job cost. 
    Section 102 Building Department. 
    102.1 Establishment. There is hereby established a department to be called the Building Department and the person in charge shall be known as the Building Official. 
    102.2 Employee qualifications. 
    102.2.1 Building Official Qualifications. The Building Official shall be licensed as a Building Code Administrator by the State of Florida. The Building official shall be appointed or hired by the applicable governing authority and shall not be removed from office except for cause after full opportunity has been given to be heard on specific charges before such applicable governing authority. 
    102.2.3 Employee qualifications. The Building Official, with the approval of the applicable governing authority, may appoint or hire such number of officers, inspectors, plans examiners, assistant and other employees as shall be authorized from time to time. A person shall not be appointed or hired as inspector or plans examiner unless that person meets the qualifications for licensure as an inspector or plans examiner, in the appropriate trade as established by the State of Florida. 
    102.3 Restrictions on employees. An officer or employee connected with the department, except one whose only connection is as a member of the board established by this Code, shall not be financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material, or appliances for the construction, alteration, or maintenance of a building, structure, service, system or in the making of plans or of specifications thereof, within the jurisdiction of the department, unless he is the owner of such. This officer or employee shall not engage in any other work which is inconsistent with his duties or conflict with the interest of the department. 
    102.4 Records. The Building Official shall keep, or cause to be kept, a record of the business of all the department. The records of the department shall be open to public inspection. 
    102.5 Liability. Any officer or employee, or member of the Board of Adjustments and Appeals, charged with the enforcement of this Code, acting for the applicable governing authority in the discharge of his duties, shall not thereby render himself personally liable, and is hereby relieved from all personal liability, for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties. Any suit brought against any officer or employee or member because of such act performed by him in the enforcement of any provisions of this Code shall be defended by the department of law until the final termination of the proceedings, unless such person is found to have acted in bad faith or with malicious purpose or in a manner exhibiting wanton and willful disregard for the safety, health, and welfare of the public. 
    Section 103 Powers And Duties Of The Building Official. 
    103.1 General. The building official is hereby authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of this Code. The building official shall have the authority to render interpretations of this Code and adopt policies and procedures in order to clarify the application of its provisions. Such interpretations, policies and procedures shall be in compliance with the intent and purpose of this Code, and shall not have the effect of waiving requirements specifically provided for in this Code. 
    103.2 Right of entry. 
    103.2.1 Whenever necessary to make an inspection to enforce any of the provisions of this Code, or whenever the building official has reasonable cause to believe that there exists in any building or upon any premises any condition or code violation which makes such building, structure, premises, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing systems unsafe, dangerous or hazardous, the building official may enter such building, structure or premises at all reasonable times to inspect the same or to perform any duty imposed upon the building official by this Code. If such building or premises are occupied, he shall first present proper credentials and request entry. If such building, structure, or premises are unoccupied, he shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of such and request entry. If entry is refused, the building official shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
    103.2.2 When the building official shall have first obtained a proper inspection warrant or other remedy provided by law to secure entry, no owner or occupant or any other persons having charge, care or control of any building, structure, or premises shall fail or neglect, after proper request is made as herein provided, to promptly permit entry therein by the building official for the purpose of inspection and examination pursuant to this Code. 
    103.3 Stop work orders. Upon notice from the building official, work on any building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system that is being done contrary to the provisions of this Code or in a dangerous or unsafe manner, shall immediately cease. Such notice shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to his agent, or to the person doing the work, and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. Where an emergency exists, the building official shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping the work. 
    103.4 Revocation of permits. The building official is authorized to suspend or revoke a permit issued under the provisions of this Code wherever the permit is issued in error or on the basis of incorrect, inaccurate or incomplete information, or in violation of any ordinance or regulation or any provisions of this Code. 
    103.4.1 Misrepresentation of application. The building official may revoke a permit or approval, issued under the provisions of this Code, in case there has been any false statement or misrepresentation as to the material fact in the application or plans on which the permit or approval was based. 
    103.4.2 Violation of code provisions. The building official may revoke a permit upon determination by the building official that the construction, erection, alteration, repair, moving, demolition, installation or replacement of the building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing systems for which the permit was issued is in violation of, or not in conformity with, the provisions of this Code. 
    103.5 Unsafe building or systems. All buildings, structures, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing systems which are unsafe, unsanitary, or do not provide adequate egress, or which constitute a fire hazard, or are otherwise dangerous to human life, or which in relation to existing use, constitute a hazard to safety or health, are considered unsafe buildings or service systems. All such unsafe building, structures or service systems are hereby declared illegal and shall be abated by repair and rehabilitation or by demolition in accordance with the provisions of the Standard Unsafe Building Abatement Code or other local ordinance. 
    103.6 Requirements not covered by code. Any requirements necessary for the strength, stability or proper operation of an existing or proposed building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system, or for the public safety, health and general welfare, not specifically covered by this or the other technical codes, shall be determined by the building official. 
    Section 104 Permits. 
    104.1.6 Time limitations. Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, an application for a permit for any proposed work shall be deemed to have been abandoned and shall expire by limitation and become null and void 6 months after the date of filing for the permit, or plan approval, whichever is later unless before then a permit has been issued. One (1) or more extensions of time for periods of not more than 90 days each may be allowed by the building official for the application, provided the extension is requested in writing and justifiable cause is demonstrated. 
    104.2.1.2 Additional data. The building official shall be allowed to require details, computations, stress diagrams, and other data necessary to describe the construction or installation and the basis of calculations. 
    104.2.6 Hazardous occupancies. The building official may require the following: 
1.  General site plan. A general site plan drawn at a legible scale which shall include, but not be limited to, the location of all building, exterior storage facilities, permanent access ways, evacuation routes, parking lots, internal roads, chemical loading areas, equipment cleaning areas, storm and sanitary sewer accesses, emergency equipment and adjacent property uses. The exterior storage areas shall be identified with the hazard classes and the maximum quantities per hazard class of hazardous materials stored. 
2.  Building floor plan. A building floor plan drawn to a legible scale, which shall include, but not be limited to, all hazardous materials storage facilities within the building and shall indicate rooms, doorways, corridors, exits, fire rated assemblies with their hourly rating, location of liquid tight rooms, and evacuation routes. Each hazardous materials storage facility shall be identified on the plan with the hazard classes and quantity range per hazard class of the hazardous materials stored. 
    104.3.1.1 Minimum plan review criteria for buildings. 
Manufactured/mobile homes 
1.  Site requirements 
Setback/separation (assumed property lines) 
Location of septic tanks (if applicable) 
2.  Structural 
Wind zone 
Anchoring 
Blocking 
3.  Mechanical 
Exhaust systems 
Clothes dryer exhaust 
Kitchen equipment exhaust 
4.  Electrical 
Exterior disconnect location 
    104.5 Conditions of the permit. 
    104.5.1 Permit intent. A permit issued shall be construed to be a license to proceed with the work and not as authority to violate, cancel, alter or set aside any of the provisions of the technical codes, nor shall issuance of a permit prevent the building official from thereafter requiring a correction of errors in plans, construction, or violations of this Code. Every permit issued shall become invalid unless the work authorized by such permit is commenced within 6 months after its issuance, or if the work authorized by such permit is suspended or abandoned for a period of 6 months after the time the work is commenced. Failure to obtain an approved inspection within 180 days of the previous approved inspection shall constitute suspension or abandonment. One (1) or more extensions of time, for periods not more than 180 days each, may be allowed by the building official for the permit, provided the extension is requested in writing and justifiable cause is demonstrated prior to the expiration date. The building official shall record the extension of time granted. 
    104.5.1.5 Permits issued for the demolition of a structure shall expire sixty (60) days from the date of issuance. For a justifiable cause, one (1) extension of time for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days may be allowed. Such request shall be in writing to the building official. 
    104.6.2 Work commencing before permit issuance. Any person who commences any work on a building, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing system before obtaining the building official's approval or the necessary permits shall be subject to a penalty of 100 per cent of the usual permit fee in addition to the required permit fees or as provided by local ordinance. This provision shall not apply to emergency work when delay would clearly have placed life or property in imminent danger. But in all such cases the required permit(s) must be obtained within three (3) business days and any unreasonable delay in obtaining those permit(s) shall result in the charge of a double fee. The payment of a double fee shall not preclude or be deemed a substitute for prosecution for commencing work without first obtaining a permit. The building official may grant extensions of time or waive fees when justifiable cause has been demonstrated in writing. 
    104.6.5 Types of fees enumerated. Fees may be charged for but not limited to the following: 
Permits 
Plans examination 
Certificates of competency (including fees for applications, examinations, renewal, late renewal, and reciprocity) 
Re-inspections 
Administrative fees (including fees for investigative and legal costs incurred in the context of certain disciplinary cases heard by the board) 
Variance requests 
Administrative appeals 
Violations 
Other fees as established by local ordinance 
    104.6.5 Building permit valuation. If, in the opinion of the building official, the valuation of building, alteration, structure, electrical, gas, mechanical or plumbing systems appears to be underestimated on the application, permit shall be denied, unless the applicant can show detailed estimates to meet the approval of the building official. Permit valuations shall include total cost, such as electrical, gas, mechanical, plumbing equipment and other systems, including materials and labor. The permit valuation may be calculated using the latest Building Valuation Data published by the Southern Building Code Congress International or other applicable model code organization, at the option of the building official. 
    105.1 Existing building inspections. Before issuing a permit, the building official may examine or cause to be examined any building, electrical, gas, mechanical, or plumbing systems for which an application has been received for a permit to enlarge, alter, repair, move, demolish, install, or change the occupancy. He shall inspect all buildings, structures, electrical, gas, mechanical and plumbing systems, from time to time, during and upon completion of the work for which a permit was issued. He shall make a record of every such examination and inspection and of all violations of the technical code. 
    105.2 Manufacturers and fabricators. When deemed necessary by the building official, he shall make, or cause to be made, an inspection of materials or assemblies at the point of manufacture or fabrication. A record shall be made of every such examination and inspection and of all violations of the technical codes. 
    105.3 Inspection service. The building official may make, or cause to be made, the inspections required by 105. He or she may accept reports of department inspectors, independent inspectors or of recognized inspection services, provided that after investigation he/she is satisfied as to their licensure, qualifications and reliability. A certificate required by any provision of this Code shall not be based on such reports unless the same are recorded by the building code inspector or the architect or engineer performing building code inspections in a manner specified by the building official. The building official shall ensure that all persons making such inspections shall be certified in accordance to Chapter 468 Florida Statutes. 
    105.6 Building. 
    1.2 Slab Inspection. To be made after the reinforcement is in place, all concealed conduit, piping, ducts and vents are installed and the electrical, plumbing and mechanical work is complete. Slab shall not be poured until all required inspections have been made and passed. 
    A form board survey prepared and certified by a registered surveyor shall be required for all new construction prior to approval of the rough plumbing inspection. The survey shall certify placement of the building on the site, illustrate all surrounding setback dimensions and shall be available at the job site for review by the building inspector. This survey must be stamped APPROVED by the Rockledge Building Department before any further construction or inspection commences. 
    The form board survey MUST include the following information: 
1.  Permit number 
2.  Street address 
3.  Property boundaries 
4.  All easements and rights-of-way 
5.  Setbacks. (From the slab side of form boards, or outside of block in stemwall construction to the property line at the nearest point on the front, both sides and rear.) 
6.  Firm Zone. (Noted within footprint of structure) 
7.  Inches above crown of road. (Noted within footprint of structure) 
8.  Finish floor elevation of abutting structures (in residential construction only). Indicate "vacant" if abutting lot(s) are vacant. 
9.  Dated and sealed. 
10.  Center line, center lot reference point. 
11.  All submitted surveys shall meet the minimum technical standards set forth by the rules of the Department of Professional Regulation, Board of Land Surveys, Chapter 61G17. 
NOTES: For properties located within a Special Flood Hazard Area: 
1.  Show base flood elevation 
2.  Indicate N.G.V.D. elevation 
    4.0 Roofing inspection: To be made as two inspections on tile, slate or similar roof coverings or as one (1) inspection on all other roof coverings, and shall at a minimum include the following building components: 
Dry-in 
Insulation 
Roof coverings 
Flashing 
Site debris 
    105.11.1 The contractor and/or owner of any active or inactive construction project shall be responsible for the clean-up and removal of all construction debris or any other miscellaneous discarded articles prior to receiving final inspection approval. Construction job sites must be kept clean, such that accumulation of construction debris must not remain on the property for a period of time exceeding 14 days. 
    2. All debris shall be kept in such a manner as to prevent it from being spread by any means. 
    Section 106 Certificates. 
    Section 106.1.1.1. A new Section 106.1.1.1 is added to Section 106 and reads as follows:
