(c)  No building permit or certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any parcel or plat of land which was created after the effective date of and not in conformity with the provisions of these subdivision regulations, and no construction of any public or private improvements shall take place or be commenced except in conformity with the regulations. 
70.06. - Enactment. 
    In order that land may be subdivided in accordance with these purposes and policy, these subdivision regulations are hereby adopted. 
70.07. - Interpretation, conflict and severability. 
(a)  In their interpretation and application, the provisions of these regulations shall be held to be the minimum requirements for the promotion of the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(b)  These regulations are not intended to interfere with, abrogate or annul any other ordinance, rule or regulation, statute, or other provision of law. Where any provision of these regulations imposes restrictions different from those imposed by any other provision of these regulations or any other ordinance, rule or regulation, or other provision of law, whichever provision is more restrictive or imposes higher standards shall control. 
(c)  If any part or provision of these regulations or application thereof to any person or circumstances is adjudged invalid by any court of competent jurisdiction, such judgment shall be confined in its operation to the part, provision or application directly involved in all controversy in which such judgment shall have been rendered and shall not affect or impair the validity of the remainder of these regulations. 
70.08. - Savings clause. 
    Any applicant who has submitted a subdivision plan to the city council for approval prior to the adoption of this part may elect to proceed under the prior subdivision regulations of this part for the recording of such plat. If the applicant elects to proceed under the prior subdivision regulations, the applicant must serve written notice to the city council within sixty (60) days from the date of the adoption of this part. In the absence of such written notice, the applicant must comply with the provisions of this part. 
70.09. - Amendments. 
    For the purpose of providing the public health, safety and general welfare, the city council may, from time to time, amend the provisions imposed by these regulations. Public hearings on all proposed amendments shall be held by the city council in the manner prescribed by law. 
70.10. - Waiver. 
(a)  Generally. Where the city council finds that undue hardship or unreasonable practical difficulties may result from strict compliance with this part, the council may approve a waiver to the requirements of this part if the waiver serves the public interest. 
(b)  Conditions of waiver. An applicant seeking a waiver will submit a written request to the city council for the waiver stating the reasons for the waiver and the facts which support such waiver. The council shall not approve a waiver unless it determines as follows: 
(1)  The particular physical conditions, shape or topography of the specific property involved cause an undue hardship to the applicant if the strict letter of this part is carried out; 
(2)  The granting of the waiver will not be injurious to the other adjacent property; 
(3)  The conditions upon which a request for waiver are based are peculiar to the property for which the waiver is sought and are not generally applicable to other property and do not result from actions of the applicant; and, 
(4)  The waiver is consistent with the intent and purpose of the Rockledge Zoning Ordinance, the Rockledge Comprehensive Plan and the requirements of this part. 
70.11. - Resubdivision of land. 
(a)  Procedure for resubdivision. For any change in a map of an approved or recorded subdivision plat, if such a change affects any street layout shown on such a map, or an area reserved thereon for public use, or any lot line, or if it affects any map or plan legally reached prior to the adoption of any regulations controlling subdivisions, such parcel shall be approved by the council by the same procedures, rules and regulations as for a subdivision. 
(b)  Procedure for subdivisions where future resubdivision is indicated. Whenever a parcel of land is subdivided and the subdivision plan shows one or more lots containing more than one acre of land and there are indications that such lots will eventually be resubdivided into small building sites, the city council may require that such parcel of land allow for the future opening of streets and the ultimate extension of adjacent streets. Easements provided for the future opening and extension of such streets may be made a requirement of the plat. 
70.12. - Vacation of plats. 
    An applicant may apply for the vacation of any plat or any part of any plat at any time before the sale of any lot therein, by a written instrument, to which a copy of such plat shall be attached, requesting the same to be vacated. 
70.13. - Enforcement, violations and penalties. 
(a)  Generally. No owner, or agent of the owner, of any parcel of land located in a proposed subdivision shall transfer or sell any such parcel before a plat of such subdivision has been approved by the city council, in accordance with the provisions of these regulations, and filed with the clerk of the court of Brevard County, Florida. 
    No building permit shall be issued for the construction of any building or structure located on a lot or plat subdivided or sold in violation of the provisions of these regulations. 
(b)  Violations and penalties. The zoning official is hereby authorized and directed to take any action authorized by Chapter 63-177, Florida Statutes, 1974, and these regulations, to ensure compliance with or prevent violation of the provisions of this part. 
SECTION 70.20. - PROCEDURE FOR APPROVALS OF SUBDIVISIONScustom>[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Section 70.20 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. 

70.21. - Intent. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to submit a plat for the subdivision of land located in the City of Rockledge to the clerk of Brevard County or his representative for the purpose of recording such plat in the office of the clerk until said plat has been approved by the Rockledge City Council under the provisions of this part and signed by the city mayor. In the event an unapproved plat is recorded, it shall be stricken from the public records upon the adoption of an appropriate resolution by the council. No changes, erasures, modifications or revisions shall be made in any plat after approval by city council without the consent of the city council. 
70.22. - Plat review procedure overview. 
    There are three (3) stages of review for plat approval: The development plan review, the preliminary plat review, and the final plat approval. 
(a)  Development plan review. This stage allows the applicant to solicit comments from the city staff based on a concept delineation of the proposed subdivision. 
(b)  Preliminary plat review. This stage commences on the applicant making formal application for plat review by the city staff, planning commission and city council. 
(c)  Final plat approval. This third stage follows the preliminary plat approval and is the final stage necessary before recording a plat. After preliminary plat approval, the applicant may receive final plat approval by providing the city council security that the subdivision improvements shall be constructed in accordance with the approved plans for the plat. Construction of subdivision improvements may only begin after the final plat is approved by the city and recorded. 
70.23. - Development plan review. 
(a)  Intent. The purpose of the development plan is to provide for an initial review of the development proposal and the basic development concepts prior to proceeding with the detailed phases of the preliminary plat. The developer will provide a concise statement and description of the development proposal. The expenses for engineering studies, surveying, legal information and planning studies will not be necessitated at this stage. This step is to provide an opportunity for the applicant to avail himself of the advice and assistance of the city staff to facilitate the preparation and review of the preliminary and final plats. 
(b)  Consistency with other regulations. To ensure that the proposed subdivision is consistent with other regulations upon initial submission of the development plan, all applicants will complete to the extent possible, with the assistance of the city, the Rockledge Development Fact Sheet. The subdivision development plan application will first be checked for consistency with the Rockledge Comprehensive Plan by the zoning official; no subdivision application can proceed until it is consistent with the adopted plan. All subdivision applications will then be checked for consistency with the adopted zoning ordinance; no subdivision application can proceed until it is consistent with the adopted zoning ordinance. 
(c)  Required submittals. The development plan shall be drawn at a scale of one inch equals one hundred (100) feet and show: 
(1)  Location map: Drawn to scale, showing the relationship of the proposed subdividing to existing and proposed facilities as indicated in the Rockledge Comprehensive Plan and other applicable facility plans. 
(2)  Legend: Title, legal description, scale, north arrow, approximate acreage to be subdivided, current zoning, total number of lots, minimum lot size, name, address and telephone number of the owner and his representative(s). 
(3)  Existing streets: The name, location and right-of-way width of all existing streets which abut the proposed subdivision, and existing easements on the property. 
(4)  Proposed streets: The width of proposed street rights-of-way. 
(5)  Lots: Preliminary lot layout with approximate dimensions shown. 
(6)  Soil types: Soil information from the Brevard Soil Survey will be sufficient, and shall be available at Rockledge city offices. 
(7)  Topography: As delineated by the United States Geological Survey Maps will be adequate, and shall be available at Rockledge city offices. 
(8)  Other natural features: Including lakes, marshes or swamps, watercourses, floodprone areas, and other pertinent features. 
(9)  Utilities: Proposed source of potable water and sewage disposal. 
(10)  Required submittals: The applicant shall submit eight (8) of the required submittals to the zoning official at least ten (10) days prior to the development plan review conference. 
(d)  Review process. Upon submittal of required copies of the specified development plan submittal and the completed Rockledge Development Fact Sheet, the zoning official will contact the various officials and agencies that will be affected by the proposed subdivision to schedule the development plan review conference within seven (7) days of the submittal date. The zoning official will make his required review with respect to the comprehensive plan and zoning ordinance within this seven-day period. 
    The development plan will not be approved or denied at this stage. The zoning official will prepare a written statement advising the applicant on issues, problems or shortcomings that should be addressed in the preliminary plat submission and will transmit this statement to the applicant within two (2) weeks of the development plan review conference. 
(e)  Fees. There is no required fee associated with the preliminary development plan review and conceptual conference. 
(f)  Time limit on statement. The comments provided in the development plan review statement will automatically lapse if a preliminary plan is not submitted for the site within one hundred eighty (180) days of the date of the statement. 
70.24. - Preliminary plat review. 
(a)  Intent. The purpose of the preliminary plat is to permit complete and accurate presentation of technical data and preliminary engineering drawings in such a manner as to allow complete review and evaluation of the proposed development and its impact upon both the site and surrounding areas. 
(b)  Consistency with other regulations. A completed Rockledge Development Fact Sheet and current development plan review statement are required before the preliminary plats can be accepted for review. 
(c)  Required submittals: 
(1)  Generally. All applicants shall make application for formal plat review by furnishing to the subdivision inspector eight (8) copies of the preliminary plat of a proposed subdivision, together with a completed and up-to-date development fact sheet, a current development plan review statement and the specified information. Said preliminary plat shall be drawn at a uniform scale of not smaller than one inch equals one hundred (100) feet. In the event the subdivision exceeds one hundred (100) acres in area, the applicant may submit a preliminary plat at a uniform scale of not less than one inch equals two hundred (200) feet. Said preliminary plat shall be designed in conformity with the general design standards established in these regulations and shall contain the following information: 
(a)  Title block: The title or name of the proposed subdivision and the name and address of the owner of the tract proposed for development, and the name and address of the engineer and surveyor engaged to prepare and design the preliminary plat. 
(b)  Legend: Date, scale of plat, north arrow, current zoning, total number of lots, and minimum lot size. 
(c)  Legal description: A full and detailed legal description of the tract to be platted and its approximate acreage. 
(d)  Vicinity map: A vicinity map, at scale, showing the proposed subdivision in relation to the abutting land uses and streets. 
(e)  Streets: The location, name and right-of-way and pavement width, both on and immediately contiguous to the subdivision tract will be shown. 
(f)  Public open space and easements: Existing parklands, lakes and waterways within the tract to be subdivided shall be shown on the plat. The purpose for such easements shall be indicated. 
(g)  Parks and recreation dedication: Land to be dedicated for parks and recreation shall be shown and its approximate acreage indicated. 
(h)  Dedications and reservations: All parcels of land proposed to be dedicated or reserved for public use, such as roads, easements, parks, sidewalks, bike or pedestrian trails, shall be indicated on the plat. Proposed rights-of-way and street names shall be indicated. 
(i)  Lot lines and lot numbers: The proposed lot line with appropriate dimensions and lot numbers shall be shown. Lots shall be numbered in consecutive order, starting with the numeral one (1) for the first lot in each block. 
(j)  Topography: Contour intervals of one foot, except where determined to be unreasonable by the city's subdivision inspector. 
(k)  Proposed building setback lines: See Exhibit 5 of this part. 
(l)  Finished floor elevations. Finished floor elevations shall be shown on plans and follow uniform flow patterns with adjacent streets. Finished floor elevations shall be a minimum of eighteen (18) inches above the crown of the adjacent road or roads. 
(m)  Bench marks. Plans shall show bench marks used to determine construction elevations in subdivision. Plans shall include description and elevation of bench marks or temporary bench marks to be used on site. 
Cross reference- At the direction of the city, subsections (a) and (c) of former § 20-118 of the Code of Ordinances have been included herein as subsections 70.24(c)(1)(l) and (m). 
(2)  Engineering drawings. Preliminary engineering drawings shall be submitted in two (2) copies to the subdivision inspector and show the following: 
(a)  Water system lines and support facilities. 
(b)  Sewer system lines and support facilities. 
(c)  Storm water and drainage facilities, easements and other features. 
(d)  Bulkheads. 
(e)  Street profiles. 
(f)  Sidewalks, bicycle paths and pedestrian paths. 
(g)  Excavation and fill areas. 
(3)  Other submittals: 
(a)  Covenants: A draft copy of any proposed protective covenants or deed restrictions shall be submitted. 
(b)  Dredge and fill: If any dredging or filling operation is intended in development of the area, application shall be made to the Brevard County official responsible for dredging permits. No such work will be done prior to issuance of such permit. 
(c)  Erosion control: When erosion problems are anticipated, plans and specifications for temporary and/or permanent control measures shall be outlined. 
(d)  Additional data: Such other additional information shall be such data as necessary to show that the soil and topography is suitable for the uses proposed for the property in the subdivision. Information obtained from the Brevard County Soil and Water Conservation District may be submitted for this purpose. The applicant shall also furnish the city's subdivision inspector with written or graphic information about elevations for the proposed homesites using a one-hundred-year flood with a twenty-four-hour duration, and for roads a twenty-five-year flood with a twenty-four-hour duration. The applicant shall also furnish the city's subdivision inspector such additional information as may be necessary to provide reasonable assurances that the subdivision shall conform with the requirements of this section and other sections of this part and other applicable laws, ordinances and regulations. 
(d)  Review process (preliminary): 
(1)  Upon receipt of said preliminary development plans by the zoning official, one copy of the proposed plat shall, within five (5) days of receipt, be forwarded to each of the following: To all city department heads and associated city staff who will review the preliminary development plan prior to the preliminary review conference for conformity with the provisions of this part and other applicable ordinances, policies, laws and regulations, and shall forward written comments and recommendations pertaining to the development to the zoning official. 
(2)  The preliminary review conference will be scheduled within fourteen (14) working days to include the necessary city personnel, the city engineer, the applicant, and the engineer/surveyor engaged to prepare the development plan. Comments submitted by all city staff members shall be forwarded to the developer's engineer of record for necessary revisions/changes that must occur before final plan review can be granted. 
(3)  The preliminary plat and all comments will be referred to the planning commission for its review and recommendations. The proposed plat and comments will be made part of the planning commission agenda and appear in the site plan-subdivision section. Advertisements for the planning commission public hearing on said preliminary plat are to be prepared consistent with requirements of due public notice. 
(4)  The planning commission shall make a recommendation to the Rockledge City Council to approve the application, disapprove the application, or approve the application subject to specified changes based on a consideration of the requirements of this part and other applicable policies, ordinances, laws and regulations and the conditions which affect development within the vicinity of the tract. 
(5)  The city council shall consider the application at its earliest convenience and then take action after considering the recommendation of the planning commission. 
(e)  Fees. The city council will establish from time to time, by resolution, a fee schedule for amounts deemed necessary to reimburse the City of Rockledge for the costs incurred in reviewing preliminary plats. 
(Ord. No. 1268-2002, § 29, 4-3-02) 
70.25. - Final plat review. 
(a)  Intent. The purpose of the final plat is to ensure the preparation, completion and recording of a final plat map and its accompanying legal documentation and the review and approval of final technical submittal and engineering drawings. 
(b)  Consistency with other regulations. An approved preliminary subdivision plat is required before the final plat will be accepted for review. 
(c)  Required submittals. Eight (8) copies of the final plat shall be submitted for approval to the subdivision inspector and shall be designed in conformity with the design standards and requirements established in these regulations, and the requirements of Chapter 177, Florida Statutes, as amended, and shall be in conformity with the preliminary plat as approved. In addition, certifications and documents shall accompany the final plat as follows: 
(1)  Linen. The final plat shall be prepared in black drawing ink upon one or more linen sheets thirty (30) inches by twenty-four (24) inches in size. A three-inch margin shall be provided on the left edge of all sheets; all sheets shall be numbered and the number of sheets shall be indicated in each sheet below the title. Said final plat shall be in the same format as the preliminary plat as specified in section 70.24(c). Said final plat shall contain sufficient data to determine readily and locate accurately on the ground the location, bearing and length of every right-of-way line, lot line, easement boundary line, and block line, including the radii, arcs and central angles of all curves. 
(2)  Certificate of ownership. 
(3)  Construction plans and specifications. 
(4)  Security for performance of construction as provided in this part. 
(5)  Security for maintenance meeting the requirements of this part. 
(6)  Certification of the plat by a professional land surveyor registered in the State of Florida. 
(7)  The recommendation of the city's subdivision inspector for approval of said construction plans and specifications and said final plat based upon the requirements and provisions of this part. 
(8)  Dedication of public improvements. All public improvements or property designated for public purpose on any approved final plat, including, but not limited to, all streets, alleys, easements, rights-of-way, parks and public areas, shall be expressly dedicated on the face of the final plat by the owner as indicated on the certificate of ownership. In addition, said final plat shall contain a statement of dedication to the City of Rockledge, other appropriate government units or public utilities for all water lines, sewer lines and pumping stations and appurtenances located within the tract prior to recording. 
(d)  Review process (final): 
(1)  The final plat shall be submitted to the city with documents specified in this Code at least ten (10) days prior to the meeting of the final approval conference, at which time the final plat is to be submitted for review and recommendation. Upon receipt of said information, the subdivision inspector will schedule a meeting for final review conference, and said meeting shall include the necessary city personnel: The city engineer, the applicant, and the engineer/surveyor engaged to prepare the necessary drawings. Minutes of the conference will be the reference for necessary changes or revisions before final plat approval is granted. 
(2)  Upon receipt of the minutes of the final review conference, the city will schedule the subdivision on the next agenda of the Rockledge City Council. The council shall either approve, disapprove or approve subject to specified conditions said final plat for recording based upon compliance with the required certifications and security requirements, and with the other requirements and provisions of this part and other applicable policies, ordinances, laws and regulations. Upon approval by the city council, said final plat shall be signed by the mayor of the City of Rockledge and entitled to be recorded by the clerk of the Brevard County Court under the applicable provisions of Chapter 177, Florida Statutes. Under no circumstances will the subdivision inspector schedule the subdivision on the agenda of the city council until such time as all required documents have been received. Approval of said final plat shall be deemed acceptance by the city of said proposed public improvements, water lines, sewer lines, pumping stations, appurtenances, streets, alleys, easements, rights-of-way, parks, recreational areas, ponding areas, water recharge areas, canals, drainage facilities, and other public areas dedicated to the City of Rockledge. The acceptance of dedications for public purposes shall be affixed to the face of the plat. 
(e)  Fees. The city council shall establish, from time to time, by resolution, a fee schedule for amounts deemed necessary to reimburse the City of Rockledge for costs incurred in reviewing final plats and to defray the cost for recording plat, copies of plat and travel expenses. 
70.26. - Time allowed for completion of procedures preliminary to final plat approval. 
    All procedures, steps and requirements preliminary to final plat approval, as determined from when the city council approves the preliminary plat to final plat approval by the city council shall be completed by the developer within a period of not more than one hundred eighty (180) days; the city manager may, at his discretion, provide additional extensions in sixty (60) day increments for documented delays. If the platting procedures preliminary to final plat approval are not completed within the time prescribed by this section, including extensions for documented delays, no further action will be taken by the city toward approval of the proposed plat for a period of ninety (90) days after expiration of the time herein prescribed for completion of the platting procedures. If, after the expiration of said ninety-day waiting period, the developer still seeks approval of the same or a substantially similar plat, he must recommence the prescribed platting procedures from the beginning as a newly proposed plat. 
(Ord. No. 1278-2002, § 1, 7-17-02) 
70.27. - Construction plans and specifications. 
(a)  Intent. An applicant shall obtain permission of the city before commencing construction of subdivision improvements. After approval of the final plat by the city council, and the construction plans and specifications have been approved by the subdivision inspector, an applicant may begin construction under the following procedures: 
(1)  Construction after final plat approval: The applicant may submit construction plans and specifications as required in this part for subdivision improvements after the final plat is approved if performance bonds or other assurances are secured. The plans and specifications shall provide security required for the performance of such construction. Once the improvements are completed, a certificate of completion will be issued, and a maintenance bond will be submitted. 
(b)  Required submittal. The applicant requesting a permit under the procedures in paragraph (a) hereof shall furnish to the city's subdivision inspector the construction plans and specifications designed in accordance with the requirements of these regulations for the construction of the roads, sidewalks, bikeways, drainage and water management facilities, utilities, lot filling and other improvements as required by this part, including a master drainage map and subsoil investigation report. All construction plans and specifications must be designed, signed and sealed by a professional engineer who is registered in the State of Florida. The city's subdivision inspector shall review plans and specifications for conformity with the design of the final plat and the construction specification requirements of these regulations and any other applicable policy, ordinance, law or regulation. 
    If a subdivision is to be furnished public water by a municipality or Brevard County, the applicant shall provide the city's subdivision inspector with written confirmation that the municipal or county utilities department has approved the plans and specifications for the water system in the subdivision. 
SECTION 70.40. - REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS WITHIN A SUBDIVISION 

70.41. - Generally. 
    Each subdivision shall contain improvements designed and constructed according to the requirements and specifications of these regulations and the applicable policies, regulations and ordinances of the City of Rockledge and the laws of the State of Florida. The following services and facilities are required improvements within subdivisions (see Part V): 
(1)  Streets paved, designed and constructed for public use according the standards and requirements of this Code. 
(2)  Sidewalks designed and constructed for public use according to the standards and requirements of this Code. 
(3)  Drainage and water management facilities designed and constructed according to the standards and requirements of this Code. The term "drainage," where appropriate, shall include, but not be limited to, swales, ditches, storm sewers, seepage basins, culverts, sidedrains, retention or detention basis, crossdrains and canals. 
(4)  A sanitary sewage system or individual sewage disposal system is permitted in the absence of access to a gravity sewage system (three hundred (300) feet distance). The requirements and rules and regulations of the Florida DER, covering the sanitary facilities for subdivisions, shall be considered with the minimum requirements of the City of Rockledge. 
(5)  A water system, unless an individual water supply is permitted within the tract, based upon the required standards of the Florida DER, the provisions of this Code and other applicable policies, laws, ordinances and regulations. 
(6)  Approved street signs and markers and traffic signs and signals shall be provided to control and circulate traffic within the street pattern within the subdivision in accordance with the Florida Uniform Manual of Traffic Control Devices, published by the Florida Department of Transportation. 
(7)  All utilities are to be constructed underground. 
(8)  Such other improvements as deemed necessary to comply with the requirements of this Code and to protect the public health, safety and welfare because of topography or other problems of the tract. 
(9)  Green space as may be required by ordinance. 
Section 70.42. - [Design standards.] 
(a)  Use of natural features. The arrangement of lots and blocks and the street system shall make the most advantageous use of topography and preserve mature trees and other natural features wherever possible. 
(b)  Consideration of soil and flood hazards. A subdivision plan shall not be approved unless all land intended for use as building sites can be used safely for building purposes without danger from flood or other inundation or from adverse soil or foundation conditions or from any other menace to health, safety or public welfare. In particular, lands which are within the one-hundred-year flood-prone areas, as determined by the USGS or other reliable agency, shall not be subdivided and developed until proper provisions are made for protective flood-control measures and water management facilities necessary for flood-free development and flood-free vehicular access to such sites. No filling or grade level changes will be permitted which will alter the natural drainage or adversely affect other areas downstream through added runoff or adverse water quality. Guidelines for development within the one-hundred-year floodplain are contained in the flood damage prevention ordinance, Ordinance No. 510-79, of these regulations. 
(c)  Special consideration. Special consideration shall be given in the layout of streets, lots, blocks, buildings and easements to the preservation of large and specimen individual trees. Special consideration shall also be given to preserving natural drainage methods and natural topography and landscape. Special consideration shall be given to providing special screening, buffers or berms where developments abut noncompatible land uses. 
Editor's note- At the direction of the city, subsections (B)-(D) of former § 20-111 of the Code of Ordinances have been included herein as Section 70.42. 
Section 70.45. - Low density subdivision. 
    The purpose of this section is to permit the development of subdivisions of large lots and low density areas that, due to street design, drainage requirements, location and topography, justify the construction of streets, without sidewalks or bikeways. Such subdivision will maximize percolation in drainage swales. These subdivisions are intended to be located within areas of the city where low density development will be consistent with future development patterns expressed in the Rockledge Comprehensive Plan. In any subdivision where all the lots are one acre or greater, no sidewalks or bikeways shall be required and local roadways shall have a minimum pavement width of twenty-four (24) feet with a sixty-six (66) foot right-of-way if adequate drainage facilities can be located within the right-of-way. Underground utilities shall still be required. 
Section 70.50. - Planned unit development. 
    The development of a subdivision as a planned unit development under the zoning regulations shall be in conformity with said zoning regulations and the final development plan for a planned unit development. The city council shall have the right to waive or vary the design, dedication and construction requirements of such a planned unit development from any of the provisions of these regulations if the proposed final development plan is in conformity with the requirement of said zoning regulations for a planned unit development and provided that: 
(1)  Such waiver does not violate the purpose and intent of any requirement of these regulations for the protection of the public health, safety and welfare in the subdivision of land. 
(2)  All procedures specified in this part for the approval of a final plat for recording or the issuance of a certificate of completion as the case may be, are strictly adhered to. 
(3)  All exhibits, certificates and information required in this part for the approval of a preliminary and final plat and the issuance of a certificate of completion are strictly adhered to under the applicable specified procedure. 
SECTION 70.60. - ASSURANCE FOR COMPLETION AND MAINTENANCE OF IMPROVEMENTScustom>[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 70.60 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. 

70.61. - Generally. 
    Construction of required improvements may commence after recording the final plat if performance bonds or other assurances are secured. 
70.62. - Performance security. 
(A)  Generally. Construction shall not commence until after recording the final plat. An applicant shall be required to secure its performance of the construction required under these regulations by a performance bond, letter of credit, savings account or cash. Where security is required, the applicant shall deliver an estimate certified by a professional engineer for the complete construction of all improvements in compliance with the approved construction plans and specifications, design of the final plat, and the requirements of these regulations. 
(B)  Nature of security. The applicant shall deliver security in the amount of one hundred ten (110) per cent of the estimated construction costs of the improvements that such improvements will be built according to the final plat, and the requirements of these regulations, within one hundred twenty (120) days from the date of recordation of the plat; provided, however, the city manager may, in his discretion, extend the due date for the completion of such construction an additional one hundred twenty (120) days for documented delays. The applicant will file security in the amount of fifty (50) per cent paving and drainage, and fifty (50) per cent of all other improvements, of the engineer's estimated cost of the initial security for maintenance of the improvements on completion. The applicant shall provide the city security as follows: (see section 70.63). 
(1)  The applicant shall deliver to the city a good and sufficient performance bond guaranteeing the construction of the subdivision improvements and that such improvements shall be free from defects in materials and workmanship. All bonds required by this section shall be issued from a company licensed as a surety in the State of Florida. The form of the bond submitted under this section shall be approved by the council and shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(2)  The applicant shall deliver to the city a good and sufficient letter of credit issued by a banking institution located in Brevard County in accordance with Exhibit 1 of this part that such improvements shall be free from defects in materials and workmanship. 
A letter of credit shall be accepted as security where the total cost of the subdivision improvements does not exceed five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). The applicant shall execute a performance agreement with the council and the bank or financial institution when a letter of credit, certificate of deposit or savings account is furnished as security. Any bond or letter of credit furnished the council shall contain an agreement that the surety or financial institution shall pay the council costs, including reasonable attorney's fees, if the council finds it necessary to commence legal action on the security. 
(3)  The applicant shall establish a savings account or provide a certificate of deposit in a bank or savings and loan institution in Brevard County. The savings account or certificate of deposit shall specify that payment to the City of Rockledge shall be made on the written demand of the city to the bank or institution and notice to the applicant that subdivision improvements have not been completed as required or that such improvements are not free from defects in materials or workmanship. 
(4)  In lieu of a surety on the payment and performance bond or on the maintenance bond herein required, and as an alternative to the payment and performance contract described in applicable sections of this Code, the developer may, subject to the terms and conditions herein set forth, secure such payment, performance or maintenance by an irrevocable letter of credit, certificate of deposit, savings account, or cash, delivered to the city contemporaneous with the execution and delivery of a written bond, assignment, security agreement, or escrow agreement in form and content acceptable to the city; provided, however, that only one of such forms of security will be accepted to secure a developer's entire construction and payment obligation, or maintenance obligation, with respect to any one development. Said bond, assignment, security agreement or escrow agreement shall by its terms expressly acknowledge and describe the developer's performance, payment or maintenance obligations, as the case may be, and provide that in the event of any breach or default by the developer in any of such obligations, as determined solely by the city, the city may obtain immediate and exclusive possession of the funds represented by the aforesaid security for the purpose of completing performance of the obligations of the developer. 
The following terms and conditions shall apply to the different forms of security as indicated below: 
(a)  Surety bonds. All terms and conditions prescribed in this section of the Rockledge Code, and in addition thereto, the bond shall contain an agreement that the principal and surety therein agree to pay the city all court costs and reasonable attorney's fees incurred by the city if the city commences legal action to enforce the terms of the bond. Any bond shall be issued by a company licensed as a surety in the State of Florida, listed by the U.S. Treasury Department, and rated AAAAA in Best Insurance Guide. The form of the bond submitted under this section shall be approved by the city and shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(b)  Irrevocable letters of credit. Such will be accepted as security only if issued by a bank located in Brevard County, Florida, and if the face amount of any such letter of credit is not more than five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00). The developer shall execute a written agreement with the city authorizing the city to draw upon the letter of credit if the developer fails to fully and timely complete the performance, payment or maintenance obligations undertaken by the developer. Only one letter of credit shall be accepted as security for a developer's construction obligation, or maintenance obligation, with respect to a subdivision or development, and multiple, combined, partial or successive letters of credit to secure the construction of a single subdivision, or the maintenance thereof, will not be accepted. Letters of credit shall be in form and content substantially as set out in Exhibit 1 of this part. 
(c)  Certificates of deposit and savings accounts. Such shall be in account with a bank or savings and loan institution located in Brevard County, Florida. Said certificate or account shall be assigned by the owner to the city, or in blank, at the election of the city, and shall be delivered to the city contemporaneous with the execution and delivery to the city of a written performance, payment or maintenance agreement, as the case may be in, in form and content acceptable to the city, together with a written escrow agreement, collateral pledge or security agreement providing that in the event of any default in the developer's performance, payment or maintenance obligations, the city may negotiate the certificate or draw upon the savings account and utilize the funds therefrom to complete the obligations of the developer. The agreement shall contain a provision that the developer will pay all of the city's court costs and reasonable attorney's fees in any litigation arising out of any of said agreements of the developer. 
(5)  Payment and performance contract, alternate procedure. In instances wherein strict compliance with the requirements of applicable sections of this part of this Code will impose an undue financial hardship and burden upon the developer, the developer may apply to the city council for approval of a written payment and performance contract to be executed by the developer and lending institution and the city, which contract shall provide substantially as follows: 
(a)  That the developer warrants that it will timely construct, complete and pay for the improvements and utilities in accordance with the agreement referred to in applicable sections of this part of this Code. 
(b)  That the developer will be liable to the city for all costs of completing said improvements, including, but not limited to, engineering, legal and other costs which the city may sustain on account of the developer's default in completion of said improvements. In the event the city is required to commence legal proceedings for the collection of any monies which the city is entitled to receive under the terms of said payment and performance contract, interest shall accrue at the rate of eight (8) per cent per annum on the sums due the city beginning with the commencement of such legal proceedings. In the event the city commences suit for the collection of any such sums of money, the developer agrees to pay all costs incurred by the city, including reasonable attorney's fees. 
(c)  That the lending institution agrees to the following: 
1.  To loan the developer sufficient money to complete said improvements, and to disburse the proceeds of said loan pursuant to a loan agreement approved by the city. 
2.  To withhold ten (10) per cent of each construction draw and requested payment until all improvements are completed and finally approved in writing by the city. 
3.  To make no loan disbursement on said account without the prior written approval of the city. 
4.  To make no loan disbursement until after the developer has furnished to the lending institution partial releases of lien properly executed by the persons to whom the monies to be disbursed are intended to be paid, in an amount equal to the disbursement requested, and a certified statement or bill of the particular contractor or subcontractor to whom the monies disbursed are due. 
5.  To make no loan disbursement on said account without first being furnished by the developer's consulting engineer with a certificate evidencing: 
a.  That the work has been done; 
b.  That the particular contractor or subcontractor is entitled to the said progress payment as billed; 
c.  That the city has inspected and approved and accepted that portion of the work; 
d.  That a ten (10) per cent holdback has been deducted; 
e.  That the undisbursed portion of the mortgage loan for improvements will be sufficient to pay in full all unpaid bills for work done and materials supplied in the construction and installation of the improvements, and the cost of all work and materials remaining to be done and supplied to fully complete the improvements. 
6.  To refrain from disbursing the cumulative ten (10) per cent holdback until all improvements have been completed and all work and materials incorporated therein have been fully paid for, completion of the work to be established [by]: 
a.  A certificate of the developer's consulting engineer to said effect; 
b.  The contractor's affidavit conforming to the requirements of the Florida Mechanic's Lien Law; 
c.  Full and complete releases of liens from each and every party who performed any work or supplied any materials in the construction and installation of the improvements or upon the lands involved in the development; 
d.  The acceptance in writing of the improvements by the City of Rockledge; 
e.  The acceptance and approval by the city in writing of a maintenance bond in accordance with applicable city ordinances; and, 
f.  Such other documents and papers as may be required by the city to satisfy itself that the improvements have been properly and fully completed and paid for, and that no person has any right or claim of lien upon said land for any work done. 
7.  If the developer shall fail to complete the improvements contemplated within the agreed time, and the lending institution does not elect in writing to complete said improvements within fifteen (15) days of request to complete same by the city, then and in that event, the lending institution will upon demand therefor in writing by the city disburse to the city in a lump sum all of the undisbursed funds remaining in said loan account, including the ten (10) per cent holdback, and the city shall thereupon be obligated to utilize said funds received from the lending institution toward completion of the improvements, and for no other purpose; provided, however, that the city shall be under no liability to the developer or the lending institution to continue to complete the improvements after the monies received from the lending institution as aforesaid have been exhausted toward that end. 
(d)  The city council shall not approve any payment and performance contract nor waive the bond requirements of this Code unless the following criteria are met to the satisfaction of the city council. 
1.  That the developer is solvent and will have "at risk" capital or equity in the development. 
2.  That the developer and its principals have a general reputation for responsible and reliable dealings. 
3.  That the lending institution is a corporate entity which is solvent and has a general reputation for responsible and reliable dealings. 
4.  If the lending institution is a foreign corporation, that it has obtained a permit to transact business in the State of Florida and has lawfully designated an agent in the State of Florida to accept service of process in behalf of such corporation. 
5.  That the official governing board of the lending institution has authorized by appropriate resolution the execution of the contract by its authorized agents for and in behalf of the corporation. 
6.  That neither the lending institution nor any of its principals have, within the immediate past five (5) years, been a party defendant in any litigation to enforce compliance with the terms and provisions of a development contract, or a payment bond, or a performance bond. 
7.  That neither the developer nor any of its principals have, within the immediate past five (5) years, been a party defendant in any litigation to enforce compliance with the terms and provisions of a development contract, or a payment bond, or a performance bond. 
(e)  The request for waiver of the bond requirements of this Code, and for approval of a payment and performance contract as herein described, shall be initiated by the developer and the lending institution completing and submitting to the city written applications on the prescribed forms hereinafter set forth to be supplied by the city. Said applications shall be executed under oath, and by an executive officer of any corporate applicant. In addition to completing the applications referred to above, the developer and the lending institution shall be required to furnish the city such additional information, and complete such additional forms, as the city may request or prescribe in order to obtain sufficient data and information to determine whether or not the interests of the city will be adequately protected with respect to the development described in the application. 
(f)  The form of application to be executed under oath by the developer shall be substantially as set out in Exhibit 1 of this section. 
(g)  The form of application to be executed under oath by the lending institution shall be substantially as set out in Exhibit 1 of this section. 
70.63. - Maintenance security. 
    Where a request is made for acceptance for maintenance by the city of public improvements, security for maintenance in the amount of twenty-five (25) percent of the construction cost of paving and drainage, and twenty-five (25) percent of the construction cost of all other public improvements, shall be posted with the city. The security shall provide that the city shall be indemnified if the applicant does not replace or fully repair any public improvements in the subdivision which are defective in materials or workmanship, or which were not constructed in compliance with approved plans and specifications, the design of said final plat, or the requirements of these regulations. The terms of the security shall provide that the security shall expire two (2) years from the date the improvement was accepted for maintenance by the city unless the city serves by mail to the applicant written notice that the improvements are defective in materials or workmanship or were not constructed in compliance with the approved plans and specifications, the design of said final plat, or the requirements of these regulations within the two (2) years. 
(Ord. No. 1120-96, § 33, 8-14-96) 
70.64. - Inspections. 
(a)  Generally. As the improvements are being constructed within the subdivision, the city staff and the city's engineer or consulting engineer or their representatives shall have the right and privilege to inspect and visit the tract for the purpose of ensuring that all improvements are being constructed in conformity with the provisions of these regulations and said approved construction plans and specifications. 
(b)  Notifications. The city's subdivision inspectors (public works, wastewater treatment, building department) or their authorized representative shall be specifically notified of the commencement and completion of the following items of construction so that an immediate inspection can be performed to assure construction in conformity with said approved construction plans and specifications and the requirements of these regulations: 
(1)  Drainage facilities, lift stations, and sanitary sewer lines, and all other appurtenances, prior to backfilling. 
(2)  Stabilized subgrade. 
(3)  Curb, base and concrete work. 
(4)  Roadway base. 
(5)  Surface course. 
(6)  Permanent reference monuments and permanent control points. 
The failure to notify the city's Department Heads or their designated representatives of the commencement and completion of the construction of such items may be good cause for the city's Department Heads to refuse to issue a certificate of completion. 
70.65. - Issuance of certificate of completion. 
(a)  Upon completion of construction of the improvements, the applicant or his authorized representative shall provide to the city's engineering coordinator the following items: 
(1)  A letter stipulating that construction of the improvements has been completed and requesting final inspection and approval. 
(2)  The testing reports and certificates of compliance from material suppliers specified in Part V of this Code. 
(3)  Three (3) sets of as-built construction plans. 
(4)  If a municipality is accepting a public water system, there must be a document indicating municipal acceptance of the construction of the water system. 
(5)  A document of Certificate of Completion (DER form 17-1,205(81) or as amended) must be presented to the city upon completion and final acceptance of construction of a sewer collection system. 
(b)  Upon receipt of the above items, the city's subdivision inspectors or their authorized representative shall review said data and make a final inspection of the constructed improvements and shall notify the applicant of any items of noncompliance with said construction with the design contained in the final plat, the approved construction plans and specifications and the provisions and requirements of these regulations. A certificate of completion shall be issued by the city when the construction of said improvements is completed in conformity with the design contained in the approved construction plans and specifications, and the provisions and requirements of these regulations. 
(c)  As-built information. 
(1)  The developer of a commercial or subdivision project shall be responsible for delivering a set of as-built plans to the city and proof of a final inspection approval by the Rockledge Public Works Department before a certificate of occupancy is granted. 
(2)  The as-built set of plans must bear the official seal of a currently registered professional engineer licensed by the State of Florida. 
Editor's note- At the direction of the city, former § 20-119 of the Code of Ordinances has been included herein as subsection 70.65(c). 
70.66. - Time for construction of sidewalks. 
    No person shall occupy, inhabit or dwell in any structure on any lot or parcel of land in a subdivision until after the developer of the subdivision, or the owner of such lot or parcel of land, shall have first constructed and installed in the right-of-way of any public street or streets abutting such lot or parcel of land, and on the side of such street or streets nearest such lot or parcel of land, a sidewalk extending the entire distance that such lot or parcel of land abuts the public street or streets. The sidewalk shall be constructed in accordance with the specifications and requirements of these regulations applicable to the construction of sidewalks within subdivisions, and shall conform in all respects to the applicable portion of the plans and specifications for construction of public improvements in the subdivision submitted by the developer prior to approval of the plat by the governing body of the city. No certificate of occupancy shall be granted or issued for the occupancy of any structure on any lot, piece or parcel of land in a subdivision until after the sidewalk required by this section has been installed as herein required and finally inspected and approved by the Rockledge Building Official. 
70.67. - Extended time for construction of sidewalks. 
    The developer shall be responsible for constructing sidewalks and such sidewalks shall be installed prior to the final city inspection and approval of the public improvements in the subdivision as required for the issuance of a certificate of completion; provided, however, that a developer desiring to defer construction of the sidewalks until dwellings have been constructed on the subdivision lots may extend the time for construction of the sidewalks for a period of time not to exceed two (2) years from the date the subdivision has received its certificate of completion from the city, provided the subdivision developer shall, prior to final plat approval by the city council, obtain the city council's consent to such an extension and to the posting by the developer with the city of a bond or other form of security, hereinafter referred to as "performance security," in form and amount satisfactory to the city, guarantying and securing the developer's timely completion of construction of the sidewalks in accordance with city specifications, requirements and regulations. Such bond or security shall be in the amount of fifty (50) per cent of the estimated material and labor cost of constructing the sidewalks, such estimated cost being that set forth in the engineering estimate approved by the city. Said performance security shall be accompanied by a written sidewalk construction agreement executed and acknowledged by the developer in form and content satisfactory to the city and delivered to the city with the performance security before the subdivision receives its certificate of completion. The sidewalk construction agreement shall contain, but not in way of limitation, substantially the following provisions: 
(a)  That no part of said performance security shall be refunded to the developer until all sidewalks in the entire subdivision are constructed and completed in accordance with city specifications; 
(b)  That if said sidewalks are not completed by the developer or his designee within said two-year period, all performance security shall automatically stand forfeited to the city; 
(c)  That the developer shall be liable to the city for all costs, expenses and damages incurred and sustained by the city, including reasonable attorney's fees and court costs in the event of the developer's default in any provision of said sidewalk construction agreement; and 
(d)  In the event the developer fails to complete construction of the sidewalks and the performance security is forfeited, the city may elect to take all or any of the following actions: 
(1)  Complete construction of some or all of the sidewalks, utilizing city employees and materials. 
(2)  Contract for completion of the construction of some or all of said sidewalks. 
(e)  In the event the developer fails to complete the construction of the sidewalks within the required timeframe and all performance security is forfeited to the city, the city shall not be liable to any party to continue the sidewalk improvements after said performance security has been exhausted toward that end. 
(Ord. No. 1066-93, § 2, 10-6-93) 
SECTION 70.70. - SUBDIVISION SUBMITTAL AND PROCESSING PROCEDURE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Section 70.70 was originally unnumbered. The section number has been assigned by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. Provisions originally numbered as § 70.70 have been renumbered as § 70.71. 

70.71. - Step 1: Development plan review. 
    This step is a mandatory preapplication conference (contact the Rockledge Zoning Official). 
(a)  Required submittals: 
(1)  Development fact sheet; 
(2)  Development plan. 
(b)  Development plan review conference with department heads and city manager: Submittals must be made ten (10) days prior to conference date. 
(c)  Outcome: Applicant must get a development plan review statement (good for one hundred eighty (180) days). 
Note- See the editor's note to the title of § 70.70. 
70.75. - Step 2: Preliminary plat review. 
    This step follows the development plan review, and a completed Rockledge Development Fact Sheet and current development plan review statement are required before a preliminary plat can be accepted for review. Make all submittals to the subdivision inspector. 
(a)  Review process: 
(1)  Preliminary plat: Eight (8) copies. 
(2)  Preliminary engineering drawings: Two (2) copies. 
(3)  Covenants: A draft copy of proposed protective covenants, if any. 
(4)  Special permits: If dredge and fill or other special permits will be required. 
(5)  Concurrency review forms. 
(b)  Review process: 
(1)  Preliminary review conference: City departments will recommend for or against submittal of the preliminary plat to city council for review by the planning commission. 
(2)  Referral to planning commission: City council refers the preliminary plat to the Rockledge Planning Commission for review and recommendation. 
(3)  Planning commission public hearing: The planning commission takes action and forwards all comments and recommendations to the city council. 
(4)  City council consideration: The city council will consider recommendations at their next meeting. 
(c)  Outcome: 
(1)  Approval: An approved preliminary plat is obtained. 
(2)  Submittal of construction plans and specifications: After approval of the preliminary plat, and after the Department Heads have approved the preliminary engineering drawings, construction plans and specifications may now be submitted. 
70.80. - Step 3: Final plat review. 
    An approved preliminary plat is required prior to submitting a final plat for review. 
(a)  Required submittals: 
(1)  Final plat linen and eight (8) copies properly signed as to the dedication and certification. Joinder agreements shall accompany the linen plat. 
(2)  Certificate of ownership. 
(3)  Construction drawings and specifications properly signed and sealed (eight (8) copies). 
(4)  Engineer's letter of certification as to cost of entire construction. 
(5)  Agreement for construction, properly executed. 
(6)  Performance bond or other approved surety. 
(7)  Attorney's opinion or certification as to fee simple title and mortgage interests. 
(8)  Certificate of completion (if improvements are completed prior to recording.). 
(9)  Maintenance bond (if improvements are completed prior to recording). 
(10)  Certification of the plat by a professional land surveyor. 
(11)  Recommendation from the Department Heads. 
(12)  Dedication of improvements to the City of Rockledge. 
(13)  Two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) or two (2) per cent of the construction cost, whichever is greater, as a platting fee, is required to be paid to defray the cost to the city of legal, engineering, administrative and inspection fees. Not refundable. 
(14)  Developer shall pay to the City of Rockledge one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each concrete light pole, for the purpose of street lighting within said subdivision (Ordinance No. 210-67). 
(15)  Developer shall pay the cost of installation of street identification signs. 
(b)  Review process: 
(1)  Submit to the Building Official to have checked in and scheduled on the next agenda of the city council. 
(2)  Approval of documents by city council. 
(3)  If approved, the mayor will sign the plan linen. 
(4)  One hundred dollars ($100.00) to defray the cost for recording plat, copies of plat and travel expense. 
(5)  Proof of real estate taxes having been paid. 
(6)  Final plat recording with the clerk of the Brevard Court. 
70.85. - Step 4: Construction procedure. 
    [Construction procedure is as follows:] 
(a)  Construction plans and specifications shall be approved prior to the start of construction. 
(b)  Preconstruction conference with city staff. 
(c)  Construction of improvements. 
(d)  Final inspection of improvements. 
(e)  Developer shall submit maintenance bond and conveyance of utilities. 
(f)  Final acceptance of improvements. 
Part VIII - SPECIAL REGULATION/USES IN ZONING DISTRICTS 
SECTION 80.00. - MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 80.00 was originally unnumbered. The section number and title have been added by the editor to provide for uniformity in numbering. Provisions originally numbered as § 80.00 have been renumbered as § 80.00.1. 

80.00.1. - Accessory buildings and uses in residential areas. 
(1)  Accessory building shall be constructed simultaneously with or following the construction of the primary structure. 
(2)  Setbacks for accessory uses: 
(a)  Portable sheds of one hundred (100) square feet in area or less and not attached to a permanent base or slab may be installed not less than six (6) inches from a side or rear lot line, nor closer than ten (10) feet to a principal building on an adjoining lot. 
(b)  Accessory structures shall not be closer than seven and one-half (71/2) feet to a lot line; unless the property abuts a designated retention area recognized by the City of Rockledge; in which case the setback on the abutting side is reduced to six (6) inches, provided further, that the accessory structure may not be placed on an designated easement. 
(c)  No accessory structure shall be located forward of the front building line of the primary structure. 
(d)  All accessory structures in the defined historical districts of Valencia Road, Barton Avenue and Rockledge Drive may be placed seven and one-half (71/2)) feet from the property line, provided the applicant first obtains signed consent forms allowing the reduced setback from all adjoining property owners in accordance with the procedural guidelines of the administrative setback waiver provisions of Section 21.42. 
(e)  The side-corner setback for an accessory structure on a corner lot shall be the same as for the primary structure. If the property has a six (6) foot tall privacy fence, installed and maintained in compliance with Section 81.30(c) of these regulations, along the side corner property line, the setback may be reduced to fifteen (15) feet. 
(3)  Except as otherwise specifically provided in this Code, an accessory structure shall not exceed twelve (12) feet in height and may not occupy more than thirty-five (35) percent of a required rear yard. This provision does not apply to swimming pools. The height of an accessory structure shall be measured as the vertical distance from grade plane to the average height of the highest roof surface. 
(4)  The height of an accessory structure may be increased, provided that the setback be increased two (2) feet for every one foot in increased height above twelve (12) feet. No accessory structure shall be taller than the maximum building height as allowed by the applicable zoning district regulations. 
(5)  The maximum allowable size of an accessory structure in any residential zoning district shall depend upon the lot size of the property on which the structure is located and shall be as follows: 
Lot Size *Maximum Building Area (floor area). Less than one acre 600 square feet floor area 1 acre or more, but less than 50 acres 3% of total lot area, maximum 5000 square feet floor area 50 acres or more Maximum of 7,500 square feet  
* Maximum building area is the aggregate total of all accessory structures on the lot. No single accessory structure shall exceed 2500 square feet in area, unless on a parcel of 50 acres or more. 
(Ord. No. 992-91, § 1, 2-6-91; Ord. No. 1098-95, § 11, 5-3-95; Ord. No. 1364-2004, §§ 8, 9, 12-1-04; Ord. No. 1436-2007, §§ 1, 2, 1-17-07; Ord. No. 1469-2007, § 1, 11-7-07) 
Note- See the editor's note to the title of § 80.00. 
80.00.2. - Portable storage units. 
    Structures which are constructed in whole, or in part, off of the property; are not built or attached to the property pursuant to a building permit; and are not licensed by the Florida Department of Motor Vehicles must meet the requirements set out in this section. These shall be deemed to be portable storage units without regard to the structures' actual use. 
(a)  Only one portable storage unit may be located on a property at any one time. The property owner or tenant may apply to the Rockledge Building Department for additional units, which shall be granted only if it is determined that such would not adversely impact the area in any way, and would comply with all other requirements of this section. 
(b)  A portable storage unit will not exceed eight (8) feet in height, eight (8) feet in width, and sixteen (16) feet in length. 
(c)  The property owner or tenant thereon shall notify the Rockledge Building Department in writing prior to the location of a portable storage unit on any property. Said notification must establish where the portable storage unit is to be located. The owner or tenant must receive prior approval of the Rockledge Building Department as to the location of the portable storage unit. 
(d)  A portable storage unit shall not be located in such a manner to impair a motor vehicle operator's view of vehicular, bicycle or pedestrian traffic either on or off of the property. 
(e)  A portable storage unit shall not be located in such a manner to obstruct the flow of vehicle, bicycle or pedestrian traffic. 
(f)  A portable storage unit may have affixed to it no more than two (2), twelve (12) inch by eighteen (18) inch signs. 
(g)  A portable storage unit must have affixed to it by the unit's owner a tag indicating the most recent delivery date on which the portable storage unit was delivered to the property. 
(h)  If the National Weather Advisory Service or other qualified weather advisory service identifies weather conditions which are predicted to include winds of seventy-five (75) mph or greater, all portable storage units shall be removed from all properties and placed in approved storage locations at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the predicted onset of such winds or as soon as reasonably practical if less notice is provided. This requirement may be modified by the building official upon receipt of adequate documentation from a registered architect or engineer or other professional qualified to give such opinion that a greater wind loading pertain to a particular portable storage unit model or manufacturer so that the portable storage unit is unlikely to be moved by winds greater than the predicted winds. As an alternative to removal, the portable storage vendor may submit a tie-down proposal for approval by the building official and each portable storage unit not removed shall be tied down in the approved manner. 
(i)  Any portable storage unit which is not removed at the end of the time for which it may lawfully remain in place, or immediately upon the direction of a code enforcement officer for removal of such temporary structure for safety reasons, may be removed by the city immediately, without notice, and the cost of such removal may be assessed against the property on which the temporary structure was located and may be filed as a lien against such property by the city clerk. 
(j)  A portable storage unit may be placed upon property without permit, subject to the provisions of this section and any other applicable land development regulations as follows: 
1.  Residentially zoned property: A portable storage unit may be placed on residentially zoned property for four (4) days, no more than four (4) times per year. 
2.  Nonresidentially zoned property: A portable storage unit may be placed on nonresidentially zoned property for thirty (30) days, no more than four (4) times a year. 
3.  The Rockledge Building Department may allow portable storage units to be located on a property for a larger period of time than set out above in emergency situations, for fifteen (15) days, with the right to grant an additional fifteen (15) days extension if necessary to complete emergency repairs. 
(k)  The owner or tenant will not allow any living creature to reside within a portable storage unit, at any time, for any reason. 
(Ord. No. 1302-2003, § 1, 2-5-03) 
80.01. - Churches, temples, synagogues and other places of worship. 
A.  Purpose: This section shall control the development of churches, synagogues, mosques or other places of worship, including all affiliated activities, of all types, to ensure that the unique impact associated with such activities are addressed, while still allowing for a wide range of possible locations. 
(1)  Permitted use: Churches, temples, synagogues, mosques or other places of worship, including all affiliated activities shall be a permitted use within the following zoning districts: 
a.  C1-Neighborhood retain commercial. 
b.  C1A-Restricted commercial district. 
c.  C2-General commercial. 
d.  P2-Professional. 
e.  M1-General industrial. 
f.  M2-Light industrial and warehouse. 
g.  IP-Industrial park. 
h.  PUD-Planned unit development. 
(2)  Special exceptions: Special exceptions are not permitted. 
B.  Calculation of seating capacity: For the purpose of this regulation, a seat is defined as either: 
(1)  One individual fixed seat; or 
(2)  A length of eighteen (18) inches on a pew or bench; or 
(3)  A measurement of seven (7) square feet per person for the area seating the general assembly with movable chairs or other portable seating fixtures. The total area includes aisle space, but excludes areas such as stage and podium areas, space for musical instruments, and lobbies. 
C.  General development criteria: The following development criteria shall apply to places of worship and related activities without regards to the zoning district in which it is located or the permit under which the use is processed: 
(1)  Lighting for parking lot areas, structures, statuary and signage shall comply with the development regulations for parking, lighting and signs and the design standard as required in any commercial project in the City of Rockledge. 
(2)  The use shall comply with the parking regulations for assembly uses, except that in no event shall the parking be in excess of one space per three (3) seats in a residential zone. 
(3)  The storage of buses and vans over ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross weight is permitted on-site under the following conditions: 
(a)  The location of the parking areas for these vehicles is indicated on the site plan at the time of application. 
(b)  Vehicles must be leased or owned by the owner or tenant of the site, must be in operable condition, and must have a current vehicle registration. 
(c)  Vehicles shall not intrude into the public rights-of-way or obstruct sight visibility from any driveway. 
(d)  Structural and/or natural screening, as approved by the city, shall screen the vehicles from neighboring properties. The screening requirement or amount of screening may be eliminated or reduced in commercial and industrial zones to the extent that the storage of vehicles is treated uniformly with other uses in the same zoning district. 
(4)  A transportation management plan (TMP) shall be submitted for approval by the City of Rockledge. The TMP shall address the following: traffic control, parking management (including the mitigation of overflow parking into adjoining residential areas), and traffic movement to the arterial street system. In addition to on-site parking requirements, parking in excess of the maximum may be permitted on existing off-site satellite parking lots, subject to City of Rockledge approval of a joint use agreement. Off-site parking in residential zones shall be limited to lots shared with existing institutional uses, such as schools. 
(5)  The maximum height for separate structures on-site such as bell towers, crosses, statuary, or other symbolic religious icons shall be fifteen (15) feet. 
(6)  The proposed structure(s) shall comply with the applicable design criteria for which the use is located. 
(7)  Additional standards are applicable to the use. The underlying zoning and size of the facility shall be determined if designs standards will be needed. 
D.  Development criteria for seating capacities in a residential zoning district: 
(1)  Places of worship with seating capacity of less than two hundred fifty (250) seats; 
(a)  The facility shall be located within one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet, as measured along the centerline of the right-of-way, of an arterial road (minor or principal); 
(b)  The facility shall be located on a paved road having two (2) lanes with a minimum width equal to the public works standard for a local access street; 
(c)  Buildings shall maintain a minimum setback of twenty (20) feet from all property lines; building setbacks shall be increased by five (5) feet for every one foot in building height over thirty (30) feet; 
(d)  The maximum building height does not exceed fifty (50) feet inclusive of steeples, bell towers, crosses, or other symbolic religious icons; 
(e)  The minimum lot size shall be the same as that required in the zoning district in which the proposed facility is located; 
(f)  The maximum lot coverage of structures may not exceed thirty-five (35) percent; total impervious surfaces may not exceed seventy-five (75) percent of lot area; 
(g)  No more than two (2) large vehicles in excess of ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross weight each may be stored on-site at a given period of time; and 
(h)  Structures, parking lots and lighting shall be designed to avoid excessive light and glare impacts on adjacent properties. Restrictions on light pole height and type, deflectors and other such measures may be required as necessary to prevent overspill and excessive intensity of light. 
(2)  Places of worship with a seating capacity between two hundred fifty (250) to seven hundred fifty (750): 
(a)  The proposed facility must be located adjacent to at least one arterial road (collector, minor or principal); 
(b)  Buildings shall maintain a minimum setback of twenty (20) feet from all property lines; 
(c)  The maximum building height may not exceed fifty (50) feet, inclusive, of steeples, bell towers, crosses, or other symbolic religious icons. However, building setbacks shall be increased five (5) feet for every one foot in building height over thirty (30) feet; 
(d)  The maximum lot coverage of structures may not exceed thirty-five (35) percent; total impervious surfaces may not exceed seventy-five (75) percent of the lot area; and 
(e)  No more than two (2) large vehicles in excess of ten thousand (10,000) pounds gross weight each may be stored on-site at a given period of time. 
E.  Development criteria for seating capacities in a commercial or industrial zoning district: 
(1)  Places of worship with a seating capacity between five hundred (500) to two thousand (2,000) seats. Site development shall comply with the general standards for the zone in which it is located with the exception of the following: 
(a)  The proposed facility must be located adjacent to at least one arterial road (minor or principal); 
(b)  The maximum building height permitted is fifty (50) feet. An additional allowance of fifteen (15) feet for a steeple, bell tower, cross, or other symbolic religious icon is permitted. Building setbacks shall be increased five (5) feet for every one foot in building height over forty-five (45) feet; 
(c)  Accessory/stand-along parking facilities are prohibited; 
(d)  Primary and secondary schools are permitted as a related or accessory use; 
(e)  The proposed structure(s) shall comply with the applicable design standards contained in the zoning district;
